webTitle: Hick's one-man show propels England to glory

fields.headline: Hick's one-man show propels England to glory
fields.standfirst:
England 248-7 Zimbabwe 163
England won by 85 runs
fields.trailText: Paul Weaver reports from Harare on how Hussain's men completed some unfinished business to wrap up series.
fields.body:
This time England really did flippin' murder 'em. Three years after David Lloyd mislaid a few marbles, as well as his abacus, and made his notorious misjudgment of the state of affairs in Zimbabwe, his old charges avenged him, in a manner of speaking, by winning their third match in a row to secure this four-match series.

And there, in the Sky television commentary box and doing his best to put on a wistful smile, was Bumble himself; he would have given a boxful of Eccles cakes as well as his collection of bizarre slogans if only it could have been like this in 1997.

By taking a winning 3-0 lead in the series England also landed their first one-day pot since Adam Hollioake's rather odd-looking side won in Sharjah a little over two years ago.

When it comes to title tussles this particular affair was slightly less competitive than the skirmish at Elland Road; England won by 85 runs with 3.1 overs to spare. The head-to-head record between these sides now reads like a penalty shoot-out: 6-6.

It was not a good day for one stand, opposite the pavilion, which adopted a hostile attitude towards one of their lost sons, Graeme Hick. The player was met by a barrage of boos when he went out to bat, as well as such banners as "Hick: Did You Vote?" in reference to the recent referendum.

Hick, who was born in Harare, had the last word. A whole dictionary of them, in fact. He was both England's best batsman, with a vigorous 80, and their most successful bowler, taking five for 33 in 10 overs for his best return in one-day internationals. There is some corner of a foreign field that is forever Anglo- Zimbabwean.

This result also provided vindication for the captain Nasser Hussain. With almost Jardine-like ruthlessness he has refused to rest his exhausted new-ball bowlers Andrew Caddick and Darren Gough. Again Gavin Hamilton and Ashley Giles were unlucky not to get a game, although with the series now won there may be changes for the final match on Wednesday.

With toffs in town - the chairman of selectors David Graveney and the England and Wales Cricket Board chief executive Tim Lamb - and the invidious subject of central contracts coming up for discussion within the next few days, this was no bad time to perform.

England certainly did that after Andy Flower won the toss and chose to bowl, although Hussain failed again, edging Bryan Strang to Alistair Campbell at slip in only the second over. His last eight innings have yielded only 104 runs.

When Hick is at his strongest, however, he is better in the middle than chewing the cud in the dressing room, and he set about the bowling with such gusto that there were nine fours in his fifty.

Zimbabwe bowled badly, it must be said, particularly Heath Streak and Henry Olonga. But Hick had the power to punish them, mixing muscular drives with vivid cuts. He and Nick Knight, who was never at his most fluent, put on 81 in 82 balls.

But because England's batting is as brittle as a brandy snap they always seem a wicket away from disaster. After Knight was caught, slogging, Hick's most damaging form deserted him. His fifty had come at a run a ball; his next 30 occupied 45 deliveries.

He should have been stumped on 78. He had scored only two more when, hesitat ing to Darren Maddy's call for a single, he was run out. England's innings, which appeared to be heading for something like 270 when it was 128 for two at the halfway stage, faltered. But Maddy, with his first international half-century, ensured that all impetus was not lost.

Vikram Solanki (96 in seven innings now) failed again but late runs from Craig White and Caddick boosted the total.

Zimbabwe were never in it, certainly not while Stuart Carlisle was smashing the ball to all corners of his crease in an 81-ball innings of 41. England appeared in most danger when they flung themselves to the ground to avoid a swarm of bees. It looked as though Roy Keane was playing for the opposition.

 Sachin Tendulkar has said he will quit as India's captain at the end of the imminent series against South Africa, after their disastrous tour of Australia in which they lost all three Tests and seven out of eight one-day matches. India have recalled Mohammad Azharuddin and Nayan Mongia in their 14-man squad for the first Test starting on Thursday, and have included the newcomers Wasim Jaffer, Murali Karthik and Mohammad Kaif.

webTitle: Wright's mix of hype and heart is a PR dream

fields.headline: Wright's mix of hype and heart is a PR dream
fields.standfirst: No debut goal but it's showbiz all the way for Burnley's new superstar
fields.trailText: Burnley 0 - 0 Wigan
fields.body:
After all the Ian Wright, Wright hype it was time to deliver, and the 36-year-old striker did so sufficiently to be named man of the match without ever erasing the impression of an ageing player hoping for a final fanfare.

Six thousand tickets sold in 24 hours, Burnley's first 20,000 crowd since 1992, queues stretching from the club shop into the street (500 Ian Wright foam hands cleared at £5 each), all testified to the former England forward's flashy charisma.

But perhaps a more telling statistic was that this goalless draw marked the first time he has moved clubs and failed to score on his debut, something he seemed touchily aware of.

"How was that disappointing?" he bridled. "You get chances in games and some games you take them and in others you don't and it's not something I'm going to go home and go, 'Oh, I'm so disappointed.' The main thing is it's not a losing debut."

He did not score but he remains a very good player. The pre-kick-off swagger suggested he was up for it; the easy loping stride, the sudden diagonal runs, the instinctive linking of play. And yet . . .

Opportunities fell to him but the Wigan goalkeeper Roy Carroll saved with his knees, his chest and his hands, then watched helplessly as a delicate chip just cleared his bar in the 90th minute. It was hard to shake the feeling that the Ian Wright who in 1991 scored a hat-trick on his Arsenal debut would have buried at least one.

"I'm here to score goals, I got some half-chances and I think with a few more games I'll be taking those," he said. The best chance fell to his best friend Mitchell Thomas who, with the goal gaping in the fifth minute of injury-time, hit the woodwork.

Thomas was instrumental in bringing Wright to Burnley from Celtic, Wright taking a pay cut from £20,000 to £6,000 a week but still pre-recording Friday Night's All Wright in London.

The town's inhabitants have taken to him but what he makes of this faded Lowry painting shivering on the edge of the Pennines will be interesting to see. Burnley Miners club is a fine institution but hardly compares with the Ministry of Sound. But his value to the club has been proved. "From a PR point of view it's been a dream," said the press officer Danny Reuben.

fields.headline: Walker revels in England stroll
fields.standfirst:
England 2 - 0 Portugal
Smith 26, Walker 32
fields.trailText: England's female footballers may not share the high profile of their American counterparts, who will turn professional next year, but they enjoyed a red-letter day yesterday as a record crowd of 5,114 watched them overcome Portugal in a European championship qualifier in Barnsley.
fields.body:
England's female footballers may not share the high profile of their American counterparts, who will turn professional next year, but they enjoyed a red-letter day yesterday as a record crowd of 5,114 watched them overcome Portugal in a European championship qualifier in Barnsley.

First-half goals from Susan Smith and Karen Walker, a penalty, did not reflect the extent of England's domination as they warmed up convincingly for the clash with the group leaders Norway at Carrow Road on March 7.

England's coach Hope Powell said: "Our only disappointment was that we did not score as many goals as we probably should have done. We are under no illusions about the Norway game but we are reasonably confident."

The crowd was predominantly female, although a handful of cynical lads who claimed to have gone along "for a laugh" were soon put in their place by the skill of several of England's players. Smith in particular caught the eye, not least because it has become such a rarity to see anybody with a useful left foot wearing an England football shirt, and the captain Gillian Coultard, winning her 116th cap, also stood out.

Smith put England on the road to victory when she side-footed home a wayward shot by the midfielder Becky Easton on 26 minutes. She also played a part in the second goal six minutes later when her intelligent cross was inexplicably handled by Celisa and Walker, a local woman, made no mistake from the penalty spot.

webTitle: Rovers fight shy of the work ethic

fields.headline: Rovers fight shy of the work ethic
fields.trailText: Stockport 0 - 1 Blackburn
fields.body:
Blackburn needed this win, not only for the points that keep them in sight of sixth place but to jolt them from a debilitating rut. They are still eight points off but their game in hand is more likely to be won. They had gone four for one point, and not winning can turn into a habit, as County know. They have not won this year; from sixth at Christmas they have taken three points from 24.

Money can be a burden as much as a luxury and Tony Parkes, having waved his caretaker's wand and lifted Blackburn from 19th to seventh, looked as if he might be regretting his decision in December to take the full manager's post with its implicit demand for promotion that his predecessors' outlay should guarantee.

By financial rights the sides should not be on the same field. Rovers' starting line-up cost £27m, County's barely £1m. Granted Blackburn have often paid over the odds, as if the price might frighten opponents, but why are they where they are? And why is no one interested in Stockport players, collectively their equal?

Blackburn's talents did little as a team, asking further ques tions of Parkes as well as Ashley Ward, Jason McAteer and Keith Gillespie, a £10.5m trio of prodigality notwithstanding McAteer's goal. Christian Dailly, Callum Davidson and Matt Jansen at least looked committed value for big money.

County's profile is so low as to be blank, reflecting the club's surroundings. From the depths of the Fourth Division 11 seasons ago they have made a virtue of anonymity. Their crest carries a subtitle, "the friendly football club". The programme carries potted biographies of their own team. The team carries a bunch of AN Others and a will that makes more of their skills where Rovers' makes less. Last week was one of big business: two players left for £415,000, two arrived for less than half, including the Bury striker Ian Lawson. Rovers, of course, deal in the free market. County play the flea market.

Their manager Andy Kilner duly hopped about the dug-out, unable to keep his emotions airtight. "It was big-club syndrome again," he said of a penalty refused. Parkes was equally off beam. "Our players have got to get used to playing to the First Division," he said, as if County's approach was less refined. His players would do better to observe their motto "arte et labore" and make the skill less selfish and the work greater.

fields.headline: Rangers thrown by on-the-ball Barnsley
fields.trailText: Barnsley 1 - 1 QPR
fields.body:
Even the humble throw-in is starting to cause disputes this season. First it was whether towels should be used to dry Dave Challinor's Prenton Park projectiles, now it is the role of the on-the-ball Barnsley ball boys.

QPR's manager Gerry Francis and his players expressed disquiet at the slick ball-switch for a throw-in that led to Barnsley's equaliser in the fifth extra minute. The allegations included sloppy refereeing and poor timekeeping, and the wrong ball in the wrong place at the wrong time.

Certainly QPR's defenders will never win a spot the ball competition. They failed to react, still watching a clearance sail into row Z, as the second ball zipped back into play further down the pitch.

In the ensuing panic Karl Ready brought down Georgi Hristov and Craig Hignett scored his 15th goal of the season after the referee Mike Ryan pointed to the spot.

It left Ready shaking his head at the perceived injustice. "The ball went out a long way down the pitch. Suddenly another one's come straight back in from nowhere, much nearer, and we just weren't ready," said the centre-back.

"It took us by surprise and I was the wrong side of Hristov. I tried to stand off him but he went over. We were disappointed with the referee right through, and why we were still playing after 4 minutes when they signalled three I don't know."

Barnsley's manager Dave Bassett is not the type to miss a trick, but he firmly rejected any accusation of chicanery.

"I don't know what the fuss is all about. We didn't contravene any rules. Having more than one ball available is something encouraged by Fifa to speed the game up," he said.

"We've been doing it all season and it's something open for every other team to do as well. QPR don't have an argument: our ball boys have a ball each and are instructed to throw it back to the opposition just as quickly."

Barnsley are six points behind second-placed Ipswich but Bassett believes automatic promotion is still very much on the agenda.

"Football is full of ups and downs and until it's mathematically impossible we won't give up," he said. "We'll keep working and we'll see what happens. At the start of the season everybody had us down for 13th or 14th place so I've got to be happy. With 14 games to go anything is possible."

QPR dominated the first half, Mikkel Beck hitting the bar and the sweeper Matthew Rose scoring his first goal for the club after a flowing 44th-minute move through Ian Baraclough and Gavin Peacock.

They were then under pressure, without showing signs of cracking until the frantic finale, but were fortunate to escape earlier penalty appeals for handball against Peacock and a shirt tug on Eric Tinkler by Rose.

webTitle: Mad Boro take advantage of away-day Coventry

fields.headline: Mad Boro take advantage of away-day Coventry
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough 2 - 0 Coventry
fields.body:
Happy days at Middlesbrough. But heralding this as the onset of a glorious era would be like proclaiming England world champions after a 2-0 win over Andorra. Coventry were that bad. If the FA wants to see confrontation and foul language, video footage of Gordon Strachan's post-match team talk might be a good bet.

There were flashes to admire in Middlesbrough's first victory of the millennium: the surges and crossing of Christian Ziege, a spectacular goal from Hamilton Ricard, composure and a fierce determination which seem to have been lacking recently.

But false dawns are as common here as Paul Gascoigne injuries. The home win over Tottenham in December sparked a run of sorts, but that was one point from the following six matches. No one is getting carried away.

"We are a mad team," said the centre-back Gianluca Festa. "We play well, then we play badly; we play well, then we play badly. I cannot make promises after this result but at least we are right mentally now. Perhaps we were not against Derby and Aston Villa. Things are always happening here but we have to change from being a mad team. I sense things are on the up. There is no secret, it is just about giving more."

The fans will be disappointed to hear that some players are not giving their all or are not mentally prepared as a matter of course. Beforehand many supporters sounded fed up. In the fanzine Fly Me To The Moon, one woman wrote that of 30 friends with season tickets only two will renew them if Bryan Robson stays in charge.

Fans, though, have notoriously short memories. A few wins and all might be forgotten. Here Boro harried impres sively, denying Coventry time. Leeds at home next Saturday should better indicate whether they are making progress which will persuade Robson to stay.

"We've been giving teams too much space," he said. "We talked about that. I know when I get the players fit - and the team was nearly all there today - we are a decent side."

Yet Robson's insistence that he be judged on his full-strength team misses the point. All clubs suffer with absentees, and football is more than ever a squad game. He has had the time and money to assemble a strong pool of players.

In Ziege he has a quality wing-back, though several of the German's crosses went to waste. Juninho is the only other truly creative source. Sadly he goes past opponents less than he used to. "We still need more movement in the box," said Festa.

The Italian swept Boro ahead after a Ziege cross was miskicked by Carlton Palmer, and by the 20th minute the game was over. Ricard scored from distance to seal Boro's first ever Premiership win in February and leave Coventry without an away victory this season.

"It was a bad, bad performance by the team and by the manager," Strachan said. "I don't drink but I might start after that."

fields.headline: Ipswich impatience finds Wright result
fields.trailText: Crewe 1 - 2 Ipswich
fields.body:
If, as their manager Dario Gradi insists, Crewe are not good enough to survive without help from Lady Luck, Ipswich surely carry too much skill to have to rely on the fickleness of fate. How then to explain their penchant for late, decisive goals?

There was nothing to suggest that the venomous drive Jermaine Wright unleashed a minute from time on Saturday had its origins in anything other than a team's impatience to claim what they see as their right to a Premiership future. That and a nod in the direction of the truism that dictates that players must always score against their former clubs.

Ipswich knew that victory would lift them into second place and no other incentive was required to ensure they remained vigorous and concentrated in search of a winning goal. For them, more so than any of their rivals, there is nothing to be gained from positions three to six in the table; apart, that is, from the certainty of further torment. Play-off losers in each of the past three seasons, they fear the back-door route is permanently locked against them.

"We've had our disappointments but through it all the team has stuck together and there's some big hearts in there," said George Burley. "We are unbeaten in 17 games and showing great consistency. But then so are the others."

This was not the ideal venue to assess his team's ability to outstay Charlton and Manchester City in the promotion race because the surface did not suit their passing game.

Neither can it be helping Crewe's efforts to climb out of the bottom three, though Gradi put this reverse down to nerves. Nevertheless they had the spirit to hit back four minutes after Jamie Clapham's superb effort and equalise through a Paul Tait header. They might have gone on to win it when Rodney Jack struck a post but finally succumbed to the law of the ex.

"When we hit the post I just knew that Jermaine would score the winner against us" said Gradi. "That's how our luck's been going."

webTitle: Fulham labour to justify high hopes

fields.headline: Fulham labour to justify high hopes
fields.trailText: Fulham 2 - 0 Walsall
fields.body:
Fulham's grand ambition, overseen by Mohamed Al Fayed, will be manifested in a revamped stadium, a flotation and a place in the Premiership. The owner hopes it will not be in that order.

Financial independence and top-flight football are the priorities in Al Fayed's five-year plan, and the millions he is investing will be wasted if the weekends of entertaining the likes of Walsall are not put behind them quickly.

Expectations are running high in SW6, and retaining the loyalties of the home fans, whose number slipped to 9,994 on Saturday, will require a hike in the entertainment on offer. Filling the new 30,000 stadium would be considerably easier in the Premiership.

Terry Phelan's 53rd-minute opener was the first goal Fulham have scored in open play for more than 17 hours, and murmurings of discontent at the style of Paul Bracewell's side have come from players and fans alike. Al Fayed's promise yesterday to offer both groups share options when the club are floated may keep them sweet for a little while longer.

Fulham remain in the hunt for the play-offs and Bracewell will hope that a final push can prove successful; indeed his job may depend on it. Yet such was Fulham's laboured progression in the first half that Walsall merely had to get men behind the ball to nullify the threat. Darren Wrack missed the visitors' clearest chance when he shot wide when unmarked seven yards out. Bracewell, a softly spoken man, must have put something in the players' half-time cuppa as they came out firing in the second half. Their pressure finally told when Phelan volleyed home Lee Clark's cross.

Walsall, whose manager Ray Graydon rightly felt they deserved a point, pressed hard for an equaliser to ease their relegation woes but the substitute Andy Rammell's miss from one yard with his first touch was as close as they came. Clark, having skipped two challenges, stroked home on 84 minutes to keep the Al Fayed masterplan on track.

fields.headline: Dons avert more Caley ballistics
fields.standfirst: Guntveit's late equaliser puts a dampener on another Highland fling for Celtic's conquerors
fields.trailText: Inverness CT 1 - 1 Aberdeen
fields.body:
Inverness Caledonian Thistle are still in the Scottish Cup. The 6,290-strong crowd gathered from all over the Highlands watched them take Aberdeen to a fourth-round replay; the First Division side proved to those fans that the victory over Celtic was no aberration and for long periods they dominated this tie.

Bobby Mann gave them the lead at the start of the second half but Inverness's legs weakened in the later stages. Cato Guntveit's 80th-minute equaliser made the result just about fair because both sides had at various times earned the right to live and fight another day.

The site for Caledonian Stadium, built five years ago, was deliberately chosen because it occupies a stretch of reclaimed land between the Moray Firth and the Kessock Bridge, which carries thousands of cars every day to the north of the country. So its advertising hoardings are many sizes larger than the usual boards, aimed not at the spectators but at the passing motorists.

This was a chance for the team to display themselves with equal prominence. Although the win in the previous round was startling, Inverness are not country bumpkins, weakened though they were by the absence of a player engaged in the Gold Cup; Richard Hastings was missing after a toss of the coin had taken Canada into the quarter-finals on the other side of the Atlantic.

The atmosphere was truly splendid, the club shop did a roaring trade and, inspired by fans hardly used to this level of interest, Caley made a hugely impressive start, evidence in itself that they had the right to enjoy the experience.

Another oddity was the age of the goalkeepers. Together Jim Leighton and Jim Calder notch up 80 years but Leighton had to act half that age to prevent Aberdeen falling a goal behind in the fourth minute. Charlie Christie's pass to Mark McCul loch allowed him to shoot strong and hard from only eight yards, but the 41-year-old was equal to the task, throwing himself upwards to make a fine instinctive save.

Christie, another who has been around for longer than he would care to remember, continued to boss the match and when Paul Sheerin crossed in the 26th minute Ross Tokely needed only an extra ounce off his forehead to finally beat Leighton. But he glanced too delicately and the ball drifted inches wide of the far post.

Aberdeen were pinned down for longer periods than they would have liked and it was not until the 43rd minute that they broke with any conviction, Kevin Rutkiewicz bursting forward unmarked to hit a 15-yard shot which forced Calder to drop down to save with the kind of agility not expected of one that age. Any points decision made at this time would have left CT as the undisputed winners.

CT rectified that lack of a goal quickly at the start of the second half. Sheerin swung a corner from the left over to the far post and Mann outjumped several defenders to plant the ball behind Leighton.

At last Aberdeen began to take the tie seriously, increasing their pace and pressing forward. Calder made one stunning save from Arild Stavrum but when, in the 80th minute, the substitute Chris Clark crossed for Guntveit, this time the header was strong enough to beat the goalkeeper.

Scottish Cup fifth-round draw: Motherwell or Ayr United v Partick Thistle, Rangers v Hearts, Hibs or Clydebank v Berwick Rangers or Falkirk, Alloa Athletic or Dundee United v Aberdeen or Inverness. Ties to be played March 11-12.

webTitle: Flat Forest excite only the diehards

fields.headline: Flat Forest excite only the diehards
fields.trailText: Nott Forest 2 - 0 Crystal Palace
fields.byline: Daniel Taylor at the City Ground
fields.body:
Dedication to the cause is Eberhard Kleinrensing's speciality. Some would say his devotion to Nottingham Forest deserves a medal; others might suggest a few thousand free air miles would come in more useful.

The 40-year-old travels from his home in Duisburg to every match. Last season the pilgrimage cost him £14,000 in all, and rumour has it he once flew over for a friendly against Mansfield Town only to find it had been postponed.

Saturday's match was one occasion when his fellow occupants of the Brian Clough stand might have been tempted to grasp the lapels of the German's anorak and demand: "Why, Ebby, why?"

Watching Forest is like bumping into childhood friends and coming away engulfed by disappointment. Once vibrant and exciting, their best qualities seem diminished with the sands of time.

And this was on a good day. "It's the first time this season we have won back-to-back matches, so it's taken off some of the pressure," said their manager David Platt. Pressed about the entertainment value he was defensive. "It may not have been a fluid performance but it was a battling one."

That they triumphed was largely down to their opponents' ineptitude. The Palace goalkeeper Steve Mautone will not be gluing the cuttings into his scrapbook after flailing at two routine crosses to present Alan Rogers and Nigel Quashie with a goal apiece.

"Our finances are such that we have signed a goalkeeper on a month-to-month contract. It's indicative of our situation, that's the best way of putting it," said his manager Steve Coppell, ever the diplomat. "These are desperate times. We've got nothing and our situation almost puts people off joining us."

At least Palace cannot be accused of the extravagance shown by their hosts. To reach the dizzy heights of 18th position Platt has spent £11m. Forest fans need not have sleepless nights over relegation but it's no wonder Cloughie spends his spare Saturdays watching Burton Albion.

fields.headline: Magpies' many happy returns
fields.trailText: Tranmere 2 - 3 Newcastle
fields.body:
Previous experience dictates it would be unwise to book the open-top bus, but Newcastle's management, players and entourage can allow themselves a smile of satisfaction. For the third successive season they are heading Wembley way in the FA Cup and despite a feeling of deja vu it is a safe bet they will improve on the lukewarm offerings of the past two occasions.

Bobby Robson's smile told its own story: 67 years young, a glint in his eye, the thumbs-up to the Toon Army after they lauded him with a stirring rendition of Happy Birthday.

How time flies for football's elder statesman. As a young professional at Fulham with his heart still in the north-east, Robson stood among the Newcastle masses to watch them win their last domestic trophy in the 1955 Cup final against Manchester City. Since then there have been only scraps and morsels, year after year of underachievement and near misses on Tyneside.

Now, quicker than even Robson could have imagined, his aspiration to retire as a Geordie legend is close to fruition after his side gave Tranmere a caustic reminder of the realities of life among the big-hitters. A semi-final against Chelsea awaits.

"I guess you could say it's a belated birthday present," said Robson. "We played the better football and we deserved to go through. Wembley is a cathedral and it will be a very special match."

After an afternoon of craning necks in the visiting defence, Robson was especially happy with how his side combated the Dave Challinor factor and those "bloody meteors". The Tranmere defender with the world-record throw-ins into the penalty area posed more problems to the Premiership club than anything constructed from open play. No wonder the home fans held up banners reading "Go Dave, go goal" every time Newcastle kicked a ball into touch.

It was a weapon Tranmere utilised to maximum effect late in the first half when Wayne Allison jumped at the far post to head one of Challinor's 40-metre specials in off a post. By then, however, Newcastle were already booking fittings for their Wembley suits after a period of incessant attacking left their opponents gasping for breath.

Newcastle proved they quite literally belonged to a different league with two goals from Kevin Gallacher's supply line. First Gary Speed was clinical in his execution, then further confusion in the home defence allowed Didier Domi space to manoeuvre before flicking the ball beyond the goalkeeper Joe Murphy. Tranmere's early exuberance was replaced by waves of trepidation.

"We were well on top at that stage and we conceded a goal just at the wrong time," said Robson. "But in my opinion Challinor's throw-ins are more difficult to deal with than David Beckham's crosses."

Newcastle re-emphasised the gulf in class soon after the interval. One pulsating move ended with Alan Shearer thumping his shot against an upright and within 90 seconds their two-goal advantage had been restored. Kieron Dyer, irrepressible and indefatigable, scampered down the right, looked up and picked out Duncan Ferguson charging into the penalty area. From six yards it was a formality.

Chances came and went before Tranmere's Gary Jones set up a frantic finale, lashing in from close range after Allison's miscued shot ricocheted off David Kelly into his path.

For Tranmere, conquerors of four Premiership clubs already this season, thoughts now turn to their own Wembley experience when they face Leicester City in the Worthington Cup final next Sunday. But their preparations were dealt a cruel blow: the defender Gareth Roberts was thought to have broken his leg in a 50-50 with Dyer and although it turns out to be only severely bruised it is still enough to rule him out.

webTitle: Combustible Carbone the winner and loser

fields.headline: Combustible Carbone the winner and loser
fields.trailText: Everton 1 - 2 Aston Villa
fields.body:
Some three months after his detractors had gleefully pronounced his managerial career at Aston Villa to be over, John Gregory was yesterday sporting the satisfied smile of a vindicated man.

Gregory will take nothing for granted but with only Bolton Wanderers of the First Division blocking Villa's route to a first FA Cup final appearance since they won the trophy 43 years ago, the omens are good. The long wait may soon be over.

It was close, and Everton's wounds were largely self- inflicted, but Villa deserved to finish on top for they came seeking not a replay but a win and such ambition is worthy of generous reward.

"This is a tremendous result - if hardly a tremendous performance," said Gregory. "The result will kick in over the next 24 hours and only then will we realise what we have achieved. I'm happy with the semi-final draw because if Bobby Robson and Gianluca Vialli had had a choice they, too, would have picked Bolton."

Perplexingly, in view of Villa's somewhat less that statuesque strike force of Benito Carbone and Julian Joachim, the Everton manager Walter Smith opted to place his faith in a triple centre-back system which in the past has actually served to dilute his side's potential for expansive football. Faced by this unyielding wall of heaving flesh, Villa, rather wisely, kept the ball on the deck and relied upon guile not strength.

If the game was always too frantic to paint itself as anything other than fractious, it managed to hold its appeal simply because the devilish pace ensured that the centre of action was constantly on the move.

There was a general paucity of chances but then, from nowhere, a goal - followed swiftly by another.

Villa struck first. Paul Merson's first contribution proved important as he whipped over a cross from the left after his corner had been played back to him by Carbone.

Ugo Ehiogu, standing in splendid isolation at the far post, turned the ball back across goal for Steve Stone to apply the final touch with a diving header, one which bounced and reared up awkwardly in front of Thomas Myhre and found the net off the goalkeeper's body.

Everton had lost their way and yet, perversely, at the pre cise moment Villa shaped as if to claim a second goal, they dragged themselves back into the match.

Gareth Barry's failure to clear the ball was crucial, permitting Joe-Max Moore to step in and then step forwards. The American's chip-shot from an unsympathetic angle was delicate enough, just, to find its way up and over Peter Enckelman in the Villa goal.

Stone did marvellously well to hook the ball away but it was too late; it had crossed the line, a tight decision which Villa took without recourse to histrionics.

The first half was living on borrowed time when Villa struck the decisive blow. Having been smartly released by Joachim, Merson ran purposefully forwards before turning right and cutting across the perimeter of the penalty area. It was over, but there was still time for Carbone to embroider a deserved reputation for pettiness when he was sent off for a second caution in the last minute, foolishly encroaching at a free-kick after earlier being booked for dissent.

webTitle: Bolton do their bit to restore faith

fields.headline: Bolton do their bit to restore faith
fields.trailText: Bolton 1 - 0 Charlton
fields.body:
Prior to the kick-off of this pulsating quarter-final, which encapsulated the very best of the FA Cup and perhaps helped to ameliorate the damage done by Manchester United's withdrawal, the big screen in the Reebok Stadium showed black-and-white footage of Bolton's 2-0 triumph over the Reds in the 1958 final.

One of Bolton's goals, you may remember, came when Nat Lofthouse clattered into the United goalkeeper Harry Gregg, knocking him senseless. These days Lofthouse would have been sent off and the United players would have rioted.

There was no malice to that challenge, even if it did sway the course of the final, whereas the current outbreak of violence on the field of play seems too often rooted in revenge and an accompanying lack of self-control. To hear Ray Wilkins last week argue that Chelsea and Wimbledon were not responsible for their flare-up was to enter the world of Lewis Carroll.

Dean Holden's sending-off on Saturday, just after Eidur Gudjohnsen's brilliantly struck goal had ensured Charlton's 1947 FA Cup final win against Burnley was once again singularly preserved in the aspic of history, was not the blight on the match it might have been, because the referee Graham Poll acted promptly and decisively.

Holden was indeed bent on revenge against John Robinson, who had pushed the Bolton player's nose into the ground, and immediately there was the inevitable gathering of the indignant. But the Tring referee, who in the past has reached for yellow cards at the blow of a nose, watched, waited and duly delivered the right verdict.

Other crude moments followed but Poll allowed the match to flow wherever possible. And mighty thrilling it was, culminating in an extraordinary double save by Jussi Jaaskelainen in the final minutes.

Gudjohnsen makes a habit of the spectacular, suddenly erupting in the course of a match like an Icelandic geyser, and his obliquely struck winner was a diamond. Bolton acquired the Icelander on a free transfer after an ankle injury threatened his career while he was at PSV, and they are being well rewarded for their faith in his talent. This was the 21-year-old's 16th goal of the season and he has now scored in every round of this FA Cup campaign.

"The goal summed him up," said the Bolton manager Sam Allardyce. "Sometimes he slips up with the easier chances but he does different things. Some strikers would have laid that ball off. He's an exciting talent." So much so that Bolton may find they have trouble keeping him, Derby County already having made a substantial bid.

Understandably Gudjohnsen and Jaaskelainen were deemed the Bolton heroes, although after Holden's sending-off and with Charlton pressing exceptionally hard it was the South African Mark Fish, recently returned from the African Nations Cup, who displayed outstanding composure and resolve in the centre of Bolton's rearranged defence.

Despite Alan Curbishley's post-match contention that he had been "desperate" to win this Cup tie, he will be every bit as determined to extract at least a point when his side return to the Reebok Stadium for a league match on March 4.

Charlton have been generally acknowledged the best side in the First Division this season, and Curbishley, above anything, wants them back in the Premiership.

webTitle: Ten-yard rule gets go-ahead for next season

fields.headline: Ten-yard rule gets go-ahead for next season
fields.trailText: One of the most radical changes in the history of the professional game will become a reality next season if the Football Association was given the Fifa go ahead to introduce a rugby-style 10-yard rule to curb dissent and reduce the number of red and yellow cards.
fields.body:
One of the most radical changes in the history of the professional game will become a reality next season if the Football Association presses ahead with plans to introduce a rugby-style 10-yard rule to curb dissent and reduce the number of red and yellow cards.

Referees will be permitted to move direct and indirect free-kicks up to the six-yard box if the rule, already applied successfully in the Auto Windscreens Shield, is approved by the FA's board of management tomorrow. It is expected that the board will agree to implement it next season, although not necessarily in the Premiership.

At the International Board meeting in Berkshire over the weekend Fifa agreed to several amendments to the laws of the game but said the 10-yard rule was too revolutionary to be introduced worldwide at present. Football's world governing body nevertheless gave the FA the go-ahead to carry on taking the lead in experimenting with the idea.

The FA's chief executive Adam Crozier said he would try to get broad agreement for the 10-yard rule at tomorrow's meeting and did not dismiss the possibility of persuading Premiership chairmen to adopt the system. More likely, however, is that it will begin in one or more major cup competitions and in the Nationwide League.

"Both the Premier League and the Football League are very supportive," said Crozier, who also has the backing of the Scottish FA. "We now have to discuss the best way of taking it forward. We want a full idea of how it works across a league situation over a whole season rather than in one-off games. I'd like to think we could at least get it into one of the leagues."

Fifa has also agreed to change the date of the club world championship to the summer under pressure from Europe's leading clubs.

Manchester United's withdrawal from the FA Cup to take part in the inaugural tournament in Brazil last month led to criticism that the competition was unworkable in the middle of the season because of fixture congestion.

Europe's governing body Uefa recently threatened not to sanction a European team for the next tournament unless the date was moved to the summer. Fifa has yet to decide whether to stage the event annually or every two years.

The International Board also approved further research into goal-line technology, gave assistant referees the power to award penalties, and agreed to scrap the four-step rule for goalkeepers and replace it from July 1 with a six-second limit on releasing the ball.

fields.headline: Scottish round-up
fields.trailText: Alloa anguish
fields.body:
Alloa anguish

In the end there was no carnage, but the Scottish Cup bruised a few egos as the last eight refused to take shape along the correct lines. Alloa Athletic were the club feeling most badly abused.

The Second Division side had, after all, taken a two-goal lead over Dundee United by the 33rd minute through Dave Beaton and Mark Cameron. Then the plot went wrong.

Cameron missed a good chance to extend the lead, the goalkeeper Mark Cairns had to be replaced by a midfielder, and Jim Hamilton's goals meant a Tannadice replay.

"To make matters worse, under SFA rules we may have to play an 18-year-old goalkeeper if Mark is out for the replay," said Alloa's manager Terry Christie. "It just doesn't seem fair to the smaller clubs and I think we should be allowed to sign somebody."

 Hibs just about avoided humiliation on the Celtic scale. They were down to a Lee Gardner penalty at Clydebank, still to win a First Division match this season, and were relieved when Paul Hartley equalised.

 Rangers were less than impressive in a 1-0 victory over Morton at Love Street, the ground at which the First Division club did not want to play. Craig Moore managed the only goal after 50 minutes.

 Hearts had an easier time, scoring twice in the first seven minutes against Clyde at Broadwood. Partick Thistle's win against Livingstone was a small tremor, and Berwick did well to hold Falkirk at Shielfield Park.

fields.headline: Third Division round-up
fields.trailText: Fortune teller
fields.body:
Fortune teller

Rotherham moved three points clear at the top with a 4-2 win over Carlisle. Leo Fortune-West's hat-trick and a fourth from Brian Wilsterman ensured Rotherham re-established a cushion ahead of Swansea, who won on Friday. Carlisle have lost five in a row and remain two points clear of Chester at the bottom.

 Peterborough could not repeat last season's 9-1 win at Barnet but did collect three points at Underhill as goals from Steve Castle and Jason Lee secured a 2-0 win. However John Still, Barnet's manager, remains confident of automatic promotion. "When you lose, it is easy for people to get negative and not look at the wider picture. But when you assess the full picture, everyone at this club should be jumping for joy. My players will bounce back - they are such a resilient bunch. Their achievements so far are nothing short of a miracle."

 Darlington moved above Barnet into third place, Mike Oliver's goal in stoppage time condemning Southend to a 1-0 defeat. It was only the fifth time Southend have failed to score this season.

 Northampton remain in the play-off positions after their 1-0 victory over Brighton, now without a win in eight games.

 Plymouth maintained their unbeaten home record with a 2-0 win over York, who have now gone eight away games without a win and have been beaten four times in a row.

fields.headline: Second Division round-up
fields.trailText: Rovers romp
fields.body:
Rovers romp

Bristol Rovers drew level on points with Preston at the top of the table with a 4-1 victory at Luton, whose manager Lennie Lawrence described it as "the worst day of the season so far". His mood was not helped by two errors by the goalkeeper Nathan Abbey which gifted Rovers' strikers Jason Roberts and Jamie Cureton a goal apiece. The pair added another each to nullify Phil Gray's opener for Luton and secure Rovers' ninth away win of the season.

 Preston remain ahead of Rovers on goal difference after a 1-1 draw with Bury at Deepdale. Jon Macken scored his 19th league goal to give Preston the lead before Lutel James's equaliser four minutes before half-time.

 Millwall's hopes of gaining automatic promotion were bolstered by a 3-1 victory over Bournemouth, who had won on their three previous visits to the Den. They threatened to make it four on the trot when John O'Shea, on loan from Manchester United, put them ahead after three minutes. Two goals from Richard Sadlier and one from Paul Ifill kept Millwall six points off second.

 Oxford's first win in five home games, 2-1 against their fellow strugglers Chesterfield, kept them three points clear of the relegation zone. Derek Lilley secured the points a minute from time.

 Blackpool remain hopeful of survival after victory at Cambridge, their third away win in a row. Both sides remain in the bottom four but they are now separated by four points.

fields.headline: First Division round-up
fields.trailText: Brum on the up
fields.body:
Brum on the up

Birmingham strengthened their play-off chances with a 4-1 victory over Swindon, who remain 10 points adrift of safety. "No disrespect to Swindon but they were never going to get near us," Birmingham's manager Trevor Francis said after his team condemned the home side to their 17th game without a win. Darren Purse, Isaiah Rankin, Dele Adebola and Martin Grainger scored Birmingham's goals, Chris Hay providing brief hope with an equaliser for Swindon after 13 minutes.

 Marcus Bent claimed a hat-trick as Sheffield United scored six for the first time since 1993 to increase the relegation worries of West Brom, whose midfielder Richard Sneekes was sent off for violent conduct with the score at 1-0 and had to watch Paul Devlin, Alex Notman and Michael Brown make it 6-0.

webTitle: As meejah 'eroes go, wooden Wrightie is no Buzz Lightyear

fields.headline: As meejah 'eroes go, wooden Wrightie is no Buzz Lightyear
fields.trailText: Martin Kelner is appalled and Ian Wright with his chat show is the culprit.
fields.body:
If the FA is serious about stopping footballers behaving like idiots it might start by doing something about Ian Wright's ITV chat show.

" 'Ow did yer cope wiv everyfink?" was his opening gambit to Paula Yates on the first programme of a new series of Friday Night's All Wright. Yates, he informed us, was " 'ardly ever aht o' the 'eadlines", although evidently she has been out of them long enough to make an appearance on Wright's show an attractive proposition.

" 'Ow wudya describe yerself?" our fearless interrogator later asked Julian Clary. "I'm a camp comic and renowned homosexual," replied a deadpan Clary, whose own show Sticky Moments will have been perfect preparation for these shallow waters.

Of All Saints, a girl pop group, Wright asked: " 'As it been 'ard, or 'as it been easy?" Exactly what they might have found difficult I am not sure, as this "interview" was in the latter part of the show and I had rather lost the will to live by that stage. But I suspect it might have been all the attention from the meejah. The one thing Wrightie has in common with Parkinson, his opposition on the other side, is his encouragement of people who whinge about their treatment by the press.

My view is that anybody who appears before millions on a chat show to complain about media interest deserves not a sympathetic hearing but to be beaten about the head with a sock filled with horse manure. Either that or to be made to spend a week in the Spanish holiday resort of their choice with Stan Collymore and the Leicester City first-team squad.

There used to be a certain charm about Wright's naivety. When he was just Wrightie having a bash at TV he was the enfant sauvage of the medium and the asinine nature of his questions was neither here nor there. But since his first series he has been ludicrously glorified with an MBE and a This Is Your Life love-in. He is an insider now, so he can damn well be subject to the same rules as everyone else, and his show - to borrow a word he used in his penetrating All Saints interview - is mingin'.

Wright's MBE was described by the BBC commentator Mike Ingham as symptomatic of the disease afflicting the Premiership. Twenty grand a week is not enough for them, they need MBEs as well, was the basic tenor of Ingham's editorial on Radio 5 Live, which focused this week on what we, the hated running dogs of the fourth estate, were calling "football's week of shame".

Ingham picked out Kevin Keegan's press conference as a good example of football getting too big for its boots, with Keegan flanked by an army of minders and spinners as he prepared to "feed the media beast".

Whoa there Ingers, I thought, which particular media beast would that be? I was listening to 5 Live when Keegan announced the England squad, and the station was promoting one of Kev's anodyne soundbites as "the first comments on any national radio station" about his selections. This was clearly a pre-emptive strike at Talksport, which had secured Keegan to answer listeners' questions in an hour long phone-in. It was also a clue as to the nature of the "media beast".

The launch of Talksport with its endless blabathons about the game has thrown into sharp focus the highly competitive nature of football coverage these days, with those outlets that are denied access to the action itself determined to make the most of what could loosely be described as news.

So Stan and Gazza behaving like imbeciles - a dog-bites-man story if ever there was one - and a couple of brawls barely worthy of the name were endlessly recycled and dissected. The "week of shame" took us all the way from Match Of The Day through to Football Focus, where Ray Stubbs asked: "Does an insatiable, hysterical media hype everything out of all proportion?" The programme answered its own question by stationing its reporter Gary Richardson outside the Cliveden Hotel in Berkshire, where Fifa was meeting, and going over to him for regular reports as if it were the Northern Ireland peace talks.

The upshot was that our referees will be allowed to move free-kicks 10 yards forward if their decisions are disputed, in the hope that players will accept decisions with the good grace of their rugby counterparts. It occurred to me while watching the France-England match, however, that one of the reasons there is less dissent in rugby is that the players have so many other outlets for their frustration; the loose mauls, for instance, under which Dewi Morris may have spent too much time if his mystifying post-match comments on Sky are anything to go by.

"I took my daughter to see Toy Story 2 on Wednesday," announced Morris. "Her hero is Woody, no pun intended, but Jonny Wilkinson was magnificent today. Perhaps they should make Jonny Wilkinson dolls." Much more of this and it will not be long before he has his own ITV chat show.

Wright's MBE was described by the BBC commentator Mike Ingham as symptomatic of the disease afflicting the Premiership. Twenty grand a week is not enough for them, they need MBEs as well, was the basic tenor of Ingham's editorial on Radio 5 Live, which focused this week on what we, the hated running dogs of the fourth estate, were calling "football's week of shame". Ingham picked out Kevin Keegan's press conference as a good example of football getting too big for its boots, with Keegan flanked by an army of minders and spinners as he prepared to "feed the media beast". Whoa there Ingers, I thought, which particular media beast would that be? I was listening to 5 Live when Keegan announced the England squad, and the station was promoting one of Kev's anodyne soundbites as "the first comments on any national radio station" about his selections. This was clearly a pre-emptive strike at Talksport, which had secured Keegan to answer listeners' questions in an hour long phone-in. It was also a clue as to the nature of the "media beast". The launch of Talksport with its endless blabathons about the game has thrown into sharp focus the highly competitive nature of football coverage these days, with those outlets that are denied access to the action itself determined to make the most of what could loosely be described as news. So Stan and Gazza behaving like imbeciles - a dog-bites-man story if ever there was one - and a couple of brawls barely worthy of the name were endlessly recycled and dissected. The "week of shame" took us all the way from Match Of The Day through to Football Focus, where Ray Stubbs asked: "Does an insatiable, hysterical media hype everything out of all proportion?" The programme answered its own question by stationing its reporter Gary Richardson outside the Cliveden Hotel in Berkshire, where Fifa was meeting, and going over to him for regular reports as if it were the Northern Ireland peace talks. The upshot was that our referees will be allowed to move free-kicks 10 yards forward if their decisions are disputed, in the hope that players will accept decisions with the good grace of their rugby counterparts. It occurred to me while watching the France-England match, however, that one of the reasons there is less dissent in rugby is that the players have so many other outlets for their frustration; the loose mauls, for instance, under which Dewi Morris may have spent too much time if his mystifying post-match comments on Sky are anything to go by. "I took my daughter to see Toy Story 2 on Wednesday," announced Morris. "Her hero is Woody, no pun intended, but Jonny Wilkinson was magnificent today. Perhaps they should make Jonny Wilkinson dolls." Much more of this and it will not be long before he has his own ITV chat show.

fields.headline: No bad thing
fields.standfirst: How Chris Smith has announced a new discipline for the BBC
fields.trailText: Media editor Kamal Ahmed on how Chris Smith has announced a new discipline for the BBC
fields.body:
Greg Dyke, the newly installed director general of the BBC, had to put a brave face on it. This settlement is a welcome boost at the start of my time as director general, he said minutes after the government had announced the BBCs new funding settlement. And a vote of confidence for the BBC and the people who work in it.

Well, not exactly. In bald terms the governments decision to increase the licence fee by £3 in April is far short of what the corporation wanted.

The BBC argued that they needed another £700m above the funding they were already getting in order to develop new digital and internet services.

Conversely and unsurprisingly, many in the commercial television sector argued that Auntie should get nothing and that any new money should be gained from efficiency savings within the BBC itself.

Chris Smith, the secretary of state for culture, media and sport and as such the man responsible for the licence fee, has plumped for something in the middle - an increase of £200m with a quid pro quo that the BBC itself will find an extra £1bn over six years in self-help.

In short he wants the BBC to find at least as much money a year from efficiency savings and new business partnerships as the government is willing to give it in extra funding. As such he can show himself to be a friend of the people who pay for the BBC - us, the viewers who will not have to dig very deep (3p a week) for the extra funding.

Such a small increase is a blow for the corporation. It was Sir John Birt, the former director general, who argued for £700m, mindful of the fact that in satellite broadcasting the BBC was so slow on the take up Rupert Murdoch was allowed to monopolise the new technology as his own. Sir John didnt want to be left behind again.

But as Gavyn Davies, the economist and friend of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, argued in his report on BBC funding last year, the £700m was based on only the vaguest ideas about what the BBC was essentially for. Sir John wanted the BBC to be everywhere, providing every service imaginable. Davies said such a universal service plan was badly thought out and not a basis for such a huge increase.

Smith clearly agrees. His announcement means that the BBC will have to look more closely at what it does and decide on priorities. Smith made it clear where these should be - education and channels which have a clear public service function.

The commercial television sector will be delighted. Firstly the notion of an increased licence fee for digital television users only, which the commercial sector has spent millions of pounds wooing, has been left dead in the water.

This was not because Smith was particularly worried by any adverse effect such a levy would have on digital take-up (probably negligable). What he was worried about was the possibility of a legal challenge from the commercial broadcasters which said they would refuse to give lists of digital subscribers necessary for such a specific levy. Lengthy and debelitating legal argument through the European courts could have ensued.

The commercial sector will also be pleased that Smith has warned the BBC away from non-public service broadcasting such as sports or films channels. That is where they make all their money.

Dyke knows he will have to cut his cloth more carefully now and that even this small increase has come at the cost of greater regulation from bodies, as yet ill-defined, outside the BBC. Such new discipline on the corporation is seen by many as no bad thing.

webTitle: Livingstone loses by a whisker and faces his biggest gamble

fields.headline: Livingstone loses by a whisker and faces his biggest gamble
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone was last night holding out against intense pressure to throw his weight behind Frank Dobson's candidacy for elected mayor of London amid widespread dismay at the former health secretary's wafer-thin victory in Labour's electoral college.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone was last night holding out against intense pressure to throw his weight behind Frank Dobson's candidacy for elected mayor of London amid widespread dismay at the former health secretary's wafer-thin victory in Labour's electoral college.

As Mr Dobson floated the prospect of a job for the former Greater London council leader and some pro-Livingstone unions and activists warned him against the gamble of an independent candidacy, Mr Livingstone denounced the result as "tainted" - and kept his options open.

With intense support from Tony Blair and the Millbank party machine, Mr Dobson scraped home with 51.53% of the three-sided electoral college against Mr Livingstone's 48.47%, but only after the votes of the third candidate, Glenda Jackson - who won 4.21% of the initial votes - had been redistributed between the frontrunners.

The narrowest result in the bitterest internal Labour election since the Tony Benn-Denis Healey deputy leadership fight of 1981 allowed Mr Dobson to demand the support of his beaten rivals in the coming battle against the Tory candidate, Steve Norris, on May 4.

"I stand by the result and I expect other candidates to do what they said they would do," Mr Dobson said.

Ms Jackson did so even before the ballot results were announced. Mr Livingstone, who stayed at home, renewed his campaign for Mr Dobson to do the "honourable" thing and accept that he is too unpopular - and too close to Downing Street - to beat Mr Norris.

"In the interests of uniting the Labour party, I hope Frank Dobson will consider his position over the next few days. He must decide whether he is willing to accept this tainted result or stand down in the interests of Labour and London," Mr Livingstone said.

But he also urged his supporters - who helped him win the trade union and constituency sections of the electoral college, but not MPs - to "stay inside the Labour party and fight to ensure this does not happen again".

Some MPs and cabinet ministers took that as a sign that the Brent East MP will draw back from an independent candidacy which some polls say he would win, but which would be bloody and divisive.

Last night there were few signs that any prominent figures or unions would court expulsion by endorsing such a run.

Geoff Martin, London convenor of Unison - whose members voted by four to one for Mr Livingstone - called for talks to "salvage" a dream result for the Tories. "It would be an absolute disaster if Millbank just continued to plough on regardless and ignored the clear wishes of the vast majority of rank-and-file trade unionists and party members who have given such a clear and ringing endorsement to Ken Livingstone," he said.

Downing Street, widely blamed for trying to control devolved government yet again, after the battle for Welsh first secretary this time last year, stayed out of the public row, although speculation that Tony Blair will offer Mr Livingstone, 54, a ministerial job is misplaced. Instead, party officials warned that "the entire party would turn against him" if he runs, contrary to his promise to abide by the contest's rules.

That claim is disputed because of the way some affiliated organisations - the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union and the south London co-op, in particular, with 8% of the electoral college between them - failed to ballot members.

Feeling ran strong that Mr Livingstone had been denied the victory he deserved by the party machine. "We had to do what we had to do to block him, but from his point of view he won all the votes that could not be fixed," one former ally on the left conceded.

In the event, Mr Livingstone won both the members' and affiliated union sections, but was beaten by the votes of MPs, MEPs and Greater London assembly candidates. The Brent East MP polled an estimated total of 74,646 votes in all three sections, compared to 22,275 for Mr Dobson and 11,185 for Ms Jackson.

In the members' section, the former GLC leader won 19,548 first preference votes to Mr Dobson's 12,559, giving him 59.9% to 40.1% after Ms Jackson's second preferences had been shared out.

Mr Livingstone appears to be hoping that the Dobson campaign will quickly flounder amid popular indignation and allow him to step into the breach - much as Rhodri Morgan took over from the hapless Alun Michael as Welsh first secretary. But Mr Dobson, 60 next month, is generally regarded as a tougher politician than Mr Michael and pledged yesterday he would be nobody's patsy.

He went out of his way yesterday to court both Mr Livingstone and Ms Jackson as "very talented people" who he would "like to be involved both in our campaign and also any administration I presided over. But I don't want to be patronising; they might want to take part, they may not."

fields.headline: Trouble unlimited
fields.standfirst:
Frank Dobson's slim win represents a victory for no one, least of all Labour
The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: What do chronic troublemakers do when they don't get what they want? Simple question: simple answer. They make loads more trouble. And whoever, in the light of so much acrid experience, expected anything else from Ken Livingstone? Trouble unlimited.
fields.body:
What do chronic troublemakers do when they don't get what they want? Simple question: simple answer. They make loads more trouble. And whoever, in the light of so much acrid experience, expected anything else from Ken Livingstone? Trouble unlimited.

It's the naivety of Millbank and Downing Street that gets you down. They wanted a mayor for London (fizzy, reforming stuff) but they couldn't find a suitably charismatic trustee. They read the polls and saw the GLC's old Labour raptor taking flight from some primeval swamp. Much panicking in the marsh. Frank Dobson had to be frog-marched into the sacrifice zone - and then reinforced by the kind of "electoral college" that Robert Mugabe doesn't dare invent any longer.

Thus, yesterday, predictable ineptitude produced its predictable result. Dobbo "won" by a couple of bearded whiskers and will be the candidate of last resort - but one so damaged by the process of winning that he's already a glum figure of fun. And Ken? Did he instantly turn into a loyal team-player, a sporting loser? Of course not. This "tainted" result was "theft". An independent run is in the concocting. It was the ultimate naivety to believe otherwise.

Mr Livingstone has nothing to gain by playing along with No 10's charades. Spin doctors talk about making him some junior minister for overseas development, with galumphing stress on the "overseas" bit, but it's tawdry stuff. Livingstone hasn't had a career or the prospect of advancement since County Hall turned into an aquarium. His sole strength (however oddly retained) has been his continuing place in the hearts and memories of ordinary London voters. They want him, overwhelmingly, to be their mayor. Why let the Millbank bastards get away with it? Why not make as much trouble as you can along the way? You have nothing - absolutely nothing - to lose: exhortations to "party loyalty" are a cynical joke.

Tony Blair, naturally enough, is not amused. He, like countless others, thinks Ken's a wrecker. Why let him wreck this new vision of London governance or provide him with a handy platform to taunt a Labour prime minister to distraction in just the way he tipped Mrs T over the edge? Why not fight by every available means to keep him out? That's not manic centralism from a control freak, just commonsense. The difficulty here, though, is not the reasonability of the ends ordained; it's the cack-handed incompetence of the means deployed. If you're going to put the fix in, then fix it good.

We've reached a dislocated stage of the whole Blair project. One essential plank of it is the spread of political power away from the centre, the devolution of responsibility to parliaments and assemblies in Edinburgh and Cardiff, the move beyond that to regenerate big cities by giving them elected mayors. Eight million or so Londoners want their formidable say.

It is too easy, too forgetfully short-term, to dismiss all this as optional tinkering from an incoming Labour government. Scotland had to be given devolution. It was either that or a free ride for the Nats. Wales, accordingly, had to be offered something of the same. And London equally, after a decade of drift, couldn't be left without a voice of its own. Mr Blair not only did the right thing; he did the inevitable thing. His problem is that his critics don't remember what was necessary or recognise the fundamental tensions that were bound to flow. They see the surface turmoil - and make all the usual mud pies from it. What's actually happening is much more significant.

Consider, for example, the very senior minister who ought to be centre stage now, whose interests are those most affected. Where is Gordon Brown? Deep in budget purdah and reportedly counting a £7bn bonus for prudent dispersal as the general election nears. Nobody challenges the chancellor. Yet it's Mr Brown, and the entire edifice of treasury operation, which stands in the way of logical reform.

The issue that, a few days ago, disposed of Alun Michael as first minister for Wales was a treasury issue. Would Brown match European Union development grants for the principality pound for pound? That's not, and never has been, treasury policy: it passes the final say on what developments to back to Brussels: it leaves the Whitehall enforcers out of the loop. So EU cash that we've in part put up in the first place, has to go begging. Why should any self-respecting national assembly be expected to swallow that - or Mr Michael be expected to hold a ludicrous line?

In just the same way, the core policy for Londoners in May will be tube privatisation. Another money matter: another area of treasury calculation. And don't, for a second, think Scotland immune from such tensions. The "Barnett formula" determining the flow of central funds to Donald Dewar's administration is far out of date and far too generous. The treasury knows that and is already finding that regions like the north-east know it, too.

We aren't, in sum, talking individual, dissonant personalities here. There are much deeper forces at work. British government revolves around the traditional cabinet bidding process as spending ministers come cap in hand to collect their permitted dibs. The mantras of "value for money" and "equal standards of performance" - in education or health and, now, police efficiency - are extrapolations of that treasury creed. The dismantling of local government over decades has been no accident. But now the tide is turning.

Rhodri Morgan will only survive in office for as long as he "fights for Wales". Cash calls. The Scots Nats will come to number Donald Dewar's days in used Bank of Scotland fivers. Frank Dobson or Steve Norris, if elected, will have to be as bruising opponents of treasury rule as Mayor Ken could ever be. It's the system embarked on that makes the rules - not the people caught up in it. It is the absolutely natural tendency of voters, given a ballot that may tug a little more loot from the centre, to pull that lever.

Meanwhile the mayhem goes on. Dobbo bleeds and Livingstone goes through the menacing PR motions. Tony Blair's reputation for straight dealing takes another dive. The tabloid headlines will be lethal right through the spring; the possibility of another mighty kick in the pants for Labour (from an admirably savvy Norris) can't be ruled out. And, tactically, New Labour will deserve much of what it gets.

Remember, though, that this isn't the whole story: remember the serious things beneath the malign froth. Whether we realise it or not, we're asking profound questions about the way we're governed, in style and assumptions. You can't ask questions like that without being part of the search for answers as well. This is bigger than Citizen Ken.

fields.headline: The road to 'political disaster'
fields.standfirst:
The narrowness of Dobson's win is a predictable fiasco stemming from chronic indecision

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The worst outcome of Labour's London mayoral selection battle, one of Tony Blair's most trusted advisers said privately earlier this month, would be if Frank Dobson won the party's electoral college by less than 5%.
fields.body:
The worst outcome of Labour's London mayoral selection battle, one of Tony Blair's most trusted advisers said privately earlier this month, would be if Frank Dobson won the party's electoral college by less than 5%.

Such a result, he suggested, would be a "political disaster", because it would put the spotlight on the least heroic aspects of the selection process and give Ken Livingstone the most favourable ground to launch an independent campaign - and potentially split Labour's mayoral vote.

The narrowness of the former health secretary's victory yesterday - combined with convincing Livingstone wins in both members' and union ballots - will have realised that aide's worst fears. Mr Dobson's 3% margin leaves the prime minister's nominee vulnerable to accusations of being an illegitimate, "second choice" candidate, while the opposition parties crow about "Alun Michael with a beard".

Even the most committed New Labour enthusiasts find it hard to explain how such a predictable fiasco could have been allowed to happen, in effect in slow motion. Mr Blair was championing an executive mayor for London and other big cities four years ago, and Mr Livingstone's name was floated in the immediate aftermath of Labour's 1997 general election victory.

An elementary rule of political management is never to create a post before you have a credible candidate to fill it. Remarkably, in view of the prime minister's reputation as a ruthless control freak, the problem of who should head the Blairite advance guard in London for his brave new world of executive mayors was repeatedly and fatally postponed, while the Livingstone bandwagon gathered speed.

A year ago, with London opinion polls giving the former Greater London council leader convincing leads and Mr Livingstone pledging in an open letter to the Guardian to "work with your government, not against it", Mr Blair faced an urgent choice: he could take Mr Livingstone at face value and try to come to some accommodation with him, or he could lay the ground to block his candidacy with a determined political onslaught.

In fact, Mr Blair did neither. One senior Blair ally insisted yesterday that the prime minister had never regarded it as "practical or appropriate" to stop Mr Livingstone from standing. But lower down the hierarchy, it appeared that the Labour leader was incapable of making up his mind. Throughout last year decisions were postponed on who should carry Mr Blair's standard and how and when to run Labour's London selection. More important calls on Mr Blair's attention - Kosovo, Ireland, Iraq - put the looming crisis on the back-burner.

Gordon Brown, Alastair Campbell, Peter Mandelson and the prime minister's political secretary, Sally Morgan, all argued for the Brent East MP to be barred from Labour's official selection process.

John Prescott and Philip Gould, Mr Blair's polling adviser, feared a voter and party backlash and pressed for him to be allowed to run - as did Margaret McDonagh, who correctly predicted that Mr Livingstone could be defeated through an electoral college.

The decision, when it came, was Mr Blair's. But months of mixed messages helped produce the chaos of November's selection panel meetings, the last-minute catapulting of Mr Dobson into the mayoral fray and the ensuing bitter and divisive campaign.

Piling the blame on Millbank may be politically expedient, but as one cabinet minister said yesterday: "Millbank doesn't take those kind of political decisions."

The intense campaigning by Mr Dobson's team, backed by Mr Blair and cabinet and parliamentary loyalists, pulled away just enough of Mr Livingstone's lead among party members to do the trick.

But the damage to Labour has arguably been worse than in Wales, where Mr Blair's candidate, Alun Michael, was beaten by Rhodri Morgan this time last year in the members' ballot for Welsh first secretary, but won in the MPs' and union sections. Mr Dobson was beaten in both members' and union sections - and almost wherever there was a ballot.

Mr Blair's indecision has left him with an open wound in the London Labour party and an increased risk of a Labour defeat in the mayoral poll in May. The party's internal selection process has implicitly come under fire from the Council of Europe, and Mr Blair has been seen to have had to rely on Tammany Hall fixes to get his man selected.

But perhaps most dangerous in the long run for Mr Blair's grip on his party may have been the message that it is possible to to be popular without being New Labour. Mr Dobson's victory is likely to prove to have been a Pyrrhic one for the prime minister.

webTitle: Numbers racket ensures victory by a brass neck

fields.headline: Numbers racket ensures victory by a brass neck
fields.standfirst:
Numbers racket ensures victory by a brass neck

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The result was announced yesterday, except that you couldn't really call it an announcement. There was a pastiche reading of the figures for the television cameras by the "independent scrutineer". But the news had officially been passed to the Press Association, the national news agency - possibly on a scrap of paper chucked anonymously through the letter-box - an hour earlier.
fields.body:
The result was announced yesterday, except that you couldn't really call it an announcement. There was a pastiche reading of the figures for the television cameras by the "independent scrutineer". But the news had officially been passed to the Press Association, the national news agency - possibly on a scrap of paper chucked anonymously through the letter-box - an hour earlier.

Indeed, a remarkably accurate forecast of how it would go had been rumoured since Wednesday night. And Trevor Phillips, the successful candidate's running-mate, said he had known Frank Dobson would win MONTHS ago. That was probably routine political blather but, after an election like this one, it's hard to be sure.

You couldn't really call it a result, either. The scrutineer gave out a jumble of percentages, most of which were higher for Ken Livingstone than for Frank Dobson. This, we were assured, proved that Dobbo had won, by a neck. A brass neck.

The Labour party wished to be helpful. It was possible, said an official, to provide figures showing that if each trade union ballot had been broken down into individuals rather than aggregated as a bloc, he would still have won. "Could we have numbers?" someone asked. "Numbers?" came the baffled reply. "Instead of the percentages, can you tell us how many people voted for each candidate?" There was a pause. "We can PROBABLY get you those," we were told, as though it were a very eccentric request, which Labour would none the less try to indulge - Numbers! How quaint!

Actually, the numbers were quite simple. In France, people used to be divided into three estates so that the nobility and the clergy could always outnumber the common herd by two estates to one. This ceased in 1789. It is New Labour's achievement to revive the system with a special Blairite twist. Now it is the Labour Party that is divided into three estates: the members, the unions and the apparatchiks. And the apparatchiks have just outvoted the others by one estate to two.

You could call it shameless, except that Mr Dobson seemed very ashamed indeed. He came in wearing a dark suit but no tie, an outfit which suggested a man who was confused before he started. And the more upbeat he sounded, the more you could sense the desperation. He thrust his head backwards - beard at 45 degrees - then rocked to and fro, his fingers gently drumming the table, explaining why it had all been perfectly above-board really.

He smiled a lot, in his usual bluff good-old-Dobbo way. But somehow he smiled with the corners of his mouth downwards rather than upwards. Mostly, he looked more like a man trying to recite a long piece of liturgy from memory rather than a politician attempting to answer questions.

He was at his most animated when he lapsed into self-pity. "If anyone's been damaged by the system, it's been me," he insisted. And Millbank could doubtless provide percentages to prove it. Mr Phillips was altogether more suave. Ken Livingstone's votes, he said, didn't come from people who wanted him as mayor; they were just angry with the system. So that was all right then.

The third figure on the platform was the chairman of the Greater London Labour party who has the splendidly Tammany Hall-style name of Jim Fitzpatrick. He looked calm enough at first too. But question after question homed in on Labour's internal workings, and the panic grew in his eyes. No one asked about Dobbo's really very exciting plans for London. For all we know, they include a system of jury trials in which decisions will be made by minority verdicts, a plan for annual wage decreases, and a scheme to sell off the tube to the lowest bidder.

Margaret McDonagh, Labour's general secretary, said Mr Dobson would have 100% support from the party's Greater London Assembly candidates. Is that good or bad? Less is more with New Labour. Anyway, she should know that if you run ballots like this one, you should never claim 100% for anything. The traditional figure is 99.9.
