fields.headline: Let's get clever
fields.standfirst:
The future of the BBC: special report
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke's first major speech as the BBC's director-general designate was about education: "I see this as one of my priorities for my period as DG." Later, in an impromptu defence of his extracurricular activities on Radio 4's Today programme, he was asked by John Humphrys what he would like to be remembered for at the end of his term. His response? That the BBC had made good programmes. Strangely, education did not get a mention on this occasion.
fields.body:
Spot the difference. Greg Dyke's first major speech as the BBC's director-general designate was about education: "I see this as one of my priorities for my period as DG." Later, in an impromptu defence of his extracurricular activities on Radio 4's Today programme, he was asked by John Humphrys what he would like to be remembered for at the end of his term. His response? That the BBC had made good programmes. This refreshingly simple reply will have delighted BBC producers. But, strangely, education did not get a mention on this occasion.

Will education be a dominating theme of Dyke's tenure? Or was his speech just another turn of the thumbscrew on government to jack up the licence fee? The answer is probably both.

The BBC's plans for digital services include an ambitious vision for online education. When I hear the word "vision", alarm bells go off in my head. The vision thingy can be inspiring or it can border on the megalomaniacal.

A recent presentation to the BBC's board of governors spoke of the corporation creating the first comprehensive digital resource for formal education, a one-stop shop for audio-visual material to challenge the Playstation generation. And the new DG's thoughtful public speech pointed to the power of interactivity in digital education. He said the BBC was "uniquely" placed to play a central role in helping to deliver the learning "vision" of the future.

"Unique" is another of those ultra-bold words, like vision, that unnerves me. Who is going to be allowed to plug their educational content into the National Grid for Learning - the network of computer hardware being established in Britain's schools? Will there be diversity or some Blairite (Orwellian?) solution from one massive supplier?

It is an issue that is nicely crystallised by a trial currently being carried out. Three contenders are having their interactive GSCE materials tested in schools. At stake is a department of education investment of up to £100m.

The contenders are the BBC, Granada and Anglia. They have all developed part of the maths syllabus and elements of one other subject - Granada's gone for science, the BBC for geography and Anglia for history. There's a lot riding on the outcome. The victors not only get the money but also first-mover advantage in a hugely lucrative market. Within a few years, schools television broadcasts will cease because all the material will be delivered online or via ADSL technology. Some of those who work in BBC Schools believe they have to win the trial in order to save their department.

But surely this should not be winner-takes-all. There has never been just one supplier of educational books. As long as the three trialists can demonstrate that their systems work, or can be made to work, they should all receive money. Teachers and pupils should have a choice.

Of course, the BBC has a central part to play. Education must be one of its key roles in the future. It may even guarantee the licence fee for a generation. Already BBC online services like GCSE Bitesize have shown how innovative and popular it can be. Bitesize also demonstrates how public money (the licence fee) can be deployed to cover the whole spectrum of the syllabus - both core subjects for which there will be strong demand and more fringe subjects which commercial operators might ignore. But despite these strengths the BBC itself agrees, when pressed, that there should be more than one flower in bloom.

Channel 4, another broadcaster with a public service remit, has ambitious online plans of its own for its particular constituency, the 16-24-year-olds. They already offer Homework High and are poised to launch further services aimed at "transitional moments" in the lives of this relatively poorly served age group. Pearson is both in television and education and can also be expected to play a heavyweight role.

At the other end of the scale are entrepreneurial initiatives such as Espresso. This is a start-up currently raising £10m of venture capital. It's the brainchild of Lewis Bronze who, in a previous life, was a long-serving editor of Blue Peter inside the BBC. He has developed software covering Key Stages 1 and 2 of the curriculum for children in primary schools. The Espresso product will need co-operation from the broadcasters.

Espresso's ambitions serve as a neat exemplar of some principles the government should not ignore. The emerging education market needs all the broadcasters, if they are willing to contribute. There should be a diversity of services fed into schools. And the BBC can play a very important role, but not the only one.

webTitle: 'The BBC is the UK's most important cultural institution'

fields.headline: 'The BBC is the UK's most important cultural institution'
fields.standfirst: Chris Smith's statement to the Commons
fields.trailText: Full text: Chris Smith's statement to the Commons
fields.body:
With permission, Madam Speaker, I should like to make a statement setting out the Government's decisions on the future funding of the BBC. This is a matter that has generated considerable interest, because the BBC is an institution which is central to the United Kingdom's view of itself, and of the world. I want to leave the House in no doubt about the Government's commitment to public service broadcasting and to retaining the BBC at its hub.

The BBC is the UK's most important cultural institution, and we have a duty to ensure that it can continue to play a central place in the nation's life. Specifically, the BBC should provide a strong and distinctive schedule of benchmark quality programmes on all its services and should drive the take up of new digital and on-line services.

A strong BBC is crucial in ensuring that everyone can have access to information, news, education and current affairs using efficient modern methods, so that we can build a society for the 21st Century on the solid foundations set down for us in the 20th.

We welcome the fact that the BBC's main priorities for the next seven years are: improving established services; expanding education work; developing interactive services; and devolution in national and regional broadcasting. We particularly welcome the BBC's intention to re-establish BBC 1 as the Corporation's flagship; its commitment to education, in particular learning support for schools and for life-long learning, and the exploitation of new learning possibilities opened up by interactivity.

We also welcome the BBC's plans for enhancing services in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, together with a greater regional emphasis within England. It is in order to enable the BBC to deliver these priorities that I am prepared to offer the BBC more support. We shall be keeping the BBC's implementation of these plans closely under review - and ensuring that they keep the commitments that they make in return for that additional support. The BBC must understand the basis of our decision and continue to satisfy Parliament that it can and will deliver.

I want to leave you in no doubt that to achieve this vision and to improve its services, the BBC needs to raise its game; it must become even more cost effective and quality conscious. That is why we are not going to allow the BBC the massive injection of funds it has sought from the licence fee - an increase reaching more than £700m a year by 2006. We are setting it a number of challenges, in terms of sources of finance and in operations.

In our consideration of these issues we have been enormously assisted by the work of the Independent Review Panel into the Future Funding of the BBC chaired by Gavyn Davies, which reported last summer. We asked the panel to examine options for providing the BBC with additional funding, assuming that the licence fee remains the principal source of revenue during the current Charter period.

The panel was also requested to consider the arrangements under which the BBC achieves a proper balance between its public and commercial services, and the concessionary scheme for pensioners. Broadly speaking, I am today accepting the Panel's analysis, though not, in every respect, the detailed solutions it proposed.

The report was published in July 1999 for public consultation. Over 2,000 responses were received. In reaching our decisions, we have taken account of these. I shall shortly be placing a summary of responses in the House Library, and - provided respondents have given permission - the representations by organisations will be made available by my Department's Information Centre, shortly.

I have also paid close attention to the Report of the Culture Media and Sport Committee, and, now that I have taken these decisions on the way forward, I will be publishing the Government's response as quickly as possible.

I am today placing in the House Library the report of independent consultants, Pannell Kerr Forster, entitled Review of the BBC's Financial Projections, which provided a key input into my decisions on finance, together with my Department's Chief Economist's analysis, and a copy of my letter to the Chairman of the BBC which will set out the detail of this settlement.

I shall now deal with the Government's decisions under 4 headings - finance, programming, transparency and licence fee concessions. They provide a balanced package of measures which I hope can be widely welcomed.

We accept the judgement of the Davies Panel that our vision for the BBC cannot be realised within the existing funding framework. We agree with them that without the BBC's provision of high quality free-to-air digital services, the penetration of digital TV could end up being capped at around 50-60% of the population. The first place to look for new funding should be self-help by the BBC.

New licence fee funding should be secondary. We are therefore providing for an increase in licence fee funding which will raise on average around £200 million per year between now and 2006. In addition, however, we are challenging the BBC to help themselves by increased efficiency savings, and raising more revenue from their subsidiaries, to the tune of £490m million by 2006/7, over and above the £600m which they themselves estimated.

This figure presents them with a higher target than that envisaged by the Davies panel - and is in line with the conclusions of the independent analysis of BBC finances which I commissioned. It means that we are demanding over the period of this settlement, that the BBC generates over £1 billion from self-help. As envisaged by the Davies panel, a proportion of the proceeds should be re-invested in the commercial businesses.

We will leave it to the BBC how they meet the challenge, but we are leaving the BBC in no doubt that we expect them to achieve the figures set out here - by efficiency savings, partnerships, joint ventures, reductions in bureaucracy, and other means. We believe that the licence fee settlement together with self help should yield enough to ensure that the BBC enhances established services and develops a significant foothold in the digital world.

There has been considerable debate on the method of raising additional funding for the BBC. The Review Panel put forward the alternatives of a digital licence fee set at £24, which would fade away' as the normal licence fee rose to meet it; or an increase in the general licence fee payable by all. I have decided not to adopt the new mechanism of a digital supplement payable only by those households with digital TV. Though I accept that there are good arguments for such a solution, on balance, I believe that the benefits of the increased funding will be available to all through improvements in the BBC core services, and, in the case of educational programming also through schools.

Furthermore, it is my view that switchover to digital will take place in this decade, so the time has now come to recognise that digital television will soon be the norm. Following my announcement in September, it is now clear that digital switchover can happen sooner than was envisaged by the Davies panel. Against my belief that digital TV brings benefits to all, it would be wrong to signal that it is something special and only for the few.

I am therefore going for the general licence fee option, and an increase of 1.5% over RPI in each year, starting in April of this year. This means an increase of 3 pence per week above inflation each year. On 1st April this year the licence fee will rise by £3. It also means that for each £ the BBC receives from the licence fee, they are expected to generate almost the equivalent through self-help. I will shortly be laying Regulations before the House in relation to the licence fee from 1 April.

The Davies panel proposed a package of reforms in the areas of transparency, fair trading and accountability. We support the thrust of the panel's recommendations. In particular, we intend to open up the process by which I approve new BBC proposals and we will also make the BBC's commitment to fair trading more transparent.

We are making it clear that we do not expect the licence fee to fund strands of the market, such as dedicated film and sport channels, to which the distinctive role of public service broadcasting has little extra to offer and, more generally, we will institute new procedures for the introduction of new services. This will include an opportunity for public consultation before I reach decisions on proposed new services. We also propose to carry out a programme of reviews of all the current BBC digital services (News 24, Choice, Knowledge and Parliament) to ensure that services are achieving what the BBC assured me they would achieve when I gave approval to them. We propose that a priority for such scrutiny should be News 24.

We are going to open the BBC to more external scrutiny. It has, hitherto, been too much the judge and jury in its own cause. I am requiring independent scrutinies of the BBC's fair trading policies and its financial reporting and will publish both scrutiny reports. I shall in addition expect the BBC to have their regular fair trading and financial audits carried out by different auditors in future.

The fair trading auditor's full report on compliance and risk will in future be published by the BBC. I will also appoint independent consultants to carry out periodic examinations of the systems and controls in place to ensure fair trading and the nature and extent of financial systems in place. These reports will also be published.

All these scrutiny and audit reports will, of course, be available for consideration and questioning by the Select Committee of this House. Finally, we will also be reviewing the public service role and governance of the BBC in the forthcoming Broadcasting and Communications White Paper.

This means in essence:
 a review of the governance of the BBC in the forthcoming White Paper;
 clear separation of BBC fair trading and financial audits;
 regular measurement of the BBC's performance against their promises on all new services;
 independent scrutiny of the BBC's financial and fair trading systems and controls; and
 regular reviews of progress in achieving efficiency savings and commercial targets.

Turning to concessions, we have already gone beyond the Davies panel's recommendation on assistance for pensioners with the announcement of free licences for the over 75s. I can now announce that we expect the scheme to start on 1 November, subject to Parliamentary approval of the necessary legislation. From 1 April, those who will be over 75 on 1 November, or who turn 75 after that date, but before their licence would expire, will be able to buy a short term licence, lasting till 1 November.

From 1 November, refunds will be available in respect of licences already paid for. I have also asked that the BBC will take steps to ensure that all those reaching their 75th birthday know they are entitled to a free licence, and how to apply.

We accept the Davies panel's other recommendations for achieving fairness, and will therefore ensure that there is a half price television licence for blind people; that subtitling of programmes is further developed; and that the Cash Easy Entry easy payment scheme is simplified and made more equitable.

There remains the issue of what to do about the Accommodation for Residential Care (ARC) concessionary scheme, which is the main focus of current concessions. Though the majority of the current beneficiaries are over 75 and will receive free licences, there will be about 130,000 pensioners and mentally and physically disabled people left in the scheme. Notwithstanding the drop in the number of people benefiting from the scheme, we propose to keep the existing arrangements for concessionary licences.

On concessions, therefore, we are:
 introducing free television licences for the over 75s from 1 November;
 introducing half price television licences for blind people from 1 April;
 setting new targets for subtitling for new BBC digital services;
 simplifying and making more equitable one of the key easy payment schemes; and
 retaining the current Accommodation for Residential Care concessionary scheme.

In return for 3p a week extra on top of the RPI, they will be assured good programming, and good value for money from a BBC that will be able to continue to deliver the quality we expect as the new digital world increasingly becomes a reality.

This settlement will, I believe, help to ensure the BBC's position and role as our primary public service broadcaster into the new century. If we are serious about valuing the BBC at its best, and about wanting to keep it at its best, and about ensuring that we all have programmes of real quality to watch in the future, then we must give it the support it needs. This statement will, I hope, give it precisely that.

We shall be keeping the BBC's implementation of these plans closely under review - and ensuring that they keep the commitments that they make in return for that additional support. The panel was also requested to consider the arrangements under which the BBC achieves a proper balance between its public and commercial services, and the concessionary scheme for pensioners. Broadly speaking, I am today accepting the Panel's analysis, though not, in every respect, the detailed solutions it proposed. The report was published in July 1999 for public consultation. Over 2,000 responses were received. In reaching our decisions, we have taken account of these. I shall shortly be placing a summary of responses in the House Library, and - provided respondents have given permission - the representations by organisations will be made available by my Department's Information Centre, shortly. I have also paid close attention to the Report of the Culture Media and Sport Committee, and, now that I have taken these decisions on the way forward, I will be publishing the Government's response as quickly as possible. I am today placing in the House Library the report of independent consultants, Pannell Kerr Forster, entitled Review of the BBC's Financial Projections, which provided a key input into my decisions on finance, together with my Department's Chief Economist's analysis, and a copy of my letter to the Chairman of the BBC which will set out the detail of this settlement. They provide a balanced package of measures which I hope can be widely welcomed. We accept the judgement of the Davies Panel that our vision for the BBC cannot be realised within the existing funding framework. We agree with them that without the BBC's provision of high quality free-to-air digital services, the penetration of digital TV could end up being capped at around 50-60% of the population. The first place to look for new funding should be self-help by the BBC. New licence fee funding should be secondary. We are therefore providing for an increase in licence fee funding which will raise on average around £200 million per year between now and 2006. In addition, however, we are challenging the BBC to help themselves by increased efficiency savings, and raising more revenue from their subsidiaries, to the tune of £490m million by 2006/7, over and above the £600m which they themselves estimated. This figure presents them with a higher target than that envisaged by the Davies panel - and is in line with the conclusions of the independent analysis of BBC finances which I commissioned. It means that we are demanding over the period of this settlement, that the BBC generates over £1 billion from self-help. As envisaged by the Davies panel, a proportion of the proceeds should be re-invested in the commercial businesses. We will leave it to the BBC how they meet the challenge, but we are leaving the BBC in no doubt that we expect them to achieve the figures set out here - by efficiency savings, partnerships, joint ventures, reductions in bureaucracy, and other means. We believe that the licence fee settlement together with self help should yield enough to ensure that the BBC enhances established services and develops a significant foothold in the digital world. Though I accept that there are good arguments for such a solution, on balance, I believe that the benefits of the increased funding will be available to all through improvements in the BBC core services, and, in the case of educational programming also through schools. fields.headline: BBC licence fee up by £3
fields.standfirst: Chris Smith's statement to the Commons
fields.trailText: Culture secretary Chris Smith today announced a £3 rise in the BBC licence fee but shelved plans for a "digital supplement" on the annual charge.
fields.body:
Culture secretary Chris Smith today announced a £3 rise in the BBC licence fee but shelved plans for a "digital supplement" on the annual charge.

The corporation had been hoping for a £700m cash injection each year between now and 2006 to fund its expanding digital services.

But the government will instead allow £200m a year from the general licence fee, which will increase by 1.5% above the retail price index each year starting on April 1l.

"This settlement, will I believe, help to ensure the BBC's position and role as a primary public service broadcaster into the new century," Mr Smith said.

He told the Commons that a scheme to give free licences to the over-75s would start on November 1 subject to parliament approving the necessary legislation. From April, blind people would get half-price licences.

Mr Smith added: "The BBC is the UK's most important cultural institution and we have a duty to ensure that it can continue to play a central place in the nation's life.

"A strong BBC is crucial in ensuring that everyone can have access to information, news, education and current affairs using efficient methods."

Sir Christopher Bland, chairman of the BBC governors, applauded the extra £200m.

"We welcome this as a vote of confidence in the BBC," he said.

"We can continue to play an important role as one of the country's leading global broadcasters."

Under the new funding agreement the BBC will open itself up to public scrutiny. Mr Smith said that there must be a clear division between the BBC's commercial activities and its role as a public service broadcaster.

"If the BBC fails to deliver ... then we will review this licence fee settlement," he said.

Shadow culture secretary Peter Ainsworth said the viewer would have paid less under the Tories and added that that the public did not have "an unlimited appetite" for higher licence fees.

webTitle: Poll shows big shift against racism

fields.headline: Poll shows big shift against racism
fields.standfirst: Macpherson, one year on: special report
fields.trailText: A fundamental shift in social attitudes towards race has taken place in the last five years according to an exclusive Guardian/ICM opinion poll published today.
fields.body:
A fundamental shift in social attitudes towards race has taken place in the last five years according to an exclusive Guardian/ICM opinion poll published today.

The results suggest that the undercurrent of 1960s Powellite racism in British public opinion is finally disappearing. It also provides evidence - even if it is only in what people are willing to tell the pollsters - that the Stephen Lawrence case is proving a watershed in British attitudes towards racism.

The poll shows that 53% say most whites would not mind if a close relative married a black or Asian and only 36% say they would mind "a little or a lot".

In a similar survey in1995, 21% said they "would not mind" and 73% said they would mind "a little or a lot". Repeated surveys by British Social Attitudes throughout the 1980s and 1990s showed similar large majorities uncomfortable about inter-racial marriage. In 1995, 53% felt most white people would mind having a black or Asian boss at work, against 27% now. Some 63% say that most would not mind compared with 41% five years ago.

The poll shows that a year after the publication of the Macpherson inquiry into the Stephen Lawrence murder investigation, some 75% believe that the police are learning from their mistakes in investigating the death of the black teenager. There is also growing confidence that most officers are not racist, but one in three of the public still believe that the way the police operate, institutional racism leads them to discriminate against blacks and Asians.

In an exclusive interview for the Guardian today, home secretary Jack Straw says he regards tackling racism as "the most important part of my job". He believes that of all the things he has done while home secretary, setting up the Lawrence inquiry will make the greatest difference. He wants the progress of its implementation to be "one of the key things I want to be judged on". He welcomed the poll's results showing that Britain is becoming more relaxed about race but added there was still a long way to go, particularly in employment practices.

Surveys by British Social Attitudes in the 1980s and early to mid-1990s repeatedly showed that 75% of the public believed most white people did "mind a lot or a little" if a black or Asian person married into their family. That figure is now 36%.

The change has also occurred across all age groups - the figure for the over 65s is 34% who thought most white people would object - and social classes, with similar responses among both men and women and Labour and Conservative voters.

The commission for racial equality last night welcomed the poll as confirming a decisive change in public opinion . "There is this sense of a significant and overwhelming shift in public opinion in favour of a diverse society," said a CRE spokesman.

He said the results represented "a decisive shift away from the Powellite influence of the 1960s. The cathartic experience of Lawrence has enabled white people to come to terms with living in a multi-racial society. The danger figure is shifting from being a young, black man to the white racist".

ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,205 adults aged over 18 by telephone between February 11-13 2000. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

fields.headline: Siberia, Japan and Birkenhead
fields.trailText: LOOK AT THIS ADVERT
fields.body:
LOOK AT THIS ADVERT

Turn a Fiver into £10,000 with George Best! Kamikaze Football is the new online Premiership footy game. Register now at www.kamikazefootball.com.

BABY BLUES FOR THE REDS

Call the Fiver a curmudgeon if you will, but the footballing world really has lost its sense of perspective. Completely. After a weekend which saw four teams reach the semi-finals of the FA Cup and the Premiership all but decided, what do we find dominating the back (and front) pages? A Manchester United player being dropped from the first team, that's what. Cah! Bah! Pah! What on earth is the world coming to?

OK, OK, fair enough. It was David Beckham who was dropped, after all - and for one of the biggest games of the season to boot. It seems he missed training on Friday, causing the wrath of Fergie to descend upon his vacant head. Like any responsible father, Becks immediately lumped all the blame onto his 11-month-old son, who, according to the spokeswoman for his wife - the pop star Mrs Posh - had a "touch of gastro-enteritis".

The baby talk cut no ice with Fergie, however, and Becks was banished to the Siberian wastelands of Elland Road's West Stand. However, now that baby Brooklyn has bounced back to rude health, Becks has dutifully turned up to train with the England team and Fergie has calmed down enough to allow it "possible" that his errant player may be back for United's game at Wimbledon, all this unnecessary brouhaha should come to a halt.

Then again, perhaps not. Some say that Fergie is coming to the end of his tether with Beckham's attitude, and an Ince-esque parting of the ways - while United can still cash in - is said to be on the cards. The odds on Beckham leaving United by the start of next season have dropped dramatically from 4-1 to 6-4, with Arsenal the hot favourites to land him - the bidding starts at £25m. Interestingly, the Fiver has heard that Real Madrid are also in the running, offering a swap package of Roberto Carlos and... wait for it... lonely Nic Anelka. Just for the humour factor - and so we can all enjoy a good barney the next time United visit Highbury - please let that rumour be true.

MATCHSTICK MEN AND MATCHSTICK REFEREES

Can you really afford to miss Ormondroyd's cartoon take on Leicester's trip to La Manga? Or the FA Cup quarter finals? Or Leeds v Man Utd? Well, OK, you can. But don't let that stop you going to Football Unlimited to have a peek anyway.

A MASTER BUILDER NEVER LEAVES A JOB HALF DONE

Bof! Shrug! When things are not going well at Arsenal you can be sure such sentiments are far from Arsene Wenger's mind. Oh yes. So it was with some surprise that avid Japophile Granny Fiver picked up her weekly copy of Shukan Gendai and read that Wenger quite fancies the Japan national manager's job.

"I may go back to Japan sometime. It may not be soon but I will for sure," Wenger, who coached J-League Nagoya Grampus in 1995/96, told the Japanese magazine. "May?" "For sure?" Something may have been lost in the translation but it all seems perfectly clear to Granny: Wenger definitely may be off to Japan for the 2002 World Cup which is, coincidentally, exactly when his Arsenal contract expires.

Asked how long it would take him to build a decent Japanese team, master builder Wenger rubbed his chin and reckoned about one year if he had only to profit from a "plan in progress". Say, if he inherited one of the greatest back fours in history, for example. But Wenger warned the job would take "three to four years if I had to start from scratch," in no way making any comparison with Arsenal, Arsenal's defence or Arsenal's hopes of winning anything for a while. Non monsieur!

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I don't think I really get the credit I deserve when it comes to playing for England" - England's Andy Cole. Not been any goals as of yet, though, have there, Andrew? Of course, we're just tempting fate for you.

CHALLINOR ABSORBS SOME BAD NEWS

Sunday sees the first big match of the season, when the annual Leicester Challenge (sponsored by Worthington) is played at Wembley. This year's opponents for the foxy Foxes are Tranmere Rovers, who will be looking forward to their first-ever major final. However, things are already going wrong for the plucky, brave, battling First Division underdogs - they've been told towels have been banned at Wembley. Which, while sounding completely ridiculous, is in fact quite a serious matter for the Merseyside club.

You see, Tranmere defender Dave Challinor dries the ball with a towel so he can, as Brian Moore would say, get extra 'purchase' on it and throw it a very long way. (So far, in fact, that he holds the world record for it - you may have read an article about it somewhere.) Now, this tactic has upset many an opposing manager, who obviously all consider playing to your strengths the height of bad sportsmanship. So the Football League - with Martin O'Neill's blood pressure in mind - have been at pains to stress that no absorbent advantages will be allowed on Sunday.

"The fourth official will be informed that towels must not be used in the final!" chirruped a League spokesman who clearly wasn't going to be messed about over this issue. "No towels will be allowed to be placed anywhere around the pitch!" he swaggered, laying down the law and no mistake. Challinor, however, seems unperturbed with the League's ruling. "Setting up a winning goal at Wembley with one of my throws would eclipse my world record," he cooed today, obviously still determined to cover himself in glory with one big toss.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Marc Overmars will join Barcelona in the summer, according to Spanish newspaper El Mundo Reportivo. Overmars's agent Rob Jansen has agreed "contractual and economical terms" with Nou Camp boss Louis van Gaal.

Leeds have denied they are in the running for 19-year-old Brazilian striker Ronaldinho. The Gremio player would cost £20m.

Southampton have abandoned their interest in Colin Hendry, as they cannot afford the player's wage demands.

Joe Kinnear has been lined up to replace under-fire Sheffield Wednesday boss Danny Wilson.

West Ham look certain to complete the signing of Cardiff goalkeeper Ian Feuer this week. Feuer began his English career at Upton Park before moving to Luton for £550,000. He has been on a monthly contract at Second Division Cardiff.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Celestine Babayaro has been prevented from returning to his club by rioting in northern Nigeria, according to Alhaji Sabo Babayaro, his guardian. "He was supposed to leave Kaduna for Lagos today on his way back to London but as I speak to you now there is a civil disturbance in the city so Celestine is trapped," French press agency AFP was told.

Euro 2000 organisers sent a letter to the Dutch parliament today demanding that black market ticket sales be made illegal.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC1: A Question of Sport (7pm)

They've tried it with pop. They've tried it with EastEnders. And it seems to have worked. But we're not convinced the format will stretch to sport.

ITV: The Sports Show (11.30pm)

Three opinionated sportsmen are given a hard time by an audience.

Football Extra (12.35am)

22 cloggers are given a hard time by a crowd.

Sky Sports 1: You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm, 2.45am)

The nation is given a hard time by McCaff.

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 7pm SS1, 9pm, 11pm SS1)

"Germany after reunification - what next?" asks Kevin Francis.

British Eurosport: Eurogoals (10pm)

Or Poundsterlinggoals, if William Hague has his way.

Like any responsible father, Becks immediately lumped all the blame onto his 11-month-old son, who, according to the spokeswoman for his wife - the pop star Mrs Posh - had a "touch of gastro-enteritis". The baby talk cut no ice with Fergie, however, and Becks was banished to the Siberian wastelands of Elland Road's West Stand. However, now that baby Brooklyn has bounced back to rude health, Becks has dutifully turned up to train with the England team and Fergie has calmed down enough to allow it "possible" that his errant player may be back for United's game at Wimbledon, all this unnecessary brouhaha should come to a halt. Then again, perhaps not. Some say that Fergie is coming to the end of his tether with Beckham's attitude, and an Ince-esque parting of the ways - while United can still cash in - is said to be on the cards. The odds on Beckham leaving United by the start of next season have dropped dramatically from 4-1 to 6-4, with Arsenal the hot favourites to land him - the bidding starts at £25m. Interestingly, the Fiver has heard that Real Madrid are also in the running, offering a swap package of Roberto Carlos and... wait for it... lonely Nic Anelka. Just for the humour factor - and so we can all enjoy a good barney the next time United visit Highbury - please let that rumour be true. MATCHSTICK MEN AND MATCHSTICK REFEREES Can you really afford to miss Ormondroyd's cartoon take on Leicester's trip to La Manga? Or the FA Cup quarter finals? Or Leeds v Man Utd? Well, OK, you can. But don't let that stop you going to Football Unlimited to have a peek anyway. A MASTER BUILDER NEVER LEAVES A JOB HALF DONE Bof! Shrug! When things are not going well at Arsenal you can be sure such sentiments are far from Arsene Wenger's mind. Oh yes. So it was with some surprise that avid Japophile Granny Fiver picked up her weekly copy of Shukan Gendai and read that Wenger quite fancies the Japan national manager's job. "I may go back to Japan sometime. It may not be soon but I will for sure," Wenger, who coached J-League Nagoya Grampus in 1995/96, told the Japanese magazine. "May?" "For sure?" Something may have been lost in the translation but it all seems perfectly clear to Granny: Wenger definitely may be off to Japan for the 2002 World Cup which is, coincidentally, exactly when his Arsenal contract expires. Asked how long it would take him to build a decent Japanese team, master builder Wenger rubbed his chin and reckoned about one year if he had only to profit from a "plan in progress". Say, if he inherited one of the greatest back fours in history, for example. But Wenger warned the job would take "three to four years if I had to start from scratch," in no way making any comparison with Arsenal, Arsenal's defence or Arsenal's hopes of winning anything for a while. Non monsieur! QUOTE OF THE DAY "I don't think I really get the credit I deserve when it comes to playing for England" - England's Andy Cole. Not been any goals as of yet, though, have there, Andrew? Of course, we're just tempting fate for you. CHALLINOR ABSORBS SOME BAD NEWS Sunday sees the first big match of the season, when the annual Leicester Challenge (sponsored by Worthington) is played at Wembley. This year's opponents for the foxy Foxes are Tranmere Rovers, who will be looking forward to their first-ever major final. However, things are already going wrong for the plucky, brave, battling First Division underdogs - they've been told towels have been banned at Wembley. Which, while sounding completely ridiculous, is in fact quite a serious matter for the Merseyside club. You see, Tranmere defender Dave Challinor dries the ball with a towel so he can, as Brian Moore would say, get extra 'purchase' on it and throw it a very long way. (So far, in fact, that he holds the world record for it - you may have read an article about it somewhere.) Now, this tactic has upset many an opposing manager, who obviously all consider playing to your strengths the height of bad sportsmanship. So the Football League - with Martin O'Neill's blood pressure in mind - have been at pains to stress that no absorbent advantages will be allowed on Sunday. "The fourth official will be informed that towels must not be used in the final!" chirruped a League spokesman who clearly wasn't going to be messed about over this issue. "No towels will be allowed to be placed anywhere around the pitch!" he swaggered, laying down the law and no mistake. Challinor, however, seems unperturbed with the League's ruling. "Setting up a winning goal at Wembley with one of my throws would eclipse my world record," he cooed today, obviously still determined to cover himself in glory with one big toss. THE RUMOUR MILL Marc Overmars will join Barcelona in the summer, according to Spanish newspaper El Mundo Reportivo. Overmars's agent Rob Jansen has agreed "contractual and economical terms" with Nou Camp boss Louis van Gaal. Leeds have denied they are in the running for 19-year-old Brazilian striker Ronaldinho. The Gremio player would cost £20m. Southampton have abandoned their interest in Colin Hendry, as they cannot afford the player's wage demands. Joe Kinnear has been lined up to replace under-fire Sheffield Wednesday boss Danny Wilson. West Ham look certain to complete the signing of Cardiff goalkeeper Ian Feuer this week. Feuer began his English career at Upton Park before moving to Luton for £550,000. He has been on a monthly contract at Second Division Cardiff. NEWS IN BRIEF Celestine Babayaro has been prevented from returning to his club by rioting in northern Nigeria, according to Alhaji Sabo Babayaro, his guardian. "He was supposed to leave Kaduna for Lagos today on his way back to London but as I speak to you now there is a civil disturbance in the city so Celestine is trapped," French press agency AFP was told. Euro 2000 organisers sent a letter to the Dutch parliament today demanding that black market ticket sales be made illegal. TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO BBC1: A Question of Sport (7pm) They've tried it with pop. They've tried it with EastEnders. And it seems to have worked. But we're not convinced the format will stretch to sport. ITV: The Sports Show (11.30pm) Three opinionated sportsmen are given a hard time by an audience. Football Extra (12.35am) 22 cloggers are given a hard time by a crowd. Sky Sports 1: You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm, 2.45am) The nation is given a hard time by McCaff. Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 7pm SS1, 9pm, 11pm SS1) "Germany after reunification - what next?" asks Kevin Francis. British Eurosport: Eurogoals (10pm) Or Poundsterlinggoals, if William Hague has his way.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Sex workers in Calcutta protest against Water ban, Thai film fans set record, Neve Campbell on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Approximately 2,000 sex workers in Calcutta staged a demonstration on Saturday in protest against the Indian government's decision to stop the making of Water, by Canadian director, Deepa Mehta. The women carried placards voicing their silent displeasure with the World Hindu Council (Vishwa Hindu Parishad) which has said that Mehta must alter her script and get it vetted by Hindu priests before she can continue filming.

The government has twice given the go-ahead for the film and twice caved in to right-wing pressure. "This is nothing but an undemocratic attempt to throttle the voice of expression," one banner said of the council, which is aligned with Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee's ruling Hindu nationalist BJP party. The women threatened to intensify their protest if the groups prevent Mehta from filming in Marxist-governed West Bengal, of which Calcutta is the state capital. Right-wing Hindus say Water, which portrays the lives of Hindu widows in Varanasi in the 1930s, is culturally offensive and should be banned.

 A group of 14 Thai film fans have shared 100,000 baht prize money by watching 25 films for 51 hours without falling asleep. The group is now sending a video of the event to the Guinness Book of Records claiming it has beaten the previous record of 37 hours and 25 minutes.The hard-core film fans - who started off in a group of over 400 - began their film marathon in Bangkok on Friday. They were only allowed to take five-minute rests after each film plus a 15-minute break at the end of three films in order to eat. They were monitored by an infrared camera to check they weren't asleep and had to give periodic urine samples to ensure they weren't using stimulants. Unsurprisingly, the goggle-eyed 14 started nodding off rapidly once the record was set.

 Neve Campbell will star in Investigating Sex, a film about a couple of female stenographers who are asked to record a group of surrealists' perceptions of sex during the 1920s. Nick Nolte will play one of the surrealists and the project will be helmed by Alan Rudolph.

fields.headline: Harry eats humble pie
fields.trailText: Harry Knowles, the internet gossip columinst behind Aint-It-Cool-News has offered an apology to the The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences after printing an incorrect list of Oscar nominees the day before the official list came out
fields.body:
Harry Knowles, the internet gossip columinst behind Aint-It-Cool-News has offered an apology to the The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences after printing an incorrect list of Oscar nominees the day before the official list came out.

The creator of the cult site now admits that the list was indeed taken from the computer of a freelance writer for ABC.com who was preparing to load a story immediately after the real nominations were announced. Of the faux-pas, which caused a media frenzy and some very red faces in the Academy, an equally red-faced Knowles says his source was, "just some guy out there that thought he found something really cool, got excited, overstated his material and sent it to me."

"There was never an attempt on an Academy computer," he explains. "The nominations were never in any danger. And both PricewaterhouseCoopers (the accounting firm that counts the votes) and the Academy can sleep well at night knowing that at no point was there any failure in their security." Unfortunately, despite Harry's protestations, the Academy is still considering legal action.

fields.headline: Cesar for Beauté
fields.trailText: Venus Beauté (Institut), a racy account of the everyday lives of a group of love-starved beauticians scooped most of the awards at this year's Cesar awards - the French equivalent of the Oscars
fields.body:
Venus Beauté (Institut), a racy account of the everyday lives of a group of love-starved beauticians scooped most of the awards at this year's Cesar awards - the French equivalent of the Oscars.

The film, directed by actress-turned-director Tonie Marshall, won awards for best film, best director, most promising young woman actress and best script, honouring the Cesar's tradition of awarding top honours to films with small budgets. The favourite, Luc Besson's big-budget Joan of Arc, won just two awards for soundtrack and costumes. The best actor Cesar went to Daniel Auteuil for his role in Patrice Leconte's La Fille sur le Pont (The Girl on the Bridge), and Karin Viard won the best actress Cesar for her performance in Haut les coeurs! (Hearts Up!).

The best foreign film award went to All About My Mother, directed by Spain's Pedro Almodovar, at the ceremony at the Champs-Elysees theatre in Paris.

webTitle: Brave faces at the Beeb don't tell the whole story

fields.headline: Brave faces at the Beeb don't tell the whole story
fields.trailText: Sir Christopher Bland, chairman of the BBC, wore a brave face as he "welcomed" the government's statement on the corporation's future funding today. According to senior government sources, the chairman was privately shocked when told by Mr Smith how tough the report would be. Certainly, describing the decision to cut the corporation's demands for £700m a year to £200m a year as "a vote of confidence", Sir Christopher preferred not to dwell on the self help message of Chris Smith's speech and the £1bn of savings the corporation will be obliged to find.
fields.body:
Sir Christopher Bland, chairman of the BBC, wore a brave face as he "welcomed" the government's statement on the corporation's future funding today. According to senior government sources, the chairman was privately shocked when told by Mr Smith how tough the report would be. Certainly, describing the decision to cut the corporation's demands for £700m a year to £200m a year as "a vote of confidence", Sir Christopher preferred not to dwell on the self help message of Chris Smith's speech and the £1bn of savings the corporation will be obliged to find.

It was left to Greg Dyke, the new director-general, to mention the "tough decisions" ahead. As the newcomer to the 16-month campaign to boost the BBC's income to cover digital expansion, Mr Dyke is possibly the only BBC staff member who can view the government's statement with complete equanimity. With his short experience of the corporation to date, even he must wince at the thought of the changes ahead.

That Mr Smith began with the intention of increasing the BBC's income was not in doubt. Then director general Lord Birt lobbied for around two years about the inadequacy of its funding arrangements from 2000 before Mr Smith announced in October 1998 a committee inquiry with the remit of investigating alternative ways of funding the BBC on top of its £2.1bn licence fee revenue.

He pledged that the committee would consider all possible methods of boosting the corporation's revenue even as far as the previously unthinkable selling of advertising on its channels, aside from BBC1 and BBC2. But his instructions were based on the premise that, in his words, the "imperfect funding mechanism" of the licence fee would remain as the BBC's main source of income at least until a complete overhaul of the corporation's royal charter in 2006. He pointedly did not give the review panel the power to change the level of the licence fee from the five-year formula, set down in 1996.

The nine-strong panel, led by economist Gavyn Davies, deliberated through most of the first half of last year. Mr Davies, who had previously floated the idea of a digital licence fee, was a controversial choice to lead the blue sky thinking. As a friend of chancellor Gordon Brown he was dismissed as too close to the government; the commercial broadcasters, vehemently against a digital supplement, argued his mind was already made up. Sure enough, his report recommended a £24 digital supplement for the few million digital households on top of the licence fee, plus the privatisation of the BBC's resources business and the sale of a 49% stake in its commercial arm, BBC Worldwide.

It was not enough for Lord Birt. He declared Davies' recommendations insufficient to protect the BBC in the new world of global media and claimed it needed an extra £3bn to see its expansion plans through to 2007 - three times the amount budgeted by the Davies panel. Declarations such as these from the BBC served only to rile the department of culture, media and sport, making the job of the alliance of commercial broadcasters to oppose the plans.

The subsequent select committee investigating the question, led by Gerald Kaufman was blistering about the BBC's proposals. News 24 was dismissed as a waste of money and the committee was apoplectic at what it saw as the BBC's deliberate obfuscation of its finances and arrogant refusal to accept challenging or questioning.

It is that attitude from his predecessors which Mr Dyke will have to pay for. Dyke's BBC, unlike Birt's BBC, will have enforced accountability instead of the platitudes offered by an all-powerful board of governors.

As Mr Smith put it today, "the BBC is too much the judge and jury of its own cause." With the sugar coating of a licence fee linked to the retail price index came the spectre of external auditing. Although Mr Smith did not call in the national audit office, as widely expected, he ordered two sets of external auditors into the BBC to publish accounts of its finances and fair trading.

More threateningly, he announced, the forthcoming white paper on broadcasting and regulation will include an extensive review of the public service role and the governance of the BBC.

He was, sources close to him have said, horrified by the differing reports of the BBC's accounts he received throughout the campaign and exasperated at having to dispatch consultants Pannell Kerr Forster to conduct another analysis for the department. It was PKF's report which convinced Mr Smith of his tough love strategy. The firm was convinced that there was much greater scope for efficiency savings than the Davies committee - that panel was described by one BBC insider with glee as having "gone native" during its examination of the corporation.

Throughout, it seemed, Mr Smith did not buy the BBC's version of its dire financial straits. "There is no doubt that to achieve its vision, the BBC needs to raise its game", he said today. His tough prescription of self help for the corporation in over £1bn of enforced savings, which will be regularly checked, has been regarded as long overdue by the BBC's critics. Mr Dyke said: "We will have tough decisions to make on priorities and on self help. It will be more important than ever to make sure that we are spending our money on the things that really matter - programmes and services for the licence payer." There were a few clues for him today in Mr Smith's statement: the BBC is not funded to compete with the commercial broadcasters on sport and films, he said in words which Rupert Murdoch's Sky might have written for him. The BBC must instead focus on its core services, the two main channels and the radio stations, and reinstate BBC1 as the centre of British cultural life. A significant slug of the new cash must be spent on such old-fashioned things as improved programmes for BBC1, BBC2 and the radio stations.

Mr Dyke, while cutting £1bn worth of fat from the organisation, will have to open the BBC's strategy to greater scrutiny. Its current digital services, BBC Knowledge, Parliament, Choice and the News 24 will be subject to an immediate review to gauge their success against the public service model of providing something distinctive to the public. News 24, the initial focus of the review, will be hardest to justify to an already unimpressed public. Any new services, such as the proposed children's channels and the much talked about sports plans, will have to be subject to a thorough review first.

He will also have to set himself immediately to the task of unlocking income through extra revenue generation. But as a former chief executive of LWT and Pearson Television, Mr Dyke will be well able to form the joint venture partnerships and commercial alliances which Mr Smith called for, and is unlikely to have found that ruling a surprise. Those skills were, after all, part of the reason for his appointment as director-general.

webTitle: Paddington crash train 'flipped' in the air before fireball

fields.headline: Paddington crash train 'flipped' in the air before fireball
fields.standfirst: Interactive guide to the train crash
fields.trailText: A train "flipped" in the air and fires engulfed the carriages in the Paddington rail crash that killed 31 people last October, an inquest was told today.
fields.body:
A train "flipped" in the air and fires engulfed the carriages in the Paddington rail crash that killed 31 people last October, an inquest was told today.

Transport police detective superintendent Nicholas Bracken told the inquest at Westminster Council House in central London that diesel tanks burst into flames when the trains collided, causing the blaze that raged for nearly 40 minutes.

Detective Bracken told the nine person jury: "The collision had a combined speed of 100 mph." Fire spread from the front engine car of the Great Western service and from fuel tanks on the Thames train.

Britain's worst train disaster in a decade occurred at 8.10am, approximately two miles outside Paddington station, at the Ladbroke Grove junction in west London. The 6.03am Great Western train from Cheltenham, which consisted of an engine car at the front, eight passenger carriages and another power car at the rear, was heading towards London.

The three car 8.06am Thames train was bound for Bedwyn, Wiltshire, the hearing was told. As Mr Bracken gave evidence he stood at a specially constructed model of the crash scene, assembled from photographs taken at the time, to explain where the damage had occurred and the directions of the trains.

Westminster coroner, Paul Knapman, briefly adjourned the hearing so that relatives of the bereaved could examine the model. They gathered in silence around the model pointing at the different carriages and spoke quietly to each other about what they saw.

Earlier, Dr Knapman had warned jurors that they would hear distressing evidence about the tragedy 31 times as each case represented an individual person.

Transport police last month said they might scale down their inquiry into the crash because it was unlikely that any individual or company would be charged.

The move came after state prosecutors said anyone giving evidence to the inquest would be offered broad immunity from prosecution - except in the case of giving false evidence

The October 5 collision - in which 244 were injured - occurred after the driver of the Thames train went through a red light. PC Gavin Cerasale, the first policeman on the scene, said he made for the crash site after seeing a plume of black smoke.

"I jumped out of (my) vehicle and could see the flames and smoke through the security gates in front of me" at the trackside, he said.

Witnesses told him they had seen a train "flip in the air." Fireman Richard Hodson said when he and colleagues arrived on the scene they found the gates locked and initially had to scale a security fence to reach the injured.

"I was confronted with a situation the enormity of which took my breath away," Mr Hodson said. "There were a lot of passengers evacuating the train. There were people between the carriages and I was aware of some casualties on the ground around the train - obviously a lot of dazed and confused people."

The accident was Britain's worst rail crash since 1988, when three trains collided outside Clapham Junction, killing 35 people. The inquest continues Tuesday.

As Mr Bracken gave evidence he stood at a specially constructed model of the crash scene, assembled from photographs taken at the time, to explain where the damage had occurred and the directions of the trains. Westminster coroner, Paul Knapman, briefly adjourned the hearing so that relatives of the bereaved could examine the model. They gathered in silence around the model pointing at the different carriages and spoke quietly to each other about what they saw. Earlier, Dr Knapman had warned jurors that they would hear distressing evidence about the tragedy 31 times as each case represented an individual person. Transport police last month said they might scale down their inquiry into the crash because it was unlikely that any individual or company would be charged. The move came after state prosecutors said anyone giving evidence to the inquest would be offered broad immunity from prosecution - except in the case of giving false evidence The October 5 collision - in which 244 were injured - occurred after the driver of the Thames train went through a red light. PC Gavin Cerasale, the first policeman on the scene, said he made for the crash site after seeing a plume of black smoke. "I jumped out of (my) vehicle and could see the flames and smoke through the security gates in front of me" at the trackside, he said. Witnesses told him they had seen a train "flip in the air." Fireman Richard Hodson said when he and colleagues arrived on the scene they found the gates locked and initially had to scale a security fence to reach the injured. "I was confronted with a situation the enormity of which took my breath away," Mr Hodson said. "There were a lot of passengers evacuating the train. There were people between the carriages and I was aware of some casualties on the ground around the train - obviously a lot of dazed and confused people." The accident was Britain's worst rail crash since 1988, when three trains collided outside Clapham Junction, killing 35 people. fields.headline: Are you next?
fields.trailText: The list of past winners is as long as it is impressive. Andrew Rawnsley, Esther Oxford, Libby Brooks, James Wood, David Sharrock, Rachel Newsome, Emily Barr. Will you be next to win one of the most prestigious awards in student journalism? Welcome to this year's Guardian Student Media Awards.
fields.body:
The list of past winners is as long as it is impressive. Andrew Rawnsley, Esther Oxford, Libby Brooks, James Wood, David Sharrock, Rachel Newsome, Emily Barr. Will you be next to win one of the most prestigious awards in student journalism? Welcome to this year's Guardian Student Media Awards, the longest-running, most important student awards of the year.

Whether you're involved in reporting, editing, design, online or photography, these will be the key to your future career. Along with the plethora of awards, one entrant will receive an extended placement on the Guardian, plus £1,000.

The judges are as impressive as the winners, including Channel 4 news presenter Jon Snow, Guardian editor Alan Rusbridger, Mirror editor Piers Morgan, Mark Frith, editor of Heat, Martha Lane Fox, co-founder of lastminute.com, James Brown, founder of Loaded, Charlie Whelan, Gordon Brown's former adviser, now a sports columnist for the Observer, and comedian Mark Thomas.

Andrew Rawnsley
Won: Student Reporter of Year 82
Now: political columnist, Observer; presenter, Radio 4

Emily Barr
Won: Student Reporter of Year 93
Now: travel writer, Guardian; writing first book

Emily Sheffield
Won: Student Reporter of Year 95
Now: feature writer, Evening Standard

Jon Snow introduces the awards:

There is no more improbable interface than that between the naturally wayward student and the unrelenting printers' deadline. The Guardian Student Media Awards will once again pay due tribute to the unsung heroes of the world of student journalism.

I well remember my own student newspaper, the Guild Gazette, Liverpool University's "award-winning" journal. I confess I rarely, if ever, wrote for it - more often appearing in it, caught in the midst of the great 60s season of mellow protest. Indeed those who worked on the Gazette were regarded as odd grey people who rarely saw the light of day and remained aloof from the fray.

These days I urge the students I teach at Nottingham Trent's Broadcast Journalism course to remain plugged into as wide a cross-section of learning as possible. While media studies courses have produced a whole stew of journalists who enter the profession far more precisely skilled than I ever was, I suspect they are also less schooled in life than we were. So I shall be looking for breadth and originality over professional efficiency of practice.

Ultimately, journalism is an experiential enterprise. It cannot be learnt, it has to be absorbed. If a journalist doesn't wake up in the morning feeling angry, amused, distressed or invigorated by something on the internet, radio, TV or street, then he or she might just as well stay in bed for the day.

Too many journalists allow themselves to become enslaved by the sausage machine. Less than an hour is offered to come up with seven paragraphs, or 50 seconds, on the antics of a Buddhist monk found eating rattlesnake in Hungerford. This is the moment when our award-winning students will come up with a competing tale that makes the news editors forget they ever commissioned anything else.

Student journalists have got to develop bias, a bias against pap and in favour of reportage that intrigues, awakens, expands and electrifies the mind of the reader. There isn't enough bias around these days; deadlines militate against it, editors are scared by it.

Somewhere in these awards, perhaps we shall find the spark that seems so absent from much of student life, fuelled as it appears to be by complaints of not enough car spaces for students on campus and fees protests. 00's students cut a self-centred dash. Perhaps their own account of life will reveal a world we never even guessed at. Perhaps Thatcher's grandchildren have discovered society, compassion, laughter and rebellion, and the adult authors of "grown up" newspapers, magazines and websites have simply been too busy oiling their sausage machines to notice.

Five student journalists reveal how they see the future of their chosen profession

Jessica Leeman
Age: 21. Editor: Badger, Sussex

We choose the news first from what we've read in the papers: G2, Le Monde Diplomatique, alternative newsletter Schnews and z-mag.com. Then we use the internet to get more information, but it can be hard to track things down, unless you know exactly what you're looking for. Newspaper archives on the web are excellent, but I don't think the web has changed the way people get their day-to-day news - most read the paper on the train or over breakfast. Where it has had a huge impact is in getting more information about what you've read. Email also makes papers more accessible, with free news sent to subscribers.

John Woodcock
Age: 21. Editor: Edinburgh Student

I don't scour the net for news -the print version is still superior. PA and the BBC sites are worth a glance but do not yet have the same in-depth coverage as most papers. In future, I think the net will allow greater diversity of interests. People will be able to select exactly what they want, when, and customise their news intake. Access to the web is not yet advanced enough to make it as user-friendly as picking up a paper, but that is changing all the time. I think newspapers will still be around in 10 years' time, in the sense that they'll still be brand names, but the move to electronic media will continue and it may predominate.

Chris Campbell
Age: 26. Editor: London Student

Once internet businesses piggyback mainstream television broadcasting, a lot of the text-based news services now on the net will become obsolete. The web's role as a news provider will become less important as the entertainment industry exploits fully interactive

broadcasting. Newspapers in their traditional form will then become more relevant as they'll be the only place you can find news without being bothered by ad banners. Frankly, my job involves so much time in front of computers that I avoid using the net for fun.

Richard Colebourn
Age: 20. Editor: Cherwell, Oxford

I read the Guardian, Times and New Statesman in print, New York Times, Slate and BBC News on the Internet, and US e-zines. In the next 10 years, I think online operations may become more important within media organisations because the internet has the advantage of speed - when major stories break, people will go straight to the web, as they go to news channels now. But I'm sceptical about claims that the internet will kill off broadcasting or the press. TV and radio are convenient and comfortable; picking up a paper is more enjoyable than reading from a screen.

Jonti Small
Age: 20. Editor: Varsity, Cambridge

Newspapers needn't be overly worried - I think new technology will supplement rather than replace them, at least while computers are less pleasant or convenient. News Unlimited and the BBC websites are good - and are trusted, unlike most Internet sites. But they are a resource rather than a habit, like taking a newspaper. Once they start to offer something tangibly different, the future will become more interesting. The way in which the net evolves will shape how we see and receive news. The pessimist in me sees the AOL/Time Warner merger as ominous but the rapidity of AOL's growth means only a fool would draw a firmer conclusion than that we just don't know.

fields.headline: Morgan's last stand
fields.standfirst: The inquiry cleared the Mirror's editor but has it damaged his prospects in the longer term, asks  Roy Greenslade
fields.trailText: As Mirror editor Piers Morgan stretches out on a Caribbean beach this week, it won't just be the sun that brings a flush to his cheeks. He knows that his public humiliation over the City Slickers share scandal has undermined his standing, especially among journalists.
fields.body:
As Mirror editor Piers Morgan stretches out on a Caribbean beach this week, it won't just be the sun that brings a flush to his cheeks. He knows that his public humiliation over the City Slickers share scandal has undermined his standing, especially among journalists.

Here is an editor who has made much of his street cred looking like a naive chump. Why did he not realise that dealing in shares as an editor threatened his integrity?

Here is an editor who has been forced to confess that not only does he not read every word in his paper but remains blissfully unaware of the main topic in one of its highest profile columns. Here is an editor who, having breached the industry's code of practice in the past, allowed two of his staff, if not more, to ignore it with impunity.

Trinity-Mirror is obviously convinced that Morgan is innocent of any real wrongdoing. Though Fleet Street rivals have condemned the internal inquiry which cleared him, his bosses surely couldn't afford to keep him in place if they had doubts.

They know that stock exchange investigators have all the tapes of phone calls between Morgan and his broker, Anthony Laiker, who mysteriously departed from his company, Kyte Securities, last week. So they must be convinced that Morgan's purchase of £20,000 of shares in Viglen Technology the day before the Slickers tipped them was indeed a coincidence.

To the man in the street - well, in this case, a Brighton pub called the I Go Inn - that story is difficult to swallow. "Let's face it," said the barman, "it's a bloody big punt on an outsider, especially when it's owned by one of your mates."

It is possible to counter this scepticism by pointing out that Viglen isn't a tinpot company; that Sir Alan Sugar, though a Mirror columnist, is only an acquaintance of Morgan's; that the City Slickers had named the stock as one of their top ten tips weeks before Morgan bought in; and that its internet move was foreshadowed in previous national paper adverts.

It is also reasonable to point out that all internet-related stocks are hot just now and that Morgan, as an investor trying to make money, was acting rationally.

Leaving that aside, there are wider questions to consider because editing a national newspaper is a unique and precious position. The editor sets the culture of an office. If he drinks, the staff drink. If she is light-hearted, the staff tend to be light-hearted. If he is a martinet, the staff are silent.

Morgan has emerged as a rumbustious, arrogant and verbose character. None of these qualities, even if they are sometimes difficult for others to bear, are necessarily bad in an editor, especially when relieved by Morgan's self-deprecatory sense of humour and not inconsiderable charm. But his wide-boy, cocksure image has influenced the culture at Canary Wharf, as personified by the City Slickers. Their activities - buying shares which they then tipped and sold - was transparently in breach of the code of practice. Yet their defence was its very transparency. It is that realisation which haunts Morgan today: he knows he is responsible for what has happened. Two mavericks were allowed to misbehave with his tacit encouragement.

So should he go? Was Trinity-Mirror wrong to keep him? On balance, unless other skeletons emerge from the cupboard, I think Trinity is right. I understand that several directors consider him to have been "a bloody fool". While they realise this episode has lowered him in the eyes of fellow editors they know that Mirror readers haven't complained. Trinity has introduced safeguards which ensure that all its journalists now have the tightest rules on share-dealing of any group, heralding a possible change to the code. Morgan and his deputy have been required to dispose of all their holdings.

The storm isn't over yet. Fleet Street is watching and even if Morgan survives this time, he can't afford another mistake. When he returns, a chastened Morgan must take to heart the harsh lessons of the past fortnight. Editors, including his rivals, regard him as a very good editor. But a sense of judgment is a key requirement for editorship. He must attain it, or face the consequences.

fields.headline: Maggie Brown's diary
fields.trailText: * Has Mandy got a mole in the BBC newsroom? Radio 4's Six O'Clock News was phoned by Peter Mandelson's office last Monday, complaining about its report on the Northern Ireland crisis. The interesting thing was that the complaint was about a phrase suggesting "rifts" between governments - which was in a script viewable on the newsroom computer but wasn't used on air. Is someone tipping off Mandy's minions? Or, as senior executives fear, is the system being hacked into? Dozens of them are able to access the news machine from home, after all, using security passwords.
fields.body:
* Has Mandy got a mole in the BBC newsroom? Radio 4's Six O'Clock News was phoned by Peter Mandelson's office last Monday, complaining about its report on the Northern Ireland crisis. The interesting thing was that the complaint was about a phrase suggesting "rifts" between governments - which was in a script viewable on the newsroom computer but wasn't used on air. Is someone tipping off Mandy's minions? Or, as senior executives fear, is the system being hacked into? Dozens of them are able to access the news machine from home, after all, using security passwords.

*Never the best of friends, the Mail and Telegraph spent last week handbagging each other in a spat over who understands women best. Corinna Honan, formerly the Mail's showbiz editor, now the Telegraph's assistant editor, fired the first salvo at "The Daily Male" for a spate of articles blaming women for every social ill under the sun and for scoffing at the "improbable" relationship between Ralph Fiennes and (50-plus) Francesca Annis. Honan pointed out that the average age of the Mail's women readers is, ahem, 50. The Mail replied with a front page strapline boasting that it's the paper "that knows what really matters to women". And it was thrilled to reveal the average age of women Telegraph readers ... 53.

*Age is whispered to be very much on the mind of 32-year-old Daily Mail proprietor Viscount (Jonathan) Rothermere, who has discreetly pointed out that those of the paper's key pundits who are not already eligible for a bus-pass soon will be. Keith Waterhouse was 71 last week; the over-55 club also includes Lynda Lee-Potter, Ian Wooldridge, Nigel Dempster, John Edwards and Ann Leslie. The paper's glaring lack of young stars in line to replace them suggests energetic poaching is on the cards.

*Naughty Gerald Kaufman. The chairman of the Culture, Media & Sports Select Committee is to hold a one-day hearing provocatively titled Whatever Happened To News At Ten - on March 7, precisely a year after it was axed - and has invited ITV, ITN and the ITC to attend. The growing consensus is that the ITC acted too hastily and will pay in the white paper on communications due this autumn, reallocating regulatory duties. Meanwhile betting at ITN is that the late news will be brought forward, to 10.30pm, up against Newsnight.

*Relations between BSkyB and Channel 4 are at rock bottom since the latter niftily trounced Sky for the rights to ER, Friends and the top racecourses. Negotiations have now broken down over the terms for distributing C4's new E4 entertainment network, which will screen ER and Friends when it launches in November, as part of the various Sky subscription packages. The rate per household sought by C4 was about 10 times more than Sky was prepared to pay and was turned down point blank. "E4 is a basic channel, not a premium one, it's not going to be something that drives subscriptions for us," says a Sky insider. And where would it come on the electronic programme guide section listing entertainment networks? "At the bottom."

*Preliminary interviews for controller of Radio 4 have just taken place and the smart money appears to be on Anna Carragher, head of broadcasting in Northern Ireland, who has a track record of driving up audiences on Radio Ulster. Interestingly, she has just commissioned a media show for the area, raising hopes that, if she gets the R4 job, the much missed Medium Wave, which was hated by James Boyle, will be reinstated. There is also a push to claim back an extra 15 minutes for The World at One, to be followed at 1.45pm by a news quiz devised by its stalwart presenter, Nick Clarke.

*More exclusive news about Robot Wars, BBC2's top-rated programme and the diary's favourite. The BBC has just organised a merchandising deal, so remote control versions of the house robots, Sir Killalot, Sergeant Bash, Mathilda and Shunt, will be ready for Christmas. Is this the show that launched thousands of living room battles?

You can email Maggie Brown at maggiebrown.media@btinternet.com
