fields.headline: 'We're history'
fields.standfirst: The sacked City Slickers think they are scapegoats for the share-tipping scandal that cost them their Mirror jobs.  David Teather  found them licking their wounds and counting the job offers over a pint in the local pub
fields.trailText: The sacked City Slickers think they are scapegoats for the share-tipping scandal that cost them their Mirror jobs. David Teather found them licking their wounds and counting the job offers over a pint in the local pub.
fields.body:
Anil Bhoyrul, one half of the now infamous City Slickers, woke on Saturday at about 1.30pm with a raging hangover after a night that will, no doubt, stay with him for the rest of his life.

"I am knackered, shattered, tired, angry and sad," he said as the events of the previous day began to sink in. "Mostly sad because I had a great time at the Mirror."

Bhoyrul and his fellow financial columnist, James Hipwell, were sacked from the tabloid at 3pm on Friday after an investigation into the share dealings of up to 14 staff which has rocked the newspaper.

After decamping to Davy's winebar in Canary Wharf to ponder their future through the bottom of a beer glass, the men were surprised to find themselves besieged by journalists, photographers and film crews and obligingly posed stiffly, pretending to talk into their mobile phones.

They escaped the circus and retreated to Bhoyrul's local pub in Belsize Park, north London, leaving the pack trawling for them through more upmarket establishments. "I hear they were looking for us in the Ivy and Quaglino's but no one thought to look in my local pub," says Bhoyrul.

Less than two years ago Hipwell, 34, and Bhoyrul, 33, had been grinding out a living on various titles, largely under the patronage of Tom Rubython, the maverick editor who introduced them during his short stint at Sunday Business.

But the share-dealing controversy at the Mirror has fired the imagination of the media to such an extent that the two claim to have been offered cash for their stories by one tabloid and another broadsheet, a book deal and a job on Punch, the satirical magazine.

Among the flood of calls to Hipwell on Friday night was reportedly one from the publicist Max Clifford inviting him to dinner. They seem bemused by the attention.

"I went to take a piss at 2.30 on Friday and when I came back the Independent was on the phone saying they'd heard I had just gone to see the board." Was there a spy in the Mirror camp? "Well there was certainly a leak," Bhoyrul says before a typical explosive laugh.

"I'm hardly the first journalist to get fired but I'm probably the first to get fired and find half of Fleet Street waiting for me at my leaving drink. And I'm still not sure why. Was it about Piers, us or the column? The whole thing suddenly became massive."

The affair began two and a half weeks ago when it emerged that Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, had bought £20,000 worth of shares in the hi-tech firm Viglen Technology the day before the Slickers column wrote a story on the company which sent its price soaring. It subsequently emerged that Bhoyrul and Hipwell owned shares in a clutch of companies they were tipping.

They bought the shares in their own names which suggests that either they had become so cavalier that they thought they would never get caught or they were naive enough to believe they were doing nothing wrong.

Anybody who has spent any time with the Slickers has their own favourite surreal story, including Bhoyrul getting caught trying to steal a penguin from London Zoo. It was no surprise that as they faced disciplinary hearings on Wednesday the two reacted in typically absurdist style by attempting to call around 200 witnesses with the intention of quizzing them on their knowledge of the Press Complaints Commission code.

By Friday, the writing was clearly on the wall. During the investigation, Hipwell and Bhoyrul had been kept apart, contributing to the Slickers column on alternate days. This time they were called in together to see Pat Pilton who had barely featured in the inquiry and, as managing director, wears the traditional axeman mantle.

The meeting lasted just a couple of minutes. They were sacked without a penny and intend to seek compensation through their lawyers.

Bhoyrul, though, remains fiercely loyal to Morgan, whose own position is looking increasingly unsteady. "I don't point the finger at Piers. He gave me a job and he's a great editor. It is the people above Piers.

"When it comes to finger-pointing, as it will, it will be the actions of those above him that we question."

He concedes however that Morgan is under increasing pressure. "I guess the focus will be back on Piers now because we're history."

Morgan, who maintains he hadn't been aware of the Slickers' intent to write about Viglen the following day, was cleared of any wrongdoing by a separate internal inquiry. The stock exchange, however, has now handed two boxes of evidence to the department of trade and industry, thought to include a taped conversation with his broker, Anthony Laiker, which could result in a criminal prosecution. Laiker, damningly, lost his job on Thursday.

Bhoyrul says the experiences of the past two weeks have made him consider leaving journalism. "I feel very much like jacking the whole thing in. I'm even talking to friend about opening a restaurant called City Slickers where the waiters give you share tips, although I'm not sure what the Financial Services Authority might think."I'm kind of losing faith in journalism. I've written some pretty nasty things about other people but when it's done to you it's bloody awful."

He laments what he sees as the passing of the "fill your boots" style of business journalism which he thinks will be squashed by the events of the past two weeks.

"This is a great shame for us but also for the reader. When we joined the Mirror, Piers told us the opportunity was there to reinvent business journalism and I think we did that. A lot of people made a lot of money from us - and these are ordinary working-class people. They were excited by the whole thing and now they'll never get that chance again."

Hipwell and Bhoyrul feel that they have been made scapegoats and describe their hearings as a "kangaroo court". Certainly, with their sackings, the Mirror hopes to have drawn a line under the scandal.

Hipwell has hinted that there is a lot more to come out, and the decision to sack the two men without cash is either a foolish decision on the part of the Mirror board or a signal that the group is confident it has nothing more to hide.

fields.headline: No headline
fields.trailText: There is no more improbable interface than that between the naturally wayward student and the unrelenting printers' deadline. The Guardian Student Media Awards will once again pay due tribute to the unsung heroes of the world of student journalism.
fields.body:
There is no more improbable interface than that between the naturally wayward student and the unrelenting printers' deadline. The Guardian Student Media Awards will once again pay due tribute to the unsung heroes of the world of student journalism.

I well remember my own student newspaper, the Guild Gazette, Liverpool University's "award-winning" journal. I confess I rarely, if ever, wrote for it - more often appearing in it, caught in the midst of the great 60s season of mellow protest. Indeed those who worked on the Gazette were regarded as odd grey people who rarely saw the light of day and remained aloof from the fray.

These days I urge the students I teach at Nottingham Trent's Broadcast Journalism course to remain plugged into as wide a cross-section of learning as possible. While media studies courses have produced a whole stew of journalists who enter the profession far more precisely skilled than I ever was, I suspect they are also less schooled in life than we were. So I shall be looking for breadth and originality over professional efficiency of practice.

Ultimately, journalism is an experiential enterprise. It cannot be learnt, it has to be absorbed. If a journalist doesn't wake up in the morning feeling angry, amused, distressed or invigorated by something on the internet, radio, TV or street, then he or she might just as well stay in bed for the day.

Too many journalists allow themselves to become enslaved by the sausage machine. Less than an hour is offered to come up with seven paragraphs, or 50 seconds, on the antics of a Buddhist monk found eating rattlesnake in Hungerford. This is the moment when our award-winning students will come up with a competing tale that makes the news editors forget they ever commissioned anything else.

Student journalists have got to develop bias, a bias against pap and in favour of reportage that intrigues, awakens, expands and electrifies the mind of the reader. There isn't enough bias around these days; deadlines militate against it, editors are scared by it.

Somewhere in these awards, perhaps we shall find the spark that seems so absent from much of student life, fuelled as it appears to be by complaints of not enough car spaces for students on campus and fees protests. 00's students cut a self-centred dash. Perhaps their own account of life will reveal a world we never even guessed at. Perhaps Thatcher's grandchildren have discovered society, compassion, laughter and rebellion, and the adult authors of "grown up" newspapers, magazines and websites have simply been too busy oiling their sausage machines to notice. JS

fields.headline: Trust me?
fields.standfirst: The Daily Mail's Natalie Wood exposé was based on a journalist's personal contacts. Now she stands accused of betraying her friends.  Roy Greenslade investigates
fields.trailText: The story behind the Daily Mail's two-page feature on the mysterious death of film star Natalie Wood in 1981 raises the kind of ethical questions which journalists too rarely ask themselves.
fields.body:
The story behind the Daily Mail's two-page feature on the mysterious death of film star Natalie Wood in 1981 raises the kind of ethical questions which journalists too rarely ask themselves. Is a journalist ever off-duty? Are the roles of private citizen and journalist compatible? If years pass, can anyone remember what they learned on the record or off? Should journalists really expect to enjoy the same privileges afforded writers of fiction, drawing at will from real-life incidents?

The latest Natalie Wood saga began, as so many stories begin, with media hype. The March issue of Vanity Fair magazine boasted that a lengthy article on her death contained "new clues" which supposedly cast the tragedy in a very different light from previous accounts.

The Daily Telegraph's New York correspondent accepted the article at face value and filed a news story which repeated claims that Wood had drowned after a "jealous, drunken row" with her husband, actor Robert Wagner. Claiming to be based on "previously unreleased police files and witness statements", it suggested that the argument was due to Wood flirting with a guest, the actor Christopher Walken.

None of this tittle-tattle is novel, as the cuttings files show. Similar allegations surfaced within weeks of Wood's body being fished from the sea off Catalina Island, California, a mile away from the Wagners' yacht. No matter. The "new evidence" was justification for the Daily Mail to offer its own retrospective. The day after the Telegraph story, it published a story headlined "Did booze and jealous rage kill Natalie?" Written by Glenys Roberts, it had its own gimmick. As "someone who knew her and many of her friends" in Hollywood 30 years ago, Roberts was able to offer personal insights into Wood's character.

It is the nature of this "inside knowledge", its provenance and its use, which is so interesting. One of the people Roberts mentioned was Richard Gregson, a film producer and agent, who was married to Wood, and with whom she had a daughter, Natasha. After their divorce, Wood married Wagner for the second time, and Gregson stayed on friendly terms with both.

Gregson was outraged by Roberts' article, calling it "inaccurate and scurrilous". He felt that she had taken advantage of their "private" friendship. She had been indiscreet about "shared secrets". He contested her view of Wood as a persistent drunk, and was particularly upset about a key factual omission in one particular anecdote.

In her article, Roberts claimed that if Wagner showed even "polite interest in another woman", Wood would launch into "near-suicidal drinking sessions". Roberts wrote: "One evening she drank herself into oblivion because another woman was seated next to [Wagner] at a Hollywood dinner. 'He was just being his usual charming self, but she could not bear him talking to anyone else,' the girl told me.' She started drinking and did not know when to stop. 'When she got up from the table to leave, she made a dramatic show of saying goodbye, tripped over and passed out. RJ [Wagner] had to save her from injuring herself.'"

According to Gregson, "the girl" was Roberts herself. Not only had she concealed her central role, he claimed, but also failed to mention that she was flirting with Wagner, giving Wood reason to be annoyed.

Gregson is convinced that Roberts's piece "was a pretext for Glenys to unleash personal abuse" and that she has been guilty of "talking up 'unknown factors' surrounding Natalie's death because that's what sells newspapers and magazines".

Roberts argues that she was trying to do just the opposite. She also rejects the notion that Vanity Fair has uncovered anything of note and believes that her piece made her position, shared by Gregson, clear. "I was putting my personal experience and knowledge to work in order to refute the allegations," she says. "I didn't feel I was infringing the private nature of our relationship."

In fact, Roberts's article wasn't new. She wrote a first draft two years ago when the American TV cable channel, E Entertainment, made a documentary about Wood's death in its True Hollywood Stories series. "I viewed it at a screening. It was a banal rehash, saying nothing new, so I wrote a response. But the Mail didn't run it. When the Vanity Fair piece came out, the Mail called to say, 'Here's the peg'."

Given that it was all a long time ago, couldn't Roberts have left her former friend in peace? "That's exactly what I said when I was asked to do it," she says. "But the features editor said, 'We've got a job to do.' And that was that."

Roberts says: "Look, I'm a journalist, for God's sake. Would it have been less objectionable if it had been written in a book? At what point is one allowed to externalise one's memories, all the knowledge one has picked up? That dilemma dogs a writer all one's life. What I was trying to do was to tell the truth, telling it as it is, not as some PR person wants people to hear it." But does that mean everything witnessed by a journalist, even if they understand the need for discretion at the time, is fair game, their property to sell at some future date? Roberts says: "I suppose there is a conflict of interest, but you tell me how to resolve it. All I know is that my motives were good."

Non-journalists, like Gregson and evidently like members of Roberts's own family, take the opposite view. "All writers get told off for writing what they know to be the truth," says Roberts. "It's a row I've had with my family down the years. But it's a bourgeois way of viewing things, pretending nothing has happened. I was there. I was a witness. I wrote it. All the rest is PR, mundane quotes from Hollywood stars you know aren't true. I just felt I was setting the record straight." But the cuttings files never allow anyone to rest in peace.

Mysterious celebrity deaths offer endless possibilities down the years for journalists to reopen investigations on the flimsiest of evidence. The fact that Roberts agrees that the premise of the Vanity Fair piece is wholly flawed is beside the point. By raking over the same coals, she doubled the hurt for Gregson and his daughter.

Yet what was she to do? As she says, she is a journalist and that's what journalists do. But her attempt to compare herself to a novelist who draws on real life for fictional reasons is much more suspect. Journalism is different, especially in the eyes of the reader.

It's hard not to escape the conclusion that she realised she had gone too far. After her piece appeared, she says, "Richard left a message on my answerphone saying he was very pissed off. So I called a friend in Hollywood and asked, 'Was I wrong?'" The friend evidently said no, but the fact she made the call suggests her conscience was pricking.

fields.headline: Now for the moment of truth
fields.standfirst: When Living Marxism questioned the authenticity of an ITN report about a Bosnian detention camp, the TV company sued for libel.  Vikram Dodd  on a trial that the world will be watching
fields.trailText: When Living Marxism questioned the authenticity of an ITN report about a Bosnian detention camp, the TV company sued for libel.
fields.body:
From next Monday the high court in London will be transformed into a navel at which the world's media will gaze. It will be the stage for a libel case brought by Independent Television News (ITN) against Living Marxism (LM) magazine. The commercial news provider sued after the magazine claimed it had distorted footage from a detention camp in Bosnia.

What really will be on trial will be a single image: that of a Bosnian inmate whose emaciated frame when shown caused outrage around the world. Those few seconds of the ITN report snagged the conscience of the west more than hundreds of reports on the conflict had done before it.

Viewers were horrified by the image of prisoner Fikret Alic behind barbed wire, his translucent skin wrapped so tightly around his wasting body that every one of his ribs showed.

ITN won a string of awards for the report, which is credited with hastening western military involvement in the conflict. Rumours about the brutal nature of the camps the Bosnian Serbs ran had flourished but the ITN story was the first independent evidence of the treatment of inmates.

The libel trial will test the credibility of TV news and current affairs, dented by recent scandals. The case will also provide another rallying point for those who believe that Britain's libel laws need reform, amid claims that ITN is trying to use its financial clout to snuff out dissent from a small magazine. Others claim LM's alleged pro-Serbian sympathies led it to attack ITN's veracity.

Today, lawyers for ITN and LM will be at the high court for a pre-trial hearing, ahead of next week's trial. The evening before it starts there will be a comedy benefit for LM, cementing the case's status as a cause célèbre. The trial will see star correspondents on the stand, with LM having subpoenaed the BBC's world affairs editor John Simpson as a defence witness.

The path to the high court started on August 5, 1992. ITN journalists Penny Marshall and Ian Williams went to two camps in northern Bosnia.

At the second they filmed the report, transmitted the next day, which featured the image of a starved Alic. The shocking quality of the image was immediately apparent. The Mirror ran the headline "Belsen '92". The pictures were shown around the world. In the US, its then most watched evening news broadcast, ABC World News Tonight, introduced ITN's footage by saying: "The debate over the war in Bosnia Herzegovina today is focusing on those pictures which gave the world its first look at a Serbian-run detention centre."

Its report said: "But it was not until words like 'concentration camp' were used that the world's attention was captured and world leaders felt obliged to say something, though not necessarily take action."

President Bush talked tough about taking action as that one image stoked anxiety about the extent of the horrors in a complex Balkan war few could understand.

In 1997 LM ran an article attacking ITN's report under the headline "the picture that fooled the world". It was written by Thomas Deichmann, a German freelance.

ITN's lawyers have set out what was so objectionable about LM's report. LM, said ITN, claimed that the image was created by "camera angles and editing" and "that there was no barbed wire fence surrounding the camp nor were the refugees in the picture surrounded by barbed wire. It said the camp was a collection centre for refugees, not a prison."

ITN demanded that the offending issue of LM be pulped and when it was not decided to sue.

LM sells around 10-15,000 copies per edition. It started as the journal of the Revolutionary Communist Party, but has developed to fill the gap left by Marxism Today.

It bills itself as freethinking and says the cost of the case could shut down the magazine and personally bankrupt senior staff. Its fighting fund, called Off the Fence, has raised nearly £70,000.

LM has two arguments. First, it will argue that its article was justified. Second, it will claim that, whether the article was right or wrong, ITN is wrong to use its commercial might to try and silence a small maverick magazine. LM sees itself as a mouthy David under attack from a broadcasting Goliath.

The freedom of speech argument has won support from a host of writers, including Will Self, Margaret Drabble and Doris Lessing. A letter to the Spectator said ITN was "a major news broadcaster using libel laws to thwart an open press and this has serious implications for journalists". It was signed by Guardian columnists Roy Greenslade and Charlotte Raven, as well as Auberon Waugh. A letter to the Times deplored ITN's libel suit, saying it was "yet another example of libel law's chilling effect on free speech".

A signatory to both was the distinguished American linguist and critic of the mass media, Noam Chomsky. He said: "I supported the right of freedom of speech, not LM.

"If LM's reporting 'dishonoured the suffering of those in the Bosnian war', that's evil. [But] I do not support the right of some unimaginably immense mega-corporation to bring a libel suit against the New York Times and others, effectively shutting them down.

"In England, the right to do this is so broad as to be utterly outrageous, in my opinion a very significant impediment to freedom of speech." LM has other heavyweights prepared to testify on its behalf. One defence witness will be Phillip Knightley, author of The First Casualty, a book about how truth has been distorted through wars throughout the ages. He believes Deichmann may have gone too far but did raise a legitimate concern: "The case shows the problems of war journalism. It's too easy to take one single incident and use that as a base to generalise about what's happening everywhere.

"In television journalism, it's risky to allow one seductive image to drive the story and to mould the story around that seductive image."

For those with no direct experience of the wars that stained the last century, it is the defining image that conveys the suffering and emotion far better and with greater ease than reading thousands of words.

The defining image of the Spanish civil war was taken by Robert Capa in 1936, and was portrayed as showing a Republican soldier at the exact moment he was shot.

Knightley says the way this image was portrayed was misleading and illustrates the dangers of war reporting: "I spent six months looking into it and no one wanted to talk about it. I was told the negatives had been lost."

Capa's picture appeared in Life magazine a year after he sent it back from the battlefield, and only then did the caption contextualise it as showing the death of a soldier: "It could be a Republican soldier slipping over in a field," says Knightley.

Others see the issues about the ITN footage differently. They view the trial as an opportunity to defend the memory of the suffering of the victims. LM is accused of being plain wrong, and at worst revisionist and of trying to minimise the horrific suffering of the Bosnian people because it is a fellow traveller with the Serb nationalism that has wreaked so much havoc on the Balkan region.

Ed Vulliamy was there when the report was filmed and wrote about the camp for the Guardian. Now Washington correspondent for the Observer, the Guardian's sister paper, he is withering in his contempt for those supporting LM: "ITN filmed that which was before our eyes. The prisoners were there, the fence was there."

Vulliamy is unimpressed by the celebrities who are supporting LM: "They are hitching their flag to the mast of people who are either in support of the Serbs, or [they are people who will do] anything for a contrary argument. I think ITN has done the right thing. The moral and political stakes are high. Who shouldn't do what over libel is a sideshow."

fields.headline: Murdoch's makeover fails to convince
fields.standfirst: Why isn't News Corp's value soaring as spectacularly as its major rivals'? The Boss would like to know.
fields.trailText: Why isn't News Corp's value soaring as spectacularly as its major rivals'? The Boss would like to know.
fields.body:
It is rare for anyone to feel sorry for Rupert Murdoch. His master company, News Corporation, was created out of a parochial chain of Australian newspapers inherited from his father and now lays legitimate claim to being one of the world's dominant media enterprises.

Yet despite the huge increase in the value of publicly quoted media companies in recent months - boosted initially by the excitement surrounding the merger of AOL and Time Warner and then by the sudden re-rating on the stock exchange of any company with significant control over content - his share price has languished.

It must seem so unfair. After all, Murdoch's empire stretches from books to magazines to newspapers to a Hollywood studio. He has 40% of BSkyB, now worth nearly £30bn. His share alone is about £12bn, now a significant proportion of News Corp's total market capitalisation. That seems to suggest that the rest - Fox Studios, Fox Television, satellite companies, control of publisher HarperCollins, etc - isn't worth very much.

So many of his separately quoted enterprises - BSkyB and Fox Kids for a start - have seen their share prices soar. BSkyB has seen its share price double since the beginning of the year. And yet the master company is, relatively speaking, treading water.

Why? The answer might be that the market is not paying attention to a simple fact: Murdoch has a major network (satellite) through which to pump his considerable content. He has Sky in the UK, a stake in Primestar in the US, Star TV in Asia and Stream in Italy. He also controls a version of the technology that allows satellite signals to be encrypted for the purposes of delivering pay television.

The attraction of all this is clear. If you are a major creator of content, whether it be Hollywood films or television series, it is profitable to also control the distribution platforms that ensure the content makes it into homes. Even with the digital revolution, which is meant to make distribution cheaper and content more valuable, it is still a terrific business to own both the content and the distribution.

Ask CBS/Viacom, major broadcasters and cable operators, or AOL/Time Warner, which between them will control huge amounts of content, an extensive cable network and a ubiquitous internet portal. Or ask BSkyB, which recently saw its share price soar partly because it decided to embrace new platform potential: by agreeing a joint venture with Kingston Communications to deliver Sky programming via telephone lines in the UK.

Fifteen years ago, Murdoch was convinced that satellite was the right distribution platform. Since then, the received wisdom has evolved: now, satellite is viewed as too clunky, unable to deliver two-way broadband interactivity, and will always be a poor cousin to two-way systems such as cable, high-capacity telephone lines or even wireless.

All the same, satellite has taken off. Today in the UK, the biggest digital distribution system is satellite based. Sky has 2.3m satellite subscribers, while digital cable has just 105,000 and ONdigital, the terrestrial rival, is probably in 600,000 homes. Direct-to-home satellite is also big business in Italy, France, Germany, Portugal and Scandinavia, not to mention North America, Asia and India. So if owning content and distribution is important, and if satellite is a worthy distribution platform in its own right, then shouldn't big satellite-owning companies be fully rated by the stock market? Murdoch evidently thinks so. That is why News Corporation confirmed newspaper reports this past week that it was intending to create a new entity that would group all of Murdoch's satellite holdings. The idea is to concentrate the minds of investors: to show them that News Corporation has significant network operations in the form of leading satellite companies. You like strong distribution and content plays, Mr Murdoch seemed to say - then have a look at mine!

This underlines the crucial point in News Corp's announcement. Nothing has changed about Murdoch's businesses. Whether the Murdoch empire is structured as a series of partly owned companies, joint ventures, minority stakes or as regrouped publicly listed entities makes no earthly difference to the money he makes. But Murdoch understands that appearances matter. Announce an internet strategy, as radio company GWR did last week, and your share price goes up. Announce that you are going to be a major internet player, as Reed, Reuters and BSkyB have done in recent weeks, and you are rewarded with a huge increase in your share price. Announce that you are a major network operator, as News Corp did by suggesting it would regroup its disparate satellite operations into one entity, and your share price should respond.

It makes a rather awkward point about the stock market just now. There is a tendency among corporations to restructure their operations just for show, hoping for the approbation of investors. And, so far, investors are playing along.

Look! You hadn't noticed that my company is really an internet play! (So said Reed). Up go the shares.

Look! I'm a major content provider, not a provider of commodity financial information! (So said Reuters). Up go the shares.

Look! I am a major network of satellite platforms, not just a family-run media company with a vague succession plan and a reputation for screwing minority shareholders! (So said Rupert Murdoch). Jury still out.

In the end, corporate restructuring, relisting, spin-offs and the like will only go so far. The issue is, was and will be: does the company make money? The great shakeout is not yet upon us. Lastminute.com, a company with no unique market position, is likely to be able to command a flotation price of £400m. Freeserve, with no ability, as yet, to keep its users captive to its own web pages, can be worth £7bn on the stock market. Companies can still get away with a knee-jerk share price hike when they announce a refocusing on the internet, a new corporate structure, a joint venture with a new media company, a supply deal with a "dot com" upstart.

But eventually, one day, we will again ask: does it make any money? News Corporation's fiddling of corporate structure is simply a "me too" reaction - an effort to attract the market's attention at a time when the market is looking for simple answers. More important will be whether satellite delivery can survive the onslaught of telephony and wireless, and whether News Corporation's control of direct-to-home distribution systems and its own huge stable of content providers (Fox, HarperCollins, the Sun, etc) can see off the competition from behemoths such as Time Warner-AOL or Disney ABC.

You can understand Murdoch's frustration, as News Corporation failed to keep up with the re-rating of other companies on the frontier of the new media. But a simple corporate restructuring, redolent as it is of me-tooism, can't convince. What will convince is profits.

 Mathew Horsman is a media analyst at the City firm of Investec Henderson Crosthwaite Securities

webTitle: Meet your new listeners (and yes, they are old)

fields.headline: Meet your new listeners (and yes, they are old)
fields.standfirst:
Maggie Brown on why we need a radio revolution
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Commercial radio is certainly looking at itself with an unusually critical eye. It has suddenly realised that unless it broadens listener choice, adds some civilised voices alongside the lads and ladettes, and tones down the drum 'n' bass, it will hand over dominance to the BBC for years to come.
fields.body:
Are the days of the loud-mouthed shock jocks and safe, computerised playlists numbered? Well, commercial radio is certainly looking at itself with an unusually critical eye. It has suddenly realised that unless it broadens listener choice, adds some civilised voices alongside the lads and ladettes, and tones down the drum 'n' bass, it will hand over dominance to the BBC for years to come. A great big niche, the over-44s, has opened up - at the same time as commercial radio is busy concentrating all its fire-power on the under-44s, especially young men. After all, that's what the advertisers dictated during the 1990s.

And it is the BBC, with its broad range of output, which is serving this growing over-44 market best, and recruiting them fastest, points out the Radio Advertising Bureau.

Demographic change, and a failure to adapt to a greying population, could leave the commercial sector stranded, shrinking rather than expanding. The debate has been focused by the latest Rajar quarterly listening figures, which showed that the BBC has pushed up its audience share convincingly in the October/December period with a 51.3% share compared to 46.7% for commercial radio. This ends the deadlock of the past six years, when the two rivals were level-pegging.

The BBC's own predictions five years ago, that its share would fall to around 30%, just haven't come about. And, separately, the Radio Authority, which hands out licences, is concerned that the commercial sector, despite 242 local and regional stations, three national channels and a switch into digital, is out of kilter with the population. It is about to start a major consultation and study covering taste and decency standards, after cracking down hard on offensive broadcasts by London's Xfm and Hallam FM in Yorkshire.

"Older listeners," says Jason Bryant, TalkSport's managing director in charge of new development, "like a more grown-up style of presentation. They want quality news and information, not inane banter, or lists of who's shagging who around the world. There's no doubt that there's a strong market opportunity among the 45-plus age group. Commercial radio doesn't serve that audience."

This explains why a number of digital radio projects, including those from GWR, Scottish Media Group and Talk's parent, The Wireless Company, are wooing Saga, the company which caters for the over-50s but which failed to win a single commercial radio licence during the 1990s.

Last week, Capital Radio launched a new softer national radio format called Life, aimed at women, while One Word Radio (part-owned by the Guardian Media Group) is backing a (commercial) speech network, challenging Radio 4.

Ron Coles, heading the Saga Radio push says: "There's a sense in the last 12 months that there's been a shift in attitude. The over-44s market is so large, it will comprise more than 40% of audiences in 10 years. Traditionally, no one has targeted them, even Classic FM has tried to move towards younger listeners. Yet I get stacks of letters from people objecting to crude speech."

The key to Saga's format is melodic music: Nat King Cole, Cliff Richard, Elvis, Dr Hook, even Boyzone. "Not time-warped radio, that's very important. But they just don't want to listen to drum 'n' bass."

To be fair, the picture is complicated by other factors. Rival stations heap blame for commercial radio's lack of growth on Atlantic 252, the long-wave rock service beamed from Ireland, whose audience has halved in the past five years. Some regional stations with strong local news perform well.

And the sparkling exception in this tale of missed opportunities is GWR's Classic FM, which stormed to an audience of more than 6m listeners last year for the first time and has picked up an extra 1.3m regulars in the past four years by smart management and continually adjusting its output.

John Pearson, chief executive of Virgin Radio - and a newly minted millionaire thanks to the takeover deal with the Scottish Media Group - argues that the sector is constrained: the BBC, he points out, has the lion's share of best FM frequencies, and it can promote its networks on national television for free. The Radio Authority imposes too tight content restrictions, preventing shifts in tune with audiences - while the BBC can and does change its mix without recourse to anyone: Radio 2 is actually trying to attract younger listeners, Radio 1 is becoming more mainstream, Radio 5 Live outspending Talk Radio for sports rights.

But commercial operators have been stuck in a groove, other insiders argue. "They are totally research-driven and unambitious. They've been unable to come up with fresh, interesting programming to extend their appeal," says a senior industry figure. Playlists tend to be restricted to music thought least likely to cause people to switch off. Many of the "gold" services, such as Capital Gold, on outmoded AM frequencies, are networked across a number of stations. Some perform weakly.

Last year the Radio Authority allowed the greatest relaxation ever: it changed from harnessing companies to promises of performance to a far looser concept of formats. Talk Radio changed with a minimum of fuss to TalkSport, and demonstrated one key problem.

For his own business reasons Kelvin MacKenzie decided to appeal almost exclusively to young, sports- mad males. His audience is now two-thirds male, as is Radio 5 Live's. In other words, he kissed goodbye to the middle-aged women who tuned in for broadcasters like Anna Raeburn. Where did those listeners go? Not to commercial radio. Probably to Radio 2 and local BBC radio.

It has suddenly realised that unless it broadens listener choice, adds some civilised voices alongside the lads and ladettes, and tones down the drum 'n' bass, it will hand over dominance to the BBC for years to come. A great big niche, the over-44s, has opened up - at the same time as commercial radio is busy concentrating all its fire-power on the under-44s, especially young men. After all, that's what the advertisers dictated during the 1990s. And it is the BBC, with its broad range of output, which is serving this growing over-44 market best, and recruiting them fastest, points out the Radio Advertising Bureau. Demographic change, and a failure to adapt to a greying population, could leave the commercial sector stranded, shrinking rather than expanding. The debate has been focused by the latest Rajar quarterly listening figures, which showed that the BBC has pushed up its audience share convincingly in the October/December period with a 51.3% share compared to 46.7% for commercial radio. This ends the deadlock of the past six years, when the two rivals were level-pegging. The BBC's own predictions five years ago, that its share would fall to around 30%, just haven't come about. And, separately, the Radio Authority, which hands out licences, is concerned that the commercial sector, despite 242 local and regional stations, three national channels and a switch into digital, is out of kilter with the population. It is about to start a major consultation and study covering taste and decency standards, after cracking down hard on offensive broadcasts by London's Xfm and Hallam FM in Yorkshire. "Older listeners," says Jason Bryant, TalkSport's managing director in charge of new development, "like a more grown-up style of presentation. They want quality news and information, not inane banter, or lists of who's shagging who around the world. There's no doubt that there's a strong market opportunity among the 45-plus age group. Commercial radio doesn't serve that audience." This explains why a number of digital radio projects, including those from GWR, Scottish Media Group and Talk's parent, The Wireless Company, are wooing Saga, the company which caters for the over-50s but which failed to win a single commercial radio licence during the 1990s. Last week, Capital Radio launched a new softer national radio format called Life, aimed at women, while One Word Radio (part-owned by the Guardian Media Group) is backing a (commercial) speech network, challenging Radio 4. Ron Coles, heading the Saga Radio push says: "There's a sense in the last 12 months that there's been a shift in attitude. The over-44s market is so large, it will comprise more than 40% of audiences in 10 years. Traditionally, no one has targeted them, even Classic FM has tried to move towards younger listeners. Yet I get stacks of letters from people objecting to crude speech." The key to Saga's format is melodic music: Nat King Cole, Cliff Richard, Elvis, Dr Hook, even Boyzone. "Not time-warped radio, that's very important. But they just don't want to listen to drum 'n' bass." To be fair, the picture is complicated by other factors. Rival stations heap blame for commercial radio's lack of growth on Atlantic 252, the long-wave rock service beamed from Ireland, whose audience has halved in the past five years. Some regional stations with strong local news perform well. And the sparkling exception in this tale of missed opportunities is GWR's Classic FM, which stormed to an audience of more than 6m listeners last year for the first time and has picked up an extra 1.3m regulars in the past four years by smart management and continually adjusting its output. John Pearson, chief executive of Virgin Radio - and a newly minted millionaire thanks to the takeover deal with the Scottish Media Group - argues that the sector is constrained: the BBC, he points out, has the lion's share of best FM frequencies, and it can promote its networks on national television for free. The Radio Authority imposes too tight content restrictions, preventing shifts in tune with audiences - while the BBC can and does change its mix without recourse to anyone: Radio 2 is actually trying to attract younger listeners, Radio 1 is becoming more mainstream, Radio 5 Live outspending Talk Radio for sports rights. But commercial operators have been stuck in a groove, other insiders argue. "They are totally research-driven and unambitious. They've been unable to come up with fresh, interesting programming to extend their appeal," says a senior industry figure. Playlists tend to be restricted to music thought least likely to cause people to switch off. Many of the "gold" services, such as Capital Gold, on outmoded AM frequencies, are networked across a number of stations. Some perform weakly. Last year the Radio Authority allowed the greatest relaxation ever: it changed from harnessing companies to promises of performance to a far looser concept of formats. Talk Radio changed with a minimum of fuss to TalkSport, and demonstrated one key problem. For his own business reasons Kelvin MacKenzie decided to appeal almost exclusively to young, sports- mad males. His audience is now two-thirds male, as is Radio 5 Live's. In other words, he kissed goodbye to the middle-aged women who tuned in for broadcasters like Anna Raeburn. Where did those listeners go? Not to commercial radio. Probably to Radio 2 and local BBC radio.

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Martha Lane Fox
fields.trailText: Martha Lane Fox
fields.body:
Newspapers: The Guardian and the FT. I always enjoy Will Hutton. Sundays, it depends; I quite like Sunday Business, the Observer and the business section of the Sunday Times. Yes, I have to read the business papers at the weekend, too.

Magazines: Anything - from OK! magazine to the Daily Mail to the Economist. I like Business Week, too. I'm often travelling: yesterday I went to Sweden and bought Fortune, Business Week, Hello! and Newsweek.

Books: My all-time favourite is War and Peace. At the moment I'm reading John Pilger's Hidden Agendas and I've just finished JM Coetzee's novel, Disgrace; I loved his Waiting for the Barbarians. I tend to read 19th-century novels. I want to read more Trollope - my father gave me a fantastic set for my birthday last year.

Film: The last film I saw was American Beauty. I had niggles about it, but overall I liked it. My favourite movies are the MGM musicals of the 40s and 50s - Singin' in the Rain, Easter Parade, Silk Stockings, Band Wagon . . . I know them all off by heart.

Television: Haven't watched it properly for 18 months. I love Larry Sanders and Seinfeld. I hate 999 emergency rescue, tragi-documentary-type programmes - sensationalist, voyeuristic stuff. And Animal Hospital. I prefer to turn on my computer, look at the web, do my emails. I'm not a techno-geek, but with a choice of a Reggie Kray documentary and the web, I prefer the web.

Radio: Radio 4 in the morning for the news.

Ads: I hate self-consciously trendy ads, such as the Benetton "sentenced to death" advertising. It's outrageous. It's had the desired effect on me, but I think it's loathsome.

Multimedia: Palm Pilot and mobile. I think websites are just the beginning of the media's evolution and that mobile phones and other digital assistants will be really exciting in the next two to three years.

webTitle: Student journalists speculate on the future

fields.headline: Student journalists speculate on the future
fields.standfirst: Five student journalists reveal how they see the future of their chosen profession
fields.trailText: Five student journalists reveal how they see the future of their chosen profession
fields.body:
Jessica Leeman
Age: 21

Editor: Badger, Sussex

We choose the news first from what we've read in the papers: G2, Le Monde Diplomatique, alternative newsletter Schnews and z-mag.com. Then we use the internet to get more information, but it can be hard to track things down, unless you know exactly what you're looking for. Newspaper archives on the web are excellent, but I don't think the web has changed the way people get their day-to-day news - most read the paper on the train or over breakfast. Where it has had a huge impact is in getting more information about what you've read. Email also makes papers more accessible, with free news sent to subscribers.

John Woodcock

Age: 21

Editor: Edinburgh Student

I don't scour the net for news -the print version is still superior. PA and the BBC sites are worth a glance but do not yet have the same in-depth coverage as most papers. In future, I think the net will allow greater diversity of interests. People will be able to select exactly what they want, when, and customise their news intake. Access to the web is not yet advanced enough to make it as user-friendly as picking up a paper, but that is changing all the time. I think newspapers will still be around in 10 years' time, in the sense that they'll still be brand names, but the move to electronic media will continue and it may predominate.

Chris Campbell

Age: 26

Editor: London Student

Once internet businesses piggyback mainstream television broadcasting, a lot of the text-based news services now on the net will become obsolete. The web's role as a news provider will become less important as the entertainment industry exploits fully interactive broadcasting. Newspapers in their traditional form will then become more relevant as they'll be the only place you can find news without being bothered by ad banners. Frankly, my job involves so much time in front of computers that I avoid using the net for fun.

Richard Colebourn

Age: 20

Editor: Cherwell, Oxford

I read the Guardian, Times and New Statesman in print, New York Times, Slate and BBC News on the Internet, and US e-zines. In the next 10 years, I think online operations may become more important within media organisations because the internet has the advantage of speed - when major stories break, people will go straight to the web, as they go to news channels now. But I'm sceptical about claims that the internet will kill off broadcasting or the press. TV and radio are convenient and comfortable; picking up a paper is more enjoyable than reading from a screen.

Jonti Small

Age: 20

Editor: Varsity, Cambridge

Newspapers needn't be overly worried - I think new technology will supplement rather than replace them, at least while computers are less pleasant or convenient. News Unlimited and the BBC websites are good - and are trusted, unlike most Internet sites. But they are a resource rather than a habit, like taking a newspaper. Once they start to offer something tangibly different, the future will become more interesting. The way in which the net evolves will shape how we see and receive news. The pessimist in me sees the AOL/Time Warner merger as ominous but the rapidity of AOL's growth means only a fool would draw a firmer conclusion than that we just don't know.

Interviews by Carolyne Ellis

fields.headline: Victim of Russia's ugly war
fields.standfirst:
Journalist Andrei Babitsky was covering the conflict in Chechnya when he went missing in bizarre circumstances. Have the Russians silenced an irritant? Amelia Gentleman investigates
Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Journalist Andrei Babitsky was covering the conflict in Chechnya when he went missing in bizarre circumstances. Have the Russians silenced an irritant? Amelia Gentleman investigates.
fields.body:
For the Russian authorities, Radio Liberty war correspondent Andrei Babitsky was an irritant they could do without. And so they removed him - in accordance with the old Stalinist dictum: "No person, no problem." Except that in Babitsky's case, the problem refused to disappear along with the person. Instead, the irritant has developed into an international scandal, with the disturbing fate of Babitsky symbolising the worst of Russia's crackdown on media coverage of the war in Chechnya.

It has been 37 days since Babitsky last telephoned his wife; since then his voice has only been heard on two sinister videos, of uncertain origin, broadcast on national television. The Russians say he is being held by Chechen guerrillas. His friends, family and employers insist that if he is not already dead, he is in the hands of the FSB - the reorganised KGB. In the space of a few weeks, this man has been transformed from an ordinary news reporter into a dissident martyr, the victim of Russia's new drive to stifle press freedom.

Babitsky spent weeks reporting from inside the besieged Chechen capital Grozny for the US-owned radio station, repeatedly contradicting the official Kremlin line on the war. His dispatches gave details of civilian casualties, when Russian officials said that only terrorist bases were being targeted; he reported serious losses among the Russian army, as the military insisted their casualties were minimal; he depicted the plight of thousands of Chechen refugees, while Russia said that there was no humanitarian crisis.

With access to the war zone severely restricted, and with most Russian correspondents simply regurgitating official statements from the military headquarters, Babitsky's work soon became dangerously conspicuous. Then, on Jan uary 16, he went missing. For 12 days, Russian authorities said they knew nothing about what had happened to him, before suddenly admitting that he was being held by them in a detention centre in northern Chechnya.

At this point, the Russian version of events began to look fuzzy. Some officials said he had been detained because he did not have the correct military accreditation to work in the war zone. Others said it was because he had been working with the rebel enemy. But his alarmed employers at Radio Liberty were reassured by soothing government representatives that a swift release would be organised.

This never happened. Instead, the FSB released a video showing a painfully nervous-looking Babitsky being exchanged for two Russian soldiers in a bizarre prisoner swap. The cameras followed the journalist as he walked along a deserted Chechen road towards some masked gunmen, who grabbed him by the shoulder; the film cut off as they began to lead him away. Despite having filmed the transaction, the FSB denied responsibility for it.

More alarming still for Babitsky's family was the official response to the exchange - which had the ring of a death sentence. Sergei Yastrzhemsky, the spin doctor newly employed by the Kremlin to "co-ordinate" information from the war zone, declared: "From now on, all federal authorities bear no responsibility for the correspondent's fate."

Ten days ago, a second video emerged, showing the journalist looking exhausted and frightened. He told the camera that he simply wanted to go home. His family and colleagues regard both pieces of film with supreme scepticism and refuse to take them as evidence that Babitsky is still alive. They say that the prisoner swap was a crude fake, a badly acted piece of theatre designed to shift responsibility for Babitsky's fate onto the Chechens, so that if he were ever found dead, Russia would not be blamed.

Chechen warlords have repeatedly denied any involvement in the swap, and Chechen president Aslan Maskhadov has insisted that Babitsky is not in Chechen hands. Even taken at face value, the exchange presents cause for concern. Although they brandished a letter in which Babitsky appeared to give his consent, military officials have never explained the reasoning behind their apparent decision to hand a non-combatant journalist to the enemy.

Working in an environment where much is often left unexplained, the Russian press corps has become adept at dreaming up conspiracy theories and there has been no shortage of explanations for what happened to Babitsky. But there is one version which has gained widespread acceptance among those who knew the journalist.

They believe that Babitsky knew too much about one aspect of the Russian campaign, and as a consequence became the victim of a bungled silencing attempt by the Russian military - undertaken initially by local officials without sanction from Moscow. As the outcry about his disappearance gained strength, senior officials stepped in to orchestrate an urgent damage-limitation exercise - the apparent prisoner exchange - which in turn backfired disastrously.

This is the scenario advocated by Mario Corti, Radio Liberty's representative in Russia. "Someone didn't like what he was writing and decided to put a stop to it. We don't know if the decision to detain him was taken locally or not, but certainly when it became public knowledge that he was in detention, the central author ities stepped in. I think at this point it was already too late for him to be released."

Reports have recently emerged that suggest that the journalist was badly beaten at the Chernokosovo detention camp, where he was held for several days in the north of Chechnya. Accounts of the brutal regime within this prison are only gradually emerging, but human rights groups have expressed extreme concern about the conditions in which hundreds of young Chechen men are being held there. "If Babitsky had been beaten in the prison, it would have been difficult for the military to release him in case he spoke about his treatment and about the conditions there. So they started lying," Corti says.

He dismisses new reports which emerged last week - from FSB sources - suggesting that Chechen warlords were holding Babitsky prisoner. "I don't think that the Russians handed him to the Chechens; I think they delivered him to themselves. I'm quite sure that if he is not already dead then he is in the hands of the Russian agencies," he says.

Maria Eismont, another Russian journalist who reported alongside Babitsky in Grozny but who managed to leave the region safely some weeks earlier, says that if he had really been handed to Chechen rebels he would have telephoned his wife to tell her that he was all right. "The fighters have access to telephones. At the very least he could have ensured that a message got through to her," she says.

Babitsky's mysterious disappearance is an extreme example of a strengthening trend of media repression in Russia, but it is not a unique case. Earlier this month, another leading Moscow journalist, Alexander Khinshtein - an investigative reporter who specialised in reporting on Kremlin sleaze - narrowly escaped being consigned to a mental asylum by officials. This throwback to the favoured Stalinist silencing tactic of locking unwanted voices in psychiatric clinics precipitated new waves of alarm.

The enormous energy spent by government officials on controlling the flow of news from Chechnya is also symbolic of Russia's new repressive ethos. Negative media coverage of Russia's last war in Chechnya was immensely damaging to the then president Boris Yeltsin. This time, Russia's new premier Vladimir Putin - the former FSB chief who was appointed just before the war broke out - was determined to get it right. Putin has built his presidential ambitions on his tough approach to the war, and has courted supportive coverage of the army's basic mission. At the same time, he has been keen to avoid focus on the campaign's messy details: the casualties and the destruction.

From the start, severe restrictions on access to Chechnya were imposed. Journalists were only permitted to visit Russian-controlled areas of the separatist state, and only if they had special military accreditation from the defence ministry. This accreditation was given only to favoured Russian journalists. With one or two exceptions, foreign journalists were excluded from the system. Occasional excursions into the war zone for selected reporters have been set up, but organisers have been so determined to promote the official version of events that these trips have usually been completely surreal.

One recent trip saw a group of foreign reporters escorted by the military on a five-day tour of Russian-occupied Chechnya, days after Grozny fell to the Russians after two months of brutal bombardment. On the first day, villagers were brought out to perform traditional Chechen folk dances for the visitors. On day two, journalists were encouraged to inspect and write about the saunas built by Russian soldiers behind the front line. At no point were they allowed to talk freely with civilians, instead they were warned that villagers were under pressure to lie to visiting journalists.

"Finally we were taken to Grozny for a few hours on the last day of the trip, where we managed to talk briefly to some residents about their experiences. As we left the city, our escorts told us that these people had all been paid by the rebels to lie to us. The military seriously expected us to believe this, it was extraordinary," says one television reporter.

At the beginning of this month, new accreditation was widely distributed as a conciliatory gesture, but access has become no easier. The press officer at Russia's military headquarters in the region, a Colonel Astafiyev, reacts with surprised indignation when foreign journalists suggest a visit to the war zone. "What's going on here is simply none of your business," he says. "Chechnya is Russia's intimate affair. You wouldn't like it if we demanded to see what you get up to in your bedroom. We don't like you demanding to see what we're doing here."

Reporters interested in seeing a different side to the campaign have been forced by Russia's strict regulations to seek illicit ways of getting into Chechnya. For some this has involved bypassing the Russian border controls by travelling on foot along dangerous, remote footpaths. Some have resolved the problem by bribing soldiers at checkpoints with a combination of cigarettes, beer, vodka and dollars - distributed according to seniority. Others have resorted to disguise, procuring Chechen-style outfits and travelling with refugees, hoping that their documents will not be scrutinised.

Like Babitsky, journalists who travel independently risk immediate arrest if they run into Russian officials within Chechnya. Anne Nivat, a French correspondent, had her satellite telephone, notebooks and documents confiscated when the military found her working in a Chechen village. She was subjected to 12 hours of interrogation by the FSB before being sent back to Moscow. "The Russians don't want anyone to witness what they are doing there," she says. "They have done everything they can to repress news about this very nasty war."

But recently, despite this determination to get it right, Russia's heavy-handed propaganda campaign has begun to backfire. News of massacres and widespread human rights abuses has filtered out of the country despite the restrictions; international criticism of Russia's campaign has strengthened. The government is starting to lose the information war. The Kremlin's new Chechnya spokesman, Yastrzhemsky - the former spin doctor to Boris Yeltsin, who built his career on his ability to invent plausible excuses for the former president's frequently bizarre behaviour - now has an even tougher task. At his regular press briefings on the war, he has become reluctant even to discuss the Babitsky question.

Friends believe that if the reporter is alive, there is little likelihood of him being released before Russia's presidential elections on March 26. Corti's prognosis for Babitsky's future is bleak. "Babitsky is the only person who can explain what happened to him. I think the Russians are frightened of what he might tell us. He will only be released when the people who detained him feel certain that he will not speak. That can only be done by returning a Babitsky who is no longer Babitsky."

The enormous energy spent by government officials on controlling the flow of news from Chechnya is also symbolic of Russia's new repressive ethos. Negative media coverage of Russia's last war in Chechnya was immensely damaging to the then president Boris Yeltsin. This time, Russia's new premier Vladimir Putin - the former FSB chief who was appointed just before the war broke out - was determined to get it right. Putin has built his presidential ambitions on his tough approach to the war, and has courted supportive coverage of the army's basic mission. At the same time, he has been keen to avoid focus on the campaign's messy details: the casualties and the destruction. From the start, severe restrictions on access to Chechnya were imposed. Journalists were only permitted to visit Russian-controlled areas of the separatist state, and only if they had special military accreditation from the defence ministry. This accreditation was given only to favoured Russian journalists. With one or two exceptions, foreign journalists were excluded from the system. Occasional excursions into the war zone for selected reporters have been set up, but organisers have been so determined to promote the official version of events that these trips have usually been completely surreal. One recent trip saw a group of foreign reporters escorted by the military on a five-day tour of Russian-occupied Chechnya, days after Grozny fell to the Russians after two months of brutal bombardment. On the first day, villagers were brought out to perform traditional Chechen folk dances for the visitors. On day two, journalists were encouraged to inspect and write about the saunas built by Russian soldiers behind the front line. At no point were they allowed to talk freely with civilians, instead they were warned that villagers were under pressure to lie to visiting journalists. "Finally we were taken to Grozny for a few hours on the last day of the trip, where we managed to talk briefly to some residents about their experiences. As we left the city, our escorts told us that these people had all been paid by the rebels to lie to us. The military seriously expected us to believe this, it was extraordinary," says one television reporter. At the beginning of this month, new accreditation was widely distributed as a conciliatory gesture, but access has become no easier. The press officer at Russia's military headquarters in the region, a Colonel Astafiyev, reacts with surprised indignation when foreign journalists suggest a visit to the war zone. "What's going on here is simply none of your business," he says. "Chechnya is Russia's intimate affair. You wouldn't like it if we demanded to see what you get up to in your bedroom. We don't like you demanding to see what we're doing here." Reporters interested in seeing a different side to the campaign have been forced by Russia's strict regulations to seek illicit ways of getting into Chechnya. For some this has involved bypassing the Russian border controls by travelling on foot along dangerous, remote footpaths. Some have resolved the problem by bribing soldiers at checkpoints with a combination of cigarettes, beer, vodka and dollars - distributed according to seniority. Others have resorted to disguise, procuring Chechen-style outfits and travelling with refugees, hoping that their documents will not be scrutinised. Like Babitsky, journalists who travel independently risk immediate arrest if they run into Russian officials within Chechnya. Anne Nivat, a French correspondent, had her satellite telephone, notebooks and documents confiscated when the military found her working in a Chechen village. She was subjected to 12 hours of interrogation by the FSB before being sent back to Moscow. "The Russians don't want anyone to witness what they are doing there," she says. "They have done everything they can to repress news about this very nasty war." But recently, despite this determination to get it right, Russia's heavy-handed propaganda campaign has begun to backfire. News of massacres and widespread human rights abuses has filtered out of the country despite the restrictions; international criticism of Russia's campaign has strengthened. The government is starting to lose the information war. The Kremlin's new Chechnya spokesman, Yastrzhemsky - the former spin doctor to Boris Yeltsin, who built his career on his ability to invent plausible excuses for the former president's frequently bizarre behaviour - now has an even tougher task. At his regular press briefings on the war, he has become reluctant even to discuss the Babitsky question. Friends believe that if the reporter is alive, there is little likelihood of him being released before Russia's presidential elections on March 26. Corti's prognosis for Babitsky's future is bleak. "Babitsky is the only person who can explain what happened to him. I think the Russians are frightened of what he might tell us. He will only be released when the people who detained him feel certain that he will not speak. That can only be done by returning a Babitsky who is no longer Babitsky."

fields.headline: Women's raw deal
fields.standfirst: Angela Phillips examines the latest findings on pay inequality between men and women
fields.trailText: Angela Phillips examines the latest findings on pay inequality between men and women
fields.body:
Women earn less than men - not just because they are often mothers, but just because they are women. This is the finding of British government research out today.

The study, produced on behalf of the government's women's unit, has forensically examined pay structures and concluded that sex discrimination is alive and well in the hearts of British managers.

This finding overturns the popular view that women are doing as well or better than their male counterparts and only lagging in the pay race because of their "weakness for children". At the highest skill level, a woman will earn £143,000 less than a comparable man in her lifetime even if she has no children.

Indeed the having of children (according to the research) will only handicap her by a further £19,000.

Further down the skill pecking order, childless women are even more disadvantaged in relation to their male peers and at the same time, the cost of having children, in terms of lifetime earnings, mounts higher.

According to Equal Opportunities Commission research, the problem lies with the attitudes of managers who still see men as breadwinners and women as secondary earners who go out to work just to get out of the house.

Even those who don't have children will suffer from the expectation that they might become pregnant. So at every stage and age women are tied up in assumptions about the fact that as one manager put it: "Men are seen as more committed because they don't have a child to go back to." Children and caring haunt our employment prospects whatever we do.

But it isn't just that. Surveys on families and work show just how much the male identity and ego is focussed on earning. Even a recent study on men as parents showed that they could only identify their contribution to the family in terms of income.

Women see themselves and their work in a different way, but not in quite the way that these managers assume. In just about every employment survey I have ever seen, women talk about job satisfaction. Men put money at the top of the list of reasons why they work. Men pursue higher salaries whereas women tend to pursue more interesting work.

Women with children are even more likely than those without to pursue flexibility and pleasure in work than simply money, and we know that they lose heavily as a result. Employers don't value people who value their lives above their work, their happiness above their income.

David Beckham's fracas with Manchester United boss Alex Ferguson reveals more clearly than anything this survey has done, the thinking of Britain's macho managers. Ferguson clearly thinks that a man who earns what Beckham does should put his job before his baby.

As EOC commissioner Tess Woodcraft puts it: "He has found out what women have found out over the years: if you stay home to look after the baby you get dropped from the team."

In a sense this survey has told us little we didn't already know. In terms of the management that runs British industry, having a life is not compatible with work.

While this philosophy prevails, those of us who care about our friends, take weekends in the country, have babies and care for them will all be left sitting on the benches - held in suspicion of being not quite focussed enough, not quite serious enough.

webTitle: Analysis: Livingstone will stand as an independent

fields.headline: Analysis: Livingstone will stand as an independent
fields.standfirst: The defeated Labour candidate for London mayor will declare in the next few days, says his biographer John Carvel
fields.trailText: Although Ken Livingstone may not declare his hand   for a few more days, it is now a sure bet that he   will run as an independent candidate to be Londons   first elected mayor.
fields.body:
Although Ken Livingstone may not declare his hand for a few more days, it is now a sure bet that he will run as an independent candidate to be Londons first elected mayor.

His closest political intimates think he is already 95% certain about standing, but wants solid confirmation from several opinion polls that he would be likely to win.

Splitting the Labour vote and letting in a Tory or Liberal Democrat mayor has never been part of Livingstones game plan. He will run only if his lead in the opinion polls is commanding enough to survive a likely weakening of his support during fierce campaigning against him from the massed ranks of all the official parties in the run-up to the election on 4 May.

Livingstones probable calculation is that 44-50% support would be enough if the other candidates are fairly evenly split. Todays poll in the London Evening Standard satisfied that test by giving Livingstone 50%, with 22% for Labours Frank Dobson, 15% for the Tory Steven Norris and 8% for the Liberal Democrats Susan Kramer.

The question for Livingstone is all about political arithmetic. He long since passed the psychological barrier of conceiving the possibility of running against the party he has served for more than 30 years. If Tony Blair had refused to let him fight for the Labour nomination, he would have been an independent candidate already.

Blair has nothing to offer now that could conceivably be attractive enough buy his continued loyalty. Any doubts that the prime minister might have had about this must have been dispelled when the two men held private talks at Chequers on Saturday.

Livingstone will be spending much of this week working out who might run on his slate of independent candidates for seats in the Greater London assembly. He will also be looking to raise at least £500,000 to fund his campaign - way beyond the £70,000 spent by his organisation so far.

But I dont expect the announcement for a few more days.

John Carvel, the Guardians education editor, is Ken Livingstones biographer. You can buy his book, Turn Again Livingstone, online here for £6.29, a 10% saving on the list price.

fields.headline: Parliamentary privilege
fields.trailText: Martyn Jones, Labour MP for Clwyd South, is threatening to use parliamentary privilege to reveal the names of at least six suspected child sex abusers linked to the north Wales care home scandal.
fields.body:
Martyn Jones, Labour MP for Clwyd South, is threatening to use parliamentary privilege to reveal the names of at least six suspected child sex abusers linked to the north Wales care home scandal.

Parliamentary privilege covers an MPs right to say in the chamber what would be prohibited (or libelous) outside. Since Mr Jones does not believe that last week's Waterhouse report uncovered the full extent of the care home abuse he hopes his threat can force an investigation with no legal risk to himself.

Parliament takes its own privileges very seriously. This is how its joint committee defines the subject:

"Parliament makes the law and raises taxes. It is also the place where ministers are called to account by representatives of the whole nation for their decisions and their expenditure of public money. Grievances, great and small, can be aired, regardless of the power or wealth of those criticised.

"In order to carry out these public duties without fear or favour, Parliament and its members and officers need certain rights and immunities. Parliament needs the right to regulate its own affairs, free from intervention by the government or the courts. Members need to be able to speak freely, uninhibited by possible defamation claims. These rights and immunities, rooted in this country's constitutional history, are known as parliamentary privilege."

The freedom of parliamentarians to speak their minds freely dates back to the 1689 Bill of Rights. But Parliament today takes almost as seriously any accusation against members of abusing that privilege.

The joint committee on privilege (Lords as well as Commons) can recommend to their respective Houses that offending members be fined, reprimanded, suspended, or even expelled. The last MP to be thrown out of the Commons was Peter Baker, Conservative member for Norfolk South, who was given his marching orders in 1954 after being convicted of forgery.

Last May the committee carved through more than three centuries of accumulated tradition and precedent to recommend sweeping changes, scrapping the law that allowed disgraced Tory minister Neil Hamilton to bring his doomed libel action against The Guardian. They also recommended allowing MPs and peers to be tried for corruption, and a raft of other measures radically curbing their ancient privileges. (Some way down the list, but nevertheless eyecatching, was the proposal that Parliament should lost its power to impeach people for high treason, and another that mad lords should no longer be exempt from committal to a lunatic asylum).

Parliamentary privilege belongs to a imprecise accumulation of customs and practices which has often rubbed shoulders uneasily with the laws of the land. In 1985, for example, civil servant Clive Ponting was prosecuted under the Official Secrets Act for passing classified documents relating to the sinking of the Argentine cruiser Belgrano during the Falklands War, to Tam Dalyell MP - who was not prosecuted.

Most rows over privilege are more nakedly political. In 1987 there was an explosive row in the Commons when the newly elected member for Brent South, one Ken Livingstone, suggested that Airey Neave, assassinated by the IRA in 1979, had had knowledge of treasonable activities by security forces in Northern Ireland.

Privilege can be a useful tool of government, too. Only last month foreign office minister Peter Hain wrapped himself in the cloak of privilege to name three foreign businessmen whom he said had been breaking UN sanctions against rebel forces in Angola.

webTitle: I will name abusers, says MP

fields.headline: I will name abusers, says MP
fields.standfirst:
More about the Wales child abuse scandal
The issue explained: Children in care
fields.trailText: An MP yesterday threatened to use parliamentary privilege to reveal the names of at least six more suspected child sex abusers linked to the north Wales care home scandal.
fields.body:
An MP yesterday threatened to use parliamentary privilege to reveal the names of at least six more suspected child sex abusers linked to the north Wales care home scandal.

Martyn Jones, Labour MP for Clwyd South, believes that last week's Waterhouse report did not uncover the full extent of the crimes. He said there were still people named by known victims of the care home abusers who had not been properly investigated.

If Mr Jones does not get a fresh inquiry or action from the police, he says he will use parliamentary privilege to name names in the Commons.

Some of those on Mr Jones's list are believed still to be working in positions where they might come into contact with children.

Mr Jones, chairman of the Commons Welsh select committee, made a similar threat to "out" alleged abusers in order to pressure the John Major administration to launch the Waterhouse inquiry.

He added: "The names I have, I have known since 1989 - they are not simply malicious allegations on the back of the recent publicity."

 The hunt was continuing yesterday for two men believed to have been involved in the murder of a convicted child rapist. William Bruce Malcolm, 44, died after being shot in the head on Thursday night in Manor Park, east London.
