fields.headline: Pride and prejudice
fields.standfirst:
The Macpherson report sparked a huge debate about race which went beyond the police to issues of identity, employment and inequality. Here, a distinguished panel discuss the difference the inquiry has made and the opportunities it offers for change

Hear the debate
fields.trailText: The Macpherson report sparked a huge debate about race which went beyond the police to issues of identity, employment and inequality. Here, a distinguished panel discuss the difference the inquiry has made and the opportunities it offers for change. Plus: hear the debate.
fields.body:
The panel:
Gary Younge (chair); John Grieve, deputy assistant commissioner, metropolitan police force; Paul Charlton, race and violent crimes task force, metropolitan police; Cristina Odone, deputy editor, New Statesman; Lola Young, school of humanities and cultural studies, Middlesex University; Stephen Thompson, author; Faisal Bodi, news editor of UK Muslim magazine, Q news; Indhu Rubasingham, associate director, Birmingham Rep

Gary Younge:
It seems like it's been quite a difficult year for the police, balancing some of the recommendations Macpherson report with what you would call effective policing. Is that a fair assessment?

John Grieve:
No, that wouldn't be my position. The debate in the police is about effectiveness, about how you get stop-and-search better, what is an acceptable hit rate, what does proportionality mean out on the streets? We must get better at it if we want to keep the power.

GY:
When the crime figures came out it was hinted that one of the reasons certain crimes were not being detected was because there is a sense of self-consciousness among the police when they stop-and-search.

JG:
There are issues about how the police feel about being convicted of institutional racism. But it has never been part of the strategy to have stop-and-search as a tactic.

Cristina Odone:
But the feeling was much more verbalised than that wasn't it? I remember a piece by Tom Utlee saying that Macpherson had blood on his hands because they had demoralised the police force to such an extent that stop-and-search had decreased and the logical consequence of that decrease was an increase in street crime.

JG:
That's an outrageous thing for anybody to say about Sir William Macpherson.

Lola Young:
But there seemed to be a concerted campaign after the report to make a causal link between the diminution of the amount of stop-and-search going on with fears of being accused of racism, and black people being implicated in the majority of street crime. What do you feel about the extent to which that kind of media frenzy plus public awareness folds back into how the police feel about themselves and their role?

JG:
What people expect has shifted quite substantially and the police didn't keep up with that. Is that a reasonable and non-defensive answer to the point you were making?

LY:
Yes, sort of. There is an interesting relationship between how different groups of people see themselves, the way they perceive how other people perceive them and how all that gets played out through the media.

Stephen Thompson:
It's a myth that the black community closes ranks when it comes to stop-and-search. We want to catch criminals like everybody else, but at the same time we don't want a disproportionate level of stopping and searching.

GY:
Is there anyone here who would challenge the right of the police to stop someone in the street and ask them questions?

LY:
I wouldn't - but there's an assumption that black youths are up to no good, which is bad.

CO:
Black men are five times as likely to be stopped and searched. In that context, where is the Asian community?

Faisal Bodi:
I don't belong to the Asian community as such. I classify myself as a Muslim; it just happens that the majority of Muslims in this country are of an Asian background.

GY:
Is it your feeling that by dwelling on young black men, Macpherson pushes other experiences to the margins?

Indhu Rubisingham:
The report was in specific relation to the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, so in that sense I didn't feel marginalised. But there are lots of other issues that other communities experience that are different from the the Afro-Caribbean community.

ST:
I think it's important to put things in an historical context. One of the perceptions of the police is that they're unaccountable, and when it's time for them to be held to account they close ranks. I don't think Macpherson dealt with that.

GY:
One of the solutions that was suggested in the first report was recruitment of more non-white officers. Why do you think young black and Asian people have not gone into the police in the past and what would have to be done to turn that around?

LY:
It's seen as a hostile environment.

GY:
Black people generally are twice as likely to be unemployed. There are jobs there, one wonders why they're not taking them. What's stopping them? Perception? Paul, as a black police officer, what do you think?

Paul Charlton:
It's either perception or what they've heard from other people, it's not necessarily something they've experienced themselves. The police have got to be seen by their own actions to be a non-racist service.

LY:
What we have to realise is all services will benefit from equal opportunities. These policies are for everybody, so it's not just about benefits that accrue to black people. We want a police service that solves crime, we want an education system that educates people. You talk about employment, but what employment prospects are there for black boys who are excluded from classrooms across the country?

ST:
The thing is, positive discrimination doesn't work in the end because we become stigmatised as not worthy and are told we are only there because of the colour of our skin. There's a lot of tokenism involved that only serves to make those people who implement those policies feel better about themselves.

LY:
Somebody has to open the door for you slightly, but once you're in it comes down to merit. But we must recognise that there are glass ceilings.

FB:
Yes, but we've got to be wary about playing the colours game. Having the right colours in the relevant place in the higher positions doesn't achieve anything. All you're going to get is recriminations and a possible backlash.

GY:
Yes, but black people do want jobs and they aren't getting them in larger numbers than white people, which would suggest that there is some mismatch between aspiration and attainment.

LY:
It's very easy for us to make generalisations, but we need to think about these things not only in terms of race but class and gender as well. Let's not also forget about the dire performance in schools of white working class boys.

GY:
One of the ways in which current debates on race are interestingly skewed is that black people talk about their experiences of being black, white people never talk about their experiences of being white.

JG:
In terms of being a white, middle class, middle aged cop, Macpherson was a deeply shocking and shaming experience.

GY:
Paul, were you shocked when they came up with institutional racism?

PC:
No, I can't say I was.

GY:
So what have your experiences been in the police service?

PC:
You do have things happen to you from time to time, but it's not a huge catalogue. I've been stopped in my own station before and asked for ID in uniform. I've been stopped driving an unmarked police car and had the keys taken out of the ignition by a police officer who asked me to get out of the car, knowing that no radio check had been done on the car. One of the most embarrassing incidents was when I went to Wormwood Scrubs to take a prisoner out to an ID parade. I was driving an unmarked police car, with a white colleague in the back who was handcuffed to a black prisoner. We drove into the back of the station and all of a sudden a rapid response car drove right across my path. A WPC got out and banged on the window shouting, "Do you mind telling me who you are?"

GY:
Did you complain about any of these things?

PC:
No. I've dealt with these things myself, approaching people on a one-to-one basis.

GY:
Lets talk about the differences within races and also between communities. Faizal, is this is an issue?

FB:
We've got to accept that there are people who perhaps don't want to be labelled in ethnic or racial terms.

GY:
What would you call yourself?

FB:
British Muslim. My roots are here, I was born here. My parents come from the subcontinent but my connections are very tenuous. I've never been there, but at the same time I have an identity that transcends race or anything else, something that comes from within, and that's Muslim.

GY:
We're all several things at the same time and different identities will come to the fore at different moments. The issue is whether there is ever a time when Asian is a relevant thing to call someone whose ancestors come from the subcontinent.

CO:
Absolutely. I think one of the reasons we're all so exercised about this particular issue is because it is visible. It is like gender - the kind of prejudice that we all know about because it is worn outside. The fact that you're Muslim may be the most important thing to you, but to somebody from the outside it is not the most evident.

IR:
The only useful terminology is the phrase British Asian. That's the only thing that actually connects this Asian community. Faizal and my parents would have nothing in common with each other culturally. But in the context of being British Asian they would.

LY:
The historical thing is important and interesting if we think about naming and categorising people. We describe black people as black and very often we don't describe white people as white, which shows the necessity to develop a more sophisticated language, understanding and analysis of what is going on.

But because of the tension between a sense of race and a sense of place this is something that ethnic minorities have to think about and deal with on a daily basis. And now, for the first time, white people are engaged in it as well.

But I don't think John would even have announced the fact that he was a white middle-class man 10 years ago. People weren't doing that. There has been a raising of consciousness about how white people are perceived.

Is there a crisis in Englishness and whiteness? There's devolution, there's Europe, and there's William Hague on his truck saying, "Save our pound." Do you think that feeds into the debate?

LY:
Some of the reactions to the Macpherson report should be seen in that context.

IR:
I was gobsmacked to be hearing radio programmes and reading articles saying that the Brixton and Brick Lane bombs were a result of "the English being denied their culture" and "being swamped by having to be multicultural".

CO:
There is very strong evidence of insecurity. The white British male sees himself as being put upon, in terms of relinquishing the notion of empire and specialness, contemporaneously with a stronger female workforce and more emancipated female partner, not to mention all these special issues that concern people other than himself.

 Paul Charlton talks about his experiences as a black policeman
 Stephen Thomas and Gary Younge discuss postive discrimination
 Indhu Rubisingham describes the British Asian experience
 Lola Young asks the panel to think about race and class
 Faisal Bodi, Gary Younge and Cristina Odone debate multiple identities
 John Grieve discusses the Metropolitan police and how he feels to be white
fields.bodyText: The panel: Gary Younge (chair); John Grieve, deputy assistant commissioner, metropolitan police force; Paul Charlton, race and violent crimes task force, metropolitan police; Cristina Odone, deputy editor, New Statesman; Lola Young, school of humanities and cultural studies, Middlesex University; Stephen Thompson, author; Faisal Bodi, news editor of UK Muslim magazine, Q news; Indhu Rubasingham, associate director, Birmingham Rep Gary Younge: It seems like it's been quite a difficult year for the police, balancing some of the recommendations Macpherson report with what you would call effective policing. Is that a fair assessment? John Grieve: No, that wouldn't be my position. The debate in the police is about effectiveness, about how you get stop-and-search better, what is an acceptable hit rate, what does proportionality mean out on the streets? We must get better at it if we want to keep the power. GY: When the crime figures came out it was hinted that one of the reasons certain crimes were not being detected was because there is a sense of self-consciousness among the police when they stop-and-search. JG: There are issues about how the police feel about being convicted of institutional racism. But it has never been part of the strategy to have stop-and-search as a tactic. Cristina Odone: But the feeling was much more verbalised than that wasn't it? I remember a piece by Tom Utlee saying that Macpherson had blood on his hands because they had demoralised the police force to such an extent that stop-and-search had decreased and the logical consequence of that decrease was an increase in street crime. JG: That's an outrageous thing for anybody to say about Sir William Macpherson. Lola Young: But there seemed to be a concerted campaign after the report to make a causal link between the diminution of the amount of stop-and-search going on with fears of being accused of racism, and black people being implicated in the majority of street crime. What do you feel about the extent to which that kind of media frenzy plus public awareness folds back into how the police feel about themselves and their role? JG: What people expect has shifted quite substantially and the police didn't keep up with that. Is that a reasonable and non-defensive answer to the point you were making? LY: Yes, sort of. There is an interesting relationship between how different groups of people see themselves, the way they perceive how other people perceive them and how all that gets played out through the media. Stephen Thompson: It's a myth that the black community closes ranks when it comes to stop-and-search. We want to catch criminals like everybody else, but at the same time we don't want a disproportionate level of stopping and searching. GY: Is there anyone here who would challenge the right of the police to stop someone in the street and ask them questions? LY: I wouldn't - but there's an assumption that black youths are up to no good, which is bad. CO: Black men are five times as likely to be stopped and searched. In that context, where is the Asian community? Faisal Bodi: I don't belong to the Asian community as such. I classify myself as a Muslim; it just happens that the majority of Muslims in this country are of an Asian background. GY: Is it your feeling that by dwelling on young black men, Macpherson pushes other experiences to the margins? Indhu Rubisingham: The report was in specific relation to the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, so in that sense I didn't feel marginalised. But there are lots of other issues that other communities experience that are different from the the Afro-Caribbean community. ST: I think it's important to put things in an historical context. One of the perceptions of the police is that they're unaccountable, and when it's time for them to be held to account they close ranks. I don't think Macpherson dealt with that. GY: One of the solutions that was suggested in the first report was recruitment of more non-white officers. Why do you think young black and Asian people have not gone into the police in the past and what would have to be done to turn that around? LY: It's seen as a hostile environment. GY: Black people generally are twice as likely to be unemployed. There are jobs there, one wonders why they're not taking them. What's stopping them? Perception? Paul, as a black police officer, what do you think? Paul Charlton: It's either perception or what they've heard from other people, it's not necessarily something they've experienced themselves. The police have got to be seen by their own actions to be a non-racist service. LY: What we have to realise is all services will benefit from equal opportunities. These policies are for everybody, so it's not just about benefits that accrue to black people. We want a police service that solves crime, we want an education system that educates people. There's a lot of tokenism involved that only serves to make those people who implement those policies feel better about themselves. LY: Somebody has to open the door for you slightly, but once you're in it comes down to merit. But we must recognise that there are glass ceilings. FB: Yes, but we've got to be wary about playing the colours game. Having the right colours in the relevant place in the higher positions doesn't achieve anything. All you're going to get is recriminations and a possible backlash. GY: Yes, but black people do want jobs and they aren't getting them in larger numbers than white people, which would suggest that there is some mismatch between aspiration and attainment. LY: It's very easy for us to make generalisations, but we need to think about these things not only in terms of race but class and gender as well. Let's not also forget about the dire performance in schools of white working class boys. GY: One of the ways in which current debates on race are interestingly skewed is that black people talk about their experiences of being black, white people never talk about their experiences of being white. JG: In terms of being a white, middle class, middle aged cop, Macpherson was a deeply shocking and shaming experience. GY: Paul, were you shocked when they came up with institutional racism? PC: No, I can't say I was. GY: So what have your experiences been in the police service? PC: You do have things happen to you from time to time, but it's not a huge catalogue. I've been stopped in my own station before and asked for ID in uniform. I've been stopped driving an unmarked police car and had the keys taken out of the ignition by a police officer who asked me to get out of the car, knowing that no radio check had been done on the car. fields.headline: K-For weapons search continues
fields.trailText: Peacekeepers from a dozen nations completed their search for illegal weapons in the town of Mitrovice today, as some 10,000 ethnic Albanians began their march from Kosovo's capital Pristina to Mitrovice to protest the division of the town along ethnic lines.
fields.body:
Peacekeepers from a dozen nations completed their search for illegal weapons in the town of Mitrovice today, as some 10,000 ethnic Albanians began their march from Kosovo's capital Pristina to Mitrovice to protest the division of the town along ethnic lines.

"I've searched all the sectors I wanted to search," said Pierre de Saqui de Sannes, the French general responsible for peacekeeping in Mitrovice. He said, however, that while the main thrust of their search was complete, he would still reserve the right to carry out additional searches if necessary.

This was the second day of weapons searches in Mitrovice following outbursts of aggression on Sunday in which US and German troops were attacked with stones and bottles by angry crowds objecting to the search of Serb owned buildings.

The searches continued as Nato secretary general, George Robertson, denied that Kosovo Albanian charges of pro-Serb bias had forced other nationalities to join French troops in the town.

French troops managed to cordon off the area yesterday to prevent any further incidents between Serb protesters and K-For, the international peacekeeping force in Kosovo.

The arms search, which took place in both Serbian and Albanian sectors, resumed this morning and is said to have been the largest operation of its kind since NATO-led troops entered the province last June. Approximately 2,300 peacekeepers have been involved in the search and weapons had been retrieved.

In total, seven Albanians and one Serb were arrested on Sunday for illegal weapons possession and two Albanians remained in custody today.

Meanwhile, the tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians on a 40 km (25 miles) unity march from Pristina to Mitrovice have been told they will not be allowed to enter the city for fear of fuelling ethnic tensions.

Carrying banners which read "No to Partition of Kosovo" and "Without Mitrovice there is no Kosovo", only a small delegation will be allowed to enter the town which is divided along Serbian and Albanian ethnic lines.

"We had to reach a compromise as we didn't wish to inflame the situation," said Neville Clayton, a K-For spokesman.

However, the situation in Mitrovice, the third largest city in Kosovo, has become tense. A large group gathered at a bridge on the predominantly Albanian south side of the Ibar River while hundreds congregated on the mainly Serbian north bank.

The source of friction stems from fear on both sides. Albanians feel that they are still unable to return to the homes which they fled during the conflict before NATO troops moved in to establish peace. Serbians claim that their justification for grouping together in one region is to ensure protection from Albanian revenge attacks.

fields.headline: Mergers
fields.standfirst:
CGU and Norwich Union have announced a £20bn merger to create a
British insurance colossus. The merger rivals the value of Royal
Bank of Scotland's acquisition of NatWest as the largest
financial services deal in British corporate history. Mark Tran
explains the reasons behind the spate of mergers in financial
services and other sectors
fields.trailText: Why are CGU and Norwich Union merging?
fields.body:
Why are CGU and Norwich Union merging?

To cut costs and to compete with the big insurance companies. The companies intend to cut about £200m a year of their combined costs, which will involve axing 4,000 jobs, about 5% of the total workforce of 70,000. By pooling their resources, CGU and Norwich Union think they can better compete with the global leaders. The top five are Axa (France), Allianz (Germany), Nippon Life (Japan), General (Italy) and Zurich (Switzerland and Britain).

Is cost-cutting the driving force in mergers?

That is one big reason. Another reason often cited in 1980s and 1990s was synergy, although the term has dropped out of fashion. Synergy is the notion that the various elements of the combined companies would reinforce each other, in effect that the whole would be greater than the sum of its parts. The reality can be quite different.

When did it not work?

A classic case of a merger that looked wonderful on paper, but then came a cropper was AT&T, the US telecommunications giant, which acquired NCR, the computer company, in 1990. AT&T thought the alliance made sense with the convergence of telecommunications and computers. Five years, later AT&T divested itself of NCR, a stark admission that the merger had been a flop.

Is the AT&T case typical?

Various studies have shown that the majority of mergers do not add value for shareholders. Merger mania tends to occur in waves. In the 1960s, conglomerates were all the rage, as companies gobbled up businesses that bore little relation to each other. ITT was the classic conglomerate of that era, a hodgepodge of different concerns - from manufacturing to insurance. By 1995, the company split itself up. We are now experiencing another wage of mergers across the board, cars, pharmaceuticals, telecommunications, finance, the list goes on. But from the academic studies, most mergers, like marriage, are a triumph of hope over experience. The real beneficiaries are the investment bankers who cobble together the deals and then pick them apart.

If so many mergers fail to make grade, why do they occur so regularly?

It comes down to a mixture of fear, ego and business strategy. Many companies feel that safety comes through size, especially in markets that are becoming increasingly global, with the breakdown of trade barriers and the rise of the internet. Companies merge for defensive reasons. When Disney bought the ABC television network, that started the trend for other media companies to marry "content" and "distribution". As it turns out the Disney-ABC deal has been far from an unqualified success. That has not stopped Time Warner _ a media giant in its own right _ from merging with American Online, the world's leading internet service provider.

What are the obstacles to successful mergers?

Cultural differences. It is enormously difficult to graft one company's culture on to another. It took years for Time and Warner to learn how to operate with each other. At the beginning, officials from each company spent as much time fighting each other rather than working with each other. Running a massive company is also enormously difficult, although it can be done as Jack Welch proved at General Electric, a US conglomerate.

So are mergers a waste of time?

Not completely. There is sound business logic for the spate of banking mergers in the US for example. There were simply too many banks in America, so a shakeout was overdue and the Citigroup financial services combination in the US appears to be on track. In pharmaceuticals, the costs of producing a new drug are so huge, that companies needed to combine their research and development budgets. The key to success is a strong sense of direction from management.

webTitle: In the good old days when Ken was in charge...

fields.headline: In the good old days when Ken was in charge...
fields.standfirst: Paul Myers recalls the heady days of London under the GLC
fields.trailText: It was 19 years ago but the GLC's "Fares Fair" campaign still resounds. Travelling about the capital on the bus and tube suddenly became 25% cheaper. For me, as a cash-strapped student, it was a godsend. Ken Livingstone, the architect of the scheme, seemed an angel in disguise. True, there was less investment in the Underground but there were more passengers on the trains and the number of cars coming into London fell by 15%. It felt like a party.
fields.body:
It was 19 years ago but the GLC's "Fares Fair" campaign still resounds. Travelling about the capital on the bus and tube suddenly became 25% cheaper. For me, as a cash-strapped student, it was a godsend. Ken Livingstone, the architect of the scheme, seemed an angel in disguise. True, there was less investment in the Underground but there were more passengers on the trains and the number of cars coming into London fell by 15%. It felt like a party.

Other GLC projects, such as the call for greater police accountability and recognition of gay rights, are now part of the political firmament. But at the time they were so radical they were deemed "mad". I read and heard then that Ken was the embodiment of "the loony left" and everything that we should hate.

But what was so crazy about pushing for lower prices on the buses and tubes? Nowadays, with such astronomical fares, I wish some of that insanity would return. As for the police, they're now falling over themselves to expose their transparency and determination to root out racist cops.

When Margaret Thatcher smashed Ken's GLC in March 1986, he won the support of scores of London Tories who were unhappy with the interference. Tony Blair appears to have learned nothing from her arrogance, which is frustrating as he was supposed to be in tune with us all and make a difference.

Since those heady days in the early eighties I've understood that Ken is the populist who will never achieve true greatness. His power will rest in the nostalgic collective consciousness of millions of Londoners - no matter what their political colours.

That seems to be what Millbank fails to grasp and is vainly trying to eradicate. And ultimately this is what irks and saddens me. If he had won the Labour candidacy I would have voted for him. I'm unlikely to vote for anyone if Livingstone doesn't run as an independent.

I sense that there are many others like me. People not particularly overwhelmed by Steven Norris and unimpressed by Frank Dobson who, though an able health secretary, does not exude elan and, worst of all, is branded a Blair stooge. Susan Kramer? Well, my heart's not in it.

As a prospective voter for a mayor, I feel no tie with those interesting and turbulent times of the early eighties. Many Londoners did not experience that period and feel no link at all. Ken offered the connection and the chance for Blair to counter the charge that he is guilty of megalomania. Without Livingstone it will be a drab campaign. But perhaps there's only supposed to be one radical reformer in town.

webTitle: Chelsea bring Gills down to earth

fields.headline: Chelsea bring Gills down to earth
fields.trailText: Having produced a couple of surprise knockouts, Gillingham were yesterday stopped in the sixth round by heavyweight opponents who finally made their superior punching power tell.
fields.body:
Having produced a couple of surprise knockouts, Gillingham were yesterday stopped in the sixth round by heavyweight opponents who finally made their superior punching power tell.

Chelsea were never going to roll over like their Premiership counterparts Bradford and Sheffield Wednesday earlier in the competition at the hands of Peter Taylor's Second Division lightweights. But without moving out of first gear, Gianluca Vialli's world XI overcame a sloppy first-half performance to cruise past the gallant men of Kent and now head to Wembley to play their eighth semi-final in seven years, this time against Newcastle.

Gillingham were left with their memories, a standing ovation and the prospect of returning to a league campaign which could still end with a trip to Wembley if they make the play-offs. Judging by the form that took them on their best FA Cup run in their 107-year history, that remains a distinct possibility.

And as Taylor pointed out, losing 5-0 to Chelsea was no disgrace. Millions of pounds and 47 places separate these teams in the league hierarchy. In fact in world terms it has just been announced that, based on results home and abroad, Chelsea were the fifth-best side on the planet in the year to January.

Even without the suspended Dennis Wise and Frank Leboeuf and the cup-tied Emerson Thome, Chelsea were able to field a frightening array of talent. Gillingham were never overawed, though, and for much of the first half more than held their own, defending impressively and breaking forward with a neat passing game against a side who looked very lackadaisical.

The visitors, though, were the architects of their own downfall as Chelsea took the lead after only 17 minutes. Gustavo Poyet intercepted a Gillingham throw, hoisted in a cross from the left and Tore Andre Flo headed home unmarked.

Gillingham created a couple of half-chances before the interval, and George Weah hit the bar for Chelsea. The second half, though, was a different story. Gillingham brought on a second striker, Carl Asaba making his first appearance of the season after injury. But in relaxing their defensive attitude in pursuit of an equaliser, they handed Chelsea the space to get their passing game together and kill off the game.

fields.headline: The next decade
fields.standfirst: "When technology allows people to plug into the political process directly, then  Members of Parliament, like other intermediaries, may find themselves looking  for a new role in life."
fields.trailText: "When technology allows people to plug into the political process directly, then Members of Parliament, like other intermediaries, may find themselves looking for a new role in life."
fields.body:
We need a far more radical reform of the public sector, to make it more able to engage in the entrepreneurship and innovation which drives the private sector. What would that mean? We should create a venture capital or innovation fund - perhaps worth £150 million to begin with - within the public sector to invest systematically in the creation of new services and the dissemination of new ideas, especially those which combine different departments.

Venture capital-style investment in the public sector should match that of the private sector, as a proportion of GDP. We need to create a much more active market for money to flow to people with talent and ideas in the public sector, regardless of their rank and standing. So, for example, it should be a requirement that people going into the senior civil service should have been involved in at least one public sector start-up, that is an attempt to create a new form of organization. The public sector needs to learn from large private sector organizations which have innovated by creating 'skunk works' to come up with new ideas, internal venture capital markets, ideas fairs and smaller sub-brands and spin-offs, with a more innovative culture.

And finally we need to create new rewards to recognize the role of civic entrepreneurs, not necessarily in money, but through time off for study, for example. The entire welfare system should be broken up and operated by a group of competing mutuals and social enterprises. They would be mandated to meet minimum national standards of service, but they would compete in terms of their effectiveness in getting people back to work or providing quality of service. Only through creating more competition within the public sector will taxpayers be in a position to compare the relative cost and effectiveness of different ways of delivering welfare. That in turn will drive up performance. And within the next few years we should start to make more of the public sector's vast intangible assets.

The privatisation programme of the 1980s focused on the industrial economy: steel, cars, oil, gas, electricity, water. In the next ten years we could raise hundreds of millions of pounds to be ploughed back into education by seeking to extract more value from the public sector's vast stock of largely dormant intangible assets.

This New Economy privatisation programme would in turn depend on the creation of public-private partnerships to exploit these assets. As a simple example take the BBC's Top Gear website. Top Gear is an outstanding brand name. Its website gets thousands of hits from fans both of cars and of the programme's former presenter, Jeremy Clarkson. At the moment the TopGear site just sells merchandise related to the programme. However, it could become Europe's leading motoring website, allowing people to trade cars, buy accessories, search for insurance deals, upgrade their in-car navigation software and the like. That would take TopGear beyond the realm of the BBC and into the much larger marketplace for e-commerce.

But to do that the BBC would have to sell say 49 per cent of the TopGear Web-business to a private partner with e-commerce expertise. As a purely BBC website TopGear will be marginal to the emerging e-commerce marketplace for cars. In a public-private partnership it could be a huge commercial success. This recipe could be followed with a string of BBC websites covering food, travel, home decoration and the like. The BBC has done a brilliant job in creating some of the best websites in Europe. Even at today's depressed stock-market valuations for Internet companies, the BBC's online assets are probably worth about £8bn. If the BBC realized half of that by selling minority stakes in its online businesses to private partners, it could fund a massive expansion of its education activities.

The political process and the character of the state could, in theory, change dramatically. Over the next few years an electronic and online political world will develop alongside the physical one we inherited from the Victorians. How long will it be before we have our first online election? The technology to make online voting possible is readily available. We should set ourselves the target to make the election after next - 2007 - the first one in which people can vote electronically. And if we can vote electronically once, then we could do so over and over again, not once every five years but on legislation as it passes through the House of Commons.

The House of Commons, rather like other intermediary bodies, is designed to represent large groups of people. But when technology allows people to plug into the political process directly, then Members of Parliament, like other intermediaries, such as insurance brokers and travel agents, may find themselves looking for a new role in life. When people can buy, sell, trade and invest directly using the internet and its successors, as they will in the next five years, they will want to know why they cannot interact with the political system in the same direct way.

The Commons itself would continue to exist, perhaps mainly as a tourist attraction and symbolic font of parliamentary democracy, but much of the business of government, the largest paper-processing business in the country, could be conducted electronically.

Just to give you one example of what that might mean, think about what happens when you get your next prescription from your doctor. First your doctor types into her computer and prints out a piece of paper. Then you take the paper to the chemist, who writes into her computer and prints out a label for your- bottle of pills and another piece of paper which goes off to a central paper-processing unit in Newcastle. When that paper arrives in Newcastle an operator opens the envelope, takes it out and inputs the details into her computer before printing out another piece of paper which goes to the Department of Health to pay the chemist. The whole paper trail costs £40 million a year. No extra value is created and the entire procedure could be largely automated. The money saved on processing could be reinvested in services which really help consumers. Gains of that scale are available throughout the public sector.

fields.headline: Sculptor's towers for Tate
fields.trailText: When you get to artist Louise Bourgeois's age - she will be 89 next birthday - you are supposed to start scaling back. But Bourgeois, the world's greatest living sculptor, is not one for doing what she is supposed to.
fields.body:
When you get to artist Louise Bourgeois's age - she will be 89 next birthday - you are supposed to start scaling back. But Bourgeois, the world's greatest living sculptor, is not one for doing what she is supposed to.

She eats only jam for breakfast and won't read her copy of the New York Times unless it has been freshly ironed. Her career did not take off until she was a widow well into her sixties. Now she is making her biggest series of works yet for the new Tate Modern museum on the south bank of the Thames in London. The three 30ft steel towers - called the Unilever Series after the sponsors - will dominate the 500ft turbine hall of the old gutted Bankside power station.

Not only are they monuments to Bourgeois's genius, they also mark the modern marriage of art and big business. They will be in place when the £135m gallery opens in May and bring an estimated 2,400 jobs and £50m a year to an up-till-now fly-blown corner of the capital. The French-born artist, who had a show at the Serpentine Gallery last year, has never attempted any thing on such a scale before. Each tower will be topped by two chairs and a set of four large swivel mirrors, so that visitors who climb the spiral staircases will not only have to contend with dizziness but will also be thrown off balance by multiple reflected images of themselves. Bourgeois herself "imagines that the platforms will become the stage for significant conversations and human confrontations".

The three towers - which have strong echoes of the architectural sculptures of the Russian artist Tatlin and Escher's mathematical puzzle paintings - will sit high on a ramp above the cavernous entrance to the new gallery. They will be the first thing visitors see when they enter the turbine hall. The Bourgeois commission is a huge coup for the Tate Modern, which hopes to better the Pompidou Centre in Paris as the best modern art gallery in Europe. The Tate's director Nicholas Serota said he was thrilled that Bourgeois had agreed to make the £1.5m towers. "A new gallery offers new opportunities for artists and audiences." Arguably the greatest woman artist of the 20th century, Bourgeois was born in 1911 in Paris. She was a pupil of Leger in Paris in her youth, and counted such Surrealist and modernist legends as Miro, Breton, Duchamp and Le Corbusier among her friends. But for most of her life Bourgeois was best known as Mrs Robert Goldwater, the wife of one of America's most influential art historians.

Strongly influenced by the feminist movement, she first came to notice in the sixties with her tall wooden, marble and bronze sexually-charged sculptures.

fields.headline: Londoners back 'independent' Livingstone for mayor
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone would win a resounding victory if he stood as an independent candidate for mayor of London, according to a poll published today.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone would win a resounding victory if he stood as an independent candidate for mayor of London, according to a poll published today.

The ICM poll showed that if Mr Livingstone stood against Labour's official candidate Frank Dobson 50% of voters would back the former GLC leader against 22% for Mr Dobson, Tony Blair's preferred candidate.

According to the poll, in today's London Evening Standard newspaper, 61% of people questioned thought Mr Livingstone should stand as an independent after narrowly losing the Labour vote yesterday, with only 21% saying he should withdraw.

Mr Livingstone's supporters and opponents inside the Labour party today urged the former GLC leader not to split the party by standing against Mr Dobson.

Livingstone supporter Diane Abbott, Labour MP for Hackney North and Stoke Newington, called for Mr Livingstone to stay inside the party and said she would be supporting all the Labour candidates, including Mr Dobson, as she had done in London for years.

She also said that Mr Dobson should "think very hard" about quitting as Labour's official candidate after his narrow victory over Mr Livingstone. After a second ballot Mr Dobson received 51.5% against 48.5% for Mr Livingstone. His victory was secured by the party's controversial weighted electoral college even though Mr Livingstone won 60% of ordinary London Labour members' votes and was backed by all the trade unions that balloted members.

"With the London mayoral contest you don't have to look into a crystal ball, you can read the book," Ms Abbott said. "In Wales, [former assembly first secretary] Alun Michael was in this precise position. What happened was, he went on to the assembly elections, he saw the Labour vote collapse and within 12 months the whole thing has unravelled.

"I think there's no doubt that Ken stands a very good chance of winning as an independent. He has led in the polls for two straight years. There's no doubt he can win.

"If Ken declares as an independent candidate at the end of this week, Frank Dobson's career as a prospective mayor of London will have lasted really just seven days."

Mr Livingstone, who dismissed Mr Dobson's narrow victory as "tainted", yesterday announced a self-imposed vow of silence to take time to "listen to Londoners" before making any further statement.

Today's poll offers the first clear encouragement to Mr Livingstone as he contemplates an independent candidacy after his narrow defeat.

It showed that most people believe Mr Dobson won the bitter contest to be Labour's official candidate unfairly, with 53% saying the rules were rigged to stop Mr Livingstone. Only 15% thought Mr Dobson won fairly.

However, the survey also said that if Mr Livingstone did not stand, Mr Dobson would still beat the other candidates in the contest.

Asked how they would vote in an election without Mr Livingstone, 44% of people said Labour, 27% Conservative, 18% Liberal Democrat, 6% Green and 5% for Malcolm McLaren, the independent candidate.

Mr Dobson launched his formal campaign today with a hectic schedule of TV and radio appearances in which he continued to dismiss suggestions that he should stand down.

"Like Glenda Jackson and Ken Livingstone, I agreed that I would abide by the outcome, I am abiding by the outcome, Glenda is abiding by the outcome and I think that Ken will as well," he said.

Mr Dobson confirmed that Mr Blair had rung him yesterday to congratulate him, but the former health secretary moved to dispel the criticism that he is No 10's "poodle" by emphasising that he had immediately pointed out to the prime minister that London needed a "great deal" of help.

"We need additional resources for the police, we need other help. He is going to have to provide that. I did say to him if he is not willing to provide that then he is going to have a fight on his hands and I will be leading that fight," Mr Dobson said.

fields.headline: The pro-Clinton factor
fields.standfirst:
Americans want to forgive and move on. Republicans forget this
The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: The ranks of the loyalist Republicans should scarce forbear to cheer. The comeback of GW Bush in South Carolina's Saturday primary against the in-your-face insurgent John McCain was a relief to the party bosses, who have staked all on GW - but they should have seen the smiles on the faces of Al Gore's men in the Democratic encampments.
fields.body:
The ranks of the loyalist Republicans should scarce forbear to cheer. The comeback of GW Bush in South Carolina's Saturday primary against the in-your-face insurgent John McCain was a relief to the party bosses, who have staked all on GW - but they should have seen the smiles on the faces of Al Gore's men in the Democratic encampments.

The Democrats reckon that McCain, a maverick with a chest full of medals, a wise-cracking mouth and an appeal to the independent voters proven once again, would have been harder to beat in the general election. The latest poll suggests they are right. In presidential trial heats just conducted by CNN/USA Today/Gallup, Al Gore is at 45% and Bush at 50% but McCain romps away with 55% against Gore's 39%. The most recent ABC/Washington Post poll, taken between February 3 and 6 shows that with Pat Buchanan taking 5% for the Reform party - and he looks set to be the nominee - Bush and Gore are at a statistical dead heat.

Of course, the Republican scrap is not over yet. McCain will almost surely win his native state of Arizona next Tuesday and he has the edge the same day in Michigan where Bush will not be able to play Onward Christian Soldiers at the volume he did in South Carolina, where the rightwing Christian Coalition is well organised. But even if McCain wins in Michigan he faces another blitz of negative advertising and the superior resources of the Bush campaign in getting out the Republican vote on a succession of Super Tuesdays in March when many states votes.

While the Republican leaders have been sticking needles in models of John McCain, something else has been going on. Al Gore, the Democratic frontrunner, has been gaining in popularity. It is a safe bet that he has squashed the challenge from Bill Bradley, a clever and likable man who has somehow come over as a patronising whiner: folks, how privileged you are to be able to vote for me.

And now a Gore presidency is not the chimera it was thought a few months ago. The polls vary, but all agree that Gore has gained from three to five points in the last month. What is going on? Gore is coming over as a man who knows his stuff - and is less stuffy. The Bradley challenge has roused him to fight. The common wisdom has been that his experience and decency won't count because reference to eight years in the White House will remind everyone that he stood loyally by a liar. The Republicans have been playing this "Clinton fatigue" hard. Bush and McCain have been competing over who is the most unlike Clinton. Most commenta tors have bought into this leprosy theory.

I wonder.

Just as during the impeachment crisis, the public does not parrot what it is told it is supposed to be thinking. A little publicised poll by Gallup/CNN/USA Today, taken between February 2 and 15, finds Clinton's job approval rate at 62%; Fox News/Opinion Dynamics has it at a phenomenal 66%. Bill Clinton has been a very successful president: but for the 22nd amendment he might well have run and won a third term.

The good times are the principal reason for this, but there has also been a deepening realisation that there was indeed a rightwing plot to bring him down. A majority wants to forgive and forget Clinton's lapses and that was before the publication of a best selling book by the non-partisan journalist and lawyer Jeffrey Toobin. In A Vast Conspiracy, Toobin has coolly unravelled how extremists of the political right tried to use the legal system to undo Clinton's election. Clinton certainly had a less than fair press which constantly had its ear cocked, and its critical faculties suspended, for any leak from Ken Starr's prosecutorial team. fields.headline: Pinochet lawyer to become judge
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The lawyer who represented the Chilean government in the Pinochet case in the House of Lords will make legal history next October when he becomes the first solicitor to be appointed a high court judge straight from practice in a law firm.
fields.body:
The lawyer who represented the Chilean government in the Pinochet case in the House of Lords will make legal history next October when he becomes the first solicitor to be appointed a high court judge straight from practice in a law firm.

Lawrence Collins QC is only the second solicitor to reach the high court bench, but the first to move there from private practice. The only other former solicitor, Sir Michael Sachs, was a circuit judge for nine years before he was promoted to the high court in 1993.

High court judgeships were reserved for barristers until 1990, when restrictive practices in the legal profession were swept away and solicitors won the right to appear as advocates in the higher courts and sit on the high court bench.

But successive lord chancellors, including Lord Irvine, have come under fire from the Law Society, the solicitors' professional body, for the slow pace of change. Last year the society pulled out of the consultation process for selecting judges and QCs, claiming the system of "secret soundings" among senior legal figures discriminates against solicitors. Lord Irvine said yesterday: "I am delighted that we have been able to make a little history with this appointment. Lawrence Collins is an outstanding practitioner and a highly respected legal scholar here and abroad."

Mr Collins, 58, a partner with the City law firm Herbert Smith, has been a solicitor since 1968 and in 1997 was one of the first two practising solicitors to be appointed QCs. Only two others have made it since.

A specialist in international law, he acted for Chile, which was allowed to intervene when the question of General Pinochet's right to state immunity from prosecution over crimes against humanity went to the Lords for the second time last January.

He argued on Chile's behalf that when the UK, Spain and Chile signed up to the international torture convention they had not intended to waive the immunity enjoyed by former heads of state.

Mr Collins has been a fellow of Wolfson college, Cambridge, since 1975, was made a visiting professor at Queen Mary and Westfield college, University of London, in 1982, and was awarded a doctorate in law from Cambridge university in 1994. He has also written books on international and European law.

fields.headline: Time to go, boys...
fields.standfirst: ...and they went
fields.trailText: On February 9, Kamran Abbasi called for the resignation of Wasim Akram and Sachin Tendulkar. Wasim responded immediately, stepping down the next day. But Tendulkar managed to hold out until last weekend, when he announced he'd be going at the end of India's series against South Africa. Here's a reminder of how Abbasi persuaded them to give it up
fields.body:
On February 9, Kamran Abbasi called for the resignation of Wasim Akram and Sachin Tendulkar. Wasim responded immediately, stepping down the next day. But Tendulkar managed to hold out until last weekend, when he announced he'd be going at the end of India's series against South Africa. Here's a reminder of how Abbasi persuaded them to give it up

Two wounded soldiers are roaming South Asia. They are the mightiest, but their power is waning. They are bursting with pride, but their will is weakening. They are the most acclaimed, but their lustre is fading. They are, of course, deadbeat captains, Sachin and Wasim, but no one will put them out of their misery; nor us out of ours.

Between them they might just have presided over the biggest disaster in South Asian cricket history. "No," I hear you cry ("Nahin" if you speak Hindi or Urdu). But my response is "yes". The South Asians were like cornered sheep in the face of Australia's rampant tiger: devoured at will.

I am lamenting the humiliation of two modern-day cricket superpowers, for that is what they aspire to be. It is not enough to have the most fanatical fans, or keep banging on about possessing the best natural talent. That does no good on the cricket field or in the dressing room, where the captain is the head cheerleader and chief scout.

I am bemoaning the ruin of a hard-fought legacy bequeathed by Imran Khan and Javed Miandad, Kapil Dev and Sunil Gavaskar. It was in their time that South Asian teams toughened up; no longer an easy five-wicket haul or a quick double-hundred. But Sachin and Wasim, god bless their Pepsi deals and Nike swooshes, have dumped their worshipping nations back in the 1970s.

You might suggest mitigating circumstances: myopic cricket boards, sterile domestic cricket, and oppressive supporters; while their tours of Australia have been blighted by poor umpiring, and off-the-field hostilities. But these are mere excuses, used and abused to keep the captains in power, their loyal lieutenants in post, and their challengers in the wilderness.

Sachin is cultured in his strokeplay and his outlook. But as a captain he shrinks in stature, and his batting loses that crucial ten per cent extra that can lift him above all others. His approach becomes defensive and indecisive. His body language says: "I don't want to be doing this." One game he hides down the order; the next, in response to criticism, he unnecessarily promotes himself to open. "Five out, all out," is the way the Australians viewed England last winter. For India, it's worse: "One out, all out."

Sachin is a great player, but he is made mortal by the captaincy. It is uninspiring - his Indians certainly didn't show much grit. And his decision-making, like Wasim's, is influenced by personal grudges. Look no further than Mohammad Azharuddin sitting at home while India's middle order is roasted. Step aside Sachin, and get back to your glorious best; let in the passion and determination of Lancashire's very own Prince of Calcutta, Sourav Ganguly.

Wasim is much different from Sachin. He is an engaging and effervescent character. He has bursts of inspiration where his team responds, but those glorious moments are ever rarer. Where once a flash of genius would follow a moment of fury, his demeanour is now mostly one of pent-up rage. Not the calm control of a born leader, but a sharp word here, an angry glare there. And Wasim is a big complainer: his misfiring batsmen and bowlers; his butter-fingered fielders; incompetent umpires; and shoddy administrators. These are all regular targets, though sledging, the latest whinge, is the most laughable.

But Wasim has been captain countless times. He is highly experienced, and has been working with the same bunch of players for almost a year. Yet he can't get them to play as a cohesive unit. Tactically he is weak, and his amateur psychology ("The Australians will crack under pressure") is embarrassing. Time to hand over the captain's blazer to the team's beating heart: if Wasim can't, Moin Khan.

Sachin and Wasim are great players; great captains they are not. Humbly, they should rejoin the rank and file, giving their teams a chance to regenerate. The likelihood of either standing down or being sacked is slim. But that is exactly what is needed. Even if India defeat South Africa, and Pakistan beat Sri Lanka in the forthcoming home Test series, they shouldn't be absolved.

"The art of leadership is saying no, not yes," wrote Tony Blair. The question is: "Will you stay on?" The answer? Repeat after me boys: "Nahin, nahin, nahin."

Kamran Abbasi, born in Lahore, brought up in Rotherham, is assistant editor of the British Medical Journal. His Anglo-Asian View appears every other Wednesday on Cricket Unlimited and wisden.com.

fields.headline: The best showdown scene
fields.standfirst: A Room for Romeo Brass
fields.trailText: A Room for Romeo Brass
fields.body:
As Romeo (Andrew Shim), and Morell (Paddy Considine) sit in the former's living room, Romeo's estranged father Joe (Frank Harper) enters. Taking it upon himself to intervene, Morell instructs Joe to "go and stand by the back door or something".

"Oh I fucking need you, don't I?" Joe sighs. "Jesus Christ."

"I just don't think you should be in here, mate, so why don't you just leave? It's obvious Romeo don't want you here. You can leave nicely or you can leave 'orribly. It's up to you."

Joe is incredulous.

"Sorry?"

"Do you want to go nicely or would you like to go 'orribly?"

Joe bursts out laughing.

"What you laughing at?"

"You're gonna throw me out?"

"Yeah, I will throw you out."

Joe is in hysterics.

"You're fucking priceless, you are."

"What's so funny?"

"Look, I know you're just trying to give it large in front of the boy, but unfortunately I ain't leaving. So you're gonna have to throw me out."

"Romeo, just get your gear and come and stay with me. You don't have to stay with this douchebag."

Joe turns to Romeo as he leaves the room.

"What you doing hanging around with a prick like him?"

Morell squares up to Joe.

"What you calling me naughty names for?"

See also: Face/Off, The Magnificent Seven, Enter The Dragon, Westworld

Don't see also: Money Talks

fields.headline: Milan fashion shows begin
fields.trailText: Milan fashion week, which began this weekend, is often seen as a sensible contrast to the antics of London's maverick designers. But Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana of the Dolce & Gabbana house are two designers who consistently do their best to inject some teen spirit into fashion's biggest financial capital - and yesterday's show for their younger, less expensive D&G label was no exception.
fields.body:
Milan fashion week, which began this weekend, is often seen as a sensible contrast to the antics of London's maverick designers. But Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana of the Dolce & Gabbana house are two designers who consistently do their best to inject some teen spirit into fashion's biggest financial capital - and yesterday's show for their younger, less expensive D&G label was no exception.

Combination seemed to be the motto of these designers. Even before the first model appeared, the set hinted at a hotchpotch of references: an English-style garden pond with flower borders, garden gnomes and a Snow White fountain had been installed next to a drum kit with leopard skin stool and rotating disco balls. In a white wall covered in colourful, nonsensical doodles and graffiti was a door covered Mediterranean-style with a bead curtain, festooned with silk flowers.

But when the models finally appeared, the clothes effortlessly upstaged the set: this was punk crossed with the Bay City Rollers, 1960s Carnaby Street and a home counties garden party all rolled into one. Tartan, which is emerging as a strong trend for the season, featured in capes, mini-kilts and silver-studded shirts with outsize collars. Hand-painted floor length shearling coats, deconstructed denim micro-skirts, graffiti tights and tight trousers were all tailor-made for the wealthy rebel, while cute patterns - butterflies on pink chiffon, curled-up kittens on lemon, ladybirds on blue - looked anything but demure when worn head-to-toe on stiletto heels, tights, curve-hugging pencil skirt, belt, blouse and bag.

The early part of the week is given over largely to such diffusion lines - more available, less expensive lines. Key diffusion labels include Versus by Versace, Philosophy by Alberta Ferretti and Emporio Armani by Giorgio Armani. The more exclusive labels come into play later in the week.

webTitle: Smiths tries buy and fly service

fields.headline: Smiths tries buy and fly service
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: WH Smith has opened a pilot store at Leeds city station offering customers everything from email facilities to airline and rail tickets - plus the chance to buy any book from the 1.3m currently in print, for collection as your plane touches down.
fields.body:
WH Smith has opened a pilot store at Leeds city station offering customers everything from email facilities to airline and rail tickets - plus the chance to buy any book from the 1.3m currently in print, for collection as your plane touches down.

If the trial is successful WH Smith plans to export the concept of books.co around the world. The group is already one of the biggest global airport chains and is working on plans for a second books.co outlet for Chicago.

The initiative is just the latest in a series of e-commerce ventures for WH Smith, which is attempting to cash in on the strength of its traditional brand name. The chain last year generated substantial enthusiasm among analysts and investors, when it first announced its web plans, and its shares peaked at 792p. But they have since fallen back rapidly to 315p and the group has even been touted as a possible takeover target.

WH Smith now claims to be the only retailer in the world to offer its wares through all possible retail channels - the high street, the internet, interactive television and the new generation of Wap (wireless application protocol) technology.

The company currently has 10% of the UK online book market, which is thought to be worth some £55m, but is committed to winning 20% within three years.

The total UK book market - of which WH Smith controls about 25% - is valued at around £1.2bn.

It hopes to boost its online sales further with the introduction this week of its full range of stationery products to cyber-buyers.

The new Leeds books.co store is believed to have shot through initial sales targets - partly due to the fact that it is located just a few minutes' walk from a nurses' home. Student nurses have been using the service to order speciality textbooks, which would normally take weeks to arrive or require a visit to a specialist medical bookshop.

Teamtalk Marc Overmars will join Barcelona in the summer, according to Spanish newspaper El Mundo Reportivo. Overmars's agent Rob Jansen has agreed "contractual and economical terms" with Nou Camp boss Louis van Gaal.

Leeds have denied they are in the running for 19-year-old Brazilian striker Ronaldinho. The Gremio player would cost £20m.

Southampton have abandoned their interest in Colin Hendry, as they cannot afford the player's wage demands.

fields.headline: Keep up
fields.standfirst: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here
fields.trailText: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here
fields.body:
Allen Weiner www.forbes.com
According to data from Nielsen/NetRatings, the new breed of continuous, multimedia news outlets - ZDNet, MSNBC and CNet - all had larger audiences in December than the largest online newspaper, USA Today.

In order to survive online, the mentality needs to be far more 24-hour-a-day news radio and far less Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein. The battle for online news eyeballs is far from over.

Newspapers have maintained their position in the market by providing a high-quality product and developing a reputation for being the top information providers in their localities. It's time for the print folks to wash the ink off their hands and jump onto the web with both feet.

Leslie Walker, www.washingtonpost.com
The New York Times's decision to sell stock in its internet operation, and publisher Donald E Graham's decision to relinquish day-to-day management of the Washington Post to spend more time on internet strategy, are signs that the newspaper industry is struggling to reinvent itself in cyberspace.

Newspaper companies are working hard to ensure that if digital products do cannibalise newspapers, they themselves own those internet cannibals. They are pouring money into their own electronic news services in an attempt to re-create online their core mission of providing information.

The threat newspapers are facing, though, will intensify as next-generation portable computer devices and screens hit the market, making reading online more convenient and easier on the eyes.

That will spawn more competition from web upstarts and may accelerate the shift of ad revenue to digital media. The weak spot for newspapers is their classified ads, which make up 40% of the industry's revenue. It also doesn't help that most web content is free.

That's the backdrop for the Times' announcement last Friday that it will issue a tracking stock for its internet division, allowing the public to buy shares in Times Company Digital, its new-media subsidiary. Unfortunately for the Times, the attempt to mine dot-com gold on Wall Street comes as investors are growing more selective. Falling lowest have been "content" sites - those whose main stock is news and information.

Their stocks have underperformed web retailers and portals. The heavy spending by both the Times (over $35m in nine months) and the Post ($85m last year) shows how important the cyber-game is to them. The Times plans to use the new shares to reward Web employees, buy other internet companies and expand as nimbly and as fast as internet start-ups.

webTitle: One year on from the Macpherson report

fields.headline: One year on from the Macpherson report
fields.standfirst: Hanif Kureishi and Ahdaf Soueif on race in Britain
fields.trailText:
Hanif Kureishi
It's deplorable that Stephen Lawrence's murder happened - I was brought up in that part of south London and it's very monocultural, very masculinist and rough. On the other hand, the fact that Labour came to power probably had a great effect on the attitudes of the police, in that they had to pursue racism with more seriousness. The main reason the institutions have changed - they have begun to - is down to the Labour government, much as one hates to admit it. So it isn't that racism has diminished, it's that it isn't allowed.
fields.body:
Hanif Kureishi
It's deplorable that Stephen Lawrence's murder happened - I was brought up in that part of south London and it's very monocultural, very masculinist and rough. On the other hand, the fact that Labour came to power probably had a great effect on the attitudes of the police, in that they had to pursue racism with more seriousness. The main reason the institutions have changed - they have begun to - is down to the Labour government, much as one hates to admit it. So it isn't that racism has diminished, it's that it isn't allowed.

It's quite interesting that the Daily Mail took up the Stephen Lawrence case and that middle England is more tolerant; or at least the penny has dropped that we're not going to go away.

The papers have reverted to type over the Afghan hijack refugees - it's Middle English hysteria. Though if you really ask people about that they are probably much more tolerant about it than the papers. It was interesting that far from complaining, the Tory MP for the area where the refugees were sent temporarily welcomed them.

I certainly think Britain is more liberal than many European countries - in France, for instance, there's far more xenophobia. And I think it's something that will improve. When I was a kid I was the only Asian in school and some teachers were racist. Now my kids' schools are very mixed and that isn't tolerated. The whole country has become more liberal.

I feel much more optimistic than before. That's partly because racist attitudes, which will always continue, are considered to be anathema. You can't get away with it. Even if you continue to think it in private, you can't get away with it in public. It's not tolerated in institutions and that's the most important thing.

Ahdaf Soueif
I should think that in terms of awareness, race is a more high profile issue. How that filters through to how people feel about race is a different question.

There have been big reports before, like the Scott inquiry, and before that the Warnock inquiry. Every time it's as if this is some amazing revelation which creates a change in the national psyche, and things can never be the same again.

I don't know how true that is. But a hunch would be that where you have a situation like we are seeing in Britain now - where there is a sizeable underclass even compared to 10 years ago, where you have a whole mass of people who are poor, who have never held down a job, who are desocialised and disenfranchised - it's extremely unlikely that you're going to find a general shift in attitudes towards tolerance.

While maybe there is a change in public awareness and a position that the elite and the educated and the upper middle classes take, whether things like that filter all the way throughout society I would very much doubt.

The media try, on the whole, to do the fair thing, and this is going to become more of an issue as you see more Asian faces in the media. You see so many names now from the sub-continent, that this on its own is going to change things.

But the Afro-Caribbean and black African community is far less represented. There's a perception that Asian people work hard and do well, but black people don't.

For instance, a great deal was made of the fact that Stephen Lawrence was an A-level student, as if he was not just like all those other black kids you see hanging around the streets.

The Macpherson report brought the problem centre stage. People have paid attention to it. But what happens next?

 Interviews by Esther Addley

fields.headline: Screen saver
fields.standfirst:
As Channel 4 moves into the
multi-media age with the launch
of its new interactive arm, Andy Anson tells Imogen O'Rorke about his plans to make the future personal
fields.trailText: As Channel 4 moves into the multi-media age with the launch of its new interactive arm, Andy Anson tells Imogen O'Rorke about his plans to make the future personal
fields.body:
Would you trust Channel 4 to plan Valentine's night 2001 for you? From the movie you watch, to where you eat, club, right down to the new shirt you wear and the gift you give - all vetted, booked and paid for through the network? In an ideal world, you might even have met your date through the online singles service.

The potential for brand extensions in the digital entertainment age is boundless. In June, Michael Jackson, chief executive of Channel 4, announced his intention of turning it into a fully realised multi-media company and to double online spending. The interactive department was launched in January, with £10m and six new businesses, under the control of Andy Anson, who had previously worked at Disney. The prize project is E4, a multi-tiered interactive entertainment platform.

The offices of strategic planning on the third floor of Channel 4's headquarters at Horseferry Road in London have been the site of much blue-sky brainstorming in recent months. First, the future was broadband (interactive cable and satellite), then ADSL (high speed video access via telephone lines), then WAP (wireless application protocol); now it's a combination of all three and the medium is no longer relevant. The sky is the limit: except that was so last year. "Sky got Open up and running first and opened up people's minds to the potential of interactive TV," says Anson, who hopes to overtake BSkyB's interactive service when E4 launches in November. Anson will also be up against BBC Online and ONdigital, which will launch an interactive TV-internet package in June. Channel 5 also wants to join the race.

E4 will cover all the traditional ground - music, film, education, comedy, clubbing, shopping and fashion - while remaining true, Anson insists, to Channel 4's core values. "The slogan for E4 is 'Friday night every night'," he says (although this phrase has already been taken by the rival Paramount Comedy Channel). In other words, your favourite American sitcom and the usual after-hours music and clubbing fare will be available "on demand". E4 will be the window to watch Friends (which it has just outbid Sky to win), Dawson's Creek, Ally McBeal and ER. Before the envelope-lickers out there start firing off letters about the Mickey Mouse-ification of their trusty public service channel, it should be pointed out that Anson, who was head of consumer products at Disney, is British and understands Channel 4's rather quirky audience. "The idea is to use the web as a breeding ground for new talent, ideas and innovation - we're looking for the next Ali G," Anson says. "Four used to be renowned for that, but since it's got a little more established, it's lost some of that edge." On the way back to that edge, Anson says he will take risks and "not be scared to screw up".

Increased commercialisation, as e-commerce becomes a major revenue stream, will mean a bespoke service for the viewer. "People are consuming media in a more niched fashion, getting music through a music channel, for example."

E4 will build up a profile of each customer so that it can target programmes and even adverts. "When you start mixing entertainment and service, then you have a pretty potent mix . . . you get closer to individuals than a broadcaster can ever get."

Personal TV, which is what this adds up to, is already a familiar concept in the US, where companies such as TiVo and Replay offer video downloads on a pay-per-storage-time model. When E4 develops into broadband on the internet, viewers could be issued with a smart card that works on a pay-per-view basis, at a rate of, say, 50p for each programme.

Channel 4's tireless pursuit of the consumer ("We have to be where-ever the consumer is consuming the things we offer," Anson says), and its desire to be the very spout of innovation, have prompted this move into an untried market. WebTV has only just been unveiled by Microsoft, so Britain is ahead of the US in large-scale interactive thinking. In the US, the combined audience share of the networks has plummeted, due to the fragmentation of the market and people forsaking the box for the net. "It's not happening as quickly over here because people still have that four channel mentality, but it's when the next generation of kids, the Sony addicts, grow up that the pressure will hit traditional broadcasters," says Anson. With Channel 4's audience share down 1% in the past five years, Anson shares Jackson's "adapt to survive" attitude. "I think the erosion of our share is inevitable. We just have to make sure that if anyone is eating into our market share, it's us."

In the interactive arena, the competition includes BBC Online (which has a clear lead on news) and Channel 5 (which, with a 5% terrestrial market share and "the three Fs" - football, films and fucking - is eyeing a substantial chunk of Channel 4's share), as well as smaller companies such as Paramount and Atom films, a US company which can already stream short movies to your PC.

To take these on will require outside resources. "We can't do it on our own - partnering is absolutely key. This is going to be a new experience for Four, which has always been one company, one channel in the public sector." Anson has been talking to everyone, from Warner Bros to Sony, to Emap, to Bob Geldof's mobile company and ISPs such as Yahoo and AOL. The challenge to keep the brand intact during all these changes will be greater than ever. Channel 4 has built customer loyalty by providing high-quality, ready-packaged broadcasting. Video-on-demand would be equivalent to an upmarket confectioner going pick 'n' mix. But Anson is adamant they have to "embrace the future rather than run away. My guess is you'll still havelinear TV channels, but you'll have to offer video-on-demand as well - with Channel 4 packages on the menu."

It is Anson's responsibility to ensure that all the programmes and talent are "in the C4 world". This might lead to alliances with smaller production companies and individual talent; and a desire to stick to the niches it knows best. Comedy will be represented by the faces of Dominic Jolly, Ali G and Smack the Pony, drama by the cast of Queer as Folk, sport by cricket and racing.

A betting channel and a lesbian and gay network out4life.com will appear before E4. The February launch of out4life, for the Queer as Folk mindset, has been postponed a couple of months "to get it right". And Anson is pleased that Channel 4 has just beaten Sky to the horse racing rights. "It's a no brainer," he says, but very lucrative.

Film 4 interactive and an education channel (a tricky area because the Discovery Channel has such a strong foothold) will be next, introducing radical new schemes such as a tutorial for 16- to 24-year-olds who want to learn how to be a movie director or record producer.

With replay TV at the touch of a button, will that Friday-night institution Friends ever be the same again? "I think the social side of TV, what the Americans call the watercooler effect, is going to make linear [broadcasting through channels] stick around," says Anson. "The value of Friends will actually go up as the value of good content becomes more and more important." Soaps and pop drama series could become even more vicariously addictive as audiences start to get interactive with plot lines. One proposed serialisation of the movie Human Traffic might run with a competition where viewers can submit MP3 mixes for next week's jingle. She's Gotta Have It, the fashion show in which contestants are given a budget to buy whatever they like, could turn into a very expensive night in with credit card interfaces.

But while life will be easier for the viewers, with a million more reasons to stay on the sofa, advertisers will have to totally rethink their modes of communication. Banner adverts, say experts, are not as effective on the internet and can be edited out by video streaming. "A huge change is coming here," says Anson. "Ad sales departments will have to think about personalised ads, brand affiliation and sponsorship - not just the usual cost per thousand mentality."

With E4, Film Four, out4life.com and "education 4" growing up alongside the parent channel, is it only a matter of time before they become the main trunk of the station? "The future is uncertain for broadcasting," says Anson. "We've got to hedge our bets and think: we've got a great brand, so let's put it wherever it needs to be for the future."
