fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.trailText: 'Our school never has the money to do fun things for the kids. None of the schools in Hackney do," says Laurel Lynch, 37, senior administrator at Northwold primary school. "We fundraise so we can do something nice - take the kids to the seaside or buy them ice-lollies on sports day.
fields.body:
'Our school never has the money to do fun things for the kids. None of the schools in Hackney do," says Laurel Lynch, 37, senior administrator at Northwold primary school. "We fundraise so we can do something nice - take the kids to the seaside or buy them ice-lollies on sports day. A lot of our kids haven't been out of Hackney, let alone to the seaside. Many of the parents are on income support - they don't have money for treats. That's why we fundraise."

Based on the edge of Northwold estate in Upper Clapton, east London, the school has 436 pupils from a working-class, multi-ethnic background including Turks, Bosnians, Asians, Kurds and Afro-Caribbeans - only around 10% of the children are white. Lynch has been helping to run fundraising schemes for the 10 years she has been in her job.

"We do fundraising through the tuck shop twice a week, selling sherbets, liquorices and crisps. We recently introduced school uniform, and a shopkeeper who sells it comes into the school and sets up shop and donates a percentage of his takings.

"When we fundraise we don't have any money to start with. At a push we might have £50. Another secretary and I will get the Yellow Pages and get on to all the local shops asking for donations. Even if they give us a bag of crisps or a loaf of bread, we're happy. You have to know what you want, then you just have to go out and ask for it. I haven't been lucky enough to get a colour TV or a hi-fi but I have tried!" she laughs.

"We'll use the donations in various ways: we can sell raffle tickets and give them away as prizes, or we can auction them to the parents. I get the job of auctioneer - I do everything because I've got the biggest mouth."

Not all fundraising attempts are successful, however. "We held car boot sales where each car pays £5 for a space, but we didn't make much. Then we tried selling table space at jumble sales - that wasn't very successful either! It can be quite demoralising sometimes."

When trying to raise cash, think creatively, she advises - often people are more willing to empty their pockets when they are enjoying themselves. "Our children like dancing so we have an international day when they can dress up in international clothes. We'll have dance competitions and provide food and drink for the parents." Lynch is a keen singer who performs at local venues and has recently been signed up with an agent - often she will sing at a school event and charge a small admission fee.

"Fundraising is something you have to really want to do - it's time-consuming, and you have to give up weekends and evenings, so you must be dedicated."

webTitle: Entrepreneurial trio launch tech investment fund

fields.headline: Entrepreneurial trio launch tech investment fund
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Three of the UK's most successful entrepreneurs this morning attempt to add an internet fortune to those they have already made in property, media and computer games.
fields.body:
Three of the UK's most successful entrepreneurs this morning attempt to add an internet fortune to those they have already made in property, media and computer games.

Eidos's chief executive, Charles Cornwall, former Carlton managing director Mike Luckwell and property developer John Beckwith are investing £9m of their own money in Convergence Holdings, which begins trading on the junior stock market, Aim, today.

The company plans to invest in the converging technologies of the internet, digital television and other new media formats. Its initial investments include a 75% interest in Invest TV, which produces the Simply Money television channel, a California based incubator fund and a wireless technology company.

Mr Cornwall's involvement in the business is likely to increase the speculation about his long-term future at Eidos, which he transformed from a £2m video compression company into a £600m computer games developer.

Today he is based mainly in Los Angeles, leaving most of the day to day management of the company to the London management and owns less than 3% of the business.

Eidos, creator of the Tomb Raider series of games, recently issued a profits warning which wiped more than a third off its market value.

Mr Luckwell said: "All three of us have spent our entire working careers successfully identifying and then developing highly valuable investment opportunities. By coupling our experience and contacts with the explosion of opportunities thrown up by the convergence of digital technology, and particularly the internet, we are creating a powerful investment vehicle."

Mr Luckwell was managing director of Carlton between 1983 and 1986, and is a non-executive director of children's television producer HIT Entertainment. Mr Beckwith, the uncle of society celebrity Tamara Beckwith, founded the London & Edinburgh Trust property company which was sold for £510m in 1990. He is also the major shareholder in Sports & Outdoor Media, which is at present the subject of a bid approach.

Investec Henderson Crosthwaite is broker to the float.

webTitle: Surging Freeserve plans a buying spree

fields.headline: Surging Freeserve plans a buying spree
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Freeserve, Britain's largest internet service provider is planning a buying spree using its soaring share price as currency.
fields.body:
Freeserve, Britain's largest internet service provider is planning a buying spree using its soaring share price as currency.

The company, valued at £1.5bn when it floated last year, is now worth nearly £8bn - more than British Airways. Its share price has risen from 150p at its launch to 769p at close of trading on Friday.

In reports over the weekend, chief executive John Pluthero said the decision to float had been a deliberate strategy to fund an acquisitions spree. Dixons, which has an 80% stake in Freeserve, is understood to have declined to put any more money into the operation.

"We floated to get a currency we could use. With the shares getting to the kind of value they are now, we can use that currency to put together the properties and elements we need," Mr Pluthero told the Observer.

He declined to name targets but said several were under consideration. "We've identified a number of areas where we want to acquire the right kind of capabilities. Sometimes they're quite small and sometimes they're pretty big."

Separate reports speculated that the German internet service provider, T-online which will be spun off from Deutsche Telekom this spring, could be Freeserve's first purchase. T-online already owns Club Internet a French ISP, and an alliance would make Freeserve the largest ISP in Europe.

Mr Pluthero said yesterday that content was a big concern in its acquisitions strategy, pointing to the huge AOL-Time Warner deal as a model. "It was a smart move. When you put content and platform together you create an even richer seam."

Last month Freeserve played down reports that it had been in talks with the troubled children's publisher, Dorling Kindersley. Freeserve's current offerings include travel, insurance, books, electrical goods and an auction site.

Mr Pluthero's other ambitions include introducing unmetered Internet access to the UK, along American lines. "I'm sure we'll get to the position soon where poeple are being charged between £10 and £15 for as much Internet access as they want."

BT has already announced it plans to introduce an unlimited internet access provider in the spring.

Launched in September 1998 as part of Dixons, Freeserve now has nearly 1.7m registered users. In January it produced the strongest set of figures in its short history, but like almost all internet companies, it is still trading in the red.

Pre-tax losses in the quarter to November stood at £3.6m on a turnover of £3.8m.

Analysts say a strong brand and its distribution network through Dixons helped it bounce back from the turmoil in the hi-tech stock market at the beginning of the year. Dixons preloads about 90% of its PCs with Freeserve's software, with the result that it is the ISP on almost a quarter of all new PCs in the UK.

Mr Pluthero said that the company is planning anadvertising campaign next month, including using television spots for the first time.

The company has also signed a deal to provide internet services to the new wireless application protocol mobile phones, (Wap) phones, due out soon.

fields.headline: Check the safety catch
fields.trailText: Jenny Bacon is simply wrong to suggest that the HSE has an evidence-based prosecution policy. The number of companies and directors prosecuted is not determined by whether there is sufficient evidence to prosecute, or indeed whether corporate criminal conduct has resulted in death or major injury, but simply on whether it can afford to prosecute.
fields.body:
Jenny Bacon, director general of the health and safety executive, is simply wrong to suggest (Letters, February 18) that the HSE has an evidence-based prosecution policy. The number of companies and directors prosecuted is not determined by whether there is sufficient evidence to prosecute, or indeed whether corporate criminal conduct has resulted in death or major injury, but simply on whether it can afford to prosecute. Our evidence to the select committee - not challenged by the HSE - indicated that from 1996 to 98, over 4,400 companies escaped prosecution simply because the HSE could not afford to even investigate the companies responsible for reported workplace amputations, burns and blindings.

We do not believe that every breach of health and safety law should result in a prosecution, but when death or major injury has resulted from criminal negligence, and there is sufficient evidence to prove it, then a prosecution should take place. The HSE's "published prose cution policy" is simply a joke. It is so vague and confused that it could allow the HSE a prosecution in every case or no case at all. In effect, the policy acts to allow the HSE to prosecute when it can afford to do so.

There is no justification for the current situation in which corporations that kill or injure are immune from criminal justice simply because the government is not willing to fund criminal investigations and prosecutions. As George Monbiot indicates (Comment, February 17), there must be a total shift in government priorities on this issue.
David Bergman
Director, Centre for Corporate Accountability david.bergman@mcr1.poptel.org.uk

Companies do kill and get away with it. Unfortunately, the figures cited by George Monbiot seriously under-state the scale of the carnage in British workplaces. His reference to 3,500 deaths over 10 years is based on HSE's highly restrictive definition of a reportable work place fatal injury. My own recent research demonstrates how, using official figures other than those collected by HSE, the actual number of people killed at work is in excess of 3,000 per annum. And this figure does not even attempt to include the thousands who die each year as a result of occupationally caused ill-health.

Monbiot is right to expose the extent to which workplace injuries are under- investigated, too infrequently prosecuted, and how those responsible predominantly evade legal accountability - but an even more telling indictment of political priorities is that we do not even bother to count accurately the numbers who die, let alone sustain serious injury, from working for a living.
Prof Steve Tombs
John Moores University, Liverpool S.P.Tombs1@livjm.ac.uk

Jenny Bacon says the select committee endorsed the HSE as a body which "effectively discharges its statutory functions". That will leave absolutely aghast many who are familiar with the facts. Evidence I presented to the committee, drawn from HSE figures, shows that between 1996-98 only one in 10 of major injuries to workers was investigated by the HSE. Would we say a headteacher or the local police were doing their jobs well if nine out of 10 major injuries in the playground or shopping precinct were left uninvestigated?

No one doubts the sincerity, professionalism and good intentions of HSE officers but the organisation is clearly pitifully resourced and it is impossible for it to fulfill both its educational and law enforcement duties together.
Dr Gary Slapper
Open University G.J.Slapper@open.ac.uk

fields.headline: Cultural studies
fields.trailText:
David Edgar (The perils of populism, February 19) blames the cultural policies of 70s municipal socialists for opening the floodgates to the dumbed down populism of the 90s, by replacing Hamlet, Keats and Beethoven with Dario Fo, Bob Dylan and the Velvet Underground. It is more likely that they would have put Monstrous Regiment, Ivor Cutler and Misty in Roots on the town hall programme. There's a big difference.
Ken Worpole
London
Worpole@dircon.co.uk

The most interesting part of your report on MPs voting records (Blair worst among equals, February 17) was that William Hague had only turned up for 27% of votes since November. You can understand Blair not being able to get to votes often, but what else does Hague have to do? Surely the least he should do for the £100,000 he is paid as leader of the opposition is to vote when he gets the chance.
Richard Burningham
Plymouth

fields.headline: Porn free
fields.trailText: Ros Coward (Sex for the teenagers, February 16) thinks there is porn on Channel 5, through the night. Just being technical, by definition there is no "porn" on any ITC-licensed service (not for long anyway): it would be a breach of licence. If what she means is programmes with sexual content - films, drama or documentaries - then these constitute less than 3% of Channel 5's output, and have never run through the night (since launch, we have scheduled sport through the night, five days out of seven). The only terrestrial channel that has shown erotica through the night is Channel 4.

webTitle: The sky's the limit for high standards

fields.headline: The sky's the limit for high standards
fields.trailText: Your article on the transport select committee's report criticising the government's proposed public-private partnership for National Air Traffic Services (Air control sell-off 'worst option', February 18) states that Gwyneth Dunwoody and her colleagues on the committee were angry at the Civil Aviation Authority's intervention, on the grounds that the CAA is an economic and safety regulator, and it was not appropriate to give the impression that it backed the government's plan.
fields.body:
Your article on the transport select committee's report criticising the government's proposed public-private partnership for National Air Traffic Services (Air control sell-off 'worst option', February 18) states that Gwyneth Dunwoody and her colleagues on the committee were angry at the Civil Aviation Authority's intervention, on the grounds that the CAA is an economic and safety regulator, and it was not appropriate to give the impression that it backed the government's plan.

The CAA gave its evidence to the committee both in its capacity as a 100% owner of Nats and as the safety regulator. As such it was quite entitled and, in the view of many, would have been expected to have an opinion on what organisational form was most appropriate to allow Nats to meet growing user demand for its services in a safe and cost-effective manner. There is no risk that the public-private partnership will compromise safety; the CAA as safety regulator will continue to ensure that rigorous safety standards are maintained.

Complete legal separation of Nats from CAA will only happen after the transport bill has received royal assent.
Sir Malcolm Field
Chairman, Civil Aviation Authority

The report of the select committee is only the latest of many to highlight the problems caused for air traffic control by the continuing growth in air traffic. There seems to be a general acceptance that this will get worse in the coming years.

But why is it assumed that the growth should be allowed to continue unchecked, that increasing demand must be met with more flight paths? It is now generally accepted that we cannot indefinitely build more roads to meet increased demand there. So why should air traffic be any different, particularly if its growth poses a threat to safety?
Tim Lamport
Croydon

webTitle: A long haul, but the Met is winning against racism

fields.headline: A long haul, but the Met is winning against racism
fields.trailText: The article by my friend Michael Mansfield paints a confused view of progress in the police service since publication of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry report. We have travelled a hard road with a considerable journey yet to come.
fields.body:
The article by my friend Michael Mansfield (White on black, February 17) paints a confused view of progress in the police service since publication of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry report. We have travelled a hard road with a considerable journey yet to come.

There are no "broken promises and inaction". Of the 70 recommendations 39 were specific to the Metropolitan police. Of these, 25 have been completed and there is an action plan for the other 14; 20% of the recommendations (that is 15 out of 70) relate to family liaison. We have trained over 800 family liaison officers in under a year at three different levels of skill. Victims and their families have benefited during the nail bombs and the Paddington rail disaster. A measure of our very specific tribute to Mr and Mrs Lawrence's persistence and courage, it is their gift to us all. Everyone in London has benefited.

Critical incident training, community and race relations training, and training for the first hour at a crime scene have all been established. New systems have been developed for intelligence and every borough in London now has a new Community Safety Unit with specialist officers tasked with dealing with these problems. These officers work with the intelligence. Over a 1000% increase of focused, accessible collection of intelligence operations have led to over 150% increase in arrests. One of Mr Mansfield's own recommendations was about intelligence collection.

The Met's Racial and Violent Crime Task Force is now recognised as a world leader by the Inspector of Constabulary (another recommendation), and time and again the unit is called upon to share its expertise with other forces throughout Britain and across the world. Independent advisors look at everything we do. We have introduced integrity testing in a way that is without parallel on this planet.

The previous commissioner, Sir Paul Condon did not "staunchly and steadfastly" resist the definition of "institutional racism". Sir Paul did ask about the way the term "institutional racism" was used and asked for clarification. I sat beside him when he asked, and we got our answer. He and I then publicly accepted the defini tion that was outlined in the final report.

It is confusing for everyone that Mr Mansfield's forensic skills deserted him by not exploring the hugely positive work that has been undertaken by thousands of officers in the Metropolitan police since the publication of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry report. Missing measurable evidence muddles us in moving forward. Not only will the witnesses and victims take counsel of their own fears but also racists will flourish. No one denies, however, that there is still a long way for us to go to make London a hostile environment for racists.
John G D Grieve
Deputy assistant commissioner and director of the Racial and Violent Crime Task Force, Metropolitan police

Of these, 25 have been completed and there is an action plan for the other 14; 20% of the recommendations (that is 15 out of 70) relate to family liaison. We have trained over 800 family liaison officers in under a year at three different levels of skill. Victims and their families have benefited during the nail bombs and the Paddington rail disaster. A measure of our very specific tribute to Mr and Mrs Lawrence's persistence and courage, it is their gift to us all. Everyone in London has benefited. Critical incident training, community and race relations training, and training for the first hour at a crime scene have all been established. New systems have been developed for intelligence and every borough in London now has a new Community Safety Unit with specialist officers tasked with dealing with these problems. These officers work with the intelligence. Over a 1000% increase of focused, accessible collection of intelligence operations have led to over 150% increase in arrests. One of Mr Mansfield's own recommendations was about intelligence collection. The Met's Racial and Violent Crime Task Force is now recognised as a world leader by the Inspector of Constabulary (another recommendation), and time and again the unit is called upon to share its expertise with other forces throughout Britain and across the world. Independent advisors look at everything we do. We have introduced integrity testing in a way that is without parallel on this planet. The previous commissioner, Sir Paul Condon did not "staunchly and steadfastly" resist the definition of "institutional racism". Sir Paul did ask about the way the term "institutional racism" was used and asked for clarification. I sat beside him when he asked, and we got our answer. He and I then publicly accepted the defini tion that was outlined in the final report. It is confusing for everyone that Mr Mansfield's forensic skills deserted him by not exploring the hugely positive work that has been undertaken by thousands of officers in the Metropolitan police since the publication of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry report. Missing measurable evidence muddles us in moving forward. Not only will the witnesses and victims take counsel of their own fears but also racists will flourish. No one denies, however, that there is still a long way for us to go to make London a hostile environment for racists. John G D Grieve Deputy assistant commissioner and director of the Racial and Violent Crime Task Force, Metropolitan police

fields.headline: Stirring up apathy
fields.trailText: I must challenge Paul Whiteley's bizarre assertion (If apathy rules, February 18) that it is Labour activists who mobilise voters. I fought Epsom and Ewell for Labour in the 1997 election and, in common with other "unwinnable" constituencies, we were told to run an absolutely minimal campaign. Any available activists were supposed to travel to target marginals.
fields.body:
I must challenge Paul Whiteley's bizarre assertion (If apathy rules, February 18) that it is Labour activists who mobilise voters. I fought Epsom and Ewell for Labour in the 1997 election and, in common with other "unwinnable" constituencies, we were told to run an absolutely minimal campaign. Any available activists were supposed to travel to target marginals.

When push came to shove, I couldn't actually persuade anyone to go to Crawley, so we did run a pretty decent campaign locally, with a small, dedicated team. Somehow we managed a 12.4% swing against the Tories - an achievement that owed just as much to perceptions of Tony Blair on the television as to our knocking on doors during spring evenings. How does Whiteley explain huge swings to Labour in seats that were considered beyond the party's reach? In many there would have been no activity apart from a few window posters.
Phil Woodford
Teddington, Middx
copy_master@hotmail.com

I take strong exception to Paul Whiteley's use of the word "apathy" in discussing the possible behaviour of Labour voters at the next election For the first time in over 40 years it is my intention not to vote at the next election. This has nothing to do with apathy, everything to do with my blazing, passionate anger at the character and most of the policies of New Labour.
Stephen Evans
Telford, Shropshire

Not voting may be less an expression of apathy as of electoral alienation or protest; as much a political statement as a cross on a ballot paper. If we are to claim to live in a representative (as opposed to participatory) democracy we face a great challenge: to find a way to represent abstention.
James Leith
Norwich

fields.headline: Now Ken must decide
fields.standfirst: Going alone would cost Labour dear
fields.trailText: This has not been a good weekend for mavericks. In London, as in South Carolina, it was the machine that won. So John McCain, the outsider, will know just how Ken Livingstone feels this morning. But there is a difference. Senator McCain has another go tomorrow, when two more states vote. Mr Livingstone has no such second chance.
fields.body:
This has not been a good weekend for mavericks. In London, as in South Carolina, it was the machine that won. So John McCain, the outsider seeking to deny George W Bush his presidential birthright, will know just how Ken Livingstone feels this morning. But there is a difference. Senator McCain has another go tomorrow, when two more states vote. Mr Livingstone has no such second chance - at least not automatically. To get the London mayoralty he covets so dearly, he would have to take "the nuclear option" - an independent candidacy, which would tear the Labour party down the middle. It will be the toughest call of the former GLC leader's career.

His immediate reaction yesterday, a doorstep demarche to the victor, Frank Dobson, suggested a man unready to withdraw from combat. By branding Labour's internal ballot "tainted" Mr Livingstone was clearly lodging the justification for an independent bid. He does have some right on his side. It is pretty rum that he could get an estimated 75,000 votes among those who were balloted, to Mr Dobson's 22,000, and still not be the winner. The former health secretary's defenders suggest that the electoral college was nothing worse than the system which elected Tony Blair, but that's untrue: all unions who took part in that 1994 contest did so by a system of one member one vote. This election included the grotesque anachronism of the engineering union despatching 4% of the entire electoral college on the whim of just 59 people. Mr Livingstone can comfortably claim that this is yet another New Labour fix, as bad as the one that imposed Alun Michael on Wales last year - and look what happened to him. These could be the two thrusts of an independent run: that yes terday's result was not only illegitimate, it will also fail. Rather than see London go through the turmoil undergone by Wales - which saw Mr Michael replaced by his popular rival in the end - why not cut out the middle man, dump Dobbo and go straight to Mr London himself?

The answer is that nothing is so simple. Independent runs rarely succeed, partly because of a boring fact about politics: it requires organisation. Without the Labour machine, Mr Livingstone would struggle. Nor does he have enough money to go head-to-head against the Tories, Lib Dems and Labour. Politically, too, there could be a cooling in sympathy for Red Ken. When he was the underdog battling Blairite control-freakery, Londoners were rooting for him. But might he now seem a sore loser, whose prime motive is personal ambition? The largest obstacle, however, is emotional. The Labour tribe does not like apostates, and many onetime Ken supporters will draw the line at voting against an official Labour candidate. Already the public sector workers' union Unison, which voted heavily for Ken, and others have urged him to stay loyal. They fear a split Labour vote would hand victory to the Tory, Steve Norris. Few, if any, MPs will back him and activists will be similarly wary: to work against Mr Dobson would be to invite expulsion. It would weigh heavy on Mr Livingstone, too, to leave the party he has worked for his entire life.

All that is clear this morning is that Labour has a mess on its hands, one chiefly of the leadership's making. It is surely time to drop the control-freakery - and promise that all future Labour elections are conducted on the only basis that can be legitimate: one member one vote.

fields.headline: Macpherson's catalogue
fields.standfirst: Straw and the Met still need a push
fields.trailText: Has the momentum which the Lawrence inquiry generated for the fight against racism begun to wane? Interviewed today in G2 on the first anniversary of the inquiry report, Jack Straw says it is one of the key issues on which he wants to be judged.
fields.body:
Has the momentum which the Lawrence inquiry generated for the fight against racism begun to wane? Interviewed today in G2 on the first anniversary of the inquiry report, Jack Straw says it is one of the key issues on which he wants to be judged. The home secretary has a right to be proud of setting up the inquiry - arrogantly and ignorantly rejected by the Tories - but he came perilously near to destroying the respect that earned by his opposition to one of its main recommendations: the need to tackle indirect discrimination.

Less than a month ago, Mr Straw was still resisting the idea that the race relations bill now before parliament should ban indirect discrimination in national public services. He was quite happy for it to be applied to private and local services such as schools and housing, but shamelessly opposed its extension to police, prisons, probation, health, inland revenue and social security. The Lawrence inquiry found no evidence of direct discrimination but profoundly disturbing signs of indirect discrimination. Belatedly Mr Straw conceded and went one welcome step further, by placing a legal duty on the entire public sector, from nursery schools to maximum security prisons, to promote racial equality.

There have been other disappointments. Last month a special inspectorate report into the Met, which rightly paid tribute to its racial and violent crime taskforce and the community safety units operating at borough level, included a long catalogue of failures: not enough consultation with minority ethnic staff; confusion over where responsibility for race relations training lies; only one out of nine boroughs inspected having minority ethnic officers. Sir William Macpherson in his Guardian interview last week added another fault: too much talk by the Met of its "grieving process". The inquiry's chairman was robust: "The Lawrences grieve and they will never stop grieving because they have lost their son. A police force doesn't grieve. The police have taken a blow, and they've got to to get over it."

Yet, one year on, there are good grounds for optimism. Police reform in Britain has been scandal-driven: it was the Devlin report which led to tighter controls over eye witness evidence, and the Maxwell Confait case which brought stricter regulation of police interrogation through tape and video recordings. The Lawrence inquiry was shaming for the Met. No one should have been surprised by its conclusions. Researchers have been pointing to the racism in the Met for two decades, but evidence-based policy-making in the UK remains rare. This latest defining disaster did put policymakers into overdrive: almost all Macpherson's 70 recommendations were accepted. New targets for ethnic officers have been set; pilot schemes are testing new stop and search procedures; a powerful taskforce is monitoring progress.

There has been a Macpherson ripple as other professionals, or their specialist press, have looked at the institutional racism in medicine, teaching, and housing administration. Most heartening of all is the evidence of our front page poll today. The British public has become remarkably more liberal - much more ready, for instance, to accept mixed race marriages or a black or Asian boss. There is even good news in the poll for the police itself: 75% believe they are learning from their mistakes. But that has yet to be proved.

fields.headline: Là ci darem la mano
fields.standfirst: Is it a song fit for a chief inspector?
fields.trailText: The trouble with critics who lay into "popular culture" - such as schools chief Chris Woodhead the other day - is that classic culture is not exactly replete with uplift and correct behaviour. Take opera.
fields.body:
The trouble with critics who lay into "popular culture" - such as schools chief Chris Woodhead the other day - is that classic culture is not exactly replete with uplift and correct behaviour. Take opera. The canon revels in blasphemy (Tannhäuser), incest (Valkyrie), torture (Turandot) and child abuse (Peter Grimes); there is devil worship (Mefistofele), sex with ghosts (Flying Dutchman), fairies (Rusalka) and goddesses (Pearl Fishers). By comparison modern opera - aliens, fellatio and the murder of disabled people - is tame.

But now, it seems, a truly offensive scenario is being adapted in which a teacher makes love to a pupil. This is the subject of a Glyndebourne collaboration in a series designed to appeal to a young audience. Could the plot have been inspired by the suggestion that once upon a time the chief inspector of schools himself was involved in a not dissimilar set of events? Ofsted's reaction yesterday was churlish. It is a rare honour to become a librettist's inspiration in your own lifetime. To that illustrious roster Bluebeard, King Herod, Don Giovanni, Count Almaviva, Fafner and Pinkerton may now be added the name... Woodhead.

fields.headline: Serbs resist K-For arms hunt
fields.standfirst:
US spearheads effort to find the guns terrorising Kosovo town

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Serbs threw stones and bricks yesterday at Nato-led troops starting an extensive house-to-house search for weapons in the divided town of Mitrovice in northern Kosovo.
fields.body:
Serbs threw stones and bricks yesterday at Nato-led troops starting an extensive house-to-house search for weapons in the divided town of Mitrovice in northern Kosovo.

The sweep was conducted by about 2,500 soldiers from several countries, and came two weeks after 10 ethnic Albanians were killed at night by Serbian gangs.

Until last year Albanians were a majority on both sides of the river which runs through the town. Now the north is mainly Serbian. The attacks caused around 1,500 Albanians to flee in panic over the next 10 days.

The arms hunt, which some Albanians said had come too late, began soon after dawn and was described by K-For, the international peacekeeping force in Kosovo, as the largest of its kind since Nato-led troops entered the province in June. Mitrovice has been sliding into the worst ethnic violence seen in Kosovo for eight months, and the arms hunt aimed to stop this.

But yesterday's operation ran into trouble when angry crowds gathered in opposition to K-For. US troops took the brunt of the attack from jeering stone-throwers as they entered Serb-owned buildings.

A cordon of French troops stood between the protesters and the buildings being searched by the Americans.

Witnesses said the Americans forced entry into some flats in at least one building when people apparently refused to open their doors. Later, some of the US troops left for the south of Mitrovice in eight armoured vehicles under a hail of rocks, stones, bricks and snowballs. It was not clear if any of the vehicles was damaged.

Oliver Ivanovic, a local Serb leader, said the Americans had broken all the doors in a stu dent dormitory and searched for weapons in a children's hospital in the north. "I think the Americans are trying to provoke, to show that in the north of Mitrovice you have evil Serbs," he said.

Mr Ivanovic said the French searched for weapons every day without a violent reaction. The ethnic Albanians say that the French forces are too easy-going.

As the operation began, K-For helicopters dropped leaflets that read: "Attention! Attention! K-For soldiers are here to search for weapons. Hand over your weapons when asked to do so by K-For soldiers. Do not impede K-For operations. K-For soldiers will treat you with dignity and respect."

According to a spokesman, Flight Lieutenant Neville Clayton, residents were also informed on local radio and by loudspeakers: "We don't want them to be worried," he said. "There will be attempts to hide weapons, but we will find as many as possible."

The search is expected to last for several days, and is also aimed at the southern part of the city, mostly populated by ethnic Albanians. Albanian gunmen fired at French troops last week after Serbs launched a grenade attack at Albanian flats in the north.

Bernard Kouchner, the United Nations administrator for Kosovo, said he intended to send a message to Belgrade that he would not accept partition of Mitrovice.

Because the town is close to Kosovo's border with Serbia proper - with only Serbian villages in between - hardliners backed by the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, have been hoping to detach the northern part of the city and its hinterland from the rest of Kosovo. An alternative for them would be to create an enclave on the model of the Serb-run entity in northern Bosnia.

Northern Mitrovice has also become a touchstone in the battle for the loyalty of Kosovan Serbs. Most Serbs in Kosovo have been forced to retreat to much smaller enclaves, which they can leave only under K-For escort. More than half the prewar population of Serbs have left.

Mr Kouchner drafted an extra 300 foreign police into Mitrovice last week to beef up the security forces' presence. He has also appointed a Swedish judge to sit in the local court, where judges are frequently intimidated.

The commander of K-For, General Klaus Reinhardt, has stepped up checkpoints and vehicle searches on the roads linking northern Mitrovice with Serbia to try to prevent paramilitaries infiltrating the city.

But there are fears that Serb guerrillas are also coming in on foot across the hills. Gen Reinhardt has also sent army contingents from 10 countries to the city to try to dilute Albanian anger against the French, who are in charge of the northern sector of Kosovo, which includes Mitrovice.

The French were accused of being too passive as Serb hardliners prepared for the recent wave of ethnic cleansing against the few thousand Albanians still left in the northern part of the town.

K-For hopes to aid the return the 1,500 Albanians who fled in the past fortnight. But some properties have already been taken over by Serbs.

fields.headline: Bush win stuns McCain
fields.standfirst:
Republican frontrunner whips up conservative fears to score big victory over party rival in South Carolina primary

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Republican senator John McCain must win primaries in Michigan and his home state of Arizona tomorrow to have any chance of winning his party's presidential nomination after Christian conservatives dealt him a crushing blow on Saturday.
fields.byline: Julian Borger  in Charleston, South Carolina
fields.body:
Republican senator John McCain must win primaries in Michigan and his home state of Arizona tomorrow to have any chance of winning his party's presidential nomination after Christian conservatives dealt him a crushing blow on Saturday.

Record numbers of rightwing Republicans voted in South Carolina's primary, giving George W Bush, the Texas governor, 53% of the vote against 42% for Mr McCain.

All together, about 600,000 voters turned out in South Carolina - double the 1996 number. Mr McCain's attempt to attract independent and Democrat voters in a primary open to the whole electorate was partly successful. But the effect of such people was swamped by Republican core voters who believed their values were threatened by the McCain challenge to the party establishment.

Mr Bush flew to Michigan over the weekend, declaring himself "honoured and humbled by the huge victory", and telling his supporters he would stick to his trademark policy of sweeping tax-cuts. "If you think I'm going to back down over taxes, you've got the wrong guy," he said.

In an unusually bitter concession speech on Saturday night, Mr McCain complained he had been beaten by "the negative message of fear" after the Bush camp mounted a television campaign of uninterrupted personal attacks. Mr McCain promised to stick to his pledge to avoid negative campaigning but vowed: "We have just begun to fight."

His advisers seemed stunned by the scale of the defeat, but the campaign's post-primary rally was determinedly upbeat. Mr McCain arrived in a haze of dry ice and strobe lighting as the sound system pumped out the theme to the film Star Wars.

The music was a reference to the senator's frequent claim to be a political Luke Skywalker taking on the Republican establishment's "Death Star".

But in South Carolina, the Empire struck back. The Republican political machine joined forces with ultra-conservative groups such as the Christian Coalition to ensure a high turn-out among supporters. In exit polls, 60% of Saturday's voters described themselves as conservatives, and a third said they belonged to the religious right, which backed Mr Bush by a 3:1 ratio.

fields.headline: Helena Smith @Belgrade
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: In the depths of a Balkan winter Belgrade is a bleak place. Drowning in bitterness and drunk with desire to belong - after eight years of sanction-filled ostracism - to a world seen only through the television and state-sponsored hate.
fields.body:
In the depths of a Balkan winter Belgrade is a bleak place. Drowning in bitterness and drunk with desire to belong - after eight years of sanction-filled ostracism - to a world seen only through the television and state-sponsored hate.

And now to add to their loathing there is fear. The fear of a nation wondering - in a week where their indicted leader sought to extend his iron grip - who will be gunned down next. People can't quite believe that their swaggering capital has been turned into Dodge City; that after Arkan, Belgrade's warlord king, it would only be a matter of weeks before Pavle Bulatovic, the defence minister, was assassinated as well. Who, for God's sake, is safe anymore?

Are gangland-style murders now the order of the day? Is lawless Serbia being shoved, as the opposition so frequently predicts, into all-out civil war?

None of my Serbian friends are keen to broach the subject openly. Even the news that the west is about to renew air links with the Balkan state has failed to cheer them up. But over family meals these are the questions they have begun to ask.

"Things are getting really spooky," says Sonja, yet another Belgrader who dreams of department stores, discotheques, bottled perfumes and bright lights. "Big Daddy's made sure that everyone's on the look-out. They say opposition politicians are now sleeping with pistols under their pillows."

Not that you'd believe it. Turn on the state-run RTS, (for most Serbs the only alternative to the white fuzz that creeps over independent channels at news-time) and you'd think you were in a theme park of happy nation builders. Serbia may be a shadow of its former self but as Slobodan Milosevic pronounced in a rare public appearance last week, it is on the mend.

Heroic reconstruction, the line goes, is putting Humpty Dumpty back together again. Almost one year after the Nato bombing campaign - and with the aid of black market funds - bridges, factories and military installations are being fixed, Milosevic says, "at the same speed with which the Nato missiles destroyed them." The financial apocalypse that many fear is, officials argue, just a figment of the imagination.

B ut patience is wearing thin. The queues for visas at foreign embassies are getting longer. Lucky Serbs take home £25 a month -not enough to enjoy a joint of meat or bowl of fruit. The mafiosi who run the state-controlled black market may live in conspicuous wealth but over half of the population is below poverty level. In Belgrade young Serbs spend entire days in public libraries and cyber-cafes to keep warm.

Despite fears of renewed repression, the criticism of the regime can be as biting as the cold winds that cut through the capital. "Every day is a battle for survival," says Milan Petrovic, a screenwriter who regards it as one of life's daily rituals to stand on his balcony bellowing "Milosevic you bastard go!" "We live in a sick, criminal society," he laments. "You try to laugh but it's hard to stay normal."

It is in the name of normality that EU foreign ministers last week debated continuing sanctions against Serbia. Apart from exterminating the middle class (hence no revolution), enriching Milosevic's men and pauperising the masses, the embargo has enabled the president to tap into the wall of resentment that now encases his people.

In spite of the west's move to hit the ruling elite with yet more sanctions, few think change will come soon. Worse, many have come to fear it.

Milosevic may be the most hated politician - polls show that over 80% of the population would like the "invisible man" to go. And in their dreams many Serbs may wish on him a Ceausescu-style demise. The reality, however, is that in the absence of a strong, viable alternative, Serbia looks likely to be lumbered with Slobo for some time yet.

webTitle: Long-term forecast: a billion years to go

fields.headline: Long-term forecast: a billion years to go
fields.trailText: Here is the good news: it will be 5bn years before the sun swells up and incinerates the earth. Here is the bad news: the oceans will dry up in 1bn years, and the planet will be uninhabitable anyway.
fields.body:
Here is the good news: it will be 5bn years before the sun swells up and incinerates the earth. Here is the bad news: the oceans will dry up in 1bn years, and the planet will be uninhabitable anyway.

James Kasting of Pennsylvania state university has spent years considering the fate of the planet.Since it formed 4.5bn years ago, the oceans have frozen over several times because the sun was once at least 30% fainter than it is now.

The seas thawed again because carbon dioxide built up to warm the atmosphere, he told the association yesterday. Carbon dioxide levels were now rising because of human pollution, and could rise to seven times the level in the 18th century.

Eventually, over hundreds of thousands of years, this carbon dioxide would dissolve in the oceans and form carbonate rock. But over the aeons, the sun would get warmer as it consumed more and more of its hydrogen fuel. The rise - about 1% every 100m years - would be imperceptible, but gradually water would evaporate, migrate to the stratosphere as vapour and be lost to the vacuum of space.

Long before this happened there would be other problems. As carbon dioxide levels fell, plants would begin to perish, becoming extinct in about 900m years.

"By 1.2bn years hence, the oceans may be lost, and the earth will go the way of its sister planet Venus," said Prof Kasting.

"This process may be delayed if increasing cloud cover helps to slow the increase in surface temperature. Nevertheless, earth is likely to become uninhabitable."

When the sun had exhausted its hydrogen fuel in about 5bn years, it would swell up to become a red giant, incinerating the nearest planets, before finally collapsing.

Prof Kasting admitted: "My calculations present a worst case scenario that does include the effects of clouds. But they say a billion years."

webTitle: Low road is the fastest route to White House

fields.headline: Low road is the fastest route to White House
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: The early primaries in this year's presidential elections have produced one telling lesson for future candidates and students of political science: negative campaigns work.
fields.body:
The early primaries in this year's presidential elections have produced one telling lesson for future candidates and students of political science: negative campaigns work.

In the last week of the South Carolina contest, Senator John McCain did not broadcast any political advertisements critical of his opponent, vowing to "stay positive". But George W Bush and his allies stepped up their personal attacks on Mr McCain, and the Texas governor was able to claw his way back from a dead heat to an 11% victory margin on Saturday.

The scale of Mr McCain's 19% victory in New Hampshire last month forced a profound rethink by the Bush team, which unleashed an effective barrage of "attack ads", portraying the opponent as a Washington insider backed by special interest lobbies.

Mr McCain's main election asset as a hero of the Vietnam war had threatened to tip the balance in a state where up to a third of the electorate were war veterans. But the Bush camp successfully neutralised the so-called "hero factor" by finding a disgruntled veteran from a fringe organisation who publicly accused Mr McCain of betraying his former comrades.

The fringe veteran, Thomas Burch, had launched a similar attack on Mr Bush's father, but the governor stood by him smiling on February 3 when he declared that McCain "came home and forgot us".

The now infamous Burch incident provided a second lesson: no attack is too low. Activists telephoned voters to denounce Mr McCain under the guise of conducting an opinion poll, while Mr Bush's allies in the Christian coalition distributed leaflets describing Mr McCain as "pro-abortion" and as "the fag candidate".

Senator McCain learned a third painful lesson in South Carolina: there is nothing worse than going "just a bit" negative.

Baited by the Bush attacks, the McCain camp hit back at the beginning of the month with a riposte accusing his rival of "twisting the truth like Clinton". It was a disaster and it provided fuel for his opponents, handing Mr Bush the sound bite: "Don't ever compare me to Clinton".

It also blurred the ethical distinction between Mr Bush and Mr McCain, who tarnished his image as a newer, cleaner kind of campaigner.

Eight days before the vote, the McCain camp realised its mistake and stopped all its attack ads and rebuttals, but the damage had been done; according to opinion polls during the weekend, more South Carolinans blamed Mr McCain for the mudslinging than Mr Bush.

Mr McCain has vowed to maintain his campaign without recourse to negative advertising, promising: "I will not take the low road to the highest office in the land."

Unfortunately for him, the low road still looks like the quickest route.

webTitle: Mirror editor faces fresh shares inquiry

fields.headline: Mirror editor faces fresh shares inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Newspaper company finds no improper behaviour by Morgan
More about the Mirror share deal scandal
fields.trailText: Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, faces a second Stock Exchange investigation after it emerged that he bought shares in another company besides Viglen on the eve of news that it was being transformed into an internet business.
fields.body:
Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, faces a second Stock Exchange investigation after it emerged that he bought shares in another company besides Viglen on the eve of news that it was being transformed into an internet business.

While Sir Victor Blank, chairman of Trinity Mirror, the newspaper's parent company, is aware of Mr Morgan's dealings in the second company, Corporate Executive Search, and accepts his explanation of the circumstances surrounding the investment, David Bailey, chairman of CES, said yesterday that a formal inquiry was now inevitable.

The latest investigation will come on top of the inquiry into Mr Morgan's dealings in Sir Alan Sugar's Viglen Technology on the day before the Mirror tipped the shares - which has now been moved from the Stock Exchange to the department of trade and industry. The affair is also being examined by the Press Complaints Commission.

Mr Morgan is understood to have bought around £10,000 worth of shares in CES in December, the day before the company announced that it was buying Data Cash, a company that encrypts credit card data over the internet and allows online retailers to check bank details. Trading in the shares was subsequently suspended and is to resume on Thursday, with the price predicted to soar from 5p to above 50p.

The Mirror editor is likely to make a profit of more than £100,000. The paper's City Slicker columnists, Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell, who were sacked on Friday, also bought the shares but did not tip the company until after dealings were suspended.

Mr Bailey said trading in CES was far busier than normal on the day Mr Morgan dealt, with some 11m shares, worth 6% of the company, changing hands. Speculators who bought that day should make a collective profit of more than £5m.

While Mr Bailey was sure details of the Data Cash acquisition did not leak, shares in CES were being promoted recklessly on certain internet investment bulletin boards and also on a television show.

Mr Bailey, a former senior stockbroker, said: "We want to be completely transparent about this. We are innocent bystanders." He suspected that unscrupulous market operators, unconnected with Mr Morgan or the City Slickers, were trying to operate a "pump and dump" scheme with CES.

Such schemes involve a market operator buying shares in a small quoted company, where the price is easy to manipulate, before spreading hype about its prospects and selling out when the share price rises.

"We were just a name to play with," Mr Bailey said, adding that none of the web chat- room pundits pushing CES had ever contacted the company itself for news on its prospects.

Sir Victor said yesterday that he had "no problem at all" with Mr Morgan's conduct. He told BBC1's Breakfast With Frost that the actions of the editor and the two journalists had been thoroughly investigated, and no improper behaviour by the editor had been uncovered.

"We came to a simple conclusion that over a period of time the two financial journalists writing the column had been indulging in improper practices. We weren't going to have it, and they have gone.

"As far as the editor was concerned, there had been an incident where he had bought the day before the shares were tipped, but we were satisfied, on the basis of the evidence we had - including the evidence of the two financial journalists who wrote the article - that he did not know that the shares were going to be tipped the following day."

Sir Victor rejected reports that Mr Morgan was suspected of buying the shares in someone else's name, saying that he had seen the contract note for the deal and it did have Mr Morgan's name on it.

New internal rules should ensure that the situation was not repeated at Trinity Mirror, he said.

He called on the Press Complaints Commission to reinforce its guidelines on share dealing by journalists to ensure that newspapers knew where they stood on the issue.

fields.headline: Queen's kitchen porter sacked
fields.trailText: Questions were raised about royal security yesterday after a kitchen porter at Sandringham, Norfolk, was sacked for allegedly telling other kitchen staff how easily she could poison the Queen by lacing her food with cyanide.
fields.body:
Questions were raised about royal security yesterday after a kitchen porter at Sandringham, Norfolk, was sacked for allegedly telling other kitchen staff how easily she could poison the Queen by lacing her food with cyanide.

Monica Traub, 46, who was employed as a porter at Buckingham Palace in December and moved to Sandringham in January, was dismissed in the presence of senior household staff and a police officer.

In a letter terminating her contract, Andrew F. Farquharson, assistant to the master of the household at Buckingham Palace, said: "You were alleged to have stated that you would have the opportunity to place poison in the Queen's food and that you could do this without being discovered.

"This action is regarded as an act of gross misconduct, and as you are still within your probation period I am able to dismiss you without notice."

Ms Traub told the News of the World that she was shocked to have been dismissed. "I was sacked because they said I wanted to poison the Queen," she said. "I don't know what cyanide is or what it looks like."

She added: "I do remember having a conversation with a cook about how easy it would be to interfere with food for the royal table. I can't believe I have been sacked for that. It's a nightmare for me as it was a dream job. Now I don't know what I'm going to do."

The newspaper reported that Ms Traub, originally from Germany, was involved in preparing food at Sandringham. It said that when she speculated about the ease of poisoning the Queen to another kitchen hand it was passed off as an offhand comment. But when she repeated it a few days later, and asked where cyanide could be obtained, she was reported to senior staff.

No police action was taken against Ms Traub, who was escorted from the Sandringham estate after her dismissal. Buckingham Palace confirmed the sacking but would not give any further details.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Father denies loyalist link

The father of one of the teenagers whose stabbed bodies were found outside the predominantly loyalist town of Tandragee, Co Armagh, said last night that his son was "in the wrong place at the wrong time".

There had been rumours that David McIlwain,18, and Andrew Robb, 19, might have been victims of a feud between the Loyalist Volunteer Force and Ulster Volunteer Force. Paul McIlwaine said: "My son has no links with any paramilitary."

Boy goes home after cliff ordeal

An 11-year-old boy was last night allowed home from hospital after surviving a cliff drama in which his grandfather was killed. He and his dog were rescued after a police helicopter with thermal imaging equipment traced him in the darkness to a ledge near the base of 400ft cliffs at Penbryn Beach in Cardigan Bay.

Dyfed Powys police believe the grandfather, whose body was found on rocks below, and the boy were forced to climb when they were trapped by tide.

Schools top £1bn in private funds

School building projects using private funding have topped £1bn since the election with more than 270 state schools in England being rebuilt or refurbished under the government's private finance initiative, David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, said yesterday. A further 400 schools are preparing similar schemes over the next two years.

Completed projects include new secondary schools in Dorset and the London borough of Hillingdon, a primary in Hull and a computer network for more than 100 schools in Dudley.
John Carvel

Man stabbed in pub car park

A man stabbed in a pub car park in Basildon, Essex, died from a single wound to the buttocks from a blade at least eight centimetres long, Essex police said yesterday.

A spokesman said Daniel Davis, 24, made his way to a friend's house around 500 yards away, and police are keen to discover whether he walked, took a taxi or got a lift.

Proprietor on death charge

The proprietor of a care home for the elderly has been charged with manslaughter over the death of a 95-year-old resident at Carnarvon Lodge Care Home, Clacton-on-Sea, Essex, last year.

Angela Postill, 41, along with three employees, is alleged to have unlawfully killed Winifred Armstrong.

£7.7m lottery win for one

One ticket holder won the National Lottery draw jackpot, winning £7,722,697 after matching numbers 1, 5, 11, 32, 43, 46. The bonus ball was 38. One ticket won the top £250,000 prize in the Thunderball draw with 16, 22, 25, 28 and 29, Thunderball 5.

fields.headline: Science in brief
fields.trailText: • Tiny devices measured in millionths of a millimetre could soon be at work removing pollution, cleaning blood or purifying biochemicals. Tiny revolving motors could be controlling the way liquids flow across solid surfaces. And tiny chemical claws could be one day be constructing fabrics a molecule at a time, Jim Gimzewski of IBM Research in Zurich told the association yesterday.
fields.body:
 Tiny devices measured in millionths of a millimetre could soon be at work removing pollution, cleaning blood or purifying biochemicals. Tiny revolving motors could be controlling the way liquids flow across solid surfaces. And tiny chemical claws could be one day be constructing fabrics a molecule at a time, Jim Gimzewski of IBM Research in Zurich told the association yesterday.

Invisible devices could be made of only 200 or so atoms, he said. Some already existed in prototype in research laboratories and were the first examples of the coming revolution in nanotechnology - technology on a scale of billionths of a metre. Mr Gimzewski said so far a wheel that turns on a single molecule had been created.

 Genetic scientists are considering the tumour as an unusually successful form of evolution - with genes that enable it to evolve faster to outwit treatment - and are thinking of ways to slow this down.

It takes 25 years from a random mutation in a cell to death by cancer. "I'm interested in what happens during these years and how the tumour gets the properties to invade, divide and metastasise," Lawrence Loeb, of the university of Washington medical school, said.

The faster evolution allowed the tumour to evade chemotherapy. If scientists understood the mutation process they might be able to delay it. "You might die of something else," he said.

webTitle: Safety doubts could shut N-plant for good

fields.headline: Safety doubts could shut N-plant for good
fields.trailText: One of the oldest nuclear plants in the country may have to shut permanently because it was not built properly in the first place and is unsafe.
fields.body:
One of the oldest nuclear plants in the country may have to shut permanently because it was not built properly in the first place and is unsafe.

The 35-year-old Hinkley Point A magnox station in Somerset has been shut down for months after checks through old papers found that some of the parts of the steel pressure vessel were not tested properly when the station was first built.

British Nuclear Fuels (BNFL), which now runs the station, is already under fire from the nuclear installations inspectorate at Sellafield for its lack of safety culture. It is having to submit a new safety case for Hinkley. The company must try and convince the government safety watchdog that Hinkley Point can be reopened.

BNFL accepts that the problem meant that the station had to be shut down because it "does not meet the required safety margins". It believes it can "work up a safety case" to allow the two reactors to start up again, probably in April.

Local people are so alarmed at the prospect of the station being allowed to generate power again that they have begun a campaign called simply Stop Hinkley. Among its sponsors are Paddy Ashdown, David Bellamy, Raymond Briggs and Julie Christie.

Jim Duffy, the Stop Hinkley coordinator, said: "This station was opened in 1965, designed to run for 20 to 25 years, and that means to close at least 10 years ago. It was built without secondary containment, now standard on modern reactors, which means if there is a release of fission materials they go straight into the atmosphere and are not kept in the plant."

Apart from the original failure to test steel materials for the pressure vessel correctly, there were other problems with the reactor. It was the same age as the Trawsfynydd station in mid Wales, shut nine years ago because the steel became brittle because of bombardment by radioactivity. This meant that the pressure vessel gradually got weaker, he said. "We believe that this must have happened at Hinkley. We want it shut."

Mr Duffy has a list of other faults, which he says make Hinkley more of a liability than an asset. The station has suffered problems of corrosion in the past.

The environment agency is also cross with BNFL, complaining that it has not been properly monitoring the discharges of radioactivity from the site. It has given the company two weeks to sort out the problem.

The difficulty for BNFL is that radiation levels in the reactor are so high it is impossible to get inside to carry out repairs. A spokesman there said they had not yet received representations from BNFL.

Hinkley Point A is one of a dwindling number of Magnox stations. Berkeley in Gloucestershire was the first to close, Hunterston in Scotland was shut on economic grounds, and Trawsfynydd for safety reasons. BNFL announced a month ago that Bradwell in Essex is to close next year.

webTitle: MI5 sent file on Lennon to help US investigation

fields.headline: MI5 sent file on Lennon to help US investigation
fields.standfirst: More about the Lennon files
fields.trailText: MI5 sent a file on John Lennon to the FBI after advisers to President Nixon ordered an investigation into the former Beatle, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
MI5 sent a file on John Lennon to the FBI after advisers to President Nixon ordered an investigation into the former Beatle, it was revealed yesterday.

The Nixon administration wanted ammunition to deport Lennon, who moved to the US in the early 1970s and campaigned against the Vietnam war

The MI5 file is believed to contain claims that Lennon helped to fund the Workers Revolutionary Party in Britain, paying £46,000 to the Trotskyist group whose supporters included the actress Vanessa Redgrave, and also gave money to Red Mole, a Marxist magazine edited by Tariq Ali, the former leftwing student leader.

Mr Ali has denied receiving money from Lennon.

The disclosure follows a US court order at the weekend ordering the FBI to release two letters and notes from a phone conversation.

The order could trigger the release of other secret papers on the musician.

The release was prompted by a 17-year campaign by the author and historian John Wiener, who tabled a legal request three years after Lennon's murder in 1980 for all US government documents on him.

"We don't think that the national security is really at stake here," Mr Wiener said outside court. "We think this is 30-year-old, trivial information about the activities of a dead rock star."

Mr Wiener said the order, by Judge Brian Robbins, for the release of the three documents was "one step towards the eventual release of the 10 remaining documents of the John Lennon FBI file".

MI5 is believed to have had a mole in the WRP but it is unlikely that he or she could be identified by the MI5 file passed to the FBI. It was reported yesterday that MI5 held back some information from the FBI, fearing - rightly - that it would eventually be made public under the US freedom of information act.

According to the former MI5 officer, David Shayler, the British security service files also say that Lennon gave money to the official IRA, before it split in the early 1970s, when the Provisional IRA - responsible for the subsequent terrorist campaign - was formed.

The official IRA was a marxist organisation infliltrated in MI5's view, according to files recently released at the public record office, by communists.

After it received the MI5 documents, the FBI stepped up its surveillance of Lennon and Yoko Ono in New York, with its agents even transcribing the lyrics of songs Lennon sang at demonstrations.

Lennon participated in Troops Out marches in Britain. After Bloody Sunday on January 30 1972, Lennon said: "If it's a choice between the IRA and the British army, I am with the IRA."

Shortly afterwards at a rally organised by the US Transport Workers Union attended by members of the IRA, Lennon issued a statement saying he was protesting "against the killing of Irish people in the civil rights movement".

Later that year he wrote the song, The Luck Of The Irish, dedicated to the victims of Bloody Sunday. The song appeared on the album Sometime in New York City, and proceeds were donated to the Irish civil rights movement.

Mr Shayler has written a statement to support attempts by Mr Wiener, a history professor in California, to get the US court to release the MI5 documents. Mr Shayler said he was shown the files in 1993.

According to another document, a confidential source told officials Lennon gave $75,000 to a group that planned to disrupt the 1972 Republican national convention.

webTitle: Ad puts dental patients' teeth on edge

fields.headline: Ad puts dental patients' teeth on edge
fields.trailText: A new milestone has been passed in the history of unfortunately placed advertising billboards.
fields.body:
A new milestone has been passed in the history of unfortunately placed advertising billboards.

An agency which promotes holidays with an image of a daydreaming dentist has put a poster outside Birmingham dental hospital.

The advert shows a dentist absent-mindedly scraping a patient's teeth while thinking of his recent golfing vacation.

It angered not only the hospital, which has enough phobic patients on its books already, but the British Dental Health Federation.

Yesterday a federation spokesman said: "It makes you wonder if people do it deliberately, to provoke a reaction".

The hospital's acting clinical director, Roy Pinson, said: "Patients visiting our hospital have enough to worry about without insensitive adverts like this adding to their distress. To suggest that a dentist isn't concentrating on his work is irresponsible."

The case has already gone into the Advertising Standards Authority's bulging archive of protests. It will join the fuss over a Littlewood Pools billboard proclaiming You'll Never Work Again, which went up outside Liverpool docks at the height of a labour dispute.

Yesterday Teletext, the company behind the dentistry poster, denied that it was trying to provoke a reaction.

A spokeswoman said: "The location of this advertisement was purely coincidental. We apologise for any offence. We were not implying medical negligence but merely suggesting people at work can have their minds on other things."

However, nuclear power stations, factories and boardrooms all over Britain will be watching to see where Teletext positions its next posters. They depict three more daydreamers: a woman factory worker, three company directors, and a nuclear scientist.

The ASA warned that wrongly placed posters could cause offence.

fields.headline: Human, all too human
fields.standfirst: This week, two new documentary series tackle some of life's biggest questions. How did we get here? Is man born or made? It's a bold move, argues  Mark Lawson, but not necessarily a wise one
fields.trailText: This week, two new documentary series tackle some of life's biggest questions. How did we get here? Is man born or made? It's a bold move, argues Mark Lawson, but not necessarily a wise one
fields.body:
The old joke about the taxi driver who asks the philosopher (in most versions of the anecdote, Bertrand Russell) "what's it all about, eh?" depends on a clash between the populist approach to the big questions and the academic tack. The cabbie expects a simple answer to the problems which have occupied his passenger's life.

TV, though, commendably fails to see the joke. There's a long tradition of serious factual television attempting to present the ideas of Russell in a form enjoyable to the man resting his feet. "What's it all about?" has been answered biologically (David Attenborough), anthropologically (Jacob Bronowski, Desmond Morris) and artistically (Lord Clark, Andrew Graham-Dixon).

This week, the medium begins two more attempts at a response: from the biological perspective in Lord Robert Winston's Child Of Our Time (Wednesday, 9.30pm, BBC1) and from an anthropological angle in Ape-Man (Tuesday, 9pm, BBC2). Expensive to make - and demanding a large investment of time and attention from the viewer - these college-on-the-box series are increasingly questioned as a form of television. They are also perfect for comparison in the laboratory of television criticism for two reasons.

The first is their similarity of subject-matter. Both series explore the evolution of human physicality and personality, although the medical series concentrates on the contemporary mind and body - assessing the relative impact of environment and inheritance on the babies of a group of volunteer families - while the academic one focuses on the conception of the very first humans: the moment when ancestors made sounds and images in their caves.

But the coinciding series also offer a useful contrast between the two most favoured ways of communicating facts on television. Child Of Our Time opts for the on-screen guide - the famous expert addressing the camera - while Ape-Man relies on a commentary read with thespian authority (Hugh Quarshie) and academics spitting out sound-bites from the feast of their research. "Over the next twenty years, I'm going to take you on an extraordinary journey" declares the late middle-aged Winston during Child Of Our Time, showing impressive faith in both his possession of the longevity gene and the maintenance of the licence fee.

His series is a species of docusoap: a scientific spin on the celebrated Michael Apted series Seven Up. If this were a series on Channels 4 or 5, the cameras would be present for the moment of conception, but it's BBC1 and so the children of a cross-section of British parents are followed from the moment when they are capable of their first screen appearance - at the initial pre-natal scan - to the home videos of their 20th birthday parties.

Although relying on sentimentality to swell its audience, the series also has edge. Although no book will be opened at Ladbrokes, this is an example - like another current BBC project, Castaway 2000 - of what might be called the betting-shop documentary. The viewer is invited to put money on the outcome of these real-life plot-lines. How many of these apparently loving couples will stay together? Will they breed heavenly children or kids from hell?

It's here that the science comes in. Whereas Michael Apted's sample in Seven Up shared the same background, Winston's set is carefully weighted on the basis of wages, race, domestic arrangements and - most crucially - DNA. Each featured family makes a contribution to the nature v nurture debate. Will the athletic dad have a child who can run? Will the dyslexic mum hand on her reading problem to her children? Will the offspring of the rich family or the poor do best at school and in the workplace?

The first episode suggests that this is a highly promising project which nicely balances ah-diddums moments with laboratory knowledge. But there are two worries about the generic make-up of the series. One is the evening sickness viewers may feel at the privacy which these people are trading in for fame. One mother, for example, is interviewed in her hospital bed shortly after a catastrophic moment in her pregnancy.

The other worry is over-strenuous attempts to add visual interest to Winston's links. In a previous series he addressed the camera from inside a diving helmet, and here he sits, with midriff towelled, in a steam-bath designed to simulate the womb. But, like many televisual metaphors, this one obscures rather than illuminates the facts.

Using no presenter, the rival series Ape-Man avoids this problem, but shows other signs of terror at losing the viewer's attention. A compelling first episode is surprisingly at its best as an arts documentary - showing extraordinary cave-paintings in France and South Africa - but suffers, like last year's Walking With Dinosaurs, from leaps of historical logic which leave the viewer wanting to make an urgent phone-call to the producer.

The irony of Ape-Man is that the contention of this interesting opening episode - that the human mind has changed little since the beginning of human habitation of the planet - is completely opposed to the belief of contemporary television executives in Britain. Their schedules and programmmes frequently suggest a belief that a Darwinian rewind is taking place in which humans are becoming more stupid. Both these series feel aimed at smaller brains than would have been the case twenty years ago, but both largely resist the worryingly contagious idea that documentary should be as simple as a cave painting.
