"Over the next twenty years, I'm going to take you on an extraordinary journey" declares the late middle-aged Winston during Child Of Our Time, showing impressive faith in both his possession of the longevity gene and the maintenance of the licence fee. His series is a species of docusoap: a scientific spin on the celebrated Michael Apted series Seven Up. If this were a series on Channels 4 or 5, the cameras would be present for the moment of conception, but it's BBC1 and so the children of a cross-section of British parents are followed from the moment when they are capable of their first screen appearance - at the initial pre-natal scan - to the home videos of their 20th birthday parties. Although relying on sentimentality to swell its audience, the series also has edge. Although no book will be opened at Ladbrokes, this is an example - like another current BBC project, Castaway 2000 - of what might be called the betting-shop documentary. The viewer is invited to put money on the outcome of these real-life plot-lines. How many of these apparently loving couples will stay together? Will they breed heavenly children or kids from hell? It's here that the science comes in. Whereas Michael Apted's sample in Seven Up shared the same background, Winston's set is carefully weighted on the basis of wages, race, domestic arrangements and - most crucially - DNA. Each featured family makes a contribution to the nature v nurture debate. Will the athletic dad have a child who can run? Will the dyslexic mum hand on her reading problem to her children? Will the offspring of the rich family or the poor do best at school and in the workplace? The first episode suggests that this is a highly promising project which nicely balances ah-diddums moments with laboratory knowledge. But there are two worries about the generic make-up of the series. One is the evening sickness viewers may feel at the privacy which these people are trading in for fame. One mother, for example, is interviewed in her hospital bed shortly after a catastrophic moment in her pregnancy. The other worry is over-strenuous attempts to add visual interest to Winston's links. In a previous series he addressed the camera from inside a diving helmet, and here he sits, with midriff towelled, in a steam-bath designed to simulate the womb. But, like many televisual metaphors, this one obscures rather than illuminates the facts. Using no presenter, the rival series Ape-Man avoids this problem, but shows other signs of terror at losing the viewer's attention. A compelling first episode is surprisingly at its best as an arts documentary - showing extraordinary cave-paintings in France and South Africa - but suffers, like last year's Walking With Dinosaurs, from leaps of historical logic which leave the viewer wanting to make an urgent phone-call to the producer. The irony of Ape-Man is that the contention of this interesting opening episode - that the human mind has changed little since the beginning of human habitation of the planet - is completely opposed to the belief of contemporary television executives in Britain. Their schedules and programmmes frequently suggest a belief that a Darwinian rewind is taking place in which humans are becoming more stupid. Both these series feel aimed at smaller brains than would have been the case twenty years ago, but both largely resist the worryingly contagious idea that documentary should be as simple as a cave painting.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Guys And Dolls | The Indian Runner | Dark Star | Glory
fields.body:
Guys And Dolls

(Joseph L Mankiewicz, 1955)

12.30pm, Carlton Cinema

A scintillating all-American musical experience, bubbling over with vivid New York energy. Feisty playing too, with Marlon Brando's Sky Masterson betting Frank Sinatra's Nathan Detroit he can charm Salvation Army girl Jean Simmons. Full of snappy Runyonesque dialogue and great song and dance, from the opening Fugue For Tinhorns in a crammed Times Square to Stubby Kaye's show-stopping Sit Down You're Rocking The Boat.

The Indian Runner

(Sean Penn, 1991)

8pm, FilmFour

Wild-boy Sean Penn wrote and directed this angsty tale of brotherly love gone wrong. Apparently inspired by a Bruce Springsteen song, Highway Patrolman, it has a morose and violent Vietnam vet (Viggo Mortensen) trying to come to terms with civilian life in 1968 Nebraska. David Morse is brother Joe, failing to re-tie the boyhood bond, while Charles Bronson shows he can act without the heavy artillery as Dad. A somewhat self- indulgent Penn-portrait.

Dark Star

(John Carpenter, 1974)

4.20am, FilmFour

Carpenter's sci-fi comedy debut was unfavourably compared to 2001, but goes down in space history as the forerunner of the Alien series. Producer and co-writer Dan O'Bannon - who also plays one of the four spaced-out hippie astronauts trying to find their way back to earth - went on to write the script for Ridley Scott's interstellar horror. The jokes about drugs and surfing wear thin, but despite the sun-ray lamps, there's a sense of space being very dark indeed.

Glory

(Edward Zwick, 1989)

11pm, Bravo

A powerful account of the first black regiment to fight in the American Civil War, and the stirrings of black consciousness therein. It's a sombre and harrowing tale that marches bravely against the racism on all sides. Matthew Broderick plays the novice Union Colonel Shaw who leads the unit; Morgan Freeman and Oscar-winning Denzel Washington are among those called up. Cinematographer Freddie Francis also won an Oscar, mainly for the battle scenes: Gettysburg and Fort Wagner are stunning.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: John McCarthy's Bible Journey | Nature
fields.body:
The leading Palestinian Hanan Ashrawi puts her finger firmly on the imponderable issue confronting religious believers. Why have most religions, as they vigorously proclaimed peace, spent their history steeped in blood? "Where everyone claims a mandate straight from Heaven," Ashrawi sighs, "you wind up with one absolutist ideology fighting another." John McCarthy's Bible Journey (11.0am, Radio 4) finds him back in the Middle East to delve into this sad reality. He finds very little for comfort.

In Nature (9.0pm, Radio 4), Mark Carwardine reports on the unforeseen results of the long campaign to protect endangered birds of prey. More peregrines, sparrowhawks, buzzards and red kites now swoop from our skies than for the past 100 years. Unfortunately they then sink their talons into game birds, songbirds and racing pigeons. Since the raptors are protected by law there are a lot of unhappy gamekeepers, pigeon fanciers, and twitchers seeking redress.

fields.headline: The living End
fields.trailText: I once worked with a TV producer who - at the end of a long shoot, when they had not perhaps achieved the ideal balance of rest and refreshment - became obsessed with discovering the first programme ever made to mark an anniversary and producing a series to mark the birthday of that broadcast. The quantity of X-years-ago-shows is one of the most common complaints to viewer and listener access series. But at least those programmes marked external events: wars, elections, the fall of walls. It's even more irritating when executives stick a birthday cake in their own navel.
fields.body:
I once worked with a TV producer who - at the end of a long shoot, when they had not perhaps achieved the ideal balance of rest and refreshment - became obsessed with discovering the first programme ever made to mark an anniversary and producing a series to mark the birthday of that broadcast. The quantity of X-years-ago-shows is one of the most common complaints to viewer and listener access series. But at least those programmes marked external events: wars, elections, the fall of walls. It's even more irritating when executives stick a birthday cake in their own navel.

But celebrations of an entirely internal anniversary - the passing of 15 years since BBC1 first screened EastEnders - enter their second week today: a level of commemoration which even the Second World War merits only for the larger landmark decades. In the next five days, the standard weekly 90 minutes of the show will be screened, but there will be five hours of Happy Birthday EastEnders (11am, daily, BBC1), live from the set of the soap opera. Ex-cast members will "drop by" and viewers can vote in a series of polls including the programme's "top bombshells".

EastEnders is important. One of my own favourite theories - delivered at the end of long shoots when conditions of rest and refreshment have not been ideal - is that the residents of Albert Square may have saved the BBC from Thatcher at the mid-80s peak of her power. Lacking popular shows, the BBC struggled to maintain the case for the universal licence fee. The huge audiences delivered by EastEnders probably got the Corporation sorted (as the Fowlers, Watts and Mitchells taught us to say) in the eyes of the Tories.

Even so, this jamboree across the schedules feels as forced and self-glorifying as the celebrations of a dictator's birthday. Most shockingly, the series is co-hosted by Jeremy Spake, the camp Aeroflot official from the docusoap Airport, who the BBC is trying to turn into a presenter. Many had assumed that the embarrassment of the millennium eve show - when, on the day of Yeltsin's resignation, the BBC's reporter in Moscow was Spake talking about how cold it was - had ended this experiment. But here he is, live on-air for five days running from Albert Square, although he has absolutely no connection with EastEnders beyond watching it with 16.99 million others. Perhaps we should find out when the fifth anniversary of the first screening of Airport was and book a holiday (though not via Aeroflot to Mosocow ) that week.

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous: Tom Sizemore in Blue Steel.
fields.body:
Tom Sizemore in Blue Steel (Kathryn Bigelow, 1989)

Who? One of the classic Where-Have-I-Seen-That-Guy-Before? actors, the reliably chunky Sizemore made a good living playing psycho killers and law enforcement officers (who are also psychos) in the likes of True Romance, Heat and Natural Born Killers (and also securing a reputation for himself as "difficult"). After an arrest for alleged spousal abuse in 1997, his drug and alcohol addictions became apparent - but thankfully good old Robert De Niro stepped in, threatening to report Tom to the cops for his heroin use if he didn't seek help. He did, and his career immediately took a distinct upturn, including work with Spielberg (Saving Private Ryan) and Scorsese (Bringing Out The Dead). His next project is sci-fi movie Red Planet, with Val Kilmer - and just in case you thought the old Tom was gone forever, there have been reports of venomous animosity between the two on set. Hurrah!

The role: "Woolcap", a convenience store robber who is unfortunate enough to be the first criminal encountered by rookie cop Jamie Lee Curtis.

Best line: As he holds a spotty clerk at gunpoint, he bellows "I'm not ordering Chinese food, fuckface, give me the money!"

Cringe factor: Low. It's exactly the kind of scumbag role Sizemore used to be so good at.

Other wannabes: Latino actress Elizabeth Peña, who later starred in Jacob's Ladder (1990) and John Sayles's Lone Star (1996).

Critical judgement: An effusive Roger Ebert called this "an efficient thriller, a movie that pays off with one shock and surprise after another".

Also not starring in: Daytime soap China Beach, in 1988, as "Sgt Vinnie Ventresca, the Dog Man". He also played "Second Mugger" in 1989's Penn And Teller Get Killed.

Blue Steel, Sky Cinema, Friday February 25, 11.50pm.

fields.headline: Livingstone cries foul
fields.standfirst:
Winner is challenged to refuse 'tainted' victory

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: This is the full statement read by Ken Livingstone outside his north London home yesterday:
fields.body:
This is the full statement read by Ken Livingstone outside his north London home yesterday:

I first want to thank everyone who has voted for me. The overwhelming majority of Labour party members and trade unionists have voted for me, whereas Frank secured the support of just over one-third of Labour party members.

At a rough estimate, a total of 80,000 people have voted for me in all sections of the electoral college, compared to 25,000 for Frank.

This huge democratic mandate is a ringing endorsement of the policies I have put to the London Labour party.

The support I have received from party members, trade unionists and ordinary Londoners has been overwhelming. I am grateful to them for their encouragement throughout this campaign.

This result has been delivered by one trade union boss, one retired MEP and one small Co-op branch, which did not ballot its members.

It is based on the fact that 8% of the electoral college was voted by Sir Ken Jackson and the South London Co-op, who refused to allow their members to cast their own votes and cast them instead for Frank Dobson.

I urge everybody to stay inside the Labour Party and fight to ensure that nothing like this ever happens again.

There must now be a serious question over whether Frank can hope to beat Steven Norris on May 4 when Londoners will widely perceive the Labour nomination to have been stolen. The lesson of Wales is that our voters will not be taken for granted.

A Labour campaign that was dead in the water from day one will limp on to polling day and never allow us to get on to the real issues that matter to Londoners, such as transport, unemployment and crime.

In the interests of uniting the Labour party, I hope Frank Dobson will consider his position over the next few days. He must decide whether he is willing to accept this tainted result or stand down in the interests of Labour and London.

Over the last six months Londoners have had to listen to politicians. Now it is time for politicians to listen to Londoners, and I shall be saying nothing further until I have had a chance to listen to Londoners.

fields.headline: Dobson's message: Your move, Ken
fields.standfirst: What next? Wounded loser ponders return as independent
fields.trailText: In Labour's HQ at Millbank Tower, as in distant South Carolina, there was the kind of buzz which is all too rare in today's dull, managerial politics. "What will he do next?" people asked of John McCain and Ken Livingstone.
fields.body:
In Labour's HQ at Millbank Tower, as in distant South Carolina, there was the kind of buzz which is all too rare in today's dull, managerial politics. "What will he do next?" people asked of John McCain and Ken Livingstone.

One is a rightwing US republican, the other London's favourite leftwing rebel. But both are outsiders, insurgents whose candidacies have put some life back into machine politics - and have both suffered setbacks in (a British novelty) crucial primary elections.

Frank Dobson has problems of momentum and legitimacy with this narrow win, a "nightmare scenario" according to his critics, though the candidate himself was insisting his campaign had steadily gained ground. But, as unions and leftwing MPs warned Mr Livingstone not to jump ship, the tactical dilemma faced by the former GLC leader was acute.

The usually perky MP for Brent East was last night keeping his own counsel, listening to friends and using waiting television crews outside his home in Cricklewood to keep in the public eye. He did so with ambiguous remarks that did not close down the option of an independent candidacy for mayor of London.

After pre-result defiance which saw him urge Mr Dobson to "step down honourably" rather than lose to Steve Norris on May 4, Mr Livingstone now sounded more cautious. "I urge everybody to stay inside the Labour party to fight to ensure that this does not happen again," he said. At the same time he still used the phrase "tainted" election.

"I know Ken well and when I saw him on TV I thought he was very, very hurt, deeply upset and angry at the result," said one old GLC colleague and fellow MP. "But the first thing he said was to stay and fight. Would he do that if he was minded to go?"

There was speculation that Downing Street would try to buy off Mr Livingstone by offering him the sort of ministerial post - preferably one that would "send him abroad a lot" - which Tony Blair refrained from giving him in 1997.

That is unlikely. Downing Street will not rush to invite Mr Livingstone round for tea and discuss the options. The pressure will be the other way round until Mr Livingstone makes it clear he will buckle under and campaign loyally for Mr Dobson.

Diehard

Mr Livingstone promises cooperation. But as a Labour foot-soldier in the GLC years, Mr Blair remains a Ken-sceptic.

Yesterday's victor moved to steer the media pack back on to policies - crime, transport and jobs - and attacked Mr Norris. Party officials predicted that Ken - all but his most diehard opponents still call him that - will draw back from the abyss. But few would bet their pension.

A freelance candidacy would earn him instant expulsion, or "expelling himself" as Labour's London chairman, Jim Fitzpatrick, put it at Millbank yesterday.

Even Diane Abbott, not an MP easily cowed, stressed yesterday that she will be backing the winner "100%", while acknowledging the pressure on Ken to run. For a man who got his party card in 1968 it would be a fearsome wrench.

A wrench, moreover, which would not even guarantee the prize of becoming Britain's first elected mayor, guiding a budget of more than £1bn and having the largest directly elected mandate in Europe outside the French presidency.

In theory Labour should easily win the mayor's race. In 1997 it took 57 seats in London with 51.35% of the capital's vote against the Tories' 11 seats and 29.5%, and the Lib Dems with six seats and 14.2%. But a three-way split is a nightmare for all three big players under the election rules.

Voters can express a second preference, to be counted if no candidate wins outright. But only the first and second-placed runners will get those preferences. What if Mr Livingstone ran, but hit a tight three-way split and narrowly came third as the Labour machine - and Labour loyalty - overwhelmed the good-old-Ken factor detected in so many polls ?

Cheeky chappie
Most of his second preferences would go to Mr Dobson. But many Tories, Liberal Democrats, Greens and assorted anti-Blair voters, would lodge them anywhere-but-Dobbo. Part of Mr Livingstone's cheeky chappie appeal - like Mr McCain's in the US - is that he reaches Tories as well as Trots, suburban moderates and Hooray Henrys.

Might his refusal to bury the hatchet let in Mr Norris? Or, the ultimate nightmare, might Mr Norris be squeezed out in a Dobbo-Ken play-off? If the polls are right Ken would win. Hence last night's uncertainty: the stakes are huge.

Mr Dobson and his deputy, Trevor Phillips, said repeatedly yesterday that the row about the electoral college had damaged them because many Labour loyalists "voted for Ken because they were annoyed about the way they were asked to vote". Being a successful mayor was about cooperation with business, with unions and with voluntary organisations. "It's not about self-publicity or fancy names," said Mr Dobson.

But first someone has to do the tricky bit - win the election. There are nine weeks left.

Transport
Backs government's public-private partnership plan for tube. London Underground would continue day to day running of service, while private sector would ensure that track, signals and stations were modernised and upgraded, take the risk and meet the cost of any over-runs. Once the improvements are made, they would return to public control. Would use money raised from enforcement of bus lanes and red routes to provide under-18s with free bus passes.

Regeneration
Supports inward investment and an "innovation partnership" between government, London Development Agency and private sector to invest in businesses. Would develop partnerships between schools and businesses. Would set targets for reducing poverty as criteria for evaluating regeneration bids, aim to extend access to IT for all Londoners.

Policing
Would give all Londoners a named police officer. Foster intensive policing, work with communities and make better use of bylaws to take the heat out of crime hotspots. Appoint Trevor Phillips to oversee Metropolitan police authority.

www.frank-dobson.org.uk

Steve Norris, Conservative

Transport
Supports privatisation of the tube. Promises investment in infrastructure but no increase in fares above inflation. Would extend the Travelcard, insist on better information, ticketing and better night services, more use of technology to improve bus services and free up bus lanes. Would remove union "stranglehold" on London Transport, and support pressing ahead with new lines, extending the Docklands Light Railway and developing the Woolwich tunnel link.

Regeneration
Attempt to create "a compassionate and inclusive London", focusing on decline of civic values and sink estates. Would address "poverty of expectation, especially among the young and London's ethnic communities", work with boroughs to tackle graffiti, litter and waste. Would set up an open spaces commission to identify sites for new architecture and sculpture.

Policing
Would crack down on petty crime. "It is time the police switched from grabbing headlines to catching muggers, car thieves and burglars ... I will be a stern critic, but the strongest ally of our police when it is needed."

www.norrisforlondon.com

Darren Johnson, Green

Transport
Opposed to full or partial privatisation of tube. Would cut bus fares. Would improve public transport, and encourage cycling and pedestrianisation with the aim of reducing inner city traffic by 30% by 2008 from 1997 levels. Increase charges for private car use in central London if traffic targets are not met. Would reduce speed limit from 30mph to 20mph, complete 2,000km London cycle network by 2003, and halt retail and entertainment developments which encourage car use.

Regeneration
Allow businesses, shops and leisure facilities to be sited closer to where people live - enhancing community life. Would create "blue belt" to protect Thames from speculative developments, and establish zero waste agency to promote waste reduction and recycling. Would produce warm homes strategy to improve insulation in housing. Would ban growing GM crops in London.

Policing
Would aim to increase the number of police officers on bikes to around 1,000 by 2004.

www.greenparty.org.uk

Susan Kramer, Lib Dem

Transport
Opposes tube sell-off. Would raise money through bonds to fund improvements to tube and buses. Impose "fair and reasonable" congestion charges on cars and lorries on Mondays to Fridays in central London only once improvements are apparent. Those who pay congestion charges will get free travel permits for public transport. Opposes break-up of tube system into different companies.

Regeneration
Would build communities of mixed income housing, provide seed money to community banks in deprived areas to support small businesses and schemes for shared ownership of houses. Would introduce town managers to help revitalise high streets. Would double arts funding for London, and sponsor creative use of streets and squares for displaying public art.

Policing
Would introduce a community constabulary to support the Met with problems like noisy neighbours, blocked bus lanes and graffiti. Would also act as housing estate wardens, park superintendents. Each neighbourhood would have a community constable responsible for regular street patrols.

www.susankramer.org

webTitle: How the electoral college votes added up

fields.headline: How the electoral college votes added up
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The result
fields.body:
The result

Frank Dobson: 51.526%

Ken Livingstone: 48.473%

Votes for the third candidate Glenda Jackson were redistributed using her supporters' second choices when she was eliminated in the first round

The first-round votes were:

Dobson: 49.569%

Livingstone: 46.009%

Jackson: 4.421%

The candidate was selected through an electoral college. Each section - Labour members, unions and affiliated societies, and MPs, MEPs and Greater London Authority candidates - had one-third of the college so each block was worth 33.333%. Section-by-section, the votes were:

Labour party members

Dobson: 11.758%

Livingstone: 18.301%

Jackson: 3.274%

When Jackson's votes were reallocated:

Dobson 13.367%

Livingstone: 19.966%

Unions and affiliated societies

Dobson: 8.982%

Livingstone: 23.654%

Jackson: 0.697%

When Jackson's votes were reallocated:

Dobson: 9.330%

Livingstone: 24.003%

MPs, MEPs, GLA candidates

Dobson: 28.829%

Livingstone: 4.054%

Jackson: 0.450%

When Jackson's votes were reallocated: Dobson: 28.829%, Livingstone: 4.504%

The mayoral election will be held on May 4. Voting will be conducted through the alternative vote system. Every voter stipulates a first and second choice. If no candidate wins on the first ballot, the second votes will be redistributed until there is a winner.

Other declared candidates include: Steve Norris (Conservative), Susan Kramer (Liberal Democrat), Daniel Johnson (Green), Malcolm McLaren (Independent).

At the same time voters will choose 25 members of the Greater London Authority.

fields.headline: Shobhana Samarth
fields.standfirst: The Indian screen goddess who was showered with coins and flowers like a true divinity from Hindu heaven
fields.trailText: Veteran actress Shobhana Samarth, who has died aged 83, became an icon of the golden age of Indian cinema in the 50s, when films had a powerful sway over the masses.
fields.body:
Veteran actress Shobhana Samarth, who has died aged 83, became an icon of the golden age of Indian cinema in the 50s, when films had a powerful sway over the masses.

She became an actress in the 30s when acting was still taboo for respectable women. Her father Prabhakar Shilotri owned his own bank, but her mother, Kantabai Shilotri, had acted in silent films. Shobhana made her debut opposite Master Vinayak in Nigah-e-Nafrat (Eye of Hatred, 1935) but it was playing the female lead in Sagar Films's Do Diwane (The Two Love Crazy, 1936) and Kokila (Nightingale, 1937) that gained her early popularity.

Her roles in films about mythology made her a star: as the goddess Sita (wife of Lord Rama) in Vijay Bhatt's Bharat Milap (The Meeting of Bharat, 1942) and in his Ram Rajya (The Ideal Rule of Rama, 1943), a film that unreeled the saga of Lord Rama's ideal kingdom. Her impact was so powerful that viewers showered coins and flowers when she appeared on the screen. A private screening of Ram Rajya was even arranged for Mahatma Gandhi, an admirer of Rama's philosophy.

Shobhana played similar mythological roles in Mahasati Anasuya (The Venerable Anasuya, 1943), Urvashi (1946) and many more. So deep was the popular identification of Shobhana with the goddess Sita that she began to appear in comic books, calendar paintings and even on posters for the rightist Hindu Movement Vishwa Hindu Parishad.

Although these parts turned her into a celebrity, they limited her as an actress and they were far removed from her life offscreen, which was noted for its careless disregard for convention. Although her husband, cinematographer Kumarsen Samarth, had initially been her mentor, she gradually grew apart from him and developed an intimate relationship with Motilal, one of the most accomplished actors of Indian cinema.

"It was a wonderful relationship... He had a flying licence hired a plane and flew over my cottage, throwing stones with letters tied to them saying 'I love you', " recalled Shobhana in one of her last interviews.

She played the lead in nearly 50 films and eventually became a producer, setting up Shobhana Pictures, and director of two films, Hamari Beti (Our Daughter, 1950) and Chhabili (Beautiful Woman, 1960), which launched her daughters, Nutan and Tanuja, as actresses.

She leaves behind a family that is now centre screen of Indian cinema. Nutan has appeared in films by Zia Sarhadi and Bimal Roy; Tanuja is a talented actress in both Hindi and regional cinema; a grand-daughter, Kajol, is one of India's top stars; a grandson, Mohinish Behl, is also an actor. Shobhana is also survived by a son, Jaideep.

 Shobhana Samarth, actress, producer and director, born November 17 1916 ; died February 9 2000

fields.headline: Anatoly Sobchak
fields.standfirst: New Russian politician and mayor of the city of St Petersburg
fields.trailText: Anatoly Sobchak, a central figure in Russia's revolution of the past decade, and once seen as a possible president of Russia, has died of a heart attack, aged 62, while drumming up electoral support for his former protégé, acting president Vladimir Putin.
fields.body:
Anatoly Sobchak, a central figure in Russia's revolution of the past decade, and once seen as a possible president of Russia, has died of a heart attack, aged 62, while drumming up electoral support for his former protégé, acting president Vladimir Putin.

A former law professor and democratic activist, Sobchak was mayor of St Petersburg from 1991-96, having earlier been leader of Leningrad; he himself rechristened it St Petersburg. Sobchak, who called himself a "radical realist" and said he was inspired by the speeches of Martin Luther King, was most renowned for his starring role in the perestroika drama under Mikhail Gorbachev at the end of the 80s, for his cool and courageous defiance of the old guard putschists in the summer of 1991, and for the early promise of his governance of Leningrad.

A gifted public speaker in a political culture known for long-winded bores, Sobchak, handsome and nattily dressed, flourished in the democratic upheavals of 1989. He was particularly unusual in that he had never been a member of the communist party. He finally joined it in the dying days of the Soviet Union (he left it two years later accusing it of a failure "to offer the country a real programme for moving to a new society") and sat in the Congress of People's Deputies, the last Soviet parliament, elected in 1989.

It was the high point of the Gorbachev era. The nation was glued to its television sets, absorbed in the raucous and thrilling debates that dominated congress. Sobchak became a star, a Gorbachev ally and one of the congress's most effective performers, his legal training helping him to cut through the weighty parliamentary procedure.

A canny politician, he also became close to Boris Yeltsin, running the Russian presidential election campaign for Yeltsin in Leningrad in 1991 and delivering the vote. By then, he was the second most popular politician in Russia and a potential president.

He instinctively rushed to Yeltsin's side in Moscow, in August 1991, supporting the Russian president in his finest hour against the communist putsch. Sobchak then risked arrest by going to Moscow airport, flying home to Leningrad and confidently confronting the regional military commander, who was poised to order the troops out into the streets in support of the coup.

In Leningrad, the troops stayed in their barracks. Sobchak went on television that evening to denounce the plotters. The next day he appeared before a huge pro-democracy demonstration in the city, perhaps the biggest since the 1917 revolution, and was acclaimed as a hero.

Sobchak was born at the height of Stalin's great terror in the Siberian railway town of Chita, near the Chinese border. His grandfather was an old Bolshevik who died after being incarcerated by Stalin. Sobchak was good at school and got a place to study law at the university of Leningrad, the city he would later make his home and power base. But he notably eschewed any communist party career.

On graduation, he practised law in Stavropol, Gorbachev's home turf in southern Russia, before taking up a law teaching career in Leningrad in the 70s. An early sign of his radicalism was a pro-capitalist doctoral work submitted, and rejected, in 1973. He specialised in economic law, later writing several books on the subject. By 1981, he had been appointed Leningrad university's first professor of economics law.

After starring in the congress in Moscow in 1989, Sobchak moved home to head the city council; in 1991 was elected mayor, following a month of paralysis in the Leningrad parliament. He held the post until 1996, when he narrowly lost his bid for a second term amid mudslinging and allegations of sleaze and nepotism. (Declaring his loyalty to Sobchak, Putin also left St Petersburg politics when his boss lost in 1996 and moved to Moscow, into the Kremlin administration of Boris Yeltsin.)

In November 1997, Sobchak fled to France fearing arrest on corruption charges. He had been summoned to give evidence over a municipal scandal for allegedly arranging to have his flat upgraded and accepting another apartment as a gift for his niece. He returned home from France to practise law last summer after the corruption case was closed, a move credited to Putin who was then head of the FSB, the successor to the KGB.

Since Putin succeeded Yeltsin on New Year's eve, Sobchak had been constant in his support for the new leader, stressing Putin's democratic convictions amid growing fears of the leader's authoritarian inclinations. Sobchak died in Kaliningrad while campaigning as Putin's envoy, seeking regional support for the presidential election on March 26.

His autobiography, For a New Russia (1992), is an insider's account of the struggles within the fledgling democratic movement to break the power of the communist party.

He leaves his wife and two daughters.

 Anatoly Sobchak, lawyer and politician, born August 10 1937; died February 20 2000

fields.headline: Robert Dodd
fields.standfirst: Blood of a lion and a big heart: a good man in Africa
fields.trailText: The principal work of the anthropologist and development worker Robert Dodd, who has died of cancer aged 59, was in the Central African Great Lakes region. For him conflicts in Africa, many of which originated in a colonial disregard for traditional structures, could best be resolved through an examination of the local cultural and historical context. Local institutions and local voices were central to lasting change.
fields.body:
The principal work of the anthropologist and development worker Robert Dodd, who has died of cancer aged 59, was in the Central African Great Lakes region. For him conflicts in Africa, many of which originated in a colonial disregard for traditional structures, could best be resolved through an examination of the local cultural and historical context. Local institutions and local voices were central to lasting change.

Dodd was 33 when he went to the London School of Economics to read anthropology. Postgraduate studies, and later teaching, led him, his wife Su Braden and their daughter Alice, then aged seven, to spend 18 months among the Baka pygmies of the Cameroun rain forest. From this stemmed his love of Africa and its peoples and he returned determined to put it to practical use.

So began a career in community development and conflict resolution work, which took him for two years to Rwanda, Burundi and Eastern Zaire as Oxfam's regional field director, and then for four years to the International Africa Institute. He conducted a tough evaluation of Oxfam's response to the 1985/6 emergency in Sudan and Ethiopia. His report set the terms of the debate on the need to combine relief and development work and was instrumental in shaping Oxfam's subsequent emergency policy.

In 1988, Dodd joined ActionAid, one of Britain's largest development agencies, and remained with them until his death, although he resigned when he thought the agency was becoming too top-down and target-driven, but returned to become international programme director, then director of policy and research and finally policy adviser on conflict and development. He also worked with the Oxfam Africa Committee, the Refugee Council and the Catholic Institute for International Relations.

He was a journalist's son from a large Lincolnshire family, who left school at 17 and, after spells in advertising and teaching English in Rome, returned to London to work in industrial communications with Wates, the building firm. One task was to monitor the Pavilion in the Parks exhibition, a controversial new way of bringing arts to the people. There he met his wife, Su, the project's joint co-ordinator. Together they helped to organise Friends of the Arts Council Operative (FACOP), a group of artists, writers and performers, whose work did not fit into the categories for Arts Council support. FACOP secured wide spread publicity for its ideas, which led to the Arts Council's first open grant-giving meetings. Then came the LSE.

Summers at the family's beloved mill near Bordeaux, reclaimed from brambles in 1972, provided the Dodds with relaxation, often in the company of friends; everybody enjoyed his humour and iconoclastic fun. He continued to work throughout his last battle with cancer, and weeks before his death had organised contributions by African colleagues to another United Nations conference on traditional forms of peace-making.

Dodd was, as an African colleague put it, "a man with a big heart, a real Mushingantahe [the wise man in Burundi culture] who always took time to listen to and understand ordinary people." And, as the hospice staff declared, he had lion's blood in him, and was tenacious to the very end.

He is survived by his wife and daughter.

And, as the hospice staff declared, he had lion's blood in him, and was tenacious to the very end. He is survived by his wife and daughter.  Robert Dodd, development worker, born April 18 1940; died January 4 2000

webTitle: Traditional healers help find new cures

fields.headline: Traditional healers help find new cures
fields.standfirst: Tim Radford  reports from the American Association for the Advancement of Science conference in Washington
fields.trailText: The root bark of an African tree could provide a new treatment to control thrush, athlete's foot, and fungal infections of the eye, thanks to advice from traditional healers and medicine men.
fields.body:
The root bark of an African tree could provide a new treatment to control thrush, athlete's foot, and fungal infections of the eye, thanks to advice from traditional healers and medicine men.

Kurt Hostettmann, of the university of Lausanne, has been using tribal knowledge to track down new medicines. But, he told the American Association for the Advancement of Science, six large trees had to die to yield just 50 grammes of the powerful fungicide for medical trials.

The natural chemical - one of more than a dozen extracted from the bark of the African tree Bobgunnia madagascarensis - is one of thousands of potent substances now being isolated from plant species around the globe. More than three quarters of all pharmaceutical medicines are based on plants. There are more than 400,000 plant species and many of them make up to 10,000 kinds of molecules as chemical defences against in sect and microbe attack. Fewer than one in 10 plants have been examined by chemists. So a new breed of scientists - called ethnobotanists - has been working in Africa, Asia and South America with tribal healers who have been using medicinal plants for thousands of years.

Dr Hostettmann's new antifungal remedy is being examined by a US drug company: under an international agreement, a percentage of any profits will go back to the university of Zimbabwe to help the country where the value of the plant was first identified. There are other treatments for thrush, Candida albicans, but this one, at first tests, appeared more powerful - and seemed to be active against 200 other fungi, he said.

Gordon Cragg of the US National Cancer Institute told the meeting that analysis of prescriptions in the US showed that 119 substances, derived from 90 plants, were important drugs in use in more than one country. Of these 119 drugs, 74% were discovered because scientists began by looking at plants used in traditional medicine.

They included the antimalarial drug quinine, from cinchona bark; the analgesic morphine, from the opium poppy; the heart treatment digoxon, from foxgloves; the hypertensive reserpine from an Indian herb used for snakebite; and ephedrine for asthma, from a Chinese herbal treatment.

One of the latest was taxol, a cancer treatment from the Pacific yew used as medicine by several North American tribes. But the research was a race against time: traditional lore is disappearing fast. Many plant compounds which kill infections turn out to be too dangerous to use. "We have to fight against the idea that what is natural must be necessarily good," said Dr Hostettmann. "The biggest toxins are also found in plants. Everything depends on the dose.

webTitle: Plastic surgeons sculpt Rio's carnival look

fields.headline: Plastic surgeons sculpt Rio's carnival look
fields.standfirst: Mere beauty may not get them on to a parade float, so some women go seeking cosmetic perfection
fields.trailText: Brazil boasts more plastic surgeons per capita than any other country in the world, according to the industry's trade association, and these past few weeks their scalpels have been working overtime.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Brazil boasts more plastic surgeons per capita than any other country in the world, according to the industry's trade association, and these past few weeks their scalpels have been working overtime.

Aspiring young models are increasingly seeking last-minute plastic surgery fixes to secure the most sought-after positions in Rio de Janeiro's carnival parade next month.

Hundreds of women, many in their early 20s, believe that having breast implants and liposuction in the weeks before the carnival is the only way to guarantee a place on the most prestigious, and prominent floats.

As Rio's carnival is screened live on Brazilian television, it gives instant exposure, and sometimes celebrity, to the most beautiful women appearing in its spotlight.

As such, the run up to the carnival sees the samba schools' social directors, who choose the women appearing on their floats, inundated with requests for positions.

While competition among aspiring starlets has always been intense, young women are going to increasing lengths to "improve" their bodies because they see the event as the best way to launch a modelling career.

In an extreme case, one model spoke of having a rib removed this week to reduce her waist two inches from 72cm (28in) to 66cm.

"The girls who are doing this are already very beautiful. But they want to be more beautiful," says plastic surgeon Edmar da Fontoura. "They realise that carnival is a showcase for the world. It can start a career."

Farid Hakme, whose Inter plastica clinic employs 53 plastic surgeons, says work doubles just before carnival.

"Normally, the first thing that the woman asks when she walks through the door is: 'Will it be ready for the parade?'" Mr Hakme says. "They come in for breast implants and usually take advantage of the operation to have liposculpture done around their buttocks. There has been a huge upsurge in the last two years."

"Large breasts never used to be fashionable in Brazil, but now they are the latest thing," he said.

Most of the operations require as little as a two-week recovery period, so the clinics often remain fully booked until a fortnight before the pre-Lent carnival, which is taking place this year between March 4-7.

And patients don't shy away from talking about which operations they have had, or who has done their work; the wife of Rio's state governor recently revealed that she had had li posuction for the festivities.

Denise Braga, 26, who works as a body double for Brazilian soap opera's shower scenes, has had breast implants and a liposculpture.

"There are so many beautiful women that you need to have it done to catch the camera's attention," she says.

Ms Braga has landed positions on four samba school floats during the parade's two main nights; once she has finished the parade with one school, she will have to run to ride with another.

"This shouldn't be too difficult - it's not as if I'll be wearing many clothes," she says. "For one school, I'll just be wearing a cover of paint." It will be a long evening for Ms Braga, but she is more than willing to participate for a chance meeting with fame.

However, not everyone likes the carnival's new, plastic direction. Monique Evans, who paraded for 10 years, said: "It's not fun any more. There's too much of a fight. People are just worried about getting into the media."

"Before you needed to keep fit," the ex- dancer said. "Now you can get it 'lipoed' away. It isn't right."

webTitle: Iran's voters give leaders a mandate for change

fields.headline: Iran's voters give leaders a mandate for change
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: Iranian voters have handed reformers a solid victory over their conservative rivals in nationwide elections for parliament, giving President Mohammed Khatami a major weapon through which to implement political and social reforms.
fields.body:
Iranian voters have handed reformers a solid victory over their conservative rivals in nationwide elections for parliament, giving President Mohammed Khatami a major weapon through which to implement political and social reforms.

With most votes counted yesterday, reform candidates had won in virtually all the main cities - some of which had been conservative strongholds. In the capital, Tehran, final results were yet to be posted but preliminary returns showed candidates from Mr Khatami's political faction poised for a big win.

First place looked like going to the president's brother, Mohammed Reza Khatami. If so, he would be a strong contender for parliamentary speaker.

The election, held on Friday, was seen as a referendum on Mr Khatami's programme for a government accountable to the people, a civil society based on the rule of law and a political system with true separation of powers.

About 80% of the electorate voted. In Tehran, they queued for hours before polling stations opened.

Results released yesterday showed reformers leading with approximately 104 of the 290 parliamentary seats so far, while about 43 seats went to conservative candidates and 37 to independents. At least 57 contests will require second-round run-offs.

The political persuasions of the independent candidates, who could have a decisive impact on the reformists' strength in the new parliament, will not be known until parliament gets under way. Some ran as "independents" in order to disguise their political affiliations.

In largely conservative Mashhad, Iran's second largest city, all five seats went to reformers from the Islamic Iran Participation Front, the Khatami ticket. The president himself was not up for election. The group also won all five seats in Isfahan, Iran's most politically polarised city.

Definitive results for Tehran will not be known for a few days, but reformers have captured at least the first five of the capital's 30 seats. The head of the leading conservative coalition, Mohammed Reza Bahonar, conceded defeat there.

One reformer who appeared to have won easily was Alireza Nouri, brother of the jailed dissident cleric Abdullah Nouri. A conservative-dominated clerical court sentenced Abdullah Nouri, one of Iran's most popular politicians, to five years in prison in November primarily to keep him out of the election; at the weekend he was allowed home from prison for a few days.

Jamileh Kadivar, a former adviser to President Khatami and the sister of a jailed reformist theologian, was also thought to have finished in the first five places for Tehran.

The voters' message of change included a lukewarm vote for the former two-term president, Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, who was the conservatives' leading candidate for a Tehran seat. Preliminary results showed he could finish as low as 25th.

His generation of leaders advocated economic liberalisation but resisted social reform.

Preliminary results released by Iran's interior ministry

Out of 290 seats:

Reformers 104

Conservatives 43

Independents 37

At least 57contests require second-round run-offs

fields.headline: Racism inquiry calls FT editor
fields.standfirst: Foreign media could face South African hearings
fields.trailText: South Africa's human rights commission is attempting to subpoena the editor of the Financial Times to answer accusations of racism at hearings in Johannesburg next month. If Richard Lambert refuses to comply, he could face a six-month prison sentence were he to visit South Africa.
fields.body:
South Africa's human rights commission is attempting to subpoena the editor of the Financial Times to answer accusations of racism at hearings in Johannesburg next month. If Richard Lambert refuses to comply, he could face a six-month prison sentence were he to visit South Africa.

Mr Lambert is the first editor of a foreign publication to join almost every mainstream South African newspaper and broadcaster, more than 30 so far, ordered to attend the inquiry into racism in the media.

It is likely that Britain's Sunday Times and at least one other foreign paper will also be summonsed.

The commission attempted to serve the subpoena on the Financial Times's Johannesburg correspondent, Victor Mallet, on Friday but he refused to accept it as it was addressed to his editor: "I said: 'I'm not the editor of the FT. He's in London. Take it to him there.' Then they went away."

The summons is believed to relate to a story which appeared in August 1996 under the headline "South Africa moves on Muslim militants" about police attempts to curb violence by Islamic vigilantes. The Media Review Network, an Islamic lobby organisation, complained to the human rights commission that the story denigrated Muslims.

The commission spokesman, Siseko Njobeni, said that other foreign publications are likely to face subpoenas, as they were named in a commission report which forms the basis of the hearings.

The controversial report, published last November, repeats allegations of racism, anti-semitism and similar charges from a variety of sources without assessing their merits. According to Mr Njobeni, being named in the report was sufficient to attract a summons.

Britain's Sunday Times is criticised in the report for an article about Muslim vigilantes in South Africa in 1996. The Singapore Straits Times, which reprinted the article, also faces a subpoena. Articles from the Guardian are also likely to come under scrutiny as many were reprinted in sister paper in Johannesburg, the Mail and Guardian, whose editor has been subpoenaed.

Four of the most prominent media groups summonsed, including the Mail and Guardian, wrote to the commission on Friday to demand that the hearings scrapped.

A former commission member, Rhoda Kadalie, has described the subpoenas as "a gross violation of freedom of expression and an attempt to prescribe to the press what they should be thinking and writing".

fields.headline: Ex-soldier shoots family
fields.trailText: A former South African soldier shot dead seven relatives, including two young children, yesterday and threatened to kill himself and a nephew aged 21.
fields.body:
A former South African soldier shot dead seven relatives, including two young children, yesterday and threatened to kill himself and a nephew aged 21.

Police were last night trying to free a woman thought to have been taken hostage by the 35-year-old suspect after the shooting spree at a farm near Prince Alfred Hamlet in Western Cape.

Louis Milne, who runs the farm, said the gunman had worked as a security guard on the farm until six months ago, when he was sacked for pointing a gun at his nephew.

The victims included the man's wife, her three sisters, a brother-in-law and two of the man's children, aged three and seven. A daughter aged 13 escaped the attack.

The suspect was upset because his wife wanted a divorce, police said. AP in Cape Town

webTitle: Sleepy viewers claim record after cinema marathon

fields.headline: Sleepy viewers claim record after cinema marathon
fields.trailText: Fourteen cinema-goers in Thailand stayed up for 51 hours over the weekend to claim the world record for watching films back to back.
fields.body:
Fourteen cinema-goers in Thailand stayed up for 51 hours over the weekend to claim the world record for watching films back to back.

A total of 468 people began the marathon attempt at noon on Friday. By the time the previous record - set by a Hungarian who watched 20 films in 37 hours and 25 minutes - was broken, only 64 contestants were still awake.

By the time all 25 films in the record bid had been shown, another 50 people had succumbed to sleep.

"What I really want now is a shower," said Sumaree Suwan-kham, 55, after watching the final film, The Messenger: The Story of Joan of Arc. Ms Sumaree was the oldest person, and one of four women, to stay the full course.

Staff at the Entertainment Global Village cinema in Bangkok had uncorked the champagne at 4am yesterday when the present record time was reached, during the showing of the 19th film, As Good As It Gets.

"We couldn't give a glass of wine to the contestants as it's not allowed," said Ananya Phungrassamee, speaking for the cinema.

Soon afterwards, contestants started to nod off. They were ushered into beds on site or into the arms of waiting relatives, who had been watching the endurance test on closed circuit television screens set up in the cinema lobby.

The participants were allowed to take only five-minute breaks after every film, with another 15 minutes at the end of three films for meals. The break periods were excluded from the record attempt.

The proceedings were monitored by an infra-red camera to check if contestants fell asleep. Organisers will now send a video of the event to the Guinness Book of Records to get confirmation of the new record, a process that takes about two months.

The winners were all taken for a medical examination and a urine sample to be checked for stimulants at the end of the record attempt. The 14 contestants who endured all 25 films will split the 100,000 baht (£1,640) in prize money.

In addition to the prize money and the glory, the winners were also given a free pass for one year to the cinema.

"It might not be what they want right now," conceded Prawattisart Kuchorn Na Ayuthaya, the cinema manager. "One contestant said it would probably take him two or three months before he wants to watch a film again."

webTitle: Bird songs affect nature of music

fields.headline: Bird songs affect nature of music
fields.trailText: Vivaldi was inspired by a goldfinch to write a flute concerto. Respighi listened to a nightingale and wrote the Fountains of Rome. The three note call of the European quail is a motif in Beethoven's Pastoral Symphony.
fields.body:
Vivaldi was inspired by a goldfinch to write a flute concerto. Respighi listened to a nightingale and wrote the Fountains of Rome. The three note call of the European quail is a motif in Beethoven's Pastoral Symphony.

And Mozart kept a pet starling who may be immortalised in his Divertimento for strings and two horns (K522), a work also known as "The Musical Joke".

Luis Baptista, an ornithologist at the Californian Academy of Sciences, told the meeting yesterday of increasing evidence that the music of nature had a way of affecting the nature of music.

Starlings varied their songs by adding or suppressing notes, recombining notes and varying patterns of notes. Two scientists in 1990 taught starlings human songs, and found that the birds incorporated these into their repertoire.

Mozart's pet starling died on May 27 1784, Dr Baptista said. It was buried with hymns sung at the graveside and a poem penned in its honour.

The divertimento was composed eight days later. The sleeve notes of one recording, said Dr Baptista, talked of "the awkward, unproportioned and illogical" piecing together of material. Since 1990, some experts had suspected that the illogicality was deliberate: it was inspired by the starling's ability to intertwine whistled tunes, do so off-key, and end the performance abruptly.

Starlings had two sound producing organs, collectively called the syrynx, which could operate together or separately. Theoretically, starlings could compose in counterpoint. One starling had been documented producing the high-pitched call of a grey fantail and the low-pitched cry of a kelp gull simultaneously.

Mozart was not afraid to experiment, said Dr Baptista. He deliberately used dissonances in one quartet, K465. "Twentieth century composers often use dissonance for its own sake," he said. "Birds such as starlings have probably used this compositional device long before humans."

One starling had been documented producing the high-pitched call of a grey fantail and the low-pitched cry of a kelp gull simultaneously. Mozart was not afraid to experiment, said Dr Baptista. He deliberately used dissonances in one quartet, K465. "Twentieth century composers often use dissonance for its own sake," he said. "Birds such as starlings have probably used this compositional device long before humans."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Haider party dismisses rally
fields.body:
Haider party dismisses rally

After 150,000 people took part in Austria's biggest anti-government protest since the second world war, Jörg Haider's far right Freedom party yesterday dismissed the Saturday demonstration as the work of leftist extremists.

The party's parliamentary leader, Peter Westenthaler, said the protest against his group's inclusion in government was "nothing more than a rather thin deployment of the communist international with Austria's socialists".
Reuters, Vienna

Jack Lang bids to run Paris

France's former cultural minister, Jack Lang, has stated his intention to become the left's candidate for mayor of Paris in the election next year.

His campaign got off to an unofficial start this weekend when he put his name forward for a party ballot next month. "I am ready to take over Paris if the party is prepared to get behind an exhilarating project run by an enthusiastic team," he said.
Paul Webster, Paris

Internet kidney auction halted

The US internet auction house, eBay, said yesterday it had stopped a human kidney auction, which drew a bid of 200,000 marks (£62,800), that was being conducted on its German website.
Reuters, Berlin

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: The owl's secret
fields.trailText: Holkham, Norfolk
fields.body:
Holkham, Norfolk

Tawny owls are the most common and familiar of our six species of owl. Except for the extreme, treeless north-west they occur right across these islands. Most parishes have a pair and most people have almost certainly heard them. But it's a smaller number that have actually seen the bird's round-winged silhouette floating silently across the sky at dusk.

Fewer still have seen anything more than this. In 30 years of birding I have never once seen a tawny owl hunting or, indeed, performing any interesting behaviour. They are neighbours to most of us, yet their lives are still a wonderful, dark secret.

It was that element of mystery which first galvanised my interest in childhood. Some of my first bird expeditions were into the woods with an electric torch at nightfall. Needless to say, we never once clapped eyes on any owls. The most intimate terms I established with the bird, was hunting down their regurgitated pellets of undigested bone and fur, one of the few means by which owls can be studied in any detail.

These have revealed some remarkable facts. For instance, tawny owls have been found to take prey ranging from insects to birds the size of mallard. Another bizarre anomaly for this quintessentially woodland inhabitant is a record of an individual catching and eating sea-cliff-nesting kittiwakes. But my deepest envy is for the observer who once watched a tawny owl sit in a hedgerow then fly repeatedly out across a freshly ploughed field to squabble with the gulls for worms.

The best I can do is to make regular winter pilgrimage down through the park around Holkham Hall to the towering monument raised in honour of Thomas Coke, the first Earl of Leicester. Nearby is a huge cedar and a pair of roosting tawny owls is usually to be found in residence. Occasionally one of them will shuffle a few feathers or open a sleepy eye, but don't expect much more. These birds and their long ranks of ancestors have probably been perched in the vicinity of this spot, silent and mobile, patiently waiting for nightfall since the 19th century.

fields.headline: We was robbed
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: So, he was robbed. And so was the Labour party and now, possibly, Londoners too. The margin of Ken Livingstone's defeat - only 3% - to Frank Dobson was so narrow that the culprits can be identified more or less straight away.
fields.body:
So, he was robbed. And so was the Labour party and now, possibly, Londoners too. The margin of Ken Livingstone's defeat - only 3% - to Frank Dobson was so narrow that the culprits can be identified more or less straight away.

Step forward Sir Ken Jackson and engineering and electrical union, the AEEU, which cast its block vote for Frank Dobson after a secret vote of 70 or so union delegates. "Just how many AEEU members does it take to change a lightbulb?" asked one wag. The answer? "None; they all have to ask Downing Street first." Step forward also the South London Co-op, who put even the North Korean Communist party to shame, by refusing a ballot of members - instead opting for a "consultation" and throwing a 50,000 block vote behind Dobbo.

"Sixty-seven per cent of those consulted in Lambeth supported Frank," reported a breathless panjandrum, to an executive thrust into the limelight. "So how many consultation forms were returned?" riposted one brave soul. "Er, three!" came the answer.

And what of the London Labour MPs, now so very visibly divorced from the active members who helped propel them to parliament in the first place? A majority trooped loyally into the Dobbo lobby to aid the pyrrhic victory, a handful were alternatively cajoled or offered tea with Tony. Still others were told that support might "not be forthcoming from HQ" come election time - a threat, given recent events - of dubious value. And step forward the former MEP, Pauline Green. Now residing in Manchester, her vote was worth a thousand times that of any ordinary member.

This result is the worst possible result for the Labour party. If there is now a sense of crisis, it is entirely of Downing Street's manufacture and of Millbank's implementation. The forces of "New" Labour armed with a particularly ancient "old" Labour rule book have succeeded in scuppering the chances of the most popular candidate, Ken Livingstone, and saddled the party with another, Frank Dobson, whose credibility has decreased with each passing week. All of this was avoidable. Indeed, the original intention was to hold a quick election on the basis of one member, one vote.

The immediate question is - and it is on everyone's lips - will Ken Livingstone stand as an independent? The public may expect him too, as much of Fleet Street will in turn urge him. Livingstone will feel alternatively angry and cheated by the squalid nature of the campaign run against him, a campaign at times horribly reminiscent of Daily Mail-style red-baiting. He has asked Frank Dobson "as a man of honour" to respect the votes of the members and step down. But Frank's honour has been horribly tarnished. All the while he has expressed mock outrage at the excesses of his pimply entourage, expressing surprise as membership lists arrived and ignorance as those lists were put to his sole advantage. Livingstone has another trump card. He must know that he could stand as an independent - and still win. The BBC's polls show that 70% of Londoners would vote in the mayoral elections if Livingstone had been Labour's official candidate. This plummets to around 50% with Dobson as the front man. And in the wake of a Wales-style Labour voter stay-at-home, thousands of London Labourites may now choose to go on strike. With some justification Livingstone may well wonder if Tony Blair has really wanted Stephen Norris as mayor all along.

But at this point Livingstone may opt for the longer game. He would be wise to do so. He could find, like Rhodri Morgan, a transport of delights awaiting him in a few months time. Also, Livingstone as "independent" would deepen the already gaping wound created by Frank Dobson's zealous lieutenants. The London Labour movement, which so transparently favours Livingstone, would begin to haemorrhage through a wave of defections and expulsions. The SDP split from Labour in the early 80s is a very powerful memory for all of those who have spent years berating the treachery of Messrs Jenkins, Owen and Williams.

It may also occur to Livingstone that there is now only one figure with a base in the wider movement to rival that of Tony Blair. This is not Gordon Brown, John Prescott or Robin Cook - but Mr Kenneth Livingstone. Perhaps this is the real reason that he is feared and as good a reason as any for him to continue to fight his corner in the Labour party.

 Mark Seddon is editor of Tribune

webTitle: Antonov bid puts MoD on the line

fields.headline: Antonov bid puts MoD on the line
fields.trailText: A small, privately-owned British air charter company has joined forces with the Ukrainian aeroplane maker, Antonov, to offer the government a low-cost transporter for ferrying troops and armour to the world's crisis regions.
fields.body:
A small, privately-owned British air charter company has joined forces with the Ukrainian aeroplane maker, Antonov, to offer the government a low-cost transporter for ferrying troops and armour to the world's crisis regions.

A key ministry of defence committee will today consider competing bids for the £500m short-term strategic airlift from a consortium led by Luton-based Air Foyle and US company Boeing.

Its recommendations to the cabinet on this and bids from European and American guided weapons manufacturers to supply smart missiles for the RAF's Eurofighters are seen as defining moments in the government's relations with Europe.

The last-ditch bid from the Air Foyle consortium, including Marshall Aerospace, would save the MoD £300m by offering to supply two Antonov 124-100s for the joint rapid reaction force during 500 hours a year.

Bruce Bird, an Air Foyle director, said yesterday: "The UK - and Europe - have the opportunity to benefit from what is a firesale of the former Soviet Union. For the moment these planes are very cheap and Britain and Europe can help the Ukraine and Russia [which supplies components] by giving them some business."

Mr Bird said the two giant transporters, capable of carrying 120 tonnes of equipment or twice that of the Boeing C-17 on offer, would be acquired by the consortium, operated and crewed by British teams and released to the MoD for the 500 flying hours it requires.

Each of them, he said, is capable of delivering a regiment of 40 Challenger II tanks, 100 tonnes of ammunition and 100 tonnes of spares to a battlefield such as Kosovo within five days days.

The planes - and a further six available at commercial rates - would be deployed on civil freight charter work when not required by the MoD so the consortium could raise enough revenue to sustain the operation.

The MoD is keen, after a series of problems in the Kosovo crisis, to deploy the transporters from next year until 2007 before a more permanent transporter, known as the future transport aircraft, is brought into service.

The later competition puts Boeing, which is offering four C-17s in the short-term, up against a European Airbus consortium building a new A400M and Lockheed Martin's smaller C130-J. The MoD said it would decide its short-term and long-term solutions at the same time.

Mr Bird admitted that the military favoured the C-17 but Boeing had been unable to meet the £500m budget ceiling - and, politically, the cabinet preferred the Airbus transporter, still on the drawing board, in the longer term.

"Ministers need time, within tight budgets, to clarify the problems and options but, in the short term, they have no time," he said.

Ultimately, he added, the best solution for Europe's proposed common army would be to acquire both Antonovs and the smaller A400Ms.

webTitle: IMF stakes its name on a Thai miracle

fields.headline: IMF stakes its name on a Thai miracle
fields.trailText: Thailand has graduated with the "highest honours" from the International Monetary Fund school of economic reform, the fund's outgoing director Michel Camdessus declared last week. The country which was the tinderbox for the Asian financial crisis two and half years ago has bounced back from recession and is set to record growth of around 4% this year.
fields.body:
Thailand has graduated with the "highest honours" from the International Monetary Fund school of economic reform, the fund's outgoing director Michel Camdessus declared last week. The country which was the tinderbox for the Asian financial crisis two and half years ago has bounced back from recession and is set to record growth of around 4% this year.

Signs of renewed vigour are everywhere - cranes are sprouting on the Bangkok skyline again, traffic jams are nearly as bad as three years ago and the streets are full of new vehicles.

It was all very different in the summer 1997. The crisis which brought some of the world's most successful economies to their knees was sparked by the collapse of Thailand's largest finance company, Finance One. For most of the 1990s the country enjoyed a property boom on the back of soft loans from companies such as Finance One, underwritten by foreign investors in search of returns as towering as Bangkok's skyscrapers.

Scramble

But when the company revealed it was bankrupt in May 1997, investors began to question whether the property market was sustainable and started to withdraw their funds, putting the baht under pressure.

Two months after Finance One's collapse, the government gave up defending the value of baht and it depreciated by more than 20% in a week. The crisis quickly spread to neighbouring countries as investors scrambled to pull out of the entire region, sending currencies and stock markets crashing. The governments of the wounded tigers were forced to go cap in hand to the IMF for loans to keep their economies afloat.

Today, all the crisis-hit countries bar Indonesia are in recovery and the IMF is loudly trumpeting the success of the reforms it imposed on the region in exchange for its largest ever financial bail-out. But the stamp of approval from the IMF may not be of much comfort to the Thais. Some wonder whether the economy is really back on its feet, or just experiencing a dead cat bounce.

The Thai stock market has yet to regain its pre-crisis heights and suffered another setback last Thursday as heavy selling by foreign funds sent it tumbling more than 4%. Thailand's bad loans problem is giving investors the jitters - despite the fact that the economy is in its second year of growth, non-performing loans are still worth more than half of annual output.

Meanwhile some Thais are starting to question the medicine which the fund forced them to swallow. The Thai economy was among the hardest hit by the crisis and output has still to recover to its pre-crisis level. Many people blame the severity of the recession on the fund's standard prescription for economies in crisis - cut government spending and raise interest rates in order to defend the exchange rate.

"I firmly believe that the recession was more severe than it would have been otherwise," said Dr Supavud Saicheua, chief economist at Merrill Lynch in Bangkok. "Had the fund not prescribed tight fiscal and monetary policies, the economy would not have contracted by 10% in 1998."

Some Thais look enviously at neighbouring Malaysia, where the government tore up the IMF rulebook, imposing capital controls on short-term lending and abandoning fiscal austerity in favour of reflation. Capital controls have been heavily out of favour with the Washington orthodoxy - the World Bank, the Fund and the American treasury - for the past 20 years and last year, when Malaysia was the slowest to recover from the crisis together with Hong Kong, it appeared that their scepticism was justified.

Now commentators are suggesting that Malaysia's recovery may be more sustainable than in those countries which followed the fund's prescriptions more rigorously.

"The imposition of capital controls freed the authorities' hands to get on with the job of reform and repair without worrying about external influences," said Sharmila Ghosh, from Lombard Street Research in London.

Malaysia's central bank pounced on sick and vulnerable banks as soon as the crisis began and in June 1998, a national fund was set up to buy up their bad debts. Non-performing loans are now 18% of total loans.

Sick economy

In Thailand, progress on cleaning up bad debts has been much slower. Although non-performing loans have fallen from their peak of 70% of all lending, reached in March last year, at 40% of all loans the proportion is still worryingly high. "Underneath the economy is sick," said Lombard Street's Ghosh.

That is a message that neither the Thai government nor the IMF want to hear. The government insists that the current recovery is V-shaped - that growth will quickly be back at pre-crisis levels. But it is hesitating over introducing stricter bankruptcy laws to tackle the hard core of bad debtors who at the moment are able to evade their creditors.

The fund has re-examined its advice to crisis-hit countries as a result of the Asian experience and now admits controls on extremely volatile short-term capital flows may have a limited role to play when a currency is under attack. But it needs the Thai recovery to be a success to vindicate its approach. "Thailand has to recover for the sake of the IMF's reputation, said Merrill Lynch's Dr Supavud. "The teacher desperately needs the student to succeed."

Dr Supavud points out that while Thailand was studying at the IMF's school of reform, "the curriculum changed". Following Malaysia and then Korea's example, the Thai government was allowed to abandon fiscal discipline and run up a budget deficit to stimulate the economy in classic Keynesian fashion.

Although the fund has relaxed some of its more extreme recommendations for countries in crisis, its whole approach to the episode shows that it still blames debtor countries for the crisis rather than the firms in the west which did the lending. The IMF bail-outs rescued foreign lenders rather than helping the local economies and the common wisdom now is that it was crony capitalism and weak financial supervision that brought the Asian economies to their knees.

The Thai government has also found a scapegoat for the crisis. It is attempting to extradite Pin Chakkapak, the former chief of Finance One, from Britain so that he can face charges of embezzlement. Mr Pin says the government is blaming him for the entire financial collapse.

By trying to put the blame for the Asian collapse on the economies at its epicentre, policymakers could be overlooking where the next crisis is brewing. Talk of reforming the international financial system has faded as the Asian recovery has progressed. Instead, the international community has focused on disciplining the debtors rather than curbing the creditors in the west who lent the money, according to Yilmaz Akyuz, the chief economist of Unctad, the UN trade and development agency. "The great debate on the international financial architecture has turned into a discussion about fixing the plumbing," said Mr Akyuz - one of the first economists to predict the crisis back in 1996. He warns that the financial system is inherently unstable. "The danger is complacency ... economies are recovering, the people aren't."

Where will instability strike next? With the United States running a current account deficit of staggering dimensions, the most likely candidate is not hard to spot. But unlike the Asian contagion, if foreign investors pull the plug on Wall Street, the IMF will not be blaming the victim and recommending austerity. Like everyone else, they will be on their knees praying for Alan Greenspan to slash interest rates and rescue the global economy.
