The country which was the tinderbox for the Asian financial crisis two and half years ago has bounced back from recession and is set to record growth of around 4% this year. Signs of renewed vigour are everywhere - cranes are sprouting on the Bangkok skyline again, traffic jams are nearly as bad as three years ago and the streets are full of new vehicles. It was all very different in the summer 1997. The crisis which brought some of the world's most successful economies to their knees was sparked by the collapse of Thailand's largest finance company, Finance One. For most of the 1990s the country enjoyed a property boom on the back of soft loans from companies such as Finance One, underwritten by foreign investors in search of returns as towering as Bangkok's skyscrapers. Scramble But when the company revealed it was bankrupt in May 1997, investors began to question whether the property market was sustainable and started to withdraw their funds, putting the baht under pressure. Two months after Finance One's collapse, the government gave up defending the value of baht and it depreciated by more than 20% in a week. The crisis quickly spread to neighbouring countries as investors scrambled to pull out of the entire region, sending currencies and stock markets crashing. The governments of the wounded tigers were forced to go cap in hand to the IMF for loans to keep their economies afloat. Today, all the crisis-hit countries bar Indonesia are in recovery and the IMF is loudly trumpeting the success of the reforms it imposed on the region in exchange for its largest ever financial bail-out. But the stamp of approval from the IMF may not be of much comfort to the Thais. Some wonder whether the economy is really back on its feet, or just experiencing a dead cat bounce. The Thai stock market has yet to regain its pre-crisis heights and suffered another setback last Thursday as heavy selling by foreign funds sent it tumbling more than 4%. Thailand's bad loans problem is giving investors the jitters - despite the fact that the economy is in its second year of growth, non-performing loans are still worth more than half of annual output. Meanwhile some Thais are starting to question the medicine which the fund forced them to swallow. The Thai economy was among the hardest hit by the crisis and output has still to recover to its pre-crisis level. Many people blame the severity of the recession on the fund's standard prescription for economies in crisis - cut government spending and raise interest rates in order to defend the exchange rate. "I firmly believe that the recession was more severe than it would have been otherwise," said Dr Supavud Saicheua, chief economist at Merrill Lynch in Bangkok. "Had the fund not prescribed tight fiscal and monetary policies, the economy would not have contracted by 10% in 1998." Some Thais look enviously at neighbouring Malaysia, where the government tore up the IMF rulebook, imposing capital controls on short-term lending and abandoning fiscal austerity in favour of reflation. Capital controls have been heavily out of favour with the Washington orthodoxy - the World Bank, the Fund and the American treasury - for the past 20 years and last year, when Malaysia was the slowest to recover from the crisis together with Hong Kong, it appeared that their scepticism was justified. Now commentators are suggesting that Malaysia's recovery may be more sustainable than in those countries which followed the fund's prescriptions more rigorously. "The imposition of capital controls freed the authorities' hands to get on with the job of reform and repair without worrying about external influences," said Sharmila Ghosh, from Lombard Street Research in London. Malaysia's central bank pounced on sick and vulnerable banks as soon as the crisis began and in June 1998, a national fund was set up to buy up their bad debts. Non-performing loans are now 18% of total loans. Sick economy In Thailand, progress on cleaning up bad debts has been much slower. Although non-performing loans have fallen from their peak of 70% of all lending, reached in March last year, at 40% of all loans the proportion is still worryingly high. "Underneath the economy is sick," said Lombard Street's Ghosh. That is a message that neither the Thai government nor the IMF want to hear. The government insists that the current recovery is V-shaped - that growth will quickly be back at pre-crisis levels. But it is hesitating over introducing stricter bankruptcy laws to tackle the hard core of bad debtors who at the moment are able to evade their creditors. The fund has re-examined its advice to crisis-hit countries as a result of the Asian experience and now admits controls on extremely volatile short-term capital flows may have a limited role to play when a currency is under attack. But it needs the Thai recovery to be a success to vindicate its approach. "Thailand has to recover for the sake of the IMF's reputation, said Merrill Lynch's Dr Supavud. "The teacher desperately needs the student to succeed." Dr Supavud points out that while Thailand was studying at the IMF's school of reform, "the curriculum changed". Following Malaysia and then Korea's example, the Thai government was allowed to abandon fiscal discipline and run up a budget deficit to stimulate the economy in classic Keynesian fashion. Although the fund has relaxed some of its more extreme recommendations for countries in crisis, its whole approach to the episode shows that it still blames debtor countries for the crisis rather than the firms in the west which did the lending. The IMF bail-outs rescued foreign lenders rather than helping the local economies and the common wisdom now is that it was crony capitalism and weak financial supervision that brought the Asian economies to their knees. The Thai government has also found a scapegoat for the crisis. It is attempting to extradite Pin Chakkapak, the former chief of Finance One, from Britain so that he can face charges of embezzlement. Mr Pin says the government is blaming him for the entire financial collapse. By trying to put the blame for the Asian collapse on the economies at its epicentre, policymakers could be overlooking where the next crisis is brewing. Talk of reforming the international financial system has faded as the Asian recovery has progressed. Instead, the international community has focused on disciplining the debtors rather than curbing the creditors in the west who lent the money, according to Yilmaz Akyuz, the chief economist of Unctad, the UN trade and development agency. "The great debate on the international financial architecture has turned into a discussion about fixing the plumbing," said Mr Akyuz - one of the first economists to predict the crisis back in 1996. He warns that the financial system is inherently unstable. "The danger is complacency ... economies are recovering, the people aren't." Where will instability strike next? With the United States running a current account deficit of staggering dimensions, the most likely candidate is not hard to spot. But unlike the Asian contagion, if foreign investors pull the plug on Wall Street, the IMF will not be blaming the victim and recommending austerity. Like everyone else, they will be on their knees praying for Alan Greenspan to slash interest rates and rescue the global economy.

fields.headline: In Brief
fields.trailText: Virtual drug firm to float
fields.body:
Virtual drug firm to float

A Hertfordshire company that claims to be the first global "virtual" drug development company is to float on the Alternative Investment Market.

Fulcrum Pharmaceutical Developments manages the development of products for big drugs corporations.

It outsources everything to third parties. However, by cutting out bureaucracy and eliminating any unnecessary clinical trials, it claims to be able to curtail the average development time for each medicine by three to four years.

The company is raising £1m in its offering of shares through stockbroker Seymour Pierce. Its market capitalisation is likely to be between £1.5m and £2m.

Fulcrum was originally part of the drugs group Hoffman La Roche but was bought out by its management in August.

Brand insurer aims to expand

IBNet, an internet surveillance company, intends to list on Aim next month with a public raising of £4m at 50p a share.

The company, which includes a former MoD senior official on its board and employs a staff of nine, expects it will have a market capitalisation of £20m. The proceeds from the capital raising will be used to cancel debt, fund research and development and the purchase of further software. The group claims to provide an "insurance" for companies at risk of having their brand sabotaged on the internet with a programme able to identify bogus websites that may abuse a company's brand and theft of intellectual property.

Asda and Tesco renew price war

Asda and Tesco are set to go head-to-head today in a new round of price wars in Britain's supermarkets.

Tesco is promising £66m worth of cuts affecting 1,000 products, while Asda says it will be reducing prices on goods ranging from cornflakes to confectionery.

But the renewed battle between two of Britain's largest supermarket chains threatens a fresh squeeze on smaller operators, such as Somerfield and Safeway. Price wars between the big players have sent the official index of food prices into negative territory. Over the past year food prices have fallen by 1.6%.

Too few science graduates

Britain has too many arts graduates employed in jobs which underuse their qualifications and not enough mathematicians and scientists, researchers will say today.

The Centre for Economic Performance blames students for choosing the wrong mix of subjects. Too many take arts degrees and avoid taking maths, it says in a report.

fields.headline: Suffering delusions of Bragueness
fields.trailText: Once upon a time in Britain we had Butskellism, the consensus that raising spending on welfare was preferable to cutting taxes. Butskellism - the merger of Rab Butler and Hugh Gaitskell, Tory and Labour - has been replaced by a new cross-party alliance: Bragueness.
fields.body:
Once upon a time in Britain we had Butskellism, the consensus that raising spending on welfare was preferable to cutting taxes. Butskellism - the merger of Rab Butler and Hugh Gaitskell, Tory and Labour - has been replaced by a new cross-party alliance: Bragueness.

Tax levels are traditionally measured by the ratio of government tax revenues to GDP, or TTR for short. The graph shows how British tax levels have changed since 1965.

During the 1960s British TTRs increased under both Conservative and Labour governments, and in the 1970s they declined more or less equally under all administrations, reaching their lowest level in 1979.

But by 1982 they reached their highest ever, only to fall by more than any other EU country during the following 15 years. In 1965 Britain was a relatively high tax country, ranking seventh of the 24 OECD countries; in 1997 it ranked 14th.

Britain was a high tax country throughout the 1960s because of the Butskell consensus. This may have been influenced by the belief that Gaitskell's promise not to increase taxes was one of the causes of Labour's defeat in 1959. Ironically it was John Smith's threat in 1992 to increase taxes, probably one cause of Labour's defeat then, that was responsible for the apparent consensus of the 1990s between the leaders of Conservative and Labour.

Since Gordon Brown and William Hague are two of its main proponents and the consensus is based on an illusion, we should call it Bragueness.

The illusion is that greater productivity, deregulation and privatisation will enable the government to increase expenditure to balance the budget and simultaneously to reduce the TTR.

Bragueness is evidently part of the political struggle to capture the votes of the low-tax lobby, who when employed, have never had it so good. In the 1990s, whichever party was in power was attacked for breaking its promises not to raise taxes and replied that TTRs would decline and welfare targets would be met.

There is a tacit consensus between government and opposition not to attribute unachieved welfare targets to Bragueness. It is never suggested that one reason why there is little poverty in Sweden or no hospital queues in France is that in 1997, the Swedish TTR was 51.9, the French 45.1. and the British 35.4; or more generally that the low UK TTR is not unconnected to the fact that government expenditure as a percentage of GDP is well below that of every other EU country save Ireland, Portugal and Spain. It is also rarely suggested that Britain's low TTR is likely to be partially responsible for its low position in the wealth indicators.

There are valid arguments for adopting a low TTR approach as consistently preferred in Australia, Japan, Switzerland and the US, where the private sector takes on commitments adopted by the state in highly taxed north Europe. It is less easy to justify Bragueness that would pretend it is possible to sustain increased spending with a balanced budget and reduced TTR.

Despite its increase in TTRs, the present government continues to use the Brague rhetoric that TTRs will soon be falling again as the safer way of winning the next election.

Britain's strong economy renders such a strategy plausible. But it seems unlikely that the government will abandon the vagueness of Bragueness to point out with the aid of TTR statistics and welfare indicators that higher TTRs are a necessary condition of improved state provided welfare and infrastructure.

Perhaps it might do so after the next election.

 Ken Messere was head of the OECD fiscal affairs, 1971-91

webTitle: Joining euro 'is economics of the madhouse'

fields.headline: Joining euro 'is economics of the madhouse'
fields.standfirst: Regions would suffer, says report
fields.trailText: Joining the eurozone would be a disaster for Britain's depressed regions which already feel neglected by interest rate decision makers in London, anti-euro campaigners said yesterday.
fields.body:
Joining the eurozone would be a disaster for Britain's depressed regions which already feel neglected by interest rate decision makers in London, anti-euro campaigners said yesterday.

The single currency is a "straitjacket" which will widen the differences between rich and poor areas in Europe, according to Professor Tony Thirlwall.

"The euro implies one rate of interest for all participating countries regardless of their individual circumstances," he says in a pamphlet published today by the anti-euro group, Neweurope Research Trust. "This can only be described as the economics of the madhouse."

Depressed regions in Britain which already feel neglected by interest rate decisions made in London, would feel even more dissatisfied if rates were set in Frankfurt, he says, warning that the euro is putting economic and political stability at risk. "The euro could become a threat to European integration and stability if it exacerbates regional differences within the EU which I believe it is likely to do."

Supporters of the single currency claim that special European budgets earmarked for narrowing the difference between rich and poor regions will help overcome some of the problems of running a single interest rate policy.

But Prof Thirlwall describes the structural fund as a "drop in the ocean" compared with the magnitude of the problem and said that regional policies were a poor substitute for ability of individual countries to offset economic shocks by exchange rate movements.

But pro-euro campaigners said the claims were alarmist and irresponsible. "Were Britain to join a successful single currency it would still be able to use fiscal policy to offset regional differences as it does now," said Kitty Ussher, Britain in Europe's chief economist.

"Moreover we would benefit from increased trade with what is already our largest export market."

The battle of words between pro- and anti-euro camps is heating up, even as the government appears to be cooling off the idea of joining in the near future. Last week, the pro-euro group Britain in Europe said economic research showed that up to 8m jobs could be lost if Britain withdrew from the EU.

But the director of the thinktank which conducted the research, the respected National Institute of Economic and Social Research said the claim was absurd. NIESR will be boycotting the launch today of the group's Out of Europe, Out of Work campaign and trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers said he would be reprimanding Britain in Europe for distoring the research.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Sunday Business
fields.body:
Sunday Business

Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, faces more pressure over his share dealings after it emerged that he did not register shares in Viglen Technology in his name. Mr Morgan bought £20,000 of Viglen shares the day before his paper tipped them and then demonstrated his innocence by saying he would not be stupid enough to buy them in his own name if he was doing so based on such information. While he never appeared on the Viglen register, a spokesman said Mr Morgan presumed he was dealing in his own name.

Gordon Brown will signal he has no regrets about the comments which sparked a nosedive in the share price of BT, leaving the group vulnerable to takeover. He will stress his committment to competition which will be seen as underpinning remarks to the effect that the regulator was considering an early end to BT's monopoly over the local loop.

The Observer

Car group Ford could be thrown a lifeline by the government to lift the threat of closure hanging over mass production at Dagenham. Ford announced the loss of 1,500 jobs there and refused to give long-term assurances about the plant's future. A source close to senior ministers said government help would "depend on what Ford was asking for".

Scottish & Newcastle is to put its Center Parcs holiday business up for sale in the hope of raising £1bn to help fund expansion of its overseas beer business. The move follows news that Bass is considering getting out of the beer business.

Marks & Spencer is to expand its e-commerce arm in an effort to restore its fortunes. M&S will sell nearly half its products online by the end of 2000.

Sunday Times

General Motors, the world's biggest car maker, is wooing BMW in an effort to buy the Land Rover business, which the German group acquired with its takeover of Rover. Industry experts say GM may offer BMW the chance to use its Astra platform for the Rover 25 successor in return for Land Rover or a minority stake in BMW.

Goldman Sachs is planning to launch a Europe-wide online bank in partnership with Idealab, the Californian internet incubator fund.

Sunday Telegraph

Royal London, the life and pensions group, is set for the £1.2bn agreed takeover of United Assurance. It will be the largest takeover of a quoted company by a mutual. Shares rose 15% to 356p as private investors acted on the news.

Cable & Wireless is preparing to break up Optus, its Australian subsitiary and to sell or float its residential and mobile operations in a deal worth £6bn.

IoS

The Financial Services and Markets Bill could be challenged in court unless the treasury removes a clause on internet regulation experts claim breaches EU law.

William Hill is threatening to quit Britain after 66 years of bookmaking if the government fails to cut betting tax in next month's budget.

Mail on Sunday

Pressure is mounting on carpetbaggers' champion Fred Woollard to reveal who is behind his quest to force Standard Life to convert to a bank. The call follows the disclosure that an unusual number of his backers are based in tax havens.

Sunday Express

Two London bankers at the centre of America's biggest money laundering scandal are assassination targets for Russian gangsters, US investigators fear. The bankers are in danger because they are set to give evidence against influential figures in Russian organised crime. The US witness protection scheme is offering the bankers new identities.

fields.headline: Pole position
fields.standfirst: Ecclestone snaps up $1bn for a third of formula one
fields.trailText: Bernie Ecclestone has once again confounded the sceptics, clinching a $1bn (£625m) deal to sell just over a third of his Formula One motor racing business to a San Francisco-based private equity specialist, Hellman & Friedman.
fields.body:
Bernie Ecclestone has once again confounded the sceptics, clinching a $1bn (£625m) deal to sell just over a third of his Formula One motor racing business to a San Francisco-based private equity specialist, Hellman & Friedman.

The move comes a week after Morgan Grenfell Private Equity, the venture capital arm of Deutsche Bank, abandoned attempts to bring a consortium of investors into Mr Ecclestone's business including the Benetton family and Tommy Hilfiger boss Lawrence Stroll.

Having in October bought a 12% stake in Slec Holdings, which owns Formula One Holdings and Formula One Administration, for £234m, Morgan had an option to take its stake to 50% for an additional £700m. But the London-based investment fund allowed its option to lapse.

webTitle: Typical woman earns £250,000 less than a man

fields.headline: Typical woman earns £250,000 less than a man
fields.standfirst: Study shows ministers the reasons for 'female forfeit'
fields.trailText: A woman will on average earn almost £250,000 less than a man during her lifetime, with women who have middle level qualifications paying a higher price than those who have none at all.
fields.body:
A woman will on average earn almost £250,000 less than a man during her lifetime, with women who have middle level qualifications paying a higher price than those who have none at all.

Contrary to general belief, the prime cause of the gender income gap is not earnings lost by time off having children, an analysis published today concludes.

Being a mother can add dramatically to the loss, the analysis shows, but the reasons for what is termed the "female forfeit" are women being concentrated in lower paid sectors of the job market, and discrimination in pay against those doing the same work as men - 25 years after the equal pay act.

Occupations such as primary school teachers, nurses, care assistants, secretaries, cleaners and clerks, where 80% of the workforce is female, are affected.

In a surprise finding that will alarm ministers seeking to encourage teenage girls to stay on at school, the study shows that a woman who leaves school with GCSEs will "lose" £50,000 more over a lifetime than a woman with none. Women in clerical jobs lose more than shop assistants, though unskilled women lose significantly more than those with qualifications if the former have children.

The research, conducted by the London School of Economics on behalf of the government's women's unit, will put pressure on the government to act. Ministers have stressed they will not legislate to enforce gender parity, but instead will urge employers to review pay structures. The TUC, which is running an equal pay campaign, wants firmer action, while the equal opportunities commission is campaigning for effective measures short of legislation.

The findings underline the greater pay gap for women working part-time. While the full-time pay gap has narrowed over 20 years so that women earn an average 84% of men's wages, female part-timers receive 58% of the rate per hour for male full-timers.

The study, Women's Incomes Over a Lifetime, will be launched today by the two ministers for women, Baroness Jay and Tessa Jowell.

Responding to the findings, Baroness Jay will say: "This research shows that women are paying a heavy economic price just for being female.

"They are experiencing a female forfeit.

"We should celebrate the fact that women have made great progress in the labour market over the last 20 years but the analysis starkly underlines there are still many barriers that need to be overcome."

The research divides women into three categories: Mrs Low-skill, with no qualifications; Mrs Mid-skill, qualified to GCSE level and perhaps working in a clerical job; and Mrs High-skill, a graduate professional.

It shows that, for mid- and high-skilled women, the earnings penalty is higher than that incurred by having children. Only for low-skilled women, who spend much longer away from the workplace and return to work part- time, is the mother gap higher than the core "female forfeit".

The findings also confirm that the timing of motherhood is another factor affecting income, with young mothers suffering the highest income penalties. If Mrs Mid-skill has her first child by 24 she is estimated to forgo more than double the earnings of a mother who starts at 30.

A total "parent gap" meanwhile, reveals big income differences between a married mother and father with the same skills level. A low-skilled woman with two children is worst hit, earning approaching £500,000 less than her husband over a lifetime.

The income forfeited over a lifetime by women also has implications in retirement. A mid-skill woman with children pays £2,000 less in pension contributions than a similarly-educated woman without children, but receives a total of £7,000 less in pension payments.

The women's ministers will today claim that the findings would inform future policy-making on issues such as welfare support, the New Deal, childcare and career choices.

However, critics will argue that current policy, which targets low-income women with benefits such as the working family tax credit as part of the government's goal of tackling child poverty, ignores the wider factors penalising women of all backgrounds.

Campaigners including the equal opportunties commission and the TUC will want to see more done to increase low wages in female-dominated employment sectors, and steps to remedy the extra pay penalty for part-time working.

They will also press for more to be done to ensure women taking time out to have children can return at an equivalent level rather than taking a lower-paid job.

webTitle: Malcolm McLaren's top 10 books of the moment

fields.headline: Malcolm McLaren's top 10 books of the moment
fields.trailText: Malcolm McLaren is an impresario and style guru. He plans to stand for the post of London's mayor
fields.body:
Malcolm McLaren is an impresario and style guru. He plans to stand for the post of London's mayor.

1. Peter Pan by JM Barrie

The best sex story I ever read.

2. Moll Flanders by Daniel Defoe

The toughest, bitchiest indictment of a dishonest society by the best writer England has ever produced.

3. Oliver Twist by Charles Dickens

An unforgettable journey into criminal behaviour that takes me back to my own childhood fantasies. A book I read when I was extremely young, and one that justified all my desires to create an environment in which I could truthfully run wild, forever recreating those artful dodgers/Sex Pistols.

4. Christian Dior by Francoise Giroud

Does passion end in fashion? The ultimate luxury item to be browsed over in the bath.

5. The Private Case by Patrick Kearney

The dirtiest list of rudery ever published in England or elsewhere, all its contents available on request to the British Library's chief librarian. Information Hitler's spies were desperate to get their hands on during the war.

6. Out of Control by Kevin Kelly

This is a wonderful, inspirational 21st-century thinking man's guide to the new culture - how machines are becoming more human and how humans, in turn, are becoming more like machines.

7. Lady Chatterley's Lover by DH Lawrence

The most melancholic and blissfully romantic novel I have recently re-read.

8. Being Digital by Nicholas Negroponte

The allure of the digital revolution, with all the necessary roadmaps so that you cannot help but fall in love with it.

9. The Story of O by Pauline Reage

A strange and adorable journey into the sublime world of a girl's bad, mad and crazed sexual misadventures. Happiness in slavery; the laughter of genius in the bathroom of our mind.

fields.headline: Desktop icons
fields.standfirst:
No 7: Sticky tape
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: No 7: Sticky tape
fields.body:
Dick Drew always wanted to be a banjo player - which just goes to show how little understanding so many of us have of our true place in history. For Dick, a high-school dropout from Minneapolis, was destined for a far greater role in world affairs than can be easily achieved with a stringed instrument and a sense of rhythm.

Technically speaking, Drew didn't actually invent sticky tape. That honour goes to another group of musicians - a band of lute-makers in 1670 who used "little pieces of paper, so big as pence or two pences, wet with glew" to hold sycamore strips in place while they built their instruments.

But Drew's moment in the sun was assured when in 1921 he was hired by 3M, then an ailing sandpaper manufacturer. On the job, he encountered a car-painter who was struggling to complete a two-tone paint job cleanly; a few brainwaves later, Drew had created masking tape.

Coincidentally, the chemicals firm Dupont was developing Cellophane around the same time; Drew combined the two ideas and sticky tape was born.

His product - eventually named Scotch Tape - met a gaping need, helping Depression-era Americans "make do and mend", and was used for everything from patching cracked hens' eggs to sealing chewing-gum packets.

But the many applications of sticky tape don't stop there: in 1973, Swiss criminologist Max Frei deployed strips of the stuff to extract pollen grains from the Turin Shroud. Now all we need is someone to develop a foolproof way to find the end of the roll.

fields.headline: Heaven - or private hell
fields.standfirst:
Leaving the office grind to work as a personal service PA has its perks. But as Finola Lynch finds, it also has pitfalls
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Leaving the office grind to work as a personal service PA has its perks. But as Finola Lynch finds, it also has pitfalls.
fields.body:
Georgina Galanis lasted only nine days as PA to supermodel Naomi Campbell. During a stay in Canada, Galanis claimed, her celebrated boss lost her temper and hit her over the head with a mobile phone, shook her by the throat and punched her. It was the end of a promising working relationship.

Working as a personal service PA (PSPA for short) is a labour of love. Secretarial skills are a requirement, but more important are flexibility and patience by the bucketful. Nine-to-fivers need not apply.

It's not only celebrities who need an assistant-cum-secretary. "Perhaps it's a single businessman whose home and company are in different parts of the country," says Mike Dark, partner of the British Employment Agency, which specialises in recruiting private service staff. "Or a disabled person who needs someone to help them work from home."

But the majority in this niche market are working in an environment far removed from the typical workplace. "The employer can be anything from the royal family to pop stars. Lady-this and Countess-that. Majors, lords and chairmen of global conglomerates." Not for PSPAs the daily grind of office life, battling with the photocopier and taking endless calls from the supplier. Their challenges and frustrations can be as diverse as the moods of their employer.

PSPAs usually live with their employer and are responsible for juggling both their business and private affairs. The clients of private service agency Serena Le Maistre & Associates in London's Belgrave Street are usually wives of corporate chairmen. "They have to organise everything on the social front - dinner parties or grouse-shooting weekends," says Le Maistre. "Confidentiality and discretion are essential - and if the nanny is off sick, the PA does the school run too."

So why do secretaries choose to ignore the corporate ladder for a job where walking the employer's beloved dogs is as important as opening the mail? Perplexed PA professionals need only look at the perks. Caroline Travis, PSPA to one of the country's 50 richest men, has a self-contained apartment, a car and all her expenses paid. Salaries are also much higher than the commercial sector. "It's at least £300 a week, cash in hand. Without accommodation or expenses that's worth £30,000 a year in London," she says.

The job may be unusual, but snobbish stereotypes about personal secretaries apply. More than half of PSPAs are part of a couple where the husband is the gardener or butler and the wife is the secretary/housekeeper. Of the remainder, 30% are women, the majority in their 40s, either single or divorced. "They are not going to move anywhere and have nowhere to go," says Dark, "which is probably a callous way of putting it."

Callous, but fair, concedes Travis, 50, who is divorced. "I've always been an independent woman but you can't have a private life in the week because you could be called at any time."

So why did Naomi Campbell admit this month to assaulting the very person employed to look after her? Whether her PA wasn't up to the job, or Campbell's rage was a celebrity tantrum too far, the root cause lies in the very nature of this peculiar job, says Marjorie Mair, head of secretarial and administrative development for the Industrial Society. "Where do you draw the line when the personal is also the professional?" she asks.

The relationship between a PSPA and her employee is rarely like that of a boss and secretary in an office set-up, she says. For a start the majority of PSPAs do not work from a recognisable office. Employees are expected to improvise in the boss's home, drafting letters and taking telephone calls from the comfort of a silk-covered sofa where even a little coffee spill may be a major faux pas. You also have to be prepared to do anything your boss thinks is important, even if it's just collecting his dry-cleaning.

Sara Ford, 35, is PA/housekeeper to an employer with a 14-bedroom mansion in a 22-acre forest on his estate in West Sussex. She says that on occasions she has to threaten to resign to get her employers to see how busy she is. "Sometimes it's the only way to make them listen, especially if they have been away all week."

Agencies such as the British Employment Agency claim to attract "discerning employers and employees", but although the PA's CV is checked thoroughly, the potential employer is never submitted to the same level of scrutiny. Dark recognises that this is far from ideal, but says the relationship between boss and PA is difficult to police. "It all comes down to chemistry. Until the candidate sees the accommodation, the family and the property, it's hard to tell how it's going to work. And if you're not prepared to do what the employer wants, they'll just find somebody else who will."

PSPAs are also in danger of missing out on basic employment rights. Travis was never given a formal contract by her boss and says that at her interview "carrots were dangled that were never going to materialise".

"I wasn't told my employer was estranged from his wife. He's just bought an estate in Germany and I was told there would be trips abroad to help the family. Instead I'm a very disillusioned kennel maid.

"At Christmas I was ordered to give up my New Year with less than a week's notice to look after their four dogs, who all have behavioural problems, while they went on holiday to the Caribbean. I started every day cleaning up the mess and spent New Year's Eve in tears. I was the only person on this 30-acre estate for most of the time and it got very isolating.

"I believe my employers brought me here under false pretences. They know they've got someone trust- worthy and reliable to look after the house but my main responsibility is dog-sitting. The PA side to the job never materialised."

Agencies have little influence over errant employers if basic employment rights are not met. PSPAs are advised to draw up a contract setting out pay and conditions but Dark has no idea how often this is met. Travis has learnt this to her cost. "At least in the commercial sector you have some kind of warning system to go through. I don't even know what a sackable offence is."

It might seem astonishing that this experienced administrator, who has worked in catering and local government, would be prepared to tolerate such unhappy working conditions. Travis explains that, coming originally from the Channel islands, she had hoped to find a secure post in mainland Britain. "I wanted to work in the UK in an environment where one has privacy and protection of an established family who need someone on call."

Employers are not always honest, she says, about the facilities they are offering. "They seem to think that because they are offering you a flat and the use of a car as part of the deal, you should feel really grateful to them. Then you find out your room is actually in an attic within the main body of the house, which is not so private and not such an incentive after all."

Victoria Phillips, employment solicitor for trade union law firm Thompson's, says private service staff are entitled to nearly all the same rights as ordinary workers - a statement of terms and conditions of employment, pension scheme, sick pay, an itemised pay slip and recent EU directives such as the 48-hour week. However a private service employer can refuse a candidate on race or sex grounds without legal redress and tax and national insurance payments are often fudged. "Without an itemised pay slip you don't know if you're working to a legal contract," she says. "Go into private service and you're simply more vulnerable."

fields.trailText: She started at the Open University on switchboard, now she's an academic assistant. And as Tricia Smoothy tells Carol Kennedy, she has finally enrolled to do a degree.
fields.body:
February sees the start of the academic year at the Open university, Britain's largest single teaching institution, and Tricia Smoothy's telephone lines have been buzzing with queries from anxious callers.

"Students often sound worried," says Smoothy, 39, an academic assistant. "Many have full-time jobs or domestic responsibilities and time is very important to them. They need the answer straight away and I have to deal with them promptly or pass them on to the right person."

The Open university has registered more than 150,000 undergraduates this year. The majority fall into the 25-45 age group but the youngest graduate so far has been 20 - and the oldest 94. OU courses, based on books, TV and radio programmes, are designed for students studying from home anywhere in the UK, Ireland and further afield. Walton Hall in Milton Keynes is the OU's policy-making centre, but personal contact and support comes through locally based tutors and the 13 regional offices which bring the OU within reach of everyone living in the UK.

Smoothy is based at the East Anglia regional office in Cambridge, where more than 15,000 students will register this year. She has been with the social science faculty for five years, having worked her way through the switchboard, reception and the arts faculty.

She supports three academic staff who have variable working patterns involving several days away from the office, so for much of her time she works on her own initiative and to her own schedule, keeping in touch with the tutors by email and handling general queries in their absence.

She is responsible for booking study centres, mailing course materials to students and keeping tutors briefed, which requires some juggling. "Tricia is the interface with all the operational side," says staff tutor Dr Troy Cooper. "It's not a question of telling her what to do, she tells us what's reasonable or even possible. She'll also prompt us about deadlines - today she came in and gave me a kick to complete the staff contracts."

Last-minute crises do occur and Smoothy may be the only one on hand to deal with the problem. "A tutor could have a car accident on Friday afternoon and I would have to find another tutor for the Saturday tutorial or contact 15 students to tell them not to turn up."

A major change has been the computerisation of the work. "The academic staff have all become computer literate and they are willing to do their own letters," she says. She uses the internet more and more as the OU now has its own website and an online management database containing all the administrative data she would previously have accessed by telephone or internal mail.

She welcomes this change to her role. "At first, there was a lot of typing, but now I work with the academics, rather than for them. My name goes out on many letters to the tutors, so they tend to contact me with their queries."

The OU accepts a special responsibility to make higher education accessible to people with disabilities and about 5,500 of its students fall into this category. An important facet of the job is liaison with the study support advisers. "Tutors ring up to say that they have disabled students and need information about how best to help them in their studies. I can pass them on to a specialist adviser. If a student cannot get to a study centre, I can find their records on the database in a moment and contact a staff tutor, who may authorise a special tutorial session to take place on the telephone.

The highlight of the academic year is the annual graduation ceremony in Ely Cathedral, where Smoothy helps in the robing area and meets the graduates face to face. "It's very satisfying to see the pleasure on their faces," she beams. "We are all in such high spirits when we are there and you are really seeing the end results of your job."

Like many people in education, Smoothy feels that her pay doesn't adequately reflect her responsibilities. "But there's something that keeps me here. It's a very friendly and caring place to work. Besides, I've just found the courage to register for a degree course myself."

 The OU website is at www.open.ac.uk

webTitle: Staff get in on lucrative dot.com act

fields.headline: Staff get in on lucrative dot.com act
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: CGU has become one of a handful of companies which is attempting to tackle competition from internet rivals by encouraging its own staff to propose dot.com ventures.
fields.body:
CGU has become one of a handful of companies which is attempting to tackle competition from internet rivals by encouraging its own staff to propose dot.com ventures.

The company sees its support for staff internet projects not only as a way to expand its own business and keep a finger in new insurance developments but also as a way to retain employees who might otherwise simply decamp, taking their ideas and their experience with them.

Traditional businesses are increasingly recognising that they risk losing their most entrepreneurial employees unless they can devise outlets for their cutting edge ventures as well as the potentially lucrative rewards which are now associated with so many internet start ups.

CGU says about 50 projects have so far been given the green light and the first off the ground is bluecycle.com, a cyber auction site selling stolen goods recovered by the police and other insurance salvage goods. A homebuying site, which is likely to offer mortgages and insurance, is forecast to kick off in the spring.

The cyber-cultivation scheme is known as Siliconwharf, reflecting its base in a warehouse alongside the River Thames.

webTitle: 'To talk to a machine, press 1 on your keypad'

fields.headline: 'To talk to a machine, press 1 on your keypad'
fields.standfirst: When staff are told to impersonate their firm's telephone answering service because the voicemail system has crashed, is it time for businesses to re-examine their attitude to customer care?
fields.trailText: Dealing with us customers for any length of time leads many businesses to conclude that we are all barking mad, psychotic troublemakers or dimwits who only ring because they've run out of Play-Doh.
fields.body:
Dealing with us customers for any length of time leads many businesses to conclude that we are all barking mad, psychotic troublemakers or dimwits who only ring because they've run out of Play-Doh.

Customer care is best left to the machines, then, and who hasn't experiences the joy of transactions via voicemail, e-mail, call waiting and touch-tone call centres? It was only a matter of time before the humans began impersonating machines, in what has to be the ultimate irony of the technological age.

According to two leading medical journals, the NHS made staff pretend to be ansaphones when its voicemail system experienced technical difficulties. When customers became suspicious, staff were told to repeat their messages parrot-fashion.

Surely dealing with voicemail messages is bad enough without having to stem the paranoia that the robotic voice on the other end might be a real person. Here are a few customer care tips from one human being to another which might stop us all from cracking up under the strain of too much technology

Touchy-feely

Customers come in all shapes and sizes and need to be treated as individuals, which is why the 'Have a nice day' stuff just doesn't work. There is no 'one-size-fits-all' technique, so scripting staff is a waste of time and effort.

The British will put up with delays, queues and incompetence but we can't stand insincerity, being ignored or being patronised.

Mission statements or customer charters are unnecessary. If your company provides a good level of service your clients will already know and won't need to be told.

Hassle free

Difficult clients cause stress, which is why good customer care is a win-win skill. Hone your own techniques with clients by applying some of these tricks of the trade:

 Don't ask people what they want. Customer satisfaction surveys aren't welcome because so many companies use them, and people get annoyed about filling them in. Customers don't always know what they want; they expect you to offer a service or product and they'll let you know if they like it or not.

 Never over-promise or under-deliver. Unrealistic expectations are impossible to deal with. Companies have spent so long bending over backwards to please their customers that they've ended up creating rods for their own backs.

 Be honest. Phone back when you say you will. Never use phrases like 'I won't be a minute' or 'It'll only take a couple of seconds'. Avoid any delays. Estimate potential waiting times and then build in a cushion.

 Avoid using corporate patter. There is always a switch-off point when the phoney-sounding stuff kicks in, like 'Missing you already' or 'You are our customer and therefore you are the most valuable member of our team'... Nobody is listening to it, so cut it out.

 Listen. Complaining or unhappy customers have a basic desire to tell you what's wrong. Let them get to the end of their tale of woe and allow them to repeat it, if necessary. Interrupting will only add fuel to the gripes. Give your name and tell them what you will do and when you will do it.

 Understand the customer's values might not be the same as your own. Offering them a free bun and a cup of tea after a train delay might be inappropriate if they're stressed out of their skull and incoherent with rage. Refunding money doesn't always work if the faulty goods created massive inconvenience.

 Don't over-smile. Grinning like the village idiot looks phoney. Rehearse something that appears less like something out of Jaws.

 Don't over-apologise. One sorry sounds more sincere than a stream of 'terribly', 'awfully' and 'dreadfullys'.

 Don't get stressed. Stress can turn you into a raging harridan. Stay calm, even when you're handling potential conflict.

 Don't take it personally. You're dealing with a customer. It's your job, not your real life. Be professional and helpful but don't get emotionally hung-up about it.

fields.headline: Awkwardly cute
fields.standfirst:
Romeo et Juliette
Royal Opera House, Covent Garden
Rating: * *
fields.trailText: Furtive thrills and frissons of grand passion are what the Royal Opera's revival of Gounod's Romeo et Juliette is supposed to be all about.
fields.body:
Furtive thrills and frissons of grand passion are what the Royal Opera's revival of Gounod's Romeo et Juliette is supposed to be all about.

Gounod, writing for a bourgeois Parisian audience, turns Shakespeare's teenage lovers into a pair of Second Empire sensualists. Then there's the presence of Angela Gheorghiu and Roberto Alagna in the lead roles. Husband and wife off stage, opera's controversial "golden couple" have developed a reputation as a double act, specialising in the portrayal of great loves.

The inevitable question is whether they lived up to expectations. Regrettably, they didn't quite. Vocally they're now less than ideally matched. Alagna has pushed his voice beyond its natural lyrical capacities and his soft singing lacks the elegant finesse he once possessed. Gheorghiu continues to amaze but the dark, hedonistic beauty of her voice is perhaps more suited to Verdi than to the French repertoire.

The sexual and emotional chemistry between the pair took a long time to materialise. For the first three acts, they seemed to sing at rather than to each other. Only in the final scene was there any sense of physical or emotional intimacy.

Gounod's focus on his central couple makes the remaining roles ungrateful, though there were strong performances, notably William Dazely's Mercutio and an ebullient and sympathetic Capulet from Sorin Coliban. Charles Mackerras conducted with tremendous electricity, disguising the fact that when Gounod isn't aspiring to be sexy, he can sometimes be distressingly cute.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Travel broadens your career horizons
fields.standfirst:
Can taking time out to farm daffodils in New Zealand or work as a chalet girl in France strengthen your job prospects? Tom Twentyman reports
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: How does the prospect of a career break abroad sound? The thought of jetting off to foreign climes, whether to continue your chosen job or to take a breather, probably rates pretty high on most wish lists. But does skipping off for a while broaden your career prospects as well as your horizons, or is a "career break" more likely to mean a broken career?
fields.body:
How does the prospect of a career break abroad sound? The thought of jetting off to foreign climes, whether to continue your chosen job or to take a breather, probably rates pretty high on most wish lists. But does skipping off for a while broaden your career prospects as well as your horizons, or is a "career break" more likely to mean a broken career?

The news for those with itchy feet is encouraging. "Employers do value this kind of thing," says Angela Baron of the Institute of Personnel and Development. "They see it in a beneficial way, in that it enhances personal development. A few years ago, it was much less common than today, but it simply isn't the sole preserve of students on their gap year any longer."

Sarah El-Doori, PR manager of recruitment consultants Office Angels, is equally prositive. "There is such a a skills shortage that candidates with the right ones should always get work on their return," she says.

James Munro, of recruitment consultants Appointment Bi-Language, agrees. He also cites a wealth of opportunities for the experienced, and for those wanting to brush up on a language he suggests combining time out with living and working in the relevant country.

Take Rosanna Randall, a 25-year-old secretary in a large American investment bank. A graduate in French, she was a temp before realising an ambition last winter, working as a chalet girl in the French resort of Meribel.

Part of her job was liaising between guests and the resort services. "The language came in especially useful when things went wrong, such as needing to call in a plumber. I had decent French before I went to Meribel, but it definitely improved while I was there."

And what if you are tempted to go further afield? Claire Newcombe, 29, left her job as a stewardess with British Airways to accompany her partner to New Zealand. Returning via Australia, Thailand and India, the trip took 12 months. "It was a life-enriching experience, and very, very relaxing," she recalls. "This maybe sounds a bit hippy-ish, but we took in our surroundings, and appreciated things a lot more."

The couple took the decision not to do any office work during their journey. "We were on a daffodil farm in New Zealand for a time, although the fact that we didn't want to be stuck inside did leave us on a tight budget. However, that's the sort of thing which can sell something like this to prospective bosses back home."

When job-hunting, stress the advantages, she urges. "Point out that you're self-motivated enough to have actually done it. Experiencing different cultures and social groups means you've got better communication skills. Or perhaps going on a trek has helped your teamwork or leadership capabilities. Concentrate on those areas."

Once in the UK, Newcombe got back into the routine of work "horrifyingly quickly". After a stint temping, she joined the youth development charity Raleigh International last April, as PA to the resources director. She adds that, like a lot of charities, it tends to employ people with some travel as part of their background.

Even if you feel your membership of Generation X has expired, that that doesn't mean you have left it too late. Thirtysomethings on the job market after a lengthy foreign sojourn are not facing any greater risk of rejection than if they'd taken time off for other reasons, such as to start a family, report recruitment professionals.

Though Baron sounds one note of caution: "This is not the sort of thing to do on a whim. If it's a case of 'I hate my job, and I want out of here,' then it's more than likely that you haven't thought everything through." So perhaps it's better to postpone booking that farewell party just yet.

fields.headline: 4,000 jobs go in CGU link-up
fields.standfirst:
Staff to bear brunt of £200m cost cuts in £20bn merger with Norwich Union
Mergers explained
fields.trailText: The attempt to create a British insurance group able to compete with the global heavyweights will take a huge step forward today when CGU and Norwich Union unveil plans for a £20bn merger.
fields.body:
The attempt to create a British insurance group able to compete with the global heavyweights will take a huge step forward today when CGU and Norwich Union unveil plans for a £20bn merger.

The deal, which will mean the loss of about 4,000 jobs, will catapult the enlarged group to the head of the British insurance industry. If shares rise as expected this morning the new union will overtake Prudential as the largest player in the land.

CGU will immediately put up its American operations for sale with a price tag of about £2.2bn. That will reduce combined revenues but these should still top £25bn a year from the companies' 25m worldwide customers.

The merger rivals the value of Royal Bank of Scotland's acquisition of NatWest as the largest financial services deal in British corporate history and it will create a group which will claim to be the sixth biggest player in world insurance.

It follows a series of deals in the British insurance market which have transformed the competitive landscape, with all but a handful of participants being swallowed in the quest for economies of scale. The government's determination to impose a ceiling on the costs of providing stakeholders pensions has acted as an additional spur.

The new group will have nearly £190bn of policyholders' funds under management and will have operations in 60 countries. Thanks to CGU's recent overseas expansion strategy, it will be one of the largest insurers in the Netherlands and France where CGU also has a substantial shareholding in Société Générale.

Bob Scott, the chief executive of CGU who will assume command of the enlarged company, will reveal this morning that the companies intend to cut about £200m a year off their combined costs.

Jobs are expected to be lost in Norwich, where Norwich Union is the largest employer, although the attrition will be spread throughout Britain.

Mr Scott faced a similar difficulty when Commercial Union merged with General Accident which was the biggest source of work in Perth. Today an administrative centre remains in Perth, although the CGU business is run from London. Norwich will remain a major hub.

In all, more than 5% of the total 70,000 employees are likely to lose their jobs although the new company clearly hopes to expand its life and pensions business in Britain - where it will sell one in every eight insurance policies - boosted by the awareness that cradle-to-grave provision by the government is no longer likely. It is understood that Richard Harvey, the Norwich Union boss, will become deputy chief executive of the new company and will be seen as the most likely successor to Mr Scott who retires in two years. Pehr Gyllenhammar, the CGU, chairman will continue in the same role at the enlarged group.

Peter Foster of CGU becomes finance director while Norwich Union's finance chief, Mike Biggs, will run general insurance.

Thanks to CGU's recent overseas expansion strategy, it will be one of the largest insurers in the Netherlands and France where CGU also has a substantial shareholding in Société Générale. Bob Scott, the chief executive of CGU who will assume command of the enlarged company, will reveal this morning that the companies intend to cut about £200m a year off their combined costs. Jobs are expected to be lost in Norwich, where Norwich Union is the largest employer, although the attrition will be spread throughout Britain. Mr Scott faced a similar difficulty when Commercial Union merged with General Accident which was the biggest source of work in Perth. Today an administrative centre remains in Perth, although the CGU business is run from London. Norwich will remain a major hub. In all, more than 5% of the total 70,000 employees are likely to lose their jobs although the new company clearly hopes to expand its life and pensions business in Britain - where it will sell one in every eight insurance policies - boosted by the awareness that cradle-to-grave provision by the government is no longer likely. It is understood that Richard Harvey, the Norwich Union boss, will become deputy chief executive of the new company and will be seen as the most likely successor to Mr Scott who retires in two years. Pehr Gyllenhammar, the CGU, chairman will continue in the same role at the enlarged group. Peter Foster of CGU becomes finance director while Norwich Union's finance chief, Mike Biggs, will run general insurance.

webTitle: Vic Marks's top 10 books on cricket

fields.headline: Vic Marks' top 10 books on cricket
fields.trailText: Vic Marks is a cricket writer and the co-author of the Wisden Illustrated History of Cricket.
fields.body:
Vic Marks is a cricket writer and the co-author of the Wisden Illustrated History of Cricket.

1. The Art of Captaincy by Mike Brearley

OK, he writes for the Observer, but this is the best book of its kind, enhanced by countless well-remembered examples from games in which he was involved.

2. The Cricket Captains of England by Alan Gibson

Gibson was a minor genius - whether as a broadcaster, writer or journalist, arriving late from Didcot.

3. Harold Gimblett, Tormented Genius of Cricket by David Foot

Foot is obviously fascinated by tormented West Country geniuses - a biography of Hammond was to follow. Gimblett was his boyhood hero, but he explores him with rigour nonetheless.

4. 46 Not Out by RC Robertson Glasgow

Another tormented West Country genius who wrote beautifully.

5. Cricket With A Swing by John Clarke

Probably not a classic, but the first tour book I read. It recalls the wonderful 1963 tour of England by Frank Worrell's West Indians.

6. A Lot of Hard Yakka by Simon Hughes

Irreverent stuff about the era in which I played: most of it rings true.

7. The Art of Cricket by Donald Bradman

Because we ought to find out how the greatest batsman thought the game should be played.

8. A Century of Great Cricket Quotes by David Hopps

Not a great title, perhaps, and it could do with a proper index, but there are some gems in here.

9. Tales From a Long Room by Peter Tinniswood

More gems, this time from the Brigidier who loves "fine claret, Vimto, quail in season, barrage balloons, blotting paper, EW Swanson and his sister, Gloria".

10. Beyond a Boundary by CLR James

Well, we should all read this at some time or another.

fields.headline: A question of substance
fields.standfirst:
Companies are increasingly asking prospective employees to take a drugs test. But do you have to comply if you want the job? Ann Bird looks at workers' rights
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Discovering at a job interview that your handwriting might be analysed is unconventional although not uncommon, but what if you were asked whether you'd mind under-going a test for possible "substance abuse"? It could happen, and it's perfectly legal.
fields.body:
Discovering at a job interview that your handwriting might be analysed is unconventional although not uncommon, but what if you were asked whether you'd mind under-going a test for possible "substance abuse"? It could happen, and it's perfectly legal.

According to John Courtis, of recruitment specialists Courtis and Partners, screening potential employees for alcohol or illegal drugs is on the increase. "Interview questions are designed to provoke greater disclosure, and 'Would you permit us to arrange a test for possible substance abuse?' is a killer question. After all, it might be crucial to the firm's security, and abuse could seriously affect your performance."

Workplace drugs testing originated in America about 15 years ago. Whether you will be tested, usually by means of a urine sample, depends very much on the ethos of the company. In a typical workforce of 1,000 it's quite possible that 200 people are using illegal drugs, so it's perhaps not surprising that many companies will want to test candidates before employing them.

For anyone who may have indulged in something a little naughty, there is no point in abstaining for a few days before a possible test. "We can detect traces of some substances from over a week before the test," says Ian Dick, a corporate pathologist. Companies should always declare what they are testing for, he says, but they may merely tell you that you've failed. You're within your rights to have access to more detailed results, but it may take some time to see them.

It might all sound like an invasion of privacy, if not an abuse of your civil rights, but there is a strong legal basis to such testing. According to employment law specialist Ronnie Fox from City solicitors Fox Williams, "Potential employees have few rights apart from the right not to be discriminated against on the grounds of sex or race, and the employer can make reasonable requests." He says that, in theory, any company can arrange to test at any time.

As an employee, it is quite possible that your contract of employment states that you could be asked to take a medical examination at the company's request - and this could include a test for substance abuse. If you refuse, you could be sacked.

Nicola Dandridge, at trade union solicitors Thompsons, says: "If an employee has a drug problem, the employer has a legal obligation to treat them as if they were ill, rather in the way they should deal with someone suffering from alcoholism; they shouldn't simply sack the employee. But if they were taking illegal drugs on the premises it may be grounds for dismissal." But she admits there are few hard and fast rules on testing: "No one quite knows because it's so new - rather like the law on sending emails. It's all rather vague."

The civil rights organisation Liberty says employers should make it explicit in contracts if they intend to test an employee regularly. "Of course there are some occupations where everyone accepts that routine drug testing is inevitable," says Liz Parratt, campaigns manager. "Commercial pilots, for example, have a heavy responsibility for public safety and know that they will be routinely drug tested. But if you're a data entry clerk in a bank, the equation is entirely different.

"In general, what staff get up to in their leisure time is not their employer's business. The reality is that many young people are recreational drug users. They're not addicts. Drug use doesn't cause them significant problems, and it has no discernible impact on their work."

She recommends that "if your employer is introducing drug testing and you are not happy about your privacy being invaded in this way, you should contact your trade union. If your workplace is not unionised, then contact your local law centre or citizens advice bureaux."

Transform, which campaigns for the legalisation of all drugs, believes that, aside from issues of civil liberties, screening itself can be highly flawed. "Drug testing in the workplace is a complete distraction from adequate personnel procedures," says spokesman Danny Kushlick. "It gives employers a false sense of security."

He argues that many other factors may impact on competency - including physical or mental illness, lack of sleep, stress and emotional trauma - which are not discernible through urine testing. He also cites the case of a woman in the US who ate two poppy seed muffins one morning and registered a positive morphine level in a test that afternoon. She was fired, says Kushlick, because she was deemed a "drug abuser".

Mike Goodman, director of Release, the national drugs and legal advice service, is also highly critical of workplace testing, claiming that it is "a major industry based on false science. There's no evidence it is of any value and yet it is on the increase both in the United States and here."

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: A safe place to work | Trains are a pain | Sorted storage | Data protection shock | Travelling desktop
fields.byline: Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine
fields.body:
A SAFE PLACE TO WORK

Do you have a burning idea about how to improve safety in your workplace? The health & safety executive is inviting firms to enter its "competition of ideas", offering funding for future research. The competition, which closes on 3 May, attracted more than 300 proposals last year. The HSE has just published a document giving details of current research projects and information on how to enter the competition. Copies are available free from HSE by emailing fiona.garner@hse.gsi.gov.uk

 TRAINS ARE A PAIN

If your boss prefers to fly rather than take the train, it could be because standards on the railways are falling. That's the view of travelling executives surveyed for Barclaycard's "travel in business" report. Only a fifth of the 2,000 travellers polled had a good word to say about the levels of cleanliness and reliability of today's trains, while less than half considered them comfortable. Overall, a quarter of regular travellers believe the network has declined since it was privatised, and now represents poor value for money.

 SORTED STORAGE

Some storage boxes are so complicated you need a degree in origami to work them out. Fellowes claims to have come to the rescue with the introduction of FastFold. Designed to be assembled in a couple of simple moves, the boxes are also stronger than before. Call 01302 890099 for stockists.

 DATA PROTECTION SHOCK

It is now only a matter of weeks before the new data protection act comes into force, but some research rings alarm bells for British businesses. GB Information Management believes firms are "pitifully unprepared for new hard-hitting legislation". More than half the company directors polled were not aware that if an individual successfully sues a business for misuse of personal information, the directors may find themselves in prison. For more info, call 01244 657333, or visit the website at www.dataprotection.gov.uk

TRAVELLING DESKTOP

For temps moving from one office to the next, keeping up to speed with files and diary can be tricky. OfficeClick.com is an online desktop designed for the unpredictable working conditions of temporary staff. Features include a detailed daily planner, an order tracker and a bulletin board for communicating with other online temps. But the real advantage of the system for the itinerant temp is that it follows you wherever you go. Log on to OfficeClick from any computer and your personal details appear. A good way to feel at home in a strange office.

webTitle: Pru plans to cash in its nest Egg

fields.headline: Pru plans to cash in its nest Egg
fields.trailText: The Prudential insurance group will this week seek to release some of the value of its successful internet bank, Egg, by confirming plans to float parts of the business.
fields.body:
The Prudential insurance group will this week seek to release some of the value of its successful internet bank, Egg, by confirming plans to float parts of the business.

The likely flotation, which could value Egg at £4.5bn, comes as research from Datamonitor predicts the number of people in Europe who are banking on-line will quadruple to 21m by 2004.

The Pru, which has already registered the Egg name throughout Europe, has been considering selling shares in its online bank - which now has 800,000 customers - for some time but technical problems have delayed a decision.

Shares in the Pru have been undermined in the past few weeks because of fears over the competitive damage which could come from the recent internet initiatives of big banking groups.

It is understood, however, that the Pru has now given the thumbs up for a partial flotation of Egg to be announced alongside its annual results on Wednesday.

Jonathan Bloomer, who takes over from Sir Peter Davis as chief executive next month, will be keen to deflect attention away from last week's abrupt decision by Les Cullen, the group's finance director, to quit. Mr Cullen will present the financial results to analysts and shareholders on Wednesday.

Sir Peter, who is credited with having transformed Prudential during his tenure, will be keen to move to his new job at Sainsbury's.

Although the Pru's operating profits are expected to have slipped from £860m to £780m, with some £150m of losses chalked up by Egg, analysts predict that the promise of a partial flotation for the internet bank will keep the market happy.

The market is expecting Pru to sell off between 15% and 25% of Egg. Valuations which have been put on the operation range from a worst case £1bn to a possible £4.5bn.

The start-up costs for Egg - which have taken some £7.6bn in savings and have provided £600m of mortgages - have set the Pru back £300m.

webTitle: TV access to web will fuel e-commerce bonanza

fields.headline: TV access to web will fuel e-commerce bonanza
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Easy access to the internet through phones and televisions will fuel an explosion in e-commerce in Britain to £113bn by 2009, according to research out this week from the Henley centre.
fields.body:
Easy access to the internet through phones and televisions will fuel an explosion in e-commerce in Britain to £113bn by 2009, according to research out this week from the Henley centre.

The consumer consultancy reckons that an eighth of all everyday spending will be made on the net within nine years.

Andrew Curry, associate director of the Henley centre, said: "The rates of growth which are talked about can worry people because they are so high - it's easy to write them off as hype. But the numbers do make sense in the context of the ways in which consumer spending habits are changing."

The figures were calculated using a new analytical model called DeMAND, which combines macro-economic spending patterns with in-depth research into individual spending patterns.

Mr Curry believes access to the net on phones and televisions will introduce e-commerce to people who lack the money or inclination to buy a computer. At present, just 32% of Britons are on-line.

Considering the spending habits of these new entrants, the Henley centre predicts an explosion in online demand for food, travel, alcohol, cars and clothes.

Wealthier people who are already connected will buy more books, music and entertainment tickets on-line.

Year-on-year growth in e-commerce is likely to be about 70%, the centre forecasts.

fields.headline: Lost in the woods
fields.standfirst:
As You Like It
Gate Theatre, Dublin
Rating: * * *
fields.trailText: This frothy old favourite doesn't hang together as a play, yet it always weathers well, its startling modernity and gloomy profundities neatly underpinning the wooings of aristocracy and peasants in the forest of Arden.
fields.body:
This frothy old favourite doesn't hang together as a play, yet it always weathers well, its startling modernity and gloomy profundities neatly underpinning the wooings of aristocracy and peasants in the forest of Arden.

Under Jonathan Miller's direction, the dappled glade is pared back to a big, white-cube set, with felled trees strewn across the stage. The costume is 20th century, from the pin-striped mafiosi of the Duke's courtiers, to the hunting gear and shepherd's rags of the woodland inhabitants.

Miller aims for jocular punch and panache, with touches of lewdness. Thus Touchstone, philosophising to his fat shepherdess, grips his crotch a lot. Fair Rosalind (played with the usual twinkling warmth by Donna Dent) remains pure as driven snow, tinged with emotional sado-masochism in her cross-dressed deception of Orlando. Elsewhere, the Duke's courtier Le Beau becomes a twitching, unctuous faggot; and Phoebe, just to provide some colour, is a lumpen hippie, rolling her own ciggies. The biggest groan is the Duke's wrestler, like something from a Dublinised version of Bouncers.

As the Duke, Gerard McSorley gives an urgent, menacing performance, while as Touchstone, Pat Kinevane cuts a strange and vivid figure.

Despite these gems, and the polish of the production, this is a good-humoured old snooze with no rhyme or reason to it.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

Until April 1. Box office: 00 353 1 874 4045
